EN.14: fall in a tangle when the mainmast snaps,
EN.15: so fell that cruel beast to the ground.
EN.16: Into the fourth hollow we made our way,
EN.17: descending the dismal slope
EN.18: that crams in all the evil of the universe.
EN.19: Ah, Justice of God, who heaps up
EN.20: such strange punishment and pain as I saw there?
EN.21: And why do our sins so waste us?
EN.22: Just as the waves clash above Charybdis,
EN.23: one breaking on the other when they meet,
EN.24: so here the souls move in their necessary dance.
EN.25: Here the sinners were more numerous than elsewhere,
EN.26: and they, with great shouts, from opposite sides
EN.27: were shoving burdens forward with their chests.
EN.28: They crashed into each other, turned
EN.29: and beat retreat, shoving their loads and shouting:
EN.30: 'Why do you hoard?' or 'Why do you squander?'
EN.31: Thus they proceeded in their dismal round
EN.32: on both sides toward the opposite point,
EN.33: taunting each other with the same refrain.
EN.34: Once at that point, each group turned back
EN.35: along its semi-circle to the next encounter.
EN.36: And I, my heart pierced almost through,
EN.37: said: 'Master, now explain to me
EN.38: who these people are. Were those with tonsured heads,
EN.39: the ones there to our left, all clerics?'
EN.40: 'All of them had such squinting minds
EN.41: in their first lives,' he said,
EN.42: 'they kept no measure in their spending.
EN.43: 'Their voices howl this clear enough
EN.44: just as they reach the twin points on the circle
EN.45: where opposing sins divide them.
EN.46: 'These were clerics who have no lid of hair
EN.47: upon their heads, and popes and cardinals,
EN.48: in whom avarice achieves its excess.'
EN.49: And I: 'Master, in such a crew as this
EN.50: I ought to recognize at least a few
EN.51: who were befouled with these offenses.'
EN.52: And he to me: 'You muster an empty thought.
EN.53: The undiscerning life that made them foul
EN.54: now makes them hard to recognize.
EN.55: 'The two groups will collide forever.
EN.56: These will rise from the grave
EN.57: with fists tight, these with hair cropped.
EN.58: 'Ill-giving and ill-keeping have stolen
EN.59: the fair world from them and set them to this scuffle.
EN.60: As for that, I prettify no words for it.
EN.61: 'Now you see, my son, what brief mockery
EN.62: Fortune makes of goods we trust her with,
EN.63: for which the race of men embroil themselves.
EN.64: 'All the gold that lies beneath the moon,
EN.65: or ever did, could never give a moment's rest
EN.66: to any of these wearied souls.'
EN.67: 'Master,' I said, 'tell me more: this Fortune
EN.68: whom you mention, who is she that holds
EN.69: the world's possessions tightly in her clutches?'
EN.70: And he to me: 'O foolish creatures,
EN.71: what great ignorance besets you!
EN.72: I'll have you feed upon my judgment of her:
EN.73: 'He whose wisdom transcends all
EN.74: made the heavens and gave them guides,
EN.75: so that all parts reflect on every part
EN.76: 'in equal distribution of the light. Just so,
EN.77: He ordained for worldly splendors
EN.78: a general minister and guide
EN.79: 'who shifts those worthless goods, from time to time,
EN.80: from race to race, from one blood to another
EN.81: beyond the intervention of human wit.
EN.82: 'One people comes to rule, another languishes,
EN.83: in keeping with her judgment,
EN.84: as secret as a serpent hidden in the grass.
EN.85: 'Your wisdom cannot stand against her.
EN.86: She foresees, she judges, she maintains her reign,
EN.87: as do the other heavenly powers.
EN.88: 'Her mutability admits no rest.
EN.89: Necessity compels her to be swift,
EN.90: and frequent are the changes in men's state.
EN.91: 'She is reviled by the very ones
EN.92: who most should praise her,
EN.93: blaming and defaming her unjustly.
EN.94: 'But she is blessed and does not hear them.
EN.95: Happy with the other primal creatures,
EN.96: she turns her sphere, rejoicing in her bliss.
EN.97: 'Now we must descend to greater anguish.

EN.22: 'It is true I came here once before,
EN.23: conjured by pitiless Erichtho,
EN.24: who could call shades back into their bodies.
EN.25: 'I had not long been naked of my flesh
EN.26: when she compelled me to go inside this wall
EN.27: to fetch a spirit from the circle of Judas.
EN.28: 'That is the lowest place, the darkest,
EN.29: and farthest from the heaven that encircles all.
EN.30: Well do I know the way -- so have no fear.
EN.31: 'This swamp, which belches forth such noxious stench,
EN.32: hems in the woeful city, encircling it.
EN.33: Now we cannot enter without wrath.'
EN.34: And he said more, but I do not remember,
EN.35: for my eyes and thoughts were drawn
EN.36: to the high tower's blazing peak
EN.37: where all at once, erect, had risen
EN.38: three hellish, blood-stained Furies:
EN.39: they had the limbs and shape of women,
EN.40: their waists encircled by green hydras.
EN.41: Thin serpents and horned snakes entwined,
EN.42: in place of hair, their savage brows.
EN.43: And he, who knew full well the handmaids
EN.44: to the queen of endless lamentation,
EN.45: said to me: 'See the fierce Furies.
EN.46: 'That is Megaera on the left. On the right
EN.47: Alecto wails. In the middle
EN.48: is Tisiphone.' And with that he fell silent.
EN.49: Each rent her breast with her own nails.
EN.50: And with their palms they struck themselves, shrieking.
EN.51: In fear I pressed close to the poet.
EN.52: 'Let Medusa come and we'll turn him to stone,'
EN.53: they cried, looking down. 'To our cost,
EN.54: we failed to avenge the assault of Theseus.'
EN.55: 'Turn your back and keep your eyes shut,
EN.56: for if the Gorgon head appears and should you see it,
EN.57: all chance for your return above is lost.'
EN.58: While my master spoke he turned me round
EN.59: and, not relying on my hands alone,
EN.60: covered my face with his hands also.
EN.61: O you who have sound intellects,
EN.62: consider the teaching that is hidden
EN.63: behind the veil of these strange verses.
EN.64: And now there came, over the turbid waves,
EN.65: a dreadful, crashing sound
EN.66: that set both shores to trembling.
EN.67: It sounded like a mighty wind,
EN.68: made violent by waves of heat,
EN.69: that strikes the forest and with unchecked force
EN.70: shatters the branches, hurls them away, and,
EN.71: magnificent in its roiling cloud of dust, drives on,
EN.72: putting beast and shepherd to flight.
EN.73: He freed my eyes and said: 'Now look
EN.74: across the scum of that primeval swamp
EN.75: to where the vapor is most dense and harsh.'
EN.76: As frogs, before their enemy the snake,
EN.77: all scatter through the water
EN.78: till each sits huddled on the bank,
EN.79: I saw more than a thousand lost souls flee
EN.80: before one who so lightly passed across the Styx
EN.81: he did not touch the water with his feet.
EN.82: He cleared the thick air from his face,
EN.83: his left hand moving it away,
EN.84: as if that murky air alone had wearied him.
EN.85: It was clear that he was sent from Heaven,
EN.86: and I turned to the master, who signaled me
EN.87: to keep silent and bow down before him.
EN.88: Ah, how full of high disdain he seemed to me!
EN.89: He came up to the gate and with a wand
EN.90: he opened it, and there was no resistance.
EN.91: 'O outcasts of Heaven, race despised,'
EN.92: he began on the terrible threshold, 'whence
EN.93: comes this insolence you harbor in your souls?
EN.94: 'Why do you kick against that will
EN.95: which never can be severed from its purpose,
EN.96: and has so many times increased your pain?
EN.97: 'What profits it to fight against the fates?
EN.98: Remember your own Cerberus still bears
EN.99: the wounds of that around his chin and neck.'
EN.100: Then he turned back along the wretched way
EN.101: without a word for us, and he seemed pressed,
EN.102: spurred on by greater cares
EN.103: than those of the man who stands before him.
EN.104: We turned our steps toward the city,
EN.105: emboldened by his holy words.
EN.106: We entered without further struggle.
EN.107: And I, in my desire to see
EN.108: what such a guarded fortress holds,
EN.109: as soon as I had entered eagerly surveyed
EN.110: the wide plain stretching on all sides,
EN.111: so filled with bitter torment and despair.
EN.112: Just as at Arles where the Rhone goes shallow,
EN.113: just as at Pola, near Quarnero's gulf,
EN.114: which hems in Italy and bathes her borders,
EN.115: the sepulchers make the land uneven,
EN.116: so all around me in this landscape
EN.117: the many tombs held even greater sorrow.
EN.118: For here the graves were strewn with flames
EN.119: that made them glow with heat
EN.120: hotter than iron is before it's worked.
EN.121: All their covers were propped open and from them
EN.122: issued such dire lamentation it was clear
EN.123: it came from wretches in despair and pain.
EN.124: And I: 'Master, who are these souls
EN.125: entombed within these chests and who make known
EN.126: their plight with sighs of sorrow?'
EN.127: And he: 'Here, with all their followers,
EN.128: are the arch-heretics of every sect.
EN.129: The tombs are far more laden than you think.
EN.130: 'Like is buried here with like,
EN.131: though their graves burn with unlike heat.'
EN.132: Then, after he turned to the right,
EN.133: we passed between the torments and the lofty ramparts.

IT.1: Ora sen va per un secreto calle,
IT.2: tra 'l muro de la terra e li martìri,
IT.3: lo mio maestro, e io dopo le spalle.
IT.4: "O virtù somma, che per li empi giri
IT.5: mi volvi," cominciai, "com' a te piace,
IT.6: parlami, e sodisfammi a' miei disiri.
IT.7: La gente che per li sepolcri giace
IT.8: potrebbesi veder? già son levati
IT.9: tutt' i coperchi, e nessun guardia face."
IT.10: E quelli a me: "Tutti saran serrati
IT.11: quando di Iosafàt qui torneranno
IT.12: coi corpi che là sù hanno lasciati.
IT.13: Suo cimitero da questa parte hanno
IT.14: con Epicuro tutti suoi seguaci,
IT.15: che l'anima col corpo morta fanno.
IT.16: Però a la dimanda che mi faci
IT.17: quinc' entro satisfatto sarà tosto,
IT.18: e al disio ancor che tu mi taci."
IT.19: E io: "Buon duca, non tegno riposto
IT.20: a te mio cuor se non per dicer poco,
IT.21: e tu m'hai non pur mo a ciò disposto."
IT.22: "O Tosco che per la città del foco
IT.23: vivo ten vai così parlando onesto,
IT.24: piacciati di restare in questo loco.
IT.25: La tua loquela ti fa manifesto
IT.26: di quella nobil patrïa natio,
IT.27: a la qual forse fui troppo molesto."
IT.28: Subitamente questo suono uscìo
IT.29: d'una de l'arche; però m'accostai,
IT.30: temendo, un poco più al duca mio.
IT.31: Ed el mi disse: "Volgiti! Che fai?
IT.32: Vedi là Farinata che s'è dritto:
IT.33: da la cintola in sù tutto 'l vedrai."
IT.34: Io avea già il mio viso nel suo fitto;
IT.35: ed el s'ergea col petto e con la fronte
IT.36: com' avesse l'inferno a gran dispitto.
IT.37: E l'animose man del duca e pronte
IT.38: mi pinser tra le sepulture a lui,
IT.39: dicendo: "Le parole tue sien conte."
IT.40: Com' io al piè de la sua tomba fui,
IT.41: guardommi un poco, e poi, quasi sdegnoso,
IT.42: mi dimandò: "Chi fuor li maggior tui?"
IT.43: Io ch'era d'ubidir disideroso,
IT.44: non gliel celai, ma tutto gliel' apersi;
IT.45: ond' ei levò le ciglia un poco in suso;
IT.46: poi disse: "Fieramente furo avversi
IT.47: a me e a miei primi e a mia parte,
IT.48: sì che per due fïate li dispersi."
IT.49: "S'ei fur cacciati, ei tornar d'ogne parte,"
IT.50: rispuos' io lui, "l'una e l'altra fïata;
IT.51: ma i vostri non appreser ben quell' arte."
IT.52: Allor surse a la vista scoperchiata
IT.53: un'ombra, lungo questa, infino al mento:
IT.54: credo che s'era in ginocchie levata.
IT.55: Dintorno mi guardò, come talento
IT.56: avesse di veder s'altri era meco;
IT.57: e poi che 'l sospecciar fu tutto spento,
IT.58: piangendo disse: "Se per questo cieco
IT.59: carcere vai per altezza d'ingegno,
IT.60: mio figlio ov' è? e perché non è teco?"
IT.61: E io a lui: "Da me stesso non vegno:
IT.62: colui ch'attende là per qui mi mena
IT.63: forse cui Guido vostro ebbe a disdegno."
IT.64: Le sue parole e 'l modo de la pena
IT.65: m'avean di costui già letto il nome;
IT.66: però fu la risposta così piena.
IT.67: Di sùbito drizzato gridò: "Come?
IT.68: dicesti 'elli ebbe'? non viv' elli ancora?
IT.69: non fiere li occhi suoi lo dolce lume?"
IT.70: Quando s'accorse d'alcuna dimora
IT.71: ch'io facëa dinanzi a la risposta,
IT.72: supin ricadde e più non parve fora.
IT.73: Ma quell' altro magnanimo, a cui posta
IT.74: restato m'era, non mutò aspetto,
IT.75: né mosse collo, né piegò sua costa;
IT.76: e sé continüando al primo detto,
IT.77: "S'elli han quell' arte," disse, "male appresa,
IT.78: ciò mi tormenta più che questo letto.
IT.79: Ma non cinquanta volte fia raccesa
IT.80: la faccia de la donna che qui regge,
IT.81: che tu saprai quanto quell' arte pesa.
IT.82: E se tu mai nel dolce mondo regge,
IT.83: dimmi: perché quel popolo è sì empio
IT.84: incontr' a' miei in ciascuna sua legge?"
IT.85: Ond' io a lui: "Lo strazio e 'l grande scempio
IT.86: che fece l'Arbia colorata in rosso,
IT.87: tal orazion fa far nel nostro tempio."
IT.88: Poi ch'ebbe sospirando il capo mosso,
IT.89: "A ciò non fu' io sol," disse, "né certo
IT.90: sanza cagion con li altri sarei mosso.
IT.91: Ma fu' io solo, là dove sofferto
IT.92: fu per ciascun di tòrre via Fiorenza,
IT.93: colui che la difesi a viso aperto."
IT.94: "Deh, se riposi mai vostra semenza,"
IT.95: prega' io lui, "solvetemi quel nodo
IT.96: che qui ha 'nviluppata mia sentenza.
IT.97: El par che voi veggiate, se ben odo,
IT.98: dinanzi quel che 'l tempo seco adduce,
IT.99: e nel presente tenete altro modo."
IT.100: "Noi veggiam, come quei c'ha mala luce,
IT.101: le cose," disse, "che ne son lontano;
IT.102: cotanto ancor ne splende il sommo duce.
IT.103: Quando s'appressano o son, tutto è vano
IT.104: nostro intelletto; e s'altri non ci apporta,
IT.105: nulla sapem di vostro stato umano.
IT.106: Però comprender puoi che tutta morta
IT.107: fia nostra conoscenza da quel punto
IT.108: che del futuro fia chiusa la porta."
IT.109: Allor, come di mia colpa compunto,
IT.110: dissi: "Or direte dunque a quel caduto
IT.111: che 'l suo nato è co' vivi ancor congiunto;
IT.112: e s'i' fui, dianzi, a la risposta muto,
IT.113: fate i saper che 'l fei perché pensava
IT.114: già ne l'error che m'avete soluto."
IT.115: E già 'l maestro mio mi richiamava;
IT.116: per ch'i' pregai lo spirto più avaccio
IT.117: che mi dicesse chi con lu' istava.
IT.118: Dissemi: "Qui con più di mille giaccio:
IT.119: qua dentro è 'l secondo Federico
IT.120: e 'l Cardinale; e de li altri mi taccio."
IT.121: Indi s'ascose; e io inver' l'antico
IT.122: poeta volsi i passi, ripensando
IT.123: a quel parlar che mi parea nemico.
IT.124: Elli si mosse; e poi, così andando,
IT.125: mi disse: "Perché se' tu sì smarrito?"
IT.126: E io li sodisfeci al suo dimando.
IT.127: "La mente tua conservi quel ch'udito
IT.128: hai contra te," mi comandò quel saggio;
IT.129: "e ora attendi qui," e drizzò 'l dito:
IT.130: "quando sarai dinanzi al dolce raggio
IT.131: di quella il cui bell' occhio tutto vede,
IT.132: da lei saprai di tua vita il vïaggio."
IT.133: Appresso mosse a man sinistra il piede:
IT.134: lasciammo il muro e gimmo inver' lo mezzo
IT.135: per un sentier ch'a una valle fiede,
IT.136: che 'nfin là sù facea spiacer suo lezzo.

EN.1: Now my master takes a hidden path
EN.2: between the city's ramparts and the torments,
EN.3: and I come close behind him.
EN.4: 'O lofty virtue,' I began, 'who lead me
EN.5: as you will around these impious circles,
EN.6: speak to me and satisfy my wishes.
EN.7: 'The souls that lie within the sepulchers,
EN.8: may they be seen? For all the lids are raised
EN.9: and there is no one standing guard.'
EN.10: And he to me: 'All will be shut and sealed
EN.11: when the souls return from Jehosaphat
EN.12: with the bodies they have left above.
EN.13: 'Here Epicurus with all his followers,
EN.14: who hold the soul dies with the body,
EN.15: have their burial place.
EN.16: 'But soon your need to have an answer
EN.17: will be satisfied right here,
EN.18: as will the wish you hide from me.'
EN.19: And I: 'Good leader, from you I do not keep
EN.20: my heart concealed except to speak few words --
EN.21: as you've from time to time advised.'
EN.22: 'O Tuscan, passing through the city of fire,
EN.23: alive, and with such courtesy of speech,
EN.24: if it would please you, stay your steps awhile.
EN.25: 'Your way of speaking makes it clear
EN.26: that you are native to that noble city
EN.27: to which I was perhaps too cruel.'
EN.28: This voice came suddenly
EN.29: from one sarcophagus, so that, startled,
EN.30: I drew closer to my leader.
EN.31: And he to me: 'Turn back! What are you doing?
EN.32: Look, there Farinata stands erect --
EN.33: you can see all of him from the waist up.'
EN.34: Already I had fixed my gaze on his.
EN.35: And he was rising, lifting chest and brow
EN.36: as though he held all Hell in utter scorn.
EN.37: At which my leader: 'Choose your words with care,'
EN.38: and his hands, ready, encouraging,
EN.39: thrust me toward him among the tombs.
EN.40: When I stood at the foot of his tomb
EN.41: he looked at me a moment. Then he asked,
EN.42: almost in disdain: 'Who were your ancestors?'
EN.43: And I, eager to obey, held nothing back,
EN.44: but told him who they were,
EN.45: at which he barely raised his eyebrows
EN.46: and said: 'They were most bitter enemies
EN.47: to me, my forebears, and my party --
EN.48: not once, but twice, I had to drive them out.'
EN.49: 'If they were banished,' I responded, 'they returned
EN.50: from every quarter both the first time and the second,
EN.51: a skill that Yours have failed to learn as well.'
EN.52: Then, beside him, in the open tomb, up came
EN.53: a shade, visible to the chin: I think
EN.54: he had raised himself upon his knees.
EN.55: He looked around me as though he wished to see
EN.56: if someone else were with me,
EN.57: and when his hesitant hopes were crushed,
EN.58: weeping, he said: 'If you pass through this dark
EN.59: prison by virtue of your lofty genius,
EN.60: where is my son and why is he not with you?'
EN.61: And I to him: 'I come not on my own:
EN.62: he who stands there waiting leads me through,
EN.63: perhaps to one Your Guido held in scorn.'
EN.64: His words and the manner of his punishment
EN.65: already had revealed his name to me,
EN.66: and thus was my reply so to the point.
EN.67: Suddenly erect, he cried: 'What?
EN.68: Did you say "he held"? Lives he not still?
EN.69: Does not the sweet light strike upon his eyes?'
EN.70: When he perceived that I made some delay
EN.71: before I answered, he fell backward
EN.72: and showed himself no more.
EN.73: But the other, that great soul at whose wish
EN.74: I had stopped, did not change countenance,
EN.75: nor bend his neck, nor move his chest.
EN.76: And he, continuing from where he'd paused:
EN.77: 'That they have badly learned this skill
EN.78: torments me more than does this bed.
EN.79: 'But the face of the lady reigning here
EN.80: will be rekindled not fifty times before you too
EN.81: shall know how difficult a skill that is to learn.
EN.82: 'And, so may you return to the sweet world,
EN.83: tell me, why are your people,
EN.84: in every edict, so pitiless against my kin?'
EN.85: Then I to him: 'The havoc and great slaughter
EN.86: that dyed the Arbia red caused them to raise
EN.87: such prayers in our temple.'
EN.88: He sighed and shook his head, then spoke:
EN.89: 'I was not alone, nor surely without cause
EN.90: would I have acted with the rest.
EN.91: 'But it was I alone, when all agreed
EN.92: to make an end of Florence, I alone
EN.93: who dared speak out in her defense.'
EN.94: 'So may Your seed sometime find peace,
EN.95: pray untie for me this knot,' I begged him,
EN.96: 'which has entangled and confused my judgment.
EN.97: 'From what I hear, it seems
EN.98: you see beforehand that which time will bring,
EN.99: but cannot know what happens in the present.'
EN.100: 'We see, like those with faulty vision,
EN.101: things at a distance,' he replied. 'That much,
EN.102: for us, the mighty Ruler's light still shines.
EN.103: 'When things draw near or happen now,
EN.104: our minds are useless. Without the words of others
EN.105: we can know nothing of your human state.
EN.106: 'Thus it follows that all our knowledge
EN.107: will perish at the very moment
EN.108: the portals of the future close.'
EN.109: Then, remorseful for my fault, I said:
EN.110: 'Will You tell him who fell back down
EN.111: his son is still among the living?
EN.112: 'And let him know, if I was slow to answer,
EN.113: it was because I was preoccupied
EN.114: with doubts You have resolved for me.'
EN.115: And now my master summoned me,
EN.116: so that I begged the spirit to reveal,
EN.117: at once, who else was down there with him.
EN.118: His answer was: 'More than a thousand lie
EN.119: here with me: both the second Frederick
EN.120: and the Cardinal. Of the rest I do not speak.'
EN.121: With that he dropped from sight. I turned my steps
EN.122: to the venerable poet, mulling
EN.123: those words that seemed to augur ill.
EN.124: He started out, and then, as we were going,
EN.125: asked: 'Why are you so bewildered?'
EN.126: And I answered fully what he asked.
EN.127: 'Keep in mind what you have heard against you,
EN.128: but also now give heed to this,'
EN.129: the sage insisted -- and he raised one finger.
EN.130: 'When you shall stand before the radiance
EN.131: of her whose fair eyes see and understand,
EN.132: from her you'll learn the journey of your life.'
EN.133: Then he turned his footsteps to the left.
EN.134: Leaving the wall, we headed toward the center
EN.135: along a path that leads into a pit.
EN.136: Its stench offended even at that height.

IT.1: In su l'estremità d'un'alta ripa
IT.2: che facevan gran pietre rotte in cerchio,
IT.3: venimmo sopra più crudele stipa;
IT.4: e quivi, per l'orribile soperchio
IT.5: del puzzo che 'l profondo abisso gitta,
IT.6: ci raccostammo, in dietro, ad un coperchio
IT.7: d'un grand' avello, ov' io vidi una scritta
IT.8: che dicea: "Anastasio papa guardo,
IT.9: lo qual trasse Fotin de la via dritta."
IT.10: "Lo nostro scender conviene esser tardo,
IT.11: sì che s'ausi un poco in prima il senso
IT.12: al tristo fiato; e poi no i fia riguardo."
IT.13: Così 'l maestro; e io "Alcun compenso,"
IT.14: dissi lui, "trova che 'l tempo non passi
IT.15: perduto." Ed elli: "Vedi ch'a ciò penso."
IT.16: "Figliuol mio, dentro da cotesti sassi,"
IT.17: cominciò poi a dir, "son tre cerchietti
IT.18: di grado in grado, come que' che lassi.
IT.19: Tutti son pien di spirti maladetti;
IT.20: ma perché poi ti basti pur la vista,
IT.21: intendi come e perché son costretti.
IT.22: D'ogne malizia, ch'odio in cielo acquista,
IT.23: ingiuria è 'l fine, ed ogne fin cotale
IT.24: o con forza o con frode altrui contrista.
IT.25: Ma perché frode è de l'uom proprio male,
IT.26: più spiace a Dio; e però stan di sotto
IT.27: li frodolenti, e più dolor li assale.
IT.28: Di vïolenti il primo cerchio è tutto;
IT.29: ma perché si fa forza a tre persone,
IT.30: in tre gironi è distinto e costrutto.
IT.31: A Dio, a sé, al prossimo si pòne
IT.32: far forza, dico in loro e in lor cose,
IT.33: come udirai con aperta ragione.
IT.34: Morte per forza e ferute dogliose
IT.35: nel prossimo si danno, e nel suo avere
IT.36: ruine, incendi e tollette dannose;
IT.37: onde omicide e ciascun che mal fiere,
IT.38: guastatori e predon, tutti tormenta
IT.39: lo giron primo per diverse schiere.
IT.40: Puote omo avere in sé man vïolenta
IT.41: e ne' suoi beni; e però nel secondo
IT.42: giron convien che sanza pro si penta
IT.43: qualunque priva sé del vostro mondo,
IT.44: biscazza e fonde la sua facultade,
IT.45: e piange là dov' esser de' giocondo.
IT.46: Puossi far forza ne la deïtade,
IT.47: col cor negando e bestemmiando quella,
IT.48: e spregiando natura e sua bontade;
IT.49: e però lo minor giron suggella
IT.50: del segno suo e Soddoma e Caorsa
IT.51: e chi, spregiando Dio col cor, favella.
IT.52: La frode, ond' ogne coscïenza è morsa,
IT.53: può l'omo usare in colui che 'n lui fida
IT.54: e in quel che fidanza non imborsa.
IT.55: Questo modo di retro par ch'incida
IT.56: pur lo vinco d'amor che fa natura;
IT.57: onde nel cerchio secondo s'annida
IT.58: ipocresia, lusinghe e chi affattura,
IT.59: falsità, ladroneccio e simonia,
IT.60: ruffian, baratti e simile lordura.
IT.61: Per l'altro modo quell' amor s'oblia
IT.62: che fa natura, e quel ch'è poi aggiunto,
IT.63: di che la fede spezïal si cria;
IT.64: onde nel cerchio minore, ov' è 'l punto
IT.65: de l'universo in su che Dite siede,
IT.66: qualunque trade in etterno è consunto."
IT.67: E io: "Maestro, assai chiara procede
IT.68: la tua ragione, e assai ben distingue
IT.69: questo baràtro e 'l popol ch'e' possiede.
IT.70: Ma dimmi: quei de la palude pingue,
IT.71: che mena il vento, e che batte la pioggia,
IT.72: e che s'incontran con sì aspre lingue,
IT.73: perché non dentro da la città roggia
IT.74: sono ei puniti, se Dio li ha in ira?
IT.75: e se non li ha, perché sono a tal foggia?"
IT.76: Ed elli a me "Perché tanto delira,"
IT.77: disse, "lo 'ngegno tuo da quel che sòle?
IT.78: o ver la mente dove altrove mira?
IT.79: Non ti rimembra di quelle parole
IT.80: con le quai la tua Etica pertratta
IT.81: le tre disposizion che 'l ciel non vole,
IT.82: incontenenza, malizia e la matta
IT.83: bestialitade? e come incontenenza
IT.84: men Dio offende e men biasimo accatta?
IT.85: Se tu riguardi ben questa sentenza,
IT.86: e rechiti a la mente chi son quelli
IT.87: che sù di fuor sostegnon penitenza,
IT.88: tu vedrai ben perché da questi felli
IT.89: sien dipartiti, e perché men crucciata
IT.90: la divina vendetta li martelli."
IT.91: "O sol che sani ogne vista turbata,
IT.92: tu mi contenti sì quando tu solvi,
IT.93: che, non men che saver, dubbiar m'aggrata.
IT.94: Ancora in dietro un poco ti rivolvi,"
IT.95: diss' io, "là dove di' ch'usura offende
IT.96: la divina bontade, e 'l groppo solvi."
IT.97: "Filosofia," mi disse, "a chi la 'ntende,
IT.98: nota, non pure in una sola parte,
IT.99: come natura lo suo corso prende
IT.100: dal divino 'ntelletto e da sua arte;
IT.101: e se tu ben la tua Fisica note,
IT.102: tu troverai, non dopo molte carte,
IT.103: che l'arte vostra quella, quanto pote,
IT.104: segue, come 'l maestro fa 'l discente;
IT.105: sì che vostr' arte a Dio quasi è nepote.
IT.106: Da queste due, se tu ti rechi a mente
IT.107: lo Genesì dal principio, convene
IT.108: prender sua vita e avanzar la gente;
IT.109: e perché l'usuriere altra via tene,
IT.110: per sé natura e per la sua seguace
IT.111: dispregia, poi ch'in altro pon la spene.
IT.112: Ma seguimi oramai che 'l gir mi piace;
IT.113: ché i Pesci guizzan su per l'orizzonta,
IT.114: e 'l Carro tutto sovra 'l Coro giace,
IT.115: e 'l balzo via là oltra si dismonta."

EN.1: At the brink of a high bank formed
EN.2: by broken boulders in a circle
EN.3: we stopped above a still more grievous throng.
EN.4: Here, the unbearable foul stench
EN.5: belched from that bottomless abyss
EN.6: made us draw back behind the slab
EN.7: of an imposing tomb, on which I saw inscribed
EN.8: the words: 'I hold Pope Anastasius:
EN.9: Photinus drew him from the right and proper path.'
EN.10: 'We must delay descending so our sense,
EN.11: inured to that vile stench,
EN.12: no longer heeds it.'
EN.13: So spoke the master. I replied: 'I know
EN.14: you'll find a useful way to pass this time.'
EN.15: And he: 'You'll see that is my plan.'
EN.16: 'My son,' he then began, 'beneath these rocks
EN.17: there are three circles, smaller, one below the other,
EN.18: but otherwise like those you leave behind.
EN.19: 'All these are filled with souls condemned.
EN.20: So that the sight alone may later be enough,
EN.21: know how and why they are confined this way.
EN.22: 'Every evil deed despised in Heaven
EN.23: has as its end injustice. Each such end
EN.24: harms someone else through either force or fraud.
EN.25: 'But since the vice of fraud is man's alone,
EN.26: it more displeases God, and thus the fraudulent
EN.27: are lower down, assailed by greater pain.
EN.28: 'The first circle holds the violent
EN.29: but is divided and constructed in three rings,
EN.30: since violence takes three different forms.
EN.31: 'Violence may be aimed at God, oneself,
EN.32: or at one's neighbor -- thus against all three
EN.33: or their possessions -- as I shall now explain.
EN.34: 'Violent death and grievous wounds may be inflicted
EN.35: upon a neighbor or, upon his goods,
EN.36: pillage, arson, and violent theft.
EN.37: 'And so murderers and everyone who wounds
EN.38: unjustly, spoilers and plunderers -- the first ring
EN.39: punishes all these in separate groups.
EN.40: 'A man may lay injurious hands upon himself
EN.41: or on his goods, and for that reason
EN.42: in the second ring must he repent in vain
EN.43: 'who robs himself of the world above
EN.44: or gambles away and wastes his substance,
EN.45: lamenting when he should rejoice.
EN.46: 'Violence may be committed against God
EN.47: when we deny and curse Him in our hearts,
EN.48: or when we scorn nature and her bounty.
EN.49: 'And so the smallest ring stamps with its seal
EN.50: both Sodom and Cahors and those
EN.51: who scorn Him with their hearts and tongues.
EN.52: 'Fraud gnaws at every conscience,
EN.53: whether used on him who trusted
EN.54: or on one who lacked such faith.
EN.55: 'Fraud against the latter only severs
EN.56: the bond of love that nature makes.
EN.57: Thus in the second circle nest
EN.58: 'hypocrisy, flatteries, and sorcerers;
EN.59: lies, theft, and simony;
EN.60: panders, barrators, and all such filth.
EN.61: 'Fraud against the trusting fails to heed
EN.62: not only natural love but the added bond
EN.63: of faith, which forms a special kind of trust.
EN.64: 'Therefore, in the tightest circle,
EN.65: the center of the universe and seat of Dis,
EN.66: all traitors are consumed eternally.'
EN.67: And I: 'Master, your account is clear
EN.68: and clearly designates the nature
EN.69: of this abyss and its inhabitants.
EN.70: 'But tell me, those spirits in the viscous marsh,
EN.71: those the wind drives, those the rain beats down on,
EN.72: those clashing with such bitter tongues,
EN.73: 'why are they not punished inside the fiery city
EN.74: if God's anger is upon them?
EN.75: And if not, why are they so afflicted?'
EN.76: And he: 'Not often do your wits stray
EN.77: far afield, as they do now -- or is your mind
EN.78: bent on pursuing other thoughts?
EN.79: 'Do you not recall the words
EN.80: your Ethics uses to expound
EN.81: the three dispositions Heaven opposes,
EN.82: 'incontinence, malice, and mad brutishness,
EN.83: and how incontinence offends God less
EN.84: and incurs a lesser blame?
EN.85: 'If you consider well this judgment
EN.86: and consider who they are
EN.87: that suffer punishment above, outside the wall,
EN.88: 'you'll understand why they are set apart
EN.89: from these wicked spirits and why God's vengeance
EN.90: smites them with a lesser wrath.'
EN.91: 'O sun, you who heal all troubled sight,
EN.92: you so content me by resolving doubts
EN.93: it pleases me no less to question than to know.
EN.94: 'But go back a little way,' I said,
EN.95: 'to where you told me usury offends
EN.96: God's goodness, and untie that knot for me.'
EN.97: 'Philosophy, for one who understands her,
EN.98: observes,' he said, 'and not in one place only,
EN.99: how nature takes her course
EN.100: 'from heavenly intellect and its operation.
EN.101: And, if you study well your Physics,
EN.102: you will find, after not too many pages,
EN.103: 'that human toil, as far as it is able,
EN.104: follows nature, as the pupil does his master,
EN.105: so that it is God's grandchild, as it were.
EN.106: 'By toil and nature, if you remember Genesis,
EN.107: near the beginning, it is man's lot
EN.108: to earn his bread and prosper.
EN.109: 'The usurer, who takes another path,
EN.110: scorns nature in herself and in her follower,
EN.111: and elsewhere sets his hopes.
EN.112: 'But follow me now, for it is time to go.
EN.113: The Fishes are flickering at the horizon
EN.114: and all the Wain lies over Caurus. And here,
EN.115: a short way off, is the descent.'

IT.1: Era lo loco ov' a scender la riva
IT.2: venimmo, alpestro e, per quel che v'er' anco,
IT.3: tal, ch'ogne vista ne sarebbe schiva.
IT.4: Qual è quella ruina che nel fianco
IT.5: di qua da Trento l'Adice percosse,
IT.6: o per tremoto o per sostegno manco,
IT.7: che da cima del monte, onde si mosse,
IT.8: al piano è sì la roccia discoscesa,
IT.9: ch'alcuna via darebbe a chi sù fosse:
IT.10: cotal di quel burrato era la scesa;
IT.11: e 'n su la punta de la rotta lacca
IT.12: l'infamïa di Creti era distesa
IT.13: che fu concetta ne la falsa vacca;
IT.14: e quando vide noi, sé stesso morse,
IT.15: sì come quei cui l'ira dentro fiacca.
IT.16: Lo savio mio inver' lui gridò: "Forse
IT.17: tu credi che qui sia 'l duca d'Atene,
IT.18: che sù nel mondo la morte ti porse?
IT.19: Pàrtiti, bestia, ché questi non vene
IT.20: ammaestrato da la tua sorella,
IT.21: ma vassi per veder le vostre pene."
IT.22: Qual è quel toro che si slaccia in quella
IT.23: c'ha ricevuto già 'l colpo mortale,
IT.24: che gir non sa, ma qua e là saltella,
IT.25: vid' io lo Minotauro far cotale;
IT.26: e quello accorto gridò: "Corri al varco;
IT.27: mentre ch'e' 'nfuria, è buon che tu ti cale."
IT.28: Così prendemmo via giù per lo scarco
IT.29: di quelle pietre, che spesso moviensi
IT.30: sotto i miei piedi per lo novo carco.
IT.31: Io gia pensando; e quei disse: "Tu pensi
IT.32: forse a questa ruina, ch'è guardata
IT.33: da quell' ira bestial ch'i' ora spensi.
IT.34: Or vo' che sappi che l'altra fïata
IT.35: ch'i' discesi qua giù nel basso inferno,
IT.36: questa roccia non era ancor cascata.
IT.37: Ma certo poco pria, se ben discerno,
IT.38: che venisse colui che la gran preda
IT.39: levò a Dite del cerchio superno,
IT.40: da tutte parti l'alta valle feda
IT.41: tremò sì, ch'i' pensai che l'universo
IT.42: sentisse amor, per lo qual è chi creda
IT.43: più volte il mondo in caòsso converso;
IT.44: e in quel punto questa vecchia roccia,
IT.45: qui e altrove, tal fece riverso.
IT.46: Ma ficca li occhi a valle, ché s'approccia
IT.47: la riviera del sangue in la qual bolle
IT.48: qual che per vïolenza in altrui noccia."
IT.49: Oh cieca cupidigia e ira folle,
IT.50: che sì ci sproni ne la vita corta,
IT.51: e ne l'etterna poi sì mal c'immolle!
IT.52: Io vidi un'ampia fossa in arco torta,
IT.53: come quella che tutto 'l piano abbraccia,
IT.54: secondo ch'avea detto la mia scorta;
IT.55: e tra 'l piè de la ripa ed essa, in traccia
IT.56: corrien centauri, armati di saette,
IT.57: come solien nel mondo andare a caccia.
IT.58: Veggendoci calar, ciascun ristette,
IT.59: e de la schiera tre si dipartiro
IT.60: con archi e asticciuole prima elette;
IT.61: e l'un gridò da lungi: "A qual martiro
IT.62: venite voi che scendete la costa?
IT.63: Ditel costinci; se non, l'arco tiro."
IT.64: Lo mio maestro disse: "La risposta
IT.65: farem noi a Chirón costà di presso:
IT.66: mal fu la voglia tua sempre sì tosta."
IT.67: Poi mi tentò, e disse: "Quelli è Nesso,
IT.68: che morì per la bella Deianira,
IT.69: e fé di sé la vendetta elli stesso.
IT.70: E quel di mezzo, ch'al petto si mira,
IT.71: è il gran Chirón, il qual nodrì Achille;
IT.72: quell' altro è Folo, che fu sì pien d'ira.
IT.73: Dintorno al fosso vanno a mille a mille,
IT.74: saettando qual anima si svelle
IT.75: del sangue più che sua colpa sortille."
IT.76: Noi ci appressammo a quelle fiere isnelle:
IT.77: Chirón prese uno strale, e con la cocca
IT.78: fece la barba in dietro a le mascelle.
IT.79: Quando s'ebbe scoperta la gran bocca,
IT.80: disse a' compagni: "Siete voi accorti
IT.81: che quel di retro move ciò ch'el tocca?
IT.82: Così non soglion far li piè d'i morti."
IT.83: E 'l mio buon duca, che già li er' al petto,
IT.84: dove le due nature son consorti,
IT.85: rispuose: "Ben è vivo, e sì soletto
IT.86: mostrar li mi convien la valle buia;
IT.87: necessità 'l ci 'nduce, e non diletto.
IT.88: Tal si partì da cantare alleluia
IT.89: che mi commise quest' officio novo:
IT.90: non è ladron, né io anima fuia.
IT.91: Ma per quella virtù per cu' io movo
IT.92: li passi miei per sì selvaggia strada,
IT.93: danne un de' tuoi, a cui noi siamo a provo,
IT.94: e che ne mostri là dove si guada,
IT.95: e che porti costui in su la groppa,
IT.96: ché non è spirto che per l'aere vada."
IT.97: Chirón si volse in su la destra poppa,
IT.98: e disse a Nesso: "Torna, e sì li guida,
IT.99: e fa cansar s'altra schiera v'intoppa."
IT.100: Or ci movemmo con la scorta fida
IT.101: lungo la proda del bollor vermiglio,
IT.102: dove i bolliti facieno alte strida.
IT.103: Io vidi gente sotto infino al ciglio;
IT.104: e 'l gran centauro disse: "E' son tiranni
IT.105: che dier nel sangue e ne l'aver di piglio.
IT.106: Quivi si piangon li spietati danni;
IT.107: quivi è Alessandro, e Dïonisio fero
IT.108: che fé Cicilia aver dolorosi anni.
IT.109: E quella fronte c'ha 'l pel così nero,
IT.110: è Azzolino; e quell' altro ch'è biondo,
IT.111: è Opizzo da Esti, il qual per vero
IT.112: fu spento dal figliastro sù nel mondo."
IT.113: Allor mi volsi al poeta, e quei disse:
IT.114: "Questi ti sia or primo, e io secondo."
IT.115: Poco più oltre il centauro s'affisse
IT.116: sovr' una gente che 'nfino a la gola
IT.117: parea che di quel bulicame uscisse.
IT.118: Mostrocci un'ombra da l'un canto sola,
IT.119: dicendo: "Colui fesse in grembo a Dio
IT.120: lo cor che 'n su Tamisi ancor si cola."
IT.121: Poi vidi gente che di fuor del rio
IT.122: tenean la testa e ancor tutto 'l casso;
IT.123: e di costoro assai riconobb' io.
IT.124: Così a più a più si facea basso
IT.125: quel sangue, sì che cocea pur li piedi;
IT.126: e quindi fu del fosso il nostro passo.
IT.127: "Sì come tu da questa parte vedi
IT.128: lo bulicame che sempre si scema,"
IT.129: disse 'l centauro, "voglio che tu credi
IT.130: che da quest' altra a più a più giù prema
IT.131: lo fondo suo, infin ch'el si raggiunge
IT.132: ove la tirannia convien che gema.
IT.133: La divina giustizia di qua punge
IT.134: quell' Attila che fu flagello in terra,
IT.135: e Pirro e Sesto; e in etterno munge
IT.136: le lagrime, che col bollor diserra,
IT.137: a Rinier da Corneto, a Rinier Pazzo,
IT.138: che fecero a le strade tanta guerra."
IT.139: Poi si rivolse e ripassossi 'l guazzo.

EN.1: Steep was the cliff we had to clamber down,
EN.2: rocky and steep, but -- even worse -- it held
EN.3: a sight that every eye would shun.
EN.4: As on the rockslide that still marks the flank
EN.5: of the Àdige, this side of Trent,
EN.6: whether by earthquake or erosion at the base,
EN.7: from the mountain-top they slid away from,
EN.8: the shattered boulders strew the precipice
EN.9: and thus give footing to one coming down --
EN.10: just so was the descent down that ravine.
EN.11: And at the chasm's jagged edge
EN.12: was sprawled the infamy of Crete,
EN.13: conceived in that false cow.
EN.14: When he caught sight of us, he gnawed himself
EN.15: like someone ruled by wrath.
EN.16: My sage cried out to him: 'You think,
EN.17: perhaps, this is the Duke of Athens,
EN.18: who in the world above put you to death.
EN.19: 'Get away, you beast, for this man
EN.20: does not come tutored by your sister,
EN.21: he comes to view your punishments.'
EN.22: Like the bull that breaks its tether
EN.23: just as it receives the mortal blow
EN.24: and cannot run, but lunges here and there,
EN.25: so raged the Minotaur. My artful guide
EN.26: called out: 'Run to the passage:
EN.27: hurry down while he is in his fury.'
EN.28: And so we made our way down the steep landslide
EN.29: on scree that often shifted
EN.30: under my feet with unexpected weight.
EN.31: I went on lost in thought. And he said:
EN.32: 'Perhaps you're wondering about this rockslide
EN.33: guarded by that bestial rage I quelled just now.
EN.34: 'I want you to know, the other time
EN.35: I came down into nether Hell
EN.36: this rock had not yet fallen.
EN.37: 'But surely, if memory does not fail,
EN.38: it was just before He came who carried off
EN.39: from Dis the great spoil of the highest circle
EN.40: 'when the deep and foul abyss shook on every side,
EN.41: so that I thought the universe felt love,
EN.42: by which, as some believe,
EN.43: 'the world has many times been turned to chaos.
EN.44: And at that moment this ancient rock,
EN.45: here and elsewhere, fell broken into pieces.
EN.46: 'But fix your eyes below, for we draw near
EN.47: the river of blood that scalds
EN.48: those who by violence do injury to others.'
EN.49: O blind covetousness, insensate wrath,
EN.50: which in this brief life goad us on and then,
EN.51: in the eternal, steep us in such misery!
EN.52: I saw a broad moat curving in its arc
EN.53: that seemed to circle all the plain,
EN.54: just as my guide had said.
EN.55: Between the edge of moat and precipice
EN.56: ran centaurs in a file and armed with arrows,
EN.57: as when they went off hunting in our world.
EN.58: They saw us coming, stopped, and three
EN.59: departed from the troop with bows
EN.60: and shafts they had selected with great care.
EN.61: One cried from afar: 'To what torment
EN.62: do you come, you two approaching down the slope?
EN.63: Tell us from there. If not, I draw my bow.'
EN.64: My master said: 'We will give our answer
EN.65: to Chiron once we have come closer.
EN.66: Your will was always hasty, to your hurt.'
EN.67: Then he nudged me, saying: 'That is Nessus,
EN.68: who died for lovely Deianira
EN.69: and fashioned of himself his own revenge.
EN.70: 'The middle one, his gaze fixed on his chest,
EN.71: is the great Chiron, he who raised Achilles.
EN.72: The other one is Pholus, who was so filled with wrath.
EN.73: 'Around the moat they go in thousands,
EN.74: shooting arrows at any soul that rises
EN.75: higher from the blood than guilt allows.'
EN.76: As we drew near those swift wild beasts,
EN.77: Chiron took an arrow and with its nock
EN.78: pulled back his beard along his jaw.
EN.79: When he had uncovered his enormous mouth
EN.80: he said to his companions: 'Have you observed
EN.81: the one behind dislodges what he touches?
EN.82: 'That is not what the feet of dead men do.'
EN.83: And my good leader, now at Chiron's breast,
EN.84: where his two natures join, replied:
EN.85: 'He is indeed alive, and so alone,
EN.86: it is my task to show him this dark valley.
EN.87: Necessity compels us, not delight.
EN.88: 'One briefly left her song of hallelujah
EN.89: and came to charge me with this novel task.
EN.90: He is no robber, nor am I a thief.
EN.91: 'But, by that power by which I move my steps
EN.92: on this wild road, lend us a guide,
EN.93: one of your band to whom we may stay close,
EN.94: 'one who will show us to the ford
EN.95: and carry this man over on his back,
EN.96: for he is not a spirit that can fly through air.'
EN.97: Chiron bent his torso to the right, then said
EN.98: to Nessus: 'Go back and guide them.
EN.99: If you meet another troop, have it give way.'
EN.100: And with this trusty escort we went on,
EN.101: skirting the edge of the vermilion boil
EN.102: from which the boiled cried out with piercing shrieks.
EN.103: There I saw some sunken to the eyebrows,
EN.104: and the great centaur said: 'They are tyrants
EN.105: who took to blood and plunder.
EN.106: 'Here they lament their ruthless crimes.
EN.107: Here is Alexander, here cruel Dionysius,
EN.108: who gave to Sicily its years of woe.
EN.109: 'And that brow with such jet-black hair
EN.110: is Ezzelino, while the other blond one there
EN.111: is Obizzo d'Este, who was indeed
EN.112: 'slain by his stepson in the world above.'
EN.113: Then I turned to the poet, and he said:
EN.114: 'Now let Nessus be your guide and I will follow.'
EN.115: A little farther on the centaur stopped
EN.116: above a crowd whose heads, down to their necks,
EN.117: seemed to issue from that boiling stream.
EN.118: He pointed out a shade apart, alone:
EN.119: 'In God's bosom that one clove in two
EN.120: the heart that on the Thames still drips with blood.'
EN.121: Then I saw some who had their heads,
EN.122: even their whole chests, out of the river,
EN.123: and of these I recognized a number,
EN.124: as the blood became even more shallow
EN.125: until it cooked nothing but their feet.
EN.126: And here was our place to cross the moat.
EN.127: 'Just as on this side you can see
EN.128: the boiling stream always diminishing,'
EN.129: said the centaur, 'so, I'll have you know,
EN.130: 'on the other side the bottom falls away
EN.131: until it plumbs the depths
EN.132: where tyranny must groan.
EN.133: 'There divine justice stings Àttila,
EN.134: who was a scourge on earth, and Pyrrhus,
EN.135: and Sextus, and eternally wrings
EN.136: 'tears, loosed by the boiling,
EN.137: from Rinier of Corneto and Rinier Pazzo,
EN.138: who on the highways made such strife.'
EN.139: Then he turned back and crossed the ford again.

IT.1: Non era ancor di là Nesso arrivato,
IT.2: quando noi ci mettemmo per un bosco
IT.3: che da neun sentiero era segnato.
IT.4: Non fronda verde, ma di color fosco;
IT.5: non rami schietti, ma nodosi e 'nvolti;
IT.6: non pomi v'eran, ma stecchi con tòsco.
IT.7: Non han sì aspri sterpi né sì folti
IT.8: quelle fiere selvagge che 'n odio hanno
IT.9: tra Cecina e Corneto i luoghi cólti.
IT.10: Quivi le brutte Arpie lor nidi fanno,
IT.11: che cacciar de le Strofade i Troiani
IT.12: con tristo annunzio di futuro danno.
IT.13: Ali hanno late, e colli e visi umani,
IT.14: piè con artigli, e pennuto 'l gran ventre;
IT.15: fanno lamenti in su li alberi strani.
IT.16: E 'l buon maestro "Prima che più entre,
IT.17: sappi che se' nel secondo girone,"
IT.18: mi cominciò a dire, "e sarai mentre
IT.19: che tu verrai ne l'orribil sabbione.
IT.20: Però riguarda ben; sì vederai
IT.21: cose che torrien fede al mio sermone."
IT.22: Io sentia d'ogne parte trarre guai
IT.23: e non vedea persona che 'l facesse;
IT.24: per ch'io tutto smarrito m'arrestai.
IT.25: Cred' ïo ch'ei credette ch'io credesse
IT.26: che tante voci uscisser, tra quei bronchi,
IT.27: da gente che per noi si nascondesse.
IT.28: Però disse 'l maestro: "Se tu tronchi
IT.29: qualche fraschetta d'una d'este piante,
IT.30: li pensier c'hai si faran tutti monchi."
IT.31: Allor porsi la mano un poco avante
IT.32: e colsi un ramicel da un gran pruno;
IT.33: e 'l tronco suo gridò: "Perché mi schiante?"
IT.34: Da che fatto fu poi di sangue bruno,
IT.35: ricominciò a dir: "Perché mi scerpi?
IT.36: non hai tu spirto di pietade alcuno?
IT.37: Uomini fummo, e or siam fatti sterpi:
IT.38: ben dovrebb' esser la tua man più pia,
IT.39: se state fossimo anime di serpi."
IT.40: Come d'un stizzo verde ch'arso sia
IT.41: da l'un de' capi, che da l'altro geme

EN.1: Nessus had not yet reached the other side
EN.2: when we made our way into a forest
EN.3: not marked by any path.
EN.4: No green leaves, but those of dusky hue --
EN.5: not a straight branch, but knotted and contorted --
EN.6: no fruit of any kind, but poisonous thorns.
EN.7: No rougher, denser thickets make a refuge
EN.8: for the wild beasts that hate tilled lands
EN.9: between the Cècina and Corneto.
EN.10: Here the filthy Harpies nest,
EN.11: who drove the Trojans from the Strophades
EN.12: with doleful prophecies of woe to come.
EN.13: They have broad wings, human necks and faces,
EN.14: taloned feet, and feathers on their bulging bellies.
EN.15: Their wailing fills the eerie trees.
EN.16: And my good master then began to speak:
EN.17: 'Before you go in deeper you should know,
EN.18: you are, and will be, in the second ring
EN.19: 'until you reach the dreadful sand.
EN.20: Pay close attention: you will see such things
EN.21: as are not easily believed from speech alone.'
EN.22: Lamentations I heard on every side
EN.23: but I saw no one who might be crying out
EN.24: so that, confused, I stopped.
EN.25: I think he thought that I thought
EN.26: all these voices in among the branches
EN.27: came from people hiding there.
EN.28: And so the master said: 'If you break off
EN.29: a twig among these brambles,
EN.30: your present thoughts will be cut short.'
EN.31: Then I stretched out my hand
EN.32: and plucked a twig from a tall thorn-bush,
EN.33: and its stem cried out: 'Why do you break me?'
EN.34: When it ran dark with blood
EN.35: it cried again: 'Why do you tear me?
EN.36: Have you no pity in you?
EN.37: 'We once were men and now are turned to thorns.
EN.38: Your hand might well have been more merciful
EN.39: had we been souls of snakes.'
EN.40: As from a green log, burning at one end,
EN.41: that blisters and hisses at the other
EN.42: with the rush of sap and air,
EN.43: so from the broken splinter oozed
EN.44: blood and words together, and I let drop
EN.45: that twig and stood like one afraid.
EN.46: 'Could he have believed it otherwise,
EN.47: O wounded soul,' my sage spoke up,
EN.48: 'what he has seen only in my verses,
EN.49: 'he would not have raised his hand against you.
EN.50: But your plight, being incredible, made me
EN.51: goad him to this deed that weighs on me.
EN.52: 'Now tell him who you were, so that, by way
EN.53: of recompense, he may revive your fame
EN.54: up in the world, where he's permitted to return.'
EN.55: And the stem said: 'With your pleasing words
EN.56: you so allure me I cannot keep silent.
EN.57: May it not offend if I am now enticed to speak.
EN.58: 'I am the one who held both keys
EN.59: to Frederick's heart, and I could turn them,
EN.60: locking and unlocking, so discreetly
EN.61: 'I kept his secrets safe from almost everyone.
EN.62: So faithful was I to that glorious office
EN.63: that first I lost my sleep and then my life.
EN.64: 'The slut who never took her whoring eyes
EN.65: from Caesar's household, the common bane
EN.66: and special vice of courts,
EN.67: 'inflamed all minds against me.
EN.68: And they, inflamed, did so inflame Augustus
EN.69: that welcome honors turned to dismal woe.
EN.70: 'My mind, in scornful temper,
EN.71: hoping by dying to escape from scorn,
EN.72: made me, though just, against myself unjust.
EN.73: 'By this tree's new-sprung roots I give my oath:
EN.74: not once did I break faith
EN.75: with my true lord, a man so worthy of honor.
EN.76: 'If one of you goes back into the world,
EN.77: let him restore my name. It even now lies helpless
EN.78: beneath the blows that envy dealt it.'
EN.79: The poet waited, then he said to me:
EN.80: 'Since he is silent now do not waste time
EN.81: but speak if you would ask him more.'
EN.82: And I replied: 'Please question him
EN.83: about the things you think I need to know.
EN.84: For I cannot, such pity fills my heart.'
EN.85: Thus he began again: 'So that this man may,
EN.86: with ready will, do as your words entreat,
EN.87: may it please you, imprisoned spirit,
EN.88: 'to tell us further how the souls are bound
EN.89: inside such gnarled wood. And tell us, if you can,
EN.90: if from such limbs one ever is set free.'
EN.91: Then the tree forced out harsh breath, and soon
EN.92: that wind was turned into a voice:
EN.93: 'My answer shall be brief.
EN.94: 'When the ferocious soul deserts the body
EN.95: after it has wrenched up its own roots,
EN.96: Minos condemns it to the seventh gulch.
EN.97: 'It falls into the forest, in a spot not chosen,
EN.98: but flung by fortune, helter-skelter,
EN.99: it fastens like a seed.
EN.100: 'It spreads into a shoot, then a wild thicket.
EN.101: The Harpies, feeding on its leaves,
EN.102: give pain and to that pain a mouth.
EN.103: 'We will come to claim our cast-off bodies
EN.104: like the others. But it would not be just if we again
EN.105: put on the flesh we robbed from our own souls.
EN.106: 'Here shall we drag it, and in this dismal wood
EN.107: our bodies will be hung, each one
EN.108: upon the thorn-bush of its painful shade.'
EN.109: Our attention was still fixed upon the tree,
EN.110: thinking it had more to tell us,
EN.111: when we were startled by a noise,
EN.112: as a man, when he hears
EN.113: the dogs, and branches snapping,
EN.114: knows the boar and hunters near.
EN.115: Now, from the left, two souls came running,
EN.116: naked and torn, and so intent on flight
EN.117: they broke straight through the tangled thicket.
EN.118: The one in front cried: 'Come, come quickly, death!'
EN.119: And the other, who thought his own pace slow:
EN.120: 'Lano, your legs were not so nimble
EN.121: at the tournament near the Toppo.'
EN.122: Then, almost out of breath, he pressed himself
EN.123: into a single tangle with a bush.
EN.124: Behind them now the woods were thick
EN.125: with bitches, black and ravenous and swift
EN.126: as hounds loosed from the leash.
EN.127: On him who had hidden in the tangle
EN.128: they set their teeth, tore him to pieces,
EN.129: and carried off those miserable limbs.
EN.130: And then my leader took me by the hand.
EN.131: He led me to the bush,
EN.132: which wept in vain lament from bleeding wounds.
EN.133: 'O Jacopo da Sant' Andrea,' it said,
EN.134: 'what use was it to make a screen of me?
EN.135: Why must I suffer for your guilty life?'
EN.136: When the master stopped beside it, he said:
EN.137: 'Who were you, that through so many wounds
EN.138: pour out with blood your doleful words?'
EN.139: And he to us: 'O souls who have arrived
EN.140: to see the shameless carnage
EN.141: that has torn from me my leaves,
EN.142: 'gather them here at the foot of this wretched bush.
EN.143: I was of the city that traded patrons --
EN.144: Mars for John the Baptist. On that account
EN.145: 'Mars with his craft will make her grieve forever.
EN.146: And were it not that at the crossing of the Arno
EN.147: some vestige of him still remains,
EN.148: 'those citizens who afterwards rebuilt it
EN.149: upon the ashes Àttila had left behind
EN.150: would have done their work in vain.
EN.151: I made my house into my gallows.'

IT.1: Poi che la carità del natio loco
IT.2: mi strinse, raunai le fronde sparte
IT.3: e rende'le a colui, ch'era già fioco.
IT.4: Indi venimmo al fine ove si parte
IT.5: lo secondo giron dal terzo, e dove
IT.6: si vede di giustizia orribil arte.
IT.7: A ben manifestar le cose nove,
IT.8: dico che arrivammo ad una landa
IT.9: che dal suo letto ogne pianta rimove.
IT.10: La dolorosa selva l'è ghirlanda
IT.11: intorno, come 'l fosso tristo ad essa;
IT.12: quivi fermammo i passi a randa a randa.
IT.13: Lo spazzo era una rena arida e spessa,
IT.14: non d'altra foggia fatta che colei
IT.15: che fu da' piè di Caton già soppressa.
IT.16: O vendetta di Dio, quanto tu dei
IT.17: esser temuta da ciascun che legge
IT.18: ciò che fu manifesto a li occhi mei!
IT.19: D'anime nude vidi molte gregge
IT.20: che piangean tutte assai miseramente,
IT.21: e parea posta lor diversa legge.
IT.22: Supin giacea in terra alcuna gente,
IT.23: alcuna si sedea tutta raccolta,
IT.24: e altra andava continüamente.
IT.25: Quella che giva 'ntorno era più molta,
IT.26: e quella men che giacëa al tormento,
IT.27: ma più al duolo avea la lingua sciolta.
IT.28: Sovra tutto 'l sabbion, d'un cader lento,
IT.29: piovean di foco dilatate falde,
IT.30: come di neve in alpe sanza vento.
IT.31: Quali Alessandro in quelle parti calde
IT.32: d'Indïa vide sopra 'l süo stuolo
IT.33: fiamme cadere infino a terra salde,
IT.34: per ch'ei provide a scalpitar lo suolo
IT.35: con le sue schiere, acciò che lo vapore
IT.36: mei si stingueva mentre ch'era solo:
IT.37: tale scendeva l'etternale ardore;
IT.38: onde la rena s'accendea, com' esca
IT.39: sotto focile, a doppiar lo dolore.
IT.40: Sanza riposo mai era la tresca
IT.41: de le misere mani, or quindi or quinci
IT.42: escotendo da sé l'arsura fresca.
IT.43: I' cominciai: "Maestro, tu che vinci
IT.44: tutte le cose, fuor che ' demon duri
IT.45: ch'a l'intrar de la porta incontra uscinci,
IT.46: chi è quel grande che non par che curi
IT.47: lo 'ncendio e giace dispettoso e torto,
IT.48: sì che la pioggia non par che 'l marturi?"
IT.49: E quel medesmo, che si fu accorto
IT.50: ch'io domandava il mio duca di lui,
IT.51: gridò: "Qual io fui vivo, tal son morto.
IT.52: Se Giove stanchi 'l suo fabbro da cui
IT.53: crucciato prese la folgore aguta
IT.54: onde l'ultimo dì percosso fui;
IT.55: o s'elli stanchi li altri a muta a muta
IT.56: in Mongibello a la focina negra,
IT.57: chiamando 'Buon Vulcano, aiuta, aiuta!'
IT.58: sì com' el fece a la pugna di Flegra,
IT.59: e me saetti con tutta sua forza:
IT.60: non ne potrebbe aver vendetta allegra."
IT.61: Allora il duca mio parlò di forza
IT.62: tanto, ch'i' non l'avea sì forte udito:
IT.63: "O Capaneo, in ciò che non s'ammorza
IT.64: la tua superbia, se' tu più punito;
IT.65: nullo martiro, fuor che la tua rabbia,
IT.66: sarebbe al tuo furor dolor compito."
IT.67: Poi si rivolse a me con miglior labbia,
IT.68: dicendo: "Quei fu l'un d'i sette regi
IT.69: ch'assiser Tebe; ed ebbe e par ch'elli abbia
IT.70: Dio in disdegno, e poco par che 'l pregi;
IT.71: ma, com' io dissi lui, li suoi dispetti
IT.72: sono al suo petto assai debiti fregi.
IT.73: Or mi vien dietro, e guarda che non metti,
IT.74: ancor, li piedi ne la rena arsiccia;
IT.75: ma sempre al bosco tien li piedi stretti."
IT.76: Tacendo divenimmo là 've spiccia
IT.77: fuor de la selva un picciol fiumicello,
IT.78: lo cui rossore ancor mi raccapriccia.
IT.79: Quale del Bulicame esce ruscello
IT.80: che parton poi tra lor le peccatrici,
IT.81: tal per la rena giù sen giva quello.
IT.82: Lo fondo suo e ambo le pendici
IT.83: fatt' era 'n pietra, e ' margini da lato;
IT.84: per ch'io m'accorsi che 'l passo era lici.
IT.85: "Tra tutto l'altro ch'i' t'ho dimostrato,
IT.86: poscia che noi intrammo per la porta
IT.87: lo cui sogliare a nessuno è negato,
IT.88: cosa non fu da li tuoi occhi scorta
IT.89: notabile com' è 'l presente rio,
IT.90: che sovra sé tutte fiammelle ammorta."
IT.91: Queste parole fuor del duca mio;
IT.92: per ch'io 'l pregai che mi largisse 'l pasto
IT.93: di cui largito m'avëa il disio.
IT.94: "In mezzo mar siede un paese guasto,"
IT.95: diss' elli allora, "che s'appella Creta,
IT.96: sotto 'l cui rege fu già 'l mondo casto.
IT.97: Una montagna v'è che già fu lieta
IT.98: d'acqua e di fronde, che si chiamò Ida;
IT.99: or è diserta come cosa vieta.
IT.100: Rëa la scelse già per cuna fida
IT.101: del suo figliuolo, e per celarlo meglio,
IT.102: quando piangea, vi facea far le grida.
IT.103: Dentro dal monte sta dritto un gran veglio,
IT.104: che tien volte le spalle inver' Dammiata
IT.105: e Roma guarda come süo speglio.
IT.106: La sua testa è di fin oro formata,
IT.107: e puro argento son le braccia e 'l petto,
IT.108: poi è di rame infino a la forcata;
IT.109: da indi in giuso è tutto ferro eletto,
IT.110: salvo che 'l destro piede è terra cotta;
IT.111: e sta 'n su quel, più che 'n su l'altro, eretto.
IT.112: Ciascuna parte, fuor che l'oro, è rotta
IT.113: d'una fessura che lagrime goccia,
IT.114: le quali, accolte, fóran quella grotta.
IT.115: Lor corso in questa valle si diroccia;
IT.116: fanno Acheronte, Stige e Flegetonta;
IT.117: poi sen van giù per questa stretta doccia,
IT.118: infin, là ove più non si dismonta,
IT.119: fanno Cocito; e qual sia quello stagno
IT.120: tu lo vedrai, però qui non si conta."
IT.121: E io a lui: "Se 'l presente rigagno
IT.122: si diriva così dal nostro mondo,
IT.123: perché ci appar pur a questo vivagno?"
IT.124: Ed elli a me: "Tu sai che 'l loco è tondo;
IT.125: e tutto che tu sie venuto molto,
IT.126: pur a sinistra, giù calando al fondo,
IT.127: non se' ancor per tutto 'l cerchio vòlto;
IT.128: per che, se cosa n'apparisce nova,
IT.129: non de' addur maraviglia al tuo volto."
IT.130: E io ancor: "Maestro, ove si trova
IT.131: Flegetonta e Letè? ché de l'un taci,
IT.132: e l'altro di' che si fa d'esta piova."
IT.133: "In tutte tue question certo mi piaci,"
IT.134: rispuose, "ma 'l bollor de l'acqua rossa
IT.135: dovea ben solver l'una che tu faci.

IT.137: là dove vanno l'anime a lavarsi
IT.138: quando la colpa pentuta è rimossa."
