EN.1: O Simon Magus! O wretches of his band,
EN.2: greedy for gold and silver,
EN.3: who prostitute the things of God
EN.4: that should be brides of goodness!
EN.5: Now must the trumpet sound for you,
EN.6: because your place is there in that third ditch.
EN.7: We had come to where the next tomb lay,
EN.8: having climbed to the point upon the ridge
EN.9: that overlooks the middle of the trench.
EN.10: O Supreme Wisdom, what great art you show
EN.11: in Heaven, on earth, and in the evil world,
EN.12: and what true justice does your power dispense!
EN.13: Along the sides and bottom I could see
EN.14: the livid stone was pierced with holes,
EN.15: all round and of a single size.
EN.16: They seemed to me as wide and deep
EN.17: as those in my beautiful Saint John
EN.18: made for the priests to baptize in,
EN.19: one of which, not many years ago,
EN.20: I broke to save one nearly drowned in it --
EN.21: and let this be my seal, to undeceive all men.
EN.22: From the mouth of each stuck out
EN.23: a sinner's feet and legs up to the thighs
EN.24: while all the rest stayed in the hole.
EN.25: They all had both their soles on fire.
EN.26: It made their knee-joints writhe so hard
EN.27: they would have severed twisted vines or ropes.
EN.28: As flames move only on the surface
EN.29: of oily matter caught on fire,
EN.30: so these flames flickered heel to toe.
EN.31: 'Who is that, master, who in his torment
EN.32: wriggles more than any of his fellows
EN.33: and is licked by redder flames?'
EN.34: And he: 'If you like, I'll take you down
EN.35: along the lower bank and you will learn,
EN.36: from him, his life and his misdeeds.'
EN.37: And I: 'Whatever pleases you is my desire.
EN.38: You are my lord and know I do your will.
EN.39: You know, too, what I leave unsaid.'
EN.40: Then we came to the fourth embankment,
EN.41: turned and descended on our left
EN.42: into a narrow bottom pierced with holes.
EN.43: The good master clasped me to his side
EN.44: and did not set me down until we came
EN.45: to the pit of one lamenting with his shanks.
EN.46: 'Whatever you are, with your upper parts below,
EN.47: planted like a post, you wretched soul,'
EN.48: said I, 'come out with something, if you can.'
EN.49: I stood there like a friar who confesses
EN.50: a treacherous assassin. Once fixed in place,
EN.51: he calls the friar back to stay his death.
EN.52: And he cried out: 'Is that you already,
EN.53: are you here already, Boniface?
EN.54: By several years the writing lied to me.
EN.55: 'Are you so swiftly sated with those profits
EN.56: for which you did not fear to take by guile
EN.57: the beautiful Lady and to do her outrage?'
EN.58: I became like those who stand there mocked,
EN.59: not comprehending what is said to them,
EN.60: and thus not knowing what to say in turn.
EN.61: Then Virgil said: 'Tell him right away,
EN.62: "I'm not the one, I'm not the one you think."'
EN.63: I gave the answer I was told to give.
EN.64: At that the spirit's feet began to writhe.
EN.65: Then, sighing, with a plaintive voice, he said:
EN.66: 'What is it then you want from me?
EN.67: 'If you are so keen to learn my name
EN.68: that you descended from the bank for it,
EN.69: know that I was cloaked in the great mantle.
EN.70: 'But in truth I was a son of the she-bear
EN.71: and so avid was I to advance my cubs
EN.72: I filled my purse as now I fill this hole.
EN.73: 'Beneath my head are crushed the others
EN.74: who practiced simony before me,
EN.75: now flattened into fissures in the rock.
EN.76: 'In turn I, too, shall be thrust lower down
EN.77: as soon as he arrives whom I mistook you for
EN.78: when I called out my hasty question.
EN.79: 'But the time I've already roasted my feet,
EN.80: upside down here, is already longer
EN.81: than he'll be planted with his feet on fire.
EN.82: 'For after him shall come a lawless shepherd
EN.83: from the west, one even fouler in his deeds,
EN.84: fit to be the cover over him and me.
EN.85: 'A new Jason shall he be, the one of whom
EN.86: we read in Maccabees, and even as the king indulged
EN.87: Jason, so the king of France shall deal with him.'
EN.88: I do not know if then I was too bold
EN.89: when I answered him in just this strain:
EN.90: 'Please tell me, how much treasure
EN.91: 'did our Lord insist on from Saint Peter
EN.92: before He gave the keys into his keeping?
EN.93: Surely He asked no more than "Follow me,"
EN.94: 'nor did Peter, or the others, take gold or silver
EN.95: from Matthias when he was picked by lot
EN.96: to fill the place lost by the guilty soul.
EN.97: 'Stay there then, for you are justly punished,
EN.98: guarding well those gains, ill-gotten,
EN.99: that made you boldly take your stand against King Charles.
EN.100: 'And were it not that I am still restrained
EN.101: by the reverence I owe the keys supreme,
EN.102: which once you held in the happy life above,
EN.103: 'I would resort to even harsher words
EN.104: because your avarice afflicts the world,
EN.105: trampling down the good and raising up the wicked.
EN.106: 'Shepherds like you the Evangelist had in mind
EN.107: when he saw the one that sits upon the waters
EN.108: committing fornication with the kings,
EN.109: 'she that was born with seven heads
EN.110: and from ten horns derived her strength
EN.111: so long as virtue pleased her bridegroom.
EN.112: 'You have wrought yourselves a god of gold and silver.
EN.113: How then do you differ from those who worship idols
EN.114: except they worship one and you a hundred?
EN.115: 'Ah, Constantine, to what evil you gave birth,
EN.116: not by your conversion, but by the dowry
EN.117: that the first rich Father had from you!'
EN.118: And while I sang such notes to him,
EN.119: whether gnawed by anger or by conscience,
EN.120: he kicked out hard with both his feet.
EN.121: Truly I believe this pleased my leader,
EN.122: he listened with a look of such contentment
EN.123: to the sound of the truthful words I spoke.
EN.124: Therefore, he caught me in his arms
EN.125: and, when he had me all upon his breast,
EN.126: remounted by the path he had descended,
EN.127: nor did he tire of holding me so close
EN.128: but bore me to the summit of the arch
EN.129: that crosses from the fourth dike to the fifth.
EN.130: Here gently he set down his burden,
EN.131: gently on account of the steep, rough ridge
EN.132: that would have made hard going for a goat.
EN.133: And there, before me, another valley opened.

IT.1: Di nova pena mi conven far versi
IT.2: e dar matera al ventesimo canto
IT.3: de la prima canzon, ch'è d'i sommersi.
IT.4: Io era già disposto tutto quanto
IT.5: a riguardar ne lo scoperto fondo,
IT.6: che si bagnava d'angoscioso pianto;
IT.7: e vidi gente per lo vallon tondo
IT.8: venir, tacendo e lagrimando, al passo
IT.9: che fanno le letane in questo mondo.
IT.10: Come 'l viso mi scese in lor più basso,
IT.11: mirabilmente apparve esser travolto
IT.12: ciascun tra 'l mento e 'l principio del casso,
IT.13: ché da le reni era tornato 'l volto,
IT.14: e in dietro venir li convenia,
IT.15: perché 'l veder dinanzi era lor tolto.
IT.16: Forse per forza già di parlasia
IT.17: si travolse così alcun del tutto;
IT.18: ma io nol vidi, né credo che sia.
IT.19: Se Dio ti lasci, lettor, prender frutto
IT.20: di tua lezione, or pensa per te stesso
IT.21: com' io potea tener lo viso asciutto,
IT.22: quando la nostra imagine di presso
IT.23: vidi sì torta, che 'l pianto de li occhi
IT.24: le natiche bagnava per lo fesso.
IT.25: Certo io piangea, poggiato a un de' rocchi
IT.26: del duro scoglio, sì che la mia scorta
IT.27: mi disse: "Ancor se' tu de li altri sciocchi?
IT.28: Qui vive la pietà quand' è ben morta;
IT.29: chi è più scellerato che colui
IT.30: che al giudicio divin passion comporta?
IT.31: Drizza la testa, drizza, e vedi a cui
IT.32: s'aperse a li occhi d'i Teban la terra;
IT.33: per ch'ei gridavan tutti: 'Dove rui,
IT.34: Anfïarao? perché lasci la guerra?'
IT.35: E non restò di ruinare a valle
IT.36: fino a Minòs che ciascheduno afferra.
IT.37: Mira c'ha fatto petto de le spalle;
IT.38: perché volse veder troppo davante,
IT.39: di retro guarda e fa retroso calle.
IT.40: Vedi Tiresia, che mutò sembiante
IT.41: quando di maschio femmina divenne,
IT.42: cangiandosi le membra tutte quante;
IT.43: e prima, poi, ribatter li convenne
IT.44: li duo serpenti avvolti, con la verga,
IT.45: che rïavesse le maschili penne.
IT.46: Aronta è quel ch'al ventre li s'atterga,
IT.47: che ne' monti di Luni, dove ronca
IT.48: lo Carrarese che di sotto alberga,
IT.49: ebbe tra ' bianchi marmi la spelonca
IT.50: per sua dimora; onde a guardar le stelle
IT.51: e 'l mar non li era la veduta tronca.
IT.52: E quella che ricuopre le mammelle,
IT.53: che tu non vedi, con le trecce sciolte,
IT.54: e ha di là ogne pilosa pelle,
IT.55: Manto fu, che cercò per terre molte;
IT.56: poscia si puose là dove nacqu' io;
IT.57: onde un poco mi piace che m'ascolte.
IT.58: Poscia che 'l padre suo di vita uscìo
IT.59: e venne serva la città di Baco,
IT.60: questa gran tempo per lo mondo gio.
IT.61: Suso in Italia bella giace un laco,
IT.62: a piè de l'Alpe che serra Lamagna
IT.63: sovra Tiralli, c'ha nome Benaco.
IT.64: Per mille fonti, credo, e più si bagna
IT.65: tra Garda e Val Camonica e Pennino
IT.66: de l'acqua che nel detto laco stagna.
IT.67: Loco è nel mezzo là dove 'l trentino
IT.68: pastore e quel di Brescia e 'l veronese
IT.69: segnar poria, s'e' fesse quel cammino.
IT.70: Siede Peschiera, bello e forte arnese
IT.71: da fronteggiar Bresciani e Bergamaschi,
IT.72: ove la riva 'ntorno più discese.
IT.73: Ivi convien che tutto quanto caschi
IT.74: ciò che 'n grembo a Benaco star non può,
IT.75: e fassi fiume giù per verdi paschi.
IT.76: Tosto che l'acqua a correr mette co,
IT.77: non più Benaco, ma Mencio si chiama
IT.78: fino a Govèrnol, dove cade in Po.
IT.79: Non molto ha corso, ch'el trova una lama,
IT.80: ne la qual si distende e la 'mpaluda;
IT.81: e suol di state talor esser grama.
IT.82: Quindi passando la vergine cruda
IT.83: vide terra, nel mezzo del pantano,
IT.84: sanza coltura e d'abitanti nuda.
IT.85: Lì, per fuggire ogne consorzio umano,
IT.86: ristette con suoi servi a far sue arti,
IT.87: e visse, e vi lasciò suo corpo vano.
IT.88: Li uomini poi che 'ntorno erano sparti
IT.89: s'accolsero a quel loco, ch'era forte
IT.90: per lo pantan ch'avea da tutte parti.
IT.91: Fer la città sovra quell' ossa morte;
IT.92: e per colei che 'l loco prima elesse,
IT.93: Mantüa l'appellar sanz' altra sorte.
IT.94: Già fuor le genti sue dentro più spesse,
IT.95: prima che la mattia da Casalodi
IT.96: da Pinamonte inganno ricevesse.
IT.97: Però t'assenno che, se tu mai odi
IT.98: originar la mia terra altrimenti,
IT.99: la verità nulla menzogna frodi."
IT.100: E io: "Maestro, i tuoi ragionamenti
IT.101: mi son sì certi e prendon sì mia fede,
IT.102: che li altri mi sarien carboni spenti.
IT.103: Ma dimmi, de la gente che procede,
IT.104: se tu ne vedi alcun degno di nota;
IT.105: ché solo a ciò la mia mente rifiede."
IT.106: Allor mi disse: "Quel che da la gota
IT.107: porge la barba in su le spalle brune,
IT.108: fu -- quando Grecia fu di maschi vòta,
IT.109: sì ch'a pena rimaser per le cune --
IT.110: augure, e diede 'l punto con Calcanta
IT.111: in Aulide a tagliar la prima fune.
IT.112: Euripilo ebbe nome, e così 'l canta
IT.113: l'alta mia tragedìa in alcun loco:
IT.114: ben lo sai tu che la sai tutta quanta.
IT.115: Quell' altro che ne' fianchi è così poco,
IT.116: Michele Scotto fu, che veramente
IT.117: de le magiche frode seppe 'l gioco.
IT.118: Vedi Guido Bonatti; vedi Asdente,
IT.119: ch'avere inteso al cuoio e a lo spago
IT.120: ora vorrebbe, ma tardi si pente.
IT.121: Vedi le triste che lasciaron l'ago,
IT.122: la spuola e 'l fuso, e fecersi 'ndivine;
IT.123: fecer malie con erbe e con imago.
IT.124: Ma vienne omai, ché già tiene 'l confine
IT.125: d'amendue li emisperi e tocca l'onda
IT.126: sotto Sobilia Caino e le spine;
IT.127: e già iernotte fu la luna tonda:
IT.128: ben ten de' ricordar, ché non ti nocque
IT.129: alcuna volta per la selva fonda."
IT.130: Sì mi parlava, e andavamo introcque.

EN.1: Of strange new pain I now must make my verse,
EN.2: giving matter to the canto numbered twenty
EN.3: of this first canzone, which tells of those submerged.
EN.4: By now I was all eagerness to see
EN.5: what sights the chasm, bathed in tears
EN.6: of anguish, would disclose.
EN.7: I saw people come along that curving canyon
EN.8: in silence, weeping, their pace the pace of slow
EN.9: processions chanting litanies in the world.
EN.10: As my gaze moved down along their shapes,
EN.11: I saw into what strange contortions
EN.12: their chins and chests were twisted.
EN.13: Their faces were reversed upon their shoulders
EN.14: so that they came on walking backward,
EN.15: since seeing forward was denied them.
EN.16: Perhaps some time by stroke of palsy
EN.17: a person could be twisted in that way,
EN.18: but I've not seen it nor do I think it likely.
EN.19: Reader, so may God let you gather fruit
EN.20: from reading this, imagine, if you can,
EN.21: how I could have kept from weeping
EN.22: when I saw, up close, our human likeness
EN.23: so contorted that tears from their eyes
EN.24: ran down their buttocks, down into the cleft.
EN.25: Yes, I wept, leaning against a spur
EN.26: of the rough crag, so that my escort said:
EN.27: 'Are you still witless as the rest?
EN.28: 'Here piety lives when pity is quite dead.
EN.29: Who is more impious than one who thinks
EN.30: that God shows passion in His judgment?
EN.31: 'Raise your head! Raise it and look on him
EN.32: under whose feet the earth gaped open
EN.33: in sight of all the shouting Thebans:
EN.34: '"Where are you rushing, Amphiaraus? Why
EN.35: do you leave the war?" Nor did he stop his plunge
EN.36: until he fell to Minos, who lays hold on all.
EN.37: 'See how his shoulder-blades are now his chest.
EN.38: Because he aspired to see too far ahead
EN.39: he looks behind and treads a backward path.
EN.40: 'See Tiresias, who changed his likeness
EN.41: when he was turned from male to female,
EN.42: transformed in every member.
EN.43: 'Later on he had to touch once more
EN.44: the two twined serpents with his rod
EN.45: before he could regain his manly plumes.
EN.46: 'He who puts his back to that one's belly is Aruns.
EN.47: In the hills of Luni -- where the Carraresi,
EN.48: who shelter in the valley, work the earth --
EN.49: 'he lived inside a cave in that white marble,
EN.50: from which he could observe the sea and stars
EN.51: in a wide and boundless prospect.
EN.52: 'And that female whose backward-flowing tresses
EN.53: fall upon her breasts so they are hidden,
EN.54: and has her hairy parts on that same side,
EN.55: 'was Manto, who searched through many lands
EN.56: before she settled in the place where I was born --
EN.57: for just a moment hear me out on this.
EN.58: 'After her father had parted from this life
EN.59: and the city of Bacchus was enslaved,
EN.60: she wandered for a time about the world.
EN.61: 'High in fair Italy, at the foot of the alps
EN.62: that form a border with Germany near Tyrol,
EN.63: lies a lake they call Benàco.
EN.64: 'By a thousand springs and more, I think, the region
EN.65: between Garda, Val Camonica, and Pennino
EN.66: is bathed by waters settling in that lake.
EN.67: 'There is an island in its middle
EN.68: that the pastors of Trent, Brescia, and Verona,
EN.69: should they pass that way, would bless.
EN.70: 'Peschiera, a strong and splendid fortress
EN.71: against the Brescians and the Bergamese,
EN.72: sits on the lowest point of land around.
EN.73: 'There all the water Benàco's bosom cannot hold
EN.74: flows over and descends into a river
EN.75: running through green pastures.
EN.76: 'This river, as it leaves the lake
EN.77: and all the way to Govérnolo, is called
EN.78: Mincio until it falls into the Po.
EN.79: 'Before that, after but the briefest run,
EN.80: it levels off and spreads to make a swamp
EN.81: sometimes scarce of water in the summer.
EN.82: 'When she passed that way, the cruel virgin
EN.83: saw dry land in the middle of the marsh
EN.84: where no one lived and no one tilled the soil.
EN.85: 'There, to avoid all company, she stopped,
EN.86: with only servants, to ply her magic arts.
EN.87: There she lived and left her empty body.
EN.88: 'Later on, the people scattered round about
EN.89: collected there because it was protected
EN.90: by the marsh on every side.
EN.91: 'They built the city over those dead bones
EN.92: and, after her who first had claimed the spot,
EN.93: named it Mantua, with no spells or incantations.
EN.94: 'Once, its population was more plentiful,
EN.95: before the foolishness of Casalodi
EN.96: bore the brunt of Pinamonte's guile.
EN.97: 'I charge you, therefore, should you ever hear
EN.98: my city's origin described another way,
EN.99: allow no lie to falsify the truth.'
EN.100: And I: 'Master, to me your explanation
EN.101: is so convincing and so takes my trust
EN.102: that any other tale would seem spent embers.
EN.103: 'But tell me, among these people who are passing,
EN.104: if you see any worthy of my notice,
EN.105: for my thoughts keep going back to them alone.'
EN.106: Then he replied: 'The one whose beard
EN.107: falls from his jowls onto his swarthy shoulders
EN.108: was -- when Greece was so deprived of males
EN.109: 'that the only ones still there were in their cradles --
EN.110: a soothsayer. At Aulis, along with Calchas,
EN.111: he told the favoring time for setting sail.
EN.112: 'Eurypylus was his name, and thus he is sung
EN.113: in certain verses of my lofty tragedy,
EN.114: as you know very well, who know it all.
EN.115: 'That other, with the skinny shanks,
EN.116: was Michael Scot, who truly understood
EN.117: the way to play the game of magic tricks.
EN.118: 'See Guido Bonatti. See Asdente, who now regrets
EN.119: not having worked his leather and his thread --
EN.120: but he repents too late.
EN.121: 'See the wretched women who gave up needle,
EN.122: spool, and spindle to take up fortune-telling,
EN.123: casting spells with images and herbs.
EN.124: 'But come now, for Cain, with his thorns,
EN.125: already stands above the border of both hemispheres
EN.126: and touches the waves below Seville.
EN.127: 'Surely you recall, two nights ago,
EN.128: the moon, already full, did you no harm
EN.129: at any time in the deep wood.'
EN.130: These were his words while we were moving on.

IT.1: Così di ponte in ponte, altro parlando
IT.2: che la mia comedìa cantar non cura,
IT.3: venimmo; e tenavamo 'l colmo, quando
IT.4: restammo per veder l'altra fessura
IT.5: di Malebolge e li altri pianti vani;
IT.6: e vidila mirabilmente oscura.
IT.7: Quale ne l'arzanà de' Viniziani
IT.8: bolle l'inverno la tenace pece
IT.9: a rimpalmare i legni lor non sani,
IT.10: ché navicar non ponno -- in quella vece
IT.11: chi fa suo legno novo e chi ristoppa
IT.12: le coste a quel che più vïaggi fece;
IT.13: chi ribatte da proda e chi da poppa;
IT.14: altri fa remi e altri volge sarte;
IT.15: chi terzeruolo e artimon rintoppa --:
IT.16: tal, non per foco ma per divin' arte,
IT.17: bollia là giuso una pegola spessa,
IT.18: che 'nviscava la ripa d'ogne parte.
IT.19: I' vedea lei, ma non vedëa in essa
IT.20: mai che le bolle che 'l bollor levava,
IT.21: e gonfiar tutta, e riseder compressa.
IT.22: Mentr' io là giù fisamente mirava,
IT.23: lo duca mio, dicendo "Guarda, guarda!"
IT.24: mi trasse a sé del loco dov' io stava.
IT.25: Allor mi volsi come l'uom cui tarda
IT.26: di veder quel che li convien fuggire
IT.27: e cui paura sùbita sgagliarda,
IT.28: che, per veder, non indugia 'l partire:
IT.29: e vidi dietro a noi un diavol nero
IT.30: correndo su per lo scoglio venire.
IT.31: Ahi quant' elli era ne l'aspetto fero!
IT.32: e quanto mi parea ne l'atto acerbo,
IT.33: con l'ali aperte e sovra i piè leggero!
IT.34: L'omero suo, ch'era aguto e superbo,
IT.35: carcava un peccator con ambo l'anche,
IT.36: e quei tenea de' piè ghermito 'l nerbo.
IT.37: Del nostro ponte disse: "O Malebranche,
IT.38: ecco un de li anzïan di Santa Zita!
IT.39: Mettetel sotto, ch'i' torno per anche
IT.40: a quella terra, che n'è ben fornita:
IT.41: ogn' uom v'è barattier, fuor che Bonturo;
IT.42: del no, per li denar, vi si fa ita."
IT.43: Là giù 'l buttò, e per lo scoglio duro
IT.44: si volse; e mai non fu mastino sciolto
IT.45: con tanta fretta a seguitar lo furo.
IT.46: Quel s'attuffò, e tornò sù convolto;
IT.47: ma i demon che del ponte avean coperchio,
IT.48: gridar: "Qui non ha loco il Santo Volto!
IT.49: qui si nuota altrimenti che nel Serchio!
IT.50: Però, se tu non vuo' di nostri graffi,
IT.51: non far sopra la pegola soverchio."
IT.52: Poi l'addentar con più di cento raffi,
IT.53: disser: "Coverto convien che qui balli,
IT.54: sì che, se puoi, nascosamente accaffi."
IT.55: Non altrimenti i cuoci a' lor vassalli
IT.56: fanno attuffare in mezzo la caldaia
IT.57: la carne con li uncin, perché non galli.
IT.58: Lo buon maestro "Acciò che non si paia
IT.59: che tu ci sia," mi disse, "giù t'acquatta
IT.60: dopo uno scheggio, ch'alcun schermo t'aia;
IT.61: e per nulla offension che mi sia fatta,
IT.62: non temer tu, ch'i' ho le cose conte,
IT.63: per ch'altra volta fui a tal baratta."
IT.64: Poscia passò di là dal co del ponte;
IT.65: e com' el giunse in su la ripa sesta,
IT.66: mestier li fu d'aver sicura fronte.
IT.67: Con quel furore e con quella tempesta
IT.68: ch'escono i cani a dosso al poverello
IT.69: che di sùbito chiede ove s'arresta,
IT.70: usciron quei di sotto al ponticello,
IT.71: e volser contra lui tutt' i runcigli;
IT.72: ma el gridò: "Nessun di voi sia fello!
IT.73: Innanzi che l'uncin vostro mi pigli,
IT.74: traggasi avante l'un di voi che m'oda,
IT.75: e poi d'arruncigliarmi si consigli."
IT.76: Tutti gridaron: "Vada Malacoda!";
IT.77: per ch'un si mosse -- e li altri stetter fermi --
IT.78: e venne a lui dicendo: "Che li approda?"
IT.79: "Credi tu, Malacoda, qui vedermi
IT.80: esser venuto," disse 'l mio maestro,
IT.81: "sicuro già da tutti vostri schermi,
IT.82: sanza voler divino e fato destro?
IT.83: Lascian' andar, ché nel cielo è voluto
IT.84: ch'i' mostri altrui questo cammin silvestro."
IT.85: Allor li fu l'orgoglio sì caduto,
IT.86: ch'e' si lasciò cascar l'uncino a' piedi,
IT.87: e disse a li altri: "Omai non sia feruto."
IT.88: E 'l duca mio a me: "O tu che siedi
IT.89: tra li scheggion del ponte quatto quatto,
IT.90: sicuramente omai a me ti riedi."
IT.91: Per ch'io mi mossi e a lui venni ratto;
IT.92: e i diavoli si fecer tutti avanti,
IT.93: sì ch'io temetti ch'ei tenesser patto;
IT.94: così vid' ïo già temer li fanti
IT.95: ch'uscivan patteggiati di Caprona,
IT.96: veggendo sé tra nemici cotanti.
IT.97: I' m'accostai con tutta la persona
IT.98: lungo 'l mio duca, e non torceva li occhi
IT.99: da la sembianza lor ch'era non buona.
IT.100: Ei chinavan li raffi e "Vuo' che 'l tocchi,"
IT.101: diceva l'un con l'altro, "in sul groppone?"
IT.102: E rispondien: "Si, fa che gliel' accocchi."
IT.103: Ma quel demonio che tenea sermone
IT.104: col duca mio, si volse tutto presto
IT.105: e disse: "Posa, posa, Scarmiglione!"
IT.106: Poi disse a noi: "Più oltre andar per questo
IT.107: iscoglio non si può, però che giace
IT.108: tutto spezzato al fondo l'arco sesto.
IT.109: E se l'andare avante pur vi piace,
IT.110: andatevene su per questa grotta;
IT.111: presso è un altro scoglio che via face.
IT.112: Ier, più oltre cinqu' ore che quest' otta,
IT.113: mille dugento con sessanta sei
IT.114: anni compié che qui la via fu rotta.
IT.115: Io mando verso là di questi miei
IT.116: a riguardar s'alcun se ne sciorina;
IT.117: gite con lor, che non saranno rei."
IT.118: "Tra'ti avante, Alichino, e Calcabrina,"
IT.119: cominciò elli a dire, "e tu, Cagnazzo;
IT.120: e Barbariccia guidi la decina.
IT.121: Libicocco vegn' oltre e Draghignazzo,
IT.122: Cirïatto sannuto e Graffiacane
IT.123: e Farfarello e Rubicante pazzo.
IT.124: Cercate 'ntorno le boglienti pane;
IT.125: costor sian salvi infino a l'altro scheggio
IT.126: che tutto intero va sovra le tane."
IT.127: "Omè, maestro, che è quel ch'i' veggio?"
IT.128: diss' io, "deh, sanza scorta andianci soli,
IT.129: se tu sa' ir; ch'i' per me non la cheggio.
IT.130: Se tu se' sì accorto come suoli,
IT.131: non vedi tu ch'e' digrignan li denti
IT.132: e con le ciglia ne minaccian duoli?"
IT.133: Ed elli a me: "Non vo' che tu paventi;
IT.134: lasciali digrignar pur a lor senno,
IT.135: ch'e' fanno ciò per li lessi dolenti."
IT.136: Per l'argine sinistro volta dienno;
IT.137: ma prima avea ciascun la lingua stretta
IT.138: coi denti, verso lor duca, per cenno;
IT.139: ed elli avea del cul fatto trombetta.

EN.1: Thus from one bridge to the next we came
EN.2: until we reached its highest point, speaking
EN.3: of things my Comedy does not care to sing.
EN.4: We stopped to look into the next crevasse
EN.5: of Malebolge and heard more useless weeping.
EN.6: All I could see was an astounding darkness.
EN.7: As in the arsenal of the Venetians
EN.8: in wintertime they boil the viscous pitch
EN.9: to caulk their unsound ships
EN.10: because they cannot sail -- one rebuilds
EN.11: his ship, while still another plugs
EN.12: the seams of his, weathered by many a voyage:
EN.13: one hammers at the stem, another at the stern,
EN.14: this one makes the oars, that one twists the ropes
EN.15: for rigging, another patches jib and mainsail --
EN.16: so, not with fire, but by the art of God,
EN.17: a thick pitch boiled there,
EN.18: sticking to the banks on either side.
EN.19: I saw the pitch but still saw nothing in it
EN.20: except the bubbles raised up by the boiling,
EN.21: the whole mass swelling and then settling back.
EN.22: While I stared fixedly upon the seething pitch,
EN.23: my leader cried: 'Look out, look out!'
EN.24: and drew me to him, away from where I stood.
EN.25: Then I turned like a man, intent
EN.26: on making out what he must run from,
EN.27: undone by sudden fear,
EN.28: who does not slow his flight for all his looking back:
EN.29: just so I caught a glimpse of some dark devil
EN.30: running toward us up the ledge.
EN.31: Ah, how ferocious were his looks
EN.32: and fierce his gesturing,
EN.33: with wings spread wide and nimble feet!
EN.34: One of his shoulders, which were high and pointed,
EN.35: was laden with the haunches of a sinner
EN.36: he held hooked by the tendons of his heels.
EN.37: From our bridge he said: 'O Malebranche,
EN.38: here is one of Santa Zita's Elders.
EN.39: Thrust him under, while I head back for more
EN.40: 'to that city, where there's such a fine supply.
EN.41: Every man there -- except Bonturo -- is a swindler.
EN.42: There money turns a No into a Yeah.'
EN.43: He flung him down and turned back up
EN.44: the stony ridge. Never did a mastiff
EN.45: set loose to chase a thief make greater haste.
EN.46: The sinner sank, then rose again, his face all pitch.
EN.47: The demons, under cover of the bridge, cried out:
EN.48: 'This is no place for the Holy Visage!
EN.49: 'Here you swim a different stroke than in the Serchio!
EN.50: Unless you'd like to feel our hooks,
EN.51: don't let yourself stick out above the pitch.'
EN.52: Then, with a hundred hooks and more,
EN.53: they ripped him, crying: 'Here you must do your dance
EN.54: in secret and pilfer -- can you? -- in the dark.'
EN.55: In just the same way cooks command their scullions
EN.56: to take their skewers and prod the meat down
EN.57: in the cauldron, lest it float back up.
EN.58: Then my good master said: 'Squat down
EN.59: behind that rock and find some cover
EN.60: so that they do not see that you are here.
EN.61: 'As for any outrage they may do me,
EN.62: have no fear. I know this place and had
EN.63: exactly such a scuffle here before.'
EN.64: After he had crossed the bridge
EN.65: and reached the other bank,
EN.66: he had to show how resolute he was:
EN.67: With all the rage and uproar
EN.68: of dogs that rush upon a beggar --
EN.69: who quickly starts to beg where he has stopped --
EN.70: they swarmed on him from underneath the bridge
EN.71: with threatening hooks. But he cried out:
EN.72: 'Wait! Let none of you do harm!
EN.73: 'Before you grapple at me with your hooks
EN.74: let one of you come forth to hear me out.
EN.75: Then take counsel, whether to use your claws.'
EN.76: All cried: 'Let Malacoda go.' One moved --
EN.77: the rest stood still -- and he came forward,
EN.78: grumbling: 'This won't do him any good.'
EN.79: 'Consider, Malacoda,' said my master,
EN.80: 'whether you would see me come this far
EN.81: unstopped by all your hindering
EN.82: 'without the will of God and favoring fate?
EN.83: Let us proceed, for it is willed in Heaven
EN.84: that I guide another down this savage way.'
EN.85: Then his pride was so abashed that he let drop
EN.86: the billhook to his feet, saying to the others:
EN.87: 'Enough, let no one touch him.'
EN.88: And my leader said to me: 'You there, cowering
EN.89: among the broken boulders of the bridge,
EN.90: now you may come back to me in safety.'
EN.91: At that I stirred and hastened to him.
EN.92: Then the devils all came surging forward
EN.93: so that I feared they might not keep the truce.
EN.94: Just so do I recall the troops
EN.95: afraid to leave Caprona with safe-conduct,
EN.96: finding themselves among so many enemies.
EN.97: I drew my body up against my leader
EN.98: but kept my eyes fixed on their faces,
EN.99: which were far from friendly.
EN.100: They aimed their hooks, and one said to another:
EN.101: 'How about I nick him on the rump?'
EN.102: And the other answered: 'Sure, let him have one.'
EN.103: But the demon who was speaking with my leader
EN.104: turned round at once and said:
EN.105: 'Easy does it, Scarmiglione!'
EN.106: And then to us: 'You can't continue farther
EN.107: down this ridge, for the sixth arch
EN.108: lies broken into pieces at the bottom.
EN.109: 'If you desire to continue on,
EN.110: then make your way along this rocky ledge.
EN.111: Nearby's another crag that yields a passage.
EN.112: 'Yesterday, at a time five hours from now,
EN.113: it was a thousand two hundred sixty-six years
EN.114: since the road down here was broken.
EN.115: 'I'm sending some men of mine along that way
EN.116: to see if anyone is out to take the air.
EN.117: Go with them -- they won't hurt you.'
EN.118: 'Step forward, Alichino, Calcabrina,'
EN.119: he continued, 'and you Cagnazzo,
EN.120: and let Barbariccia lead the squad.
EN.121: 'Let Libicocco come too, and Draghignazzo,
EN.122: Ciriatto with his tusks, and Graffiacane,
EN.123: Farfarello, and madcap Rubicante.
EN.124: 'Have a good look around the boiling glue.
EN.125: Keep these two safe as far as the next crag
EN.126: that runs all of a piece above the dens.'
EN.127: 'Oh, master,' I said, 'I don't like what I see.
EN.128: Please, let us find our way without an escort,
EN.129: if you know how. As for me, I do not want one.
EN.130: 'If you are as vigilant as ever,
EN.131: don't you see they grind their teeth
EN.132: while with their furrowed brows they threaten harm?'
EN.133: And he to me: 'Don't be afraid.
EN.134: Let them grind on to their hearts' content --
EN.135: they do it for the stewing wretches.'
EN.136: Off they set along the left-hand bank,
EN.137: but first each pressed his tongue between his teeth
EN.138: to blow a signal to their leader,
EN.139: and he had made a trumpet of his asshole.

IT.1: Io vidi già cavalier muover campo,
IT.2: e cominciare stormo e far lor mostra,
IT.3: e talvolta partir per loro scampo;
IT.4: corridor vidi per la terra vostra,
IT.5: o Aretini, e vidi gir gualdane,
IT.6: fedir torneamenti e correr giostra;
IT.7: quando con trombe, e quando con campane,
IT.8: con tamburi e con cenni di castella,
IT.9: e con cose nostrali e con istrane;
IT.10: né già con sì diversa cennamella
IT.11: cavalier vidi muover né pedoni,
IT.12: né nave a segno di terra o di stella.
IT.13: Noi andavam con li diece demoni.
IT.14: Ahi fiera compagnia! ma ne la chiesa
IT.15: coi santi, e in taverna coi ghiottoni.
IT.16: Pur a la pegola era la mia 'ntesa,
IT.17: per veder de la bolgia ogne contegno
IT.18: e de la gente ch'entro v'era incesa.
IT.19: Come i dalfini, quando fanno segno
IT.20: a' marinar con l'arco de la schiena
IT.21: che s'argomentin di campar lor legno,
IT.22: talor così, ad alleggiar la pena,
IT.23: mostrav' alcun de' peccatori 'l dosso
IT.24: e nascondea in men che non balena.
IT.25: E come a l'orlo de l'acqua d'un fosso
IT.26: stanno i ranocchi pur col muso fuori,
IT.27: sì che celano i piedi e l'altro grosso,
IT.28: sì stavan d'ogne parte i peccatori;
IT.29: ma come s'appressava Barbariccia,
IT.30: così si ritraén sotto i bollori.
IT.31: I' vidi, e anco il cor me n'accapriccia,
IT.32: uno aspettar così, com' elli 'ncontra
IT.33: ch'una rana rimane e l'altra spiccia;
IT.34: e Graffiacan, che li era più di contra,
IT.35: li arruncigliò le 'mpegolate chiome
IT.36: e trassel sù, che mi parve una lontra.
IT.37: I' sapea già di tutti quanti 'l nome,
IT.38: sì li notai quando fuorono eletti,
IT.39: e poi ch'e' si chiamaro, attesi come.
IT.40: "O Rubicante, fa che tu li metti
IT.41: li unghioni a dosso, sì che tu lo scuoi!"
IT.42: gridavan tutti insieme i maladetti.
IT.43: E io: "Maestro mio, fa, se tu puoi,
IT.44: che tu sappi chi è lo sciagurato
IT.45: venuto a man de li avversari suoi."
IT.46: Lo duca mio li s'accostò allato;
IT.47: domandollo ond' ei fosse, e quei rispuose:
IT.48: "I' fui del regno di Navarra nato.
IT.49: Mia madre a servo d'un segnor mi puose,
IT.50: che m'avea generato d'un ribaldo,
IT.51: distruggitor di sé e di sue cose.
IT.52: Poi fui famiglia del buon re Tebaldo;
IT.53: quivi mi misi a far baratteria,
IT.54: di ch'io rendo ragione in questo caldo."
IT.55: E Cirïatto, a cui di bocca uscia
IT.56: d'ogne parte una sanna come a porco,
IT.57: li fé sentir come l'una sdruscia.
IT.58: Tra male gatte era venuto 'l sorco;
IT.59: ma Barbariccia il chiuse con le braccia
IT.60: e disse: "State in là, mentr' io lo 'nforco."
IT.61: E al maestro mio volse la faccia;
IT.62: "Domanda," disse, "ancor, se più disii
IT.63: saper da lui, prima ch'altri 'l disfaccia."
IT.64: Lo duca dunque: "Or dì: de li altri rii
IT.65: conosci tu alcun che sia latino
IT.66: sotto la pece?" E quelli: "I' mi partii,
IT.67: poco è, da un che fu di là vicino.
IT.68: Così foss' io ancor con lui coperto,
IT.69: ch'i' non temerei unghia né uncino!"
IT.70: E Libicocco "Troppo avem sofferto,"
IT.71: disse; e preseli 'l braccio col runciglio,
IT.72: sì che, stracciando, ne portò un lacerto.
IT.73: Draghignazzo anco i volle dar di piglio
IT.74: giuso a le gambe; onde 'l decurio loro
IT.75: si volse intorno intorno con mal piglio.
IT.76: Quand' elli un poco rappaciati fuoro,
IT.77: a lui, ch'ancor mirava sua ferita,
IT.78: domandò 'l duca mio sanza dimoro:
IT.79: "Chi fu colui da cui mala partita
IT.80: di' che facesti per venire a proda?"
IT.81: Ed ei rispuose: "Fu frate Gomita,
IT.82: quel di Gallura, vasel d'ogne froda,
IT.83: ch'ebbe i nemici di suo donno in mano,
IT.84: e fé sì lor, che ciascun se ne loda.
IT.85: Danar si tolse e lasciolli di piano,
IT.86: sì com' e' dice; e ne li altri offici anche
IT.87: barattier fu non picciol, ma sovrano.
IT.88: Usa con esso donno Michel Zanche
IT.89: di Logodoro; e a dir di Sardigna
IT.90: le lingue lor non si sentono stanche.
IT.91: Omè, vedete l'altro che digrigna;
IT.92: i' direi anche, ma i' temo ch'ello
IT.93: non s'apparecchi a grattarmi la tigna."
IT.94: E 'l gran proposto, vòlto a Farfarello
IT.95: che stralunava li occhi per fedire,
IT.96: disse: "Fatti 'n costà, malvagio uccello!"
IT.97: "Se voi volete vedere o udire,"
IT.98: ricominciò lo spaürato appresso,
IT.99: "Toschi o Lombardi, io ne farò venire;
IT.100: ma stieno i Malebranche un poco in cesso,
IT.101: sì ch'ei non teman de le lor vendette;
IT.102: e io, seggendo in questo loco stesso,
IT.103: per un ch'io son, ne farò venir sette
IT.104: quand' io suffolerò, com' è nostro uso
IT.105: di fare allor che fori alcun si mette."
IT.106: Cagnazzo a cotal motto levò 'l muso,
IT.107: crollando 'l capo, e disse: "Odi malizia
IT.108: ch'elli ha pensata per gittarsi giuso!"
IT.109: Ond' ei, ch'avea lacciuoli a gran divizia,
IT.110: rispuose: "Malizioso son io troppo,
IT.111: quand' io procuro a' mia maggior trestizia."
IT.112: Alichin non si tenne e, di rintoppo
IT.113: a li altri, disse a lui: "Se tu ti cali,
IT.114: io non ti verrò dietro di gualoppo,
IT.115: ma batterò sovra la pece l'ali.
IT.116: Lascisi 'l collo, e sia la ripa scudo,
IT.117: a veder se tu sol più di noi vali."
IT.118: O tu che leggi, udirai nuovo ludo:
IT.119: ciascun da l'altra costa li occhi volse,
IT.120: quel prima, ch'a ciò fare era più crudo.
IT.121: Lo Navarrese ben suo tempo colse;
IT.122: fermò le piante a terra, e in un punto
IT.123: saltò e dal proposto lor si sciolse.
IT.124: Di che ciascun di colpa fu compunto,
IT.125: ma quei più che cagion fu del difetto;
IT.126: però si mosse e gridò: "Tu se' giunto!"
IT.127: Ma poco i valse: ché l'ali al sospetto
IT.128: non potero avanzar; quelli andò sotto,
IT.129: e quei drizzò volando suso il petto:
IT.130: non altrimenti l'anitra di botto,
IT.131: quando 'l falcon s'appressa, giù s'attuffa,
IT.132: ed ei ritorna sù crucciato e rotto.
IT.133: Irato Calcabrina de la buffa,
IT.134: volando dietro li tenne, invaghito
IT.135: che quei campasse per aver la zuffa;
IT.136: e come 'l barattier fu disparito,
IT.137: così volse li artigli al suo compagno,
IT.138: e fu con lui sopra 'l fosso ghermito.
IT.139: Ma l'altro fu bene sparvier grifagno
IT.140: ad artigliar ben lui, e amendue
IT.141: cadder nel mezzo del bogliente stagno.
IT.142: Lo caldo sghermitor sùbito fue;
IT.143: ma però di levarsi era neente,
IT.144: sì avieno inviscate l'ali sue.
IT.145: Barbariccia, con li altri suoi dolente,
IT.146: quattro ne fé volar da l'altra costa
IT.147: con tutt' i raffi, e assai prestamente
IT.148: di qua, di là discesero a la posta;
IT.150: ch'eran già cotti dentro da la crosta.

EN.1: I have seen the cavalry break camp,
EN.2: prepare for an attack, make their muster
EN.3: and at times fall back to save themselves.
EN.4: I have seen outriders in your land,
EN.5: O Aretines. I have seen raiding-parties,
EN.6: tournaments of teams, hand-to-hand jousts
EN.7: begun with bells, trumpets, or drums,
EN.8: with signals from the castle,
EN.9: with summons of our own and those from foreign lands,
EN.10: but never to such outlandish fanfare
EN.11: have I seen horsemen move, or infantry,
EN.12: or ship set sail at sign from land or star.
EN.13: On we went, escorted by ten demons.
EN.14: What savage company! But, as they say,
EN.15: 'in church with saints, with guzzlers in the tavern.'
EN.16: My attention was fixed upon the pitch
EN.17: to note each detail of this gulch
EN.18: and of the people poaching in it.
EN.19: Like dolphins, when they arch their backs
EN.20: above the water, giving sailors warning
EN.21: to prepare to save their ship,
EN.22: so from time to time, to ease his pain,
EN.23: one of the sinners would show his back
EN.24: and, quick as lightning, hide it once again.
EN.25: And just as in a ditch at water's edge
EN.26: frogs squat with but their snouts in sight,
EN.27: their bodies and their legs all hidden,
EN.28: so were the sinners scattered everywhere.
EN.29: But they, at the approach of Barbariccia,
EN.30: withdrew back down beneath the boiling.
EN.31: There I saw -- and my heart still shudders at it --
EN.32: one who lingered, as it can happen
EN.33: that one frog stays while yet another plunges,
EN.34: and Graffiacane, who was nearest him,
EN.35: caught a billhook in his pitchy locks
EN.36: and hauled him out, looking like an otter.
EN.37: By now I knew their names,
EN.38: since I had noted these when they were chosen
EN.39: and when they called to one another.
EN.40: 'Set your claws to work, Rubicante,
EN.41: see you rip his skin off,'
EN.42: shouted all the accursèd crew together.
EN.43: And I: 'Master, if you can do it,
EN.44: find out the name of this poor wretch
EN.45: caught in the clutches of his enemies.'
EN.46: My leader got up close beside him
EN.47: and asked him where he came from. He replied:
EN.48: 'I was born in the kingdom of Navarre.
EN.49: 'My mother, who had conceived me by a wastrel --
EN.50: destroyer of himself and all his goods --
EN.51: put me in service with a man of rank.
EN.52: 'Then I joined the retinue of worthy Thibaut:
EN.53: there first I set myself to taking bribes,
EN.54: for which I pay the reckoning in this heat.'
EN.55: And Ciriatto, from whose jaw curved up
EN.56: on either side a tusk, like the wild boar's,
EN.57: made him feel how one of these could rip.
EN.58: The mouse had fallen in with wicked cats.
EN.59: But Barbariccia blocked them with his arms
EN.60: and said: 'Stand back and let me jab him,'
EN.61: then turned to face my master:
EN.62: 'Speak up, if you are eager to learn more,
EN.63: before I let him have a mangling.'
EN.64: And my leader: 'Of the other sinners in the pitch,
EN.65: tell me, is anyone Italian?'
EN.66: And he: 'I just now came from one
EN.67: 'who hailed from near those parts. I wish
EN.68: I still were with him in the pitch --
EN.69: then I'd have no fear of hook or claw!'
EN.70: Then Libicocco said: 'This is just too much,'
EN.71: caught him with his grapple by the arm
EN.72: and, ripping, gouged out a hunk of flesh.
EN.73: Draghignazzo, too, wanted to catch him up,
EN.74: by the legs, at which their captain
EN.75: wheeled round on them with an ugly look.
EN.76: After their fury had subsided,
EN.77: my leader seized this chance to ask
EN.78: the one still staring at his wound:
EN.79: 'Who is the one you mentioned, from whom
EN.80: you parted so unwisely when you came ashore?'
EN.81: And he replied: 'It was Fra Gomìta
EN.82: 'of Gallura, a vessel full of fraud,
EN.83: who had his master's enemies in hand
EN.84: but dealt with them so each one sings his praises.
EN.85: 'He took their money and discreetly let them off,
EN.86: as he himself admits. And in his other actions
EN.87: he was no small-time swindler but a king.
EN.88: 'Don Michel Zanche of Logudoro
EN.89: keeps company with him and, when speaking
EN.90: of Sardegna, their tongues are never weary.
EN.91: 'Oh, look at that one there, gnashing his teeth! --
EN.92: I would say more, but I'm afraid that demon's
EN.93: getting set to give my mange a scratching.'
EN.94: And the great marshal, turning to Farfarello,
EN.95: who was rolling his eyes, ready to strike,
EN.96: said: 'Back off, you filthy bird!'
EN.97: 'If you would care to see or hear,'
EN.98: the emboldened spirit then began again,
EN.99: 'Tuscans or Lombards, I can make some come.
EN.100: 'But let the Malebranche stand away
EN.101: so that the sinners have no fear of vengeance,
EN.102: and, keeping to my place right here,
EN.103: 'for one of me, I will make seven come
EN.104: if I whistle, as is our custom
EN.105: when one of us pulls free out of the pitch.'
EN.106: At this Cagnazzo lifted up his snout and said,
EN.107: shaking his head: 'Hear the cunning stunt
EN.108: he has contrived to throw himself back in!'
EN.109: And he, with artifice in store, replied:
EN.110: 'I must indeed be cunning if I procure
EN.111: still greater anguish for my friends.'
EN.112: Alichino couldn't stand this any more and said,
EN.113: in opposition to the others: 'If you dive
EN.114: back in I won't pursue you on the run --
EN.115: 'oh no! I'll beat my wings above the pitch.
EN.116: Let's leave the ridge and hide behind the bank.
EN.117: We'll see if you alone can take us on.'
EN.118: Now, reader, you shall hear strange sport.
EN.119: All turned their backs to where the sinner stood,
EN.120: he first who'd most opposed the plan.
EN.121: The Navarrese chose his moment well,
EN.122: planted his feet and in a second
EN.123: leaped and escaped from their designs.
EN.124: At this they all were angry at their blunder,
EN.125: but most of all the one whose fault it was,
EN.126: so that he darted up and cried: 'Now you are caught!'
EN.127: It did him little good, for even wings
EN.128: could not catch up with terror: the sinner dove
EN.129: and the devil turned up his breast in flight,
EN.130: just as the wild duck, when the falcon nears,
EN.131: dives for the bottom, and the bird of prey
EN.132: must fly back up, angry and outsmarted.
EN.133: Calcabrina, furious at this trick,
EN.134: was winging close behind him, eager for the sinner
EN.135: to break away as an excuse to scuffle,
EN.136: and, since the barrator had vanished,
EN.137: he turned his claws against his fellow
EN.138: and came to grips with him above the ditch.
EN.139: But the other was indeed a full-fledged hawk,
EN.140: fierce with his talons, and the pair of them
EN.141: went tumbling down into the scalding pond.
EN.142: The heat unclutched them in a moment,
EN.143: but they had so beglued their wings
EN.144: there was no way to rise above the pitch.
EN.145: Barbariccia, lamenting with the rest,
EN.146: had four of them fly to the other bank,
EN.147: each with his hook in hand, and in no time
EN.148: on this side and on that they clambered down
EN.149: to their posts, reaching out their grapples
EN.150: to the pitch-trapped pair, already cooked to a crust.
EN.151: And that is how we left them in that broil.

IT.1: Taciti, soli, sanza compagnia
IT.2: n'andavam l'un dinanzi e l'altro dopo,
IT.3: come frati minor vanno per via.
IT.4: Vòlt' era in su la favola d'Isopo
IT.5: lo mio pensier per la presente rissa,
IT.6: dov' el parlò de la rana e del topo;
IT.7: ché più non si pareggia "mo" e "issa"
IT.8: che l'un con l'altro fa, se ben s'accoppia
IT.9: principio e fine con la mente fissa.
IT.10: E come l'un pensier de l'altro scoppia,
IT.11: così nacque di quello un altro poi,
IT.12: che la prima paura mi fé doppia.
IT.13: Io pensava così: "Questi per noi
IT.14: sono scherniti con danno e con beffa
IT.15: sì fatta, ch' assai credo che lor nòi.
IT.16: Se l'ira sovra 'l mal voler s'aggueffa,
IT.17: ei ne verranno dietro più crudeli
IT.18: che 'l cane a quella lievre ch'elli acceffa."
IT.19: Già mi sentia tutti arricciar li peli
IT.20: de la paura e stava in dietro intento,
IT.21: quand' io dissi: "Maestro, se non celi
IT.22: te e me tostamente, i' ho pavento
IT.23: d'i Malebranche. Noi li avem già dietro;
IT.24: io li 'magino sì, che già li sento."
IT.25: E quei: "S'i' fossi di piombato vetro,
IT.26: l'imagine di fuor tua non trarrei
IT.27: più tosto a me, che quella dentro 'mpetro.
IT.28: Pur mo venieno i tuo' pensier tra ' miei,

EN.77: cried out behind us: 'Stay your feet,

EN.86: for a while, without uttering a word,
