EN.28: he searched for yet another crag
EN.29: and said: 'Take hold of that one next
EN.30: but test it first to see if it will bear your weight.'
EN.31: This was no climb for people wearing leaden cloaks.
EN.32: Though he was weightless and I was being pushed,
EN.33: how hard a climb it was from one crag to the other!
EN.34: Were it not that on this side of the dike
EN.35: the slope was shorter -- I cannot speak for him --
EN.36: I would have given up.
EN.37: But since all Malebolge inclines
EN.38: down to the mouth of the lowest pit,
EN.39: it follows that each valley is constructed
EN.40: with one side higher than the other.
EN.41: At last we made it to the point
EN.42: where the outermost stone had broken off.
EN.43: And there I felt my lungs so sucked of breath
EN.44: that I could go no farther,
EN.45: but I sat down as quickly as I could.
EN.46: 'Now must you cast off sloth,' my master said.
EN.47: 'Sitting on feather cushions or stretched out
EN.48: under comforters, no one comes to fame.
EN.49: 'Without fame, he who spends his time on earth
EN.50: leaves only such a mark upon the world
EN.51: as smoke does on the air or foam on water.
EN.52: 'Get to your feet! Conquer this laboring breath
EN.53: with strength of mind, which wins the battle
EN.54: if not dragged down by body's weight.
EN.55: 'There is a longer stair that must be climbed.
EN.56: It's not enough to leave these souls behind.
EN.57: If you take my meaning, let it be of use.'
EN.58: At that I rose, pretending to more breath
EN.59: than I had in me, and said:
EN.60: 'Go on then, for I am strong and resolute.'
EN.61: We labored up a ridge,
EN.62: rugged, narrow, difficult,
EN.63: and steeper far than was the last.
EN.64: Not to seem so spent, I talked as I climbed up.
EN.65: Then, from the next ditch, came a voice
EN.66: that seemed unfit for forming words.
EN.67: I could not make out what it said,
EN.68: though I was at the crown that arches over,
EN.69: but the one who spoke seemed to be in motion.
EN.70: Hard as I strained to see, it was too dark
EN.71: for living eyes to plumb the depths.
EN.72: And so I said: 'Master, take your way
EN.73: 'to the next encircling bank where we can leave
EN.74: this bridge. From here I make out nothing with my ears
EN.75: nor with my eyes see anything down there.'
EN.76: 'I give no other answer than to take you,'
EN.77: he said, 'for a just request
EN.78: should be followed by the act, in silence.'
EN.79: We left the bridge at the abutment
EN.80: where it comes to rest on that eighth bank.
EN.81: From there the contents of the ditch came into view.
EN.82: In it I saw a dreadful swarm of serpents,
EN.83: of so strange a kind that even now
EN.84: when I remember them it chills my blood.
EN.85: Let Libya with all her sands no longer boast,
EN.86: for though she fosters chelydri, jaculi,
EN.87: phareae, cenchres, and amphisbaena,
EN.88: she never reared so many venomous pests,
EN.89: nor so appalling -- not with all of Ethiopia
EN.90: and the lands that lie along the Red Sea coast.
EN.91: Amid this fearsome and most awful plenty,
EN.92: people, naked and in terror, were running
EN.93: without hope of refuge or of heliotrope.
EN.94: Their hands were tied behind their backs with snakes
EN.95: that thrust their heads and tails between the legs
EN.96: and joined, knotting themselves in front.
EN.97: And behold, one of these souls was near our ridge
EN.98: when a serpent launched and pierced him through
EN.99: right where the neck and shoulders join.
EN.100: Never has 'o' nor even 'i' been writ so quick
EN.101: as he caught fire and burned, turned,
EN.102: in the very act of falling, into ashes.
EN.103: And as he lay unmade upon the ground,
EN.104: the dust regathered of its own accord
EN.105: and suddenly he was himself again.
EN.106: Just, as is attested by great sages,
EN.107: the phoenix perishes and is reborn
EN.108: when it approaches its five-hundredth year --
EN.109: lifelong it feeds on neither grain nor grasses,
EN.110: but thrives on drops of frankincense and cardamom,
EN.111: while nard and myrrh make up its winding sheet --
EN.112: and just as one who faints, and knows not why --
EN.113: whether possessed by devils that pull him down
EN.114: or seized by the sickness that causes men to fall --
EN.115: rises to his feet, and gazes round,
EN.116: wholly bewildered by the breathless anguish
EN.117: he has undergone, and as he looks, he sighs,
EN.118: such did that sinner seem when he had risen.
EN.119: O how stern it is, the power of God,
EN.120: hurling such blows as it takes vengeance!
EN.121: When my leader asked him who he was:
EN.122: 'From Tuscany I rained down,' was his answer,
EN.123: 'not long ago, into this savage gorge.
EN.124: 'I loved the life of beasts and not of men,
EN.125: just like the mule I was. I am Vanni Fucci,
EN.126: animal. Pistoia was my fitting den.'
EN.127: And I to my leader: 'Tell him not to slip away,
EN.128: then ask what sin has thrust him to this depth,
EN.129: for I knew him as a man of blood and rages.'
EN.130: And the sinner, listening, did not dissemble,
EN.131: but set his mind and eyes on me,
EN.132: then colored with a wrathful shame
EN.133: and said: 'For you to catch me
EN.134: in this misery pains me more
EN.135: than when I was taken from the other life.
EN.136: 'I can't refuse to answer what you ask.
EN.137: I am thrust so far below because I stole
EN.138: the lovely ornaments from the sacristy
EN.139: 'and the blame was wrongly laid upon another.
EN.140: But, so you take no joy in seeing me this low,
EN.141: if ever you escape from these dark regions,
EN.142: open your ears to prophecy and hear:
EN.143: First, Pistoia strips herself of Blacks,
EN.144: then Florence changes families and fashions.
EN.145: 'Next Mars draws up a bolt from Val di Magra,
EN.146: engulfed by torn and threatening clouds,
EN.147: and, with violent and stinging storms,
EN.148: 'on Campo Piceno the battle shall be joined.
EN.149: The headlong bolt shall rend the clouds,
EN.151: And this I have told that it may make you grieve.'

IT.1: Al fine de le sue parole il ladro
IT.2: le mani alzò con amendue le fiche,
IT.3: gridando: "Togli, Dio, ch'a te le squadro!"
IT.4: Da indi in qua mi fuor le serpi amiche,
IT.5: perch' una li s'avvolse allora al collo,
IT.6: come dicesse "Non vo' che più diche";
IT.7: e un'altra a le braccia, e rilegollo,
IT.8: ribadendo sé stessa sì dinanzi,
IT.9: che non potea con esse dare un crollo.
IT.10: Ahi Pistoia, Pistoia, ché non stanzi
IT.11: d'incenerarti sì che più non duri,
IT.12: poi che 'n mal fare il seme tuo avanzi?
IT.13: Per tutt' i cerchi de lo 'nferno scuri
IT.14: non vidi spirto in Dio tanto superbo,
IT.15: non quel che cadde a Tebe giù da' muri.
IT.16: El si fuggì che non parlò più verbo;
IT.17: e io vidi un centauro pien di rabbia
IT.18: venir chiamando: "Ov' è, ov' è l'acerbo?"
IT.19: Maremma non cred' io che tante n'abbia,
IT.20: quante bisce elli avea su per la groppa
IT.21: infin ove comincia nostra labbia.
IT.22: Sovra le spalle, dietro da la coppa,
IT.23: con l'ali aperte li giacea un draco;
IT.24: e quello affuoca qualunque s'intoppa.
IT.25: Lo mio maestro disse: "Questi è Caco,
IT.26: che, sotto 'l sasso di monte Aventino,
IT.27: di sangue fece spesse volte laco.
IT.28: Non va co' suoi fratei per un cammino,
IT.29: per lo furto che frodolente fece
IT.30: del grande armento ch'elli ebbe a vicino;
IT.31: onde cessar le sue opere biece
IT.32: sotto la mazza d'Ercule, che forse
IT.33: gliene diè cento, e non sentì le diece."
IT.34: Mentre che sì parlava, ed el trascorse,
IT.35: e tre spiriti venner sotto noi,
IT.36: de' quai né io né 'l duca mio s'accorse,
IT.37: se non quando gridar: "Chi siete voi?"
IT.38: per che nostra novella si ristette,
IT.39: e intendemmo pur ad essi poi.
IT.40: Io non li conoscea; ma ei seguette,
IT.41: come suol seguitar per alcun caso,
IT.42: che l'un nomar un altro convenette,
IT.43: dicendo: "Cianfa dove fia rimaso?"
IT.44: per ch'io, acciò che 'l duca stesse attento,
IT.45: mi puosi 'l dito su dal mento al naso.
IT.46: Se tu se' or, lettore, a creder lento
IT.47: ciò ch'io dirò, non sarà maraviglia
IT.48: ché io che 'l vidi, a pena il mi consento.
IT.49: Com' io tenea levate in lor le ciglia,
IT.50: e un serpente con sei piè si lancia
IT.51: dinanzi a l'uno, e tutto a lui s'appiglia.
IT.52: Co' piè di mezzo li avvinse la pancia
IT.53: e con li anterïor le braccia prese;
IT.54: poi li addentò e l'una e l'altra guancia;
IT.55: li diretani a le cosce distese,
IT.56: e miseli la coda tra 'mbedue
IT.57: e dietro per le ren sù la ritese.
IT.58: Ellera abbarbicata mai non fue
IT.59: ad alber sì, come l'orribil fiera
IT.60: per l'altrui membra avviticchiò le sue.
IT.61: Poi s'appiccar, come di calda cera
IT.62: fossero stati, e mischiar lor colore,
IT.63: né l'un né l'altro già parea quel ch'era:
IT.64: come procede innanzi da l'ardore,
IT.65: per lo papiro suso, un color bruno
IT.66: che non è nero ancora e 'l bianco more.
IT.67: Li altri due 'l riguardavano, e ciascuno
IT.68: gridava: "Omè, Agnel, come ti muti!
IT.69: Vedi che già non se' né due né uno."
IT.70: Già eran li due capi un divenuti,
IT.71: quando n'apparver due figure miste
IT.72: in una faccia, ov' eran due perduti.
IT.73: Fersi le braccia due di quattro liste;
IT.74: le cosce con le gambe e 'l ventre e 'l casso
IT.75: divenner membra che non fuor mai viste.
IT.76: Ogne primaio aspetto ivi era casso:
IT.77: due e nessun l'imagine perversa
IT.78: parea; e tal sen gio con lento passo.
IT.79: Come 'l ramarro sotto la gran fersa
IT.80: dei dì canicular, cangiando sepe,
IT.81: folgore par se la via attraversa,
IT.82: sì pareva, venendo verso l'epe
IT.83: de li altri due, un serpentello acceso,
IT.84: livido e nero come gran di pepe;
IT.85: e quella parte onde prima è preso
IT.86: nostro alimento, a l'un di lor trafisse;
IT.87: poi cadde giuso innanzi lui disteso.
IT.88: Lo trafitto 'l mirò, ma nulla disse;
IT.89: anzi, co' piè fermati, sbadigliava
IT.90: pur come sonno o febbre l'assalisse.
IT.91: Elli 'l serpente e quei lui riguardava;
IT.92: l'un per la piaga e l'altro per la bocca
IT.93: fummavan forte, e 'l fummo si scontrava.
IT.94: Taccia Lucano omai là dov' e' tocca
IT.95: del misero Sabello e di Nasidio,
IT.96: e attenda a udir quel ch'or si scocca.
IT.97: Taccia di Cadmo e d'Aretusa Ovidio,
IT.98: ché se quello in serpente e quella in fonte
IT.99: converte poetando, io non lo 'nvidio;
IT.100: ché due nature mai a fronte a fronte
IT.101: non trasmutò sì ch'amendue le forme
IT.102: a cambiar lor matera fosser pronte.
IT.103: Insieme si rispuosero a tai norme,
IT.104: che 'l serpente la coda in forca fesse,
IT.105: e 'l feruto ristrinse insieme l'orme.
IT.106: Le gambe con le cosce seco stesse
IT.107: s'appiccar sì, che 'n poco la giuntura
IT.108: non facea segno alcun che si paresse.
IT.109: Togliea la coda fessa la figura
IT.110: che si perdeva là, e la sua pelle
IT.111: si facea molle, e quella di là dura.
IT.112: Io vidi intrar le braccia per l'ascelle,
IT.113: e i due piè de la fiera, ch'eran corti,
IT.114: tanto allungar quanto accorciavan quelle.
IT.115: Poscia li piè di rietro, insieme attorti,
IT.116: diventaron lo membro che l'uom cela,
IT.117: e 'l misero del suo n'avea due porti.
IT.118: Mentre che 'l fummo l'uno e l'altro vela
IT.119: di color novo, e genera 'l pel suso
IT.120: per l'una parte e da l'altra il dipela,
IT.121: l'un si levò e l'altro cadde giuso,
IT.122: non torcendo però le lucerne empie,
IT.123: sotto le quai ciascun cambiava muso.
IT.124: Quel ch'era dritto, il trasse ver' le tempie,
IT.125: e di troppa matera ch'in là venne
IT.126: uscir li orecchi de le gote scempie;
IT.127: ciò che non corse in dietro e si ritenne
IT.128: di quel soverchio, fé naso a la faccia
IT.129: e le labbra ingrossò quanto convenne.
IT.130: Quel che giacëa, il muso innanzi caccia,
IT.131: e li orecchi ritira per la testa
IT.132: come face le corna la lumaccia;
IT.133: e la lingua, ch'avëa unita e presta
IT.134: prima a parlar, si fende, e la forcuta
IT.135: ne l'altro si richiude; e 'l fummo resta.
IT.136: L'anima ch'era fiera divenuta,
IT.137: suffolando si fugge per la valle,
IT.138: e l'altro dietro a lui parlando sputa.
IT.139: Poscia li volse le novelle spalle,
IT.140: e disse a l'altro: "I' vo' che Buoso corra,
IT.141: com' ho fatt' io, carpon per questo calle."
IT.142: Così vid' io la settima zavorra
IT.143: mutare e trasmutare; e qui mi scusi
IT.144: la novità se fior la penna abborra.
IT.145: E avvegna che li occhi miei confusi
IT.146: fossero alquanto e l'animo smagato,
IT.147: non poter quei fuggirsi tanto chiusi,
IT.148: ch'i' non scorgessi ben Puccio Sciancato;
IT.149: ed era quel che sol, di tre compagni
IT.150: che venner prima, non era mutato;
IT.151: l'altr' era quel che tu, Gaville, piagni.

EN.1: Then, making the figs with both his thumbs,
EN.2: the thief raised up his fists and cried:
EN.3: 'Take that, God! It's aimed at you!'
EN.4: From that time on the serpents were my friends,
EN.5: for one of them coiled itself around his neck
EN.6: as if to say, 'Now you shall speak no more,'
EN.7: while another enmeshed his arms and held him fast,
EN.8: knotting itself so tight around his front
EN.9: he could not even twitch his arms.
EN.10: Ah, Pistoia, Pistoia, why won't you resolve
EN.11: to burn yourself to ashes, cease to be,
EN.12: since you exceed your ancestors in evil?
EN.13: Through all the gloomy rounds of Hell
EN.14: I saw no soul so prideful against God,
EN.15: not even him who toppled from the walls at Thebes.
EN.16: He ran away without another word.
EN.17: And then I saw a centaur full of rage
EN.18: come shouting: 'Where, where is that unripe soul?'
EN.19: Maremma does not have as many snakes,
EN.20: I think, as he had on his back,
EN.21: from where the human part begins down to the rump.
EN.22: On his shoulders, at the nape of his neck,
EN.23: crouched a dragon with its wings spread wide
EN.24: that sets on fire whatever it encounters.
EN.25: My master said: 'That is Cacus,
EN.26: who in the cave beneath the Aventine
EN.27: many times over has made a lake of blood.
EN.28: 'His road is different from his brothers'
EN.29: because he stole, with wicked cunning,
EN.30: the herd of cattle he found near at hand.
EN.31: 'For that his wily ways were ended
EN.32: beneath the club of Hercules, who struck perhaps
EN.33: a hundred blows, though he felt not the tenth.'
EN.34: While my master spoke the centaur had run past.
EN.35: Below where we were standing, three new souls
EN.36: had neared, although we did not see them
EN.37: until we heard their shouts: 'You,
EN.38: who are you?' At that he stopped his tale
EN.39: and we gave heed to them alone.
EN.40: I knew none of them, and yet it happened --
EN.41: as often happens by some chance --
EN.42: that one had cause to speak another's name,
EN.43: asking: 'What's become of Cianfa?'
EN.44: And then, to catch my guide's attention,
EN.45: I held my finger up from chin to nose.
EN.46: If, reader, you are slow to credit
EN.47: what I'm about to tell you, it's no wonder:
EN.48: I saw it, and I myself can scarce believe it.
EN.49: While I stood staring, with eyebrows raised,
EN.50: a reptile with six legs propelled itself
EN.51: at one of them, and fastened itself to him.
EN.52: It grabbed his belly with its middle claws,
EN.53: then with its forepaws held his arms
EN.54: and bit through both his cheeks.
EN.55: It stretched its hind feet down the other's thighs,
EN.56: thrusting its tail between them
EN.57: and curled it up behind, above the buttocks.
EN.58: Never did clinging ivy fix itself
EN.59: so tight upon a tree as did that fearsome beast
EN.60: entwine itself around the other's limbs.
EN.61: Then they fused together, as if made
EN.62: of molten wax, mixing their colors
EN.63: so that neither seemed what it had been before,
EN.64: as over the surface of a scrap of parchment,
EN.65: before the advancing flame, a brownish color comes
EN.66: that is not black, yet makes the white die out.
EN.67: The other two were looking on and each
EN.68: was shouting: 'Oh my, Agnello, how you change!
EN.69: Look, now you are neither two nor one!'
EN.70: The two heads had already been united,
EN.71: two sets of features blending,
EN.72: both lost in a single face.
EN.73: Four separate limbs combined to form two arms.
EN.74: The thighs and calves, the stomach and the chest
EN.75: turned into members never seen before.
EN.76: All trace of their first aspect was erased
EN.77: and the unnatural figure seemed both two
EN.78: and none and lumbered off at its slow pace.
EN.79: As the green lizard beneath the scorching lash
EN.80: of dog-day heat, between one hedge and the next,
EN.81: seems lightning as it streaks across the road,
EN.82: just so appeared -- darting toward the bellies
EN.83: of the other two -- a little fiery reptile,
EN.84: black and livid as a peppercorn.
EN.85: That part where first we are nourished
EN.86: it transfixed in one of them
EN.87: and then fell prone before him.
EN.88: The one transfixed just stared, said nothing.
EN.89: Indeed, with his feet stock-still, he yawned,
EN.90: as if deep sleep or fever had assailed him.
EN.91: He and the reptile stared at one another.
EN.92: Both gave out dense smoke, one from its wound,
EN.93: the other from its mouth. Then their smoke merged.
EN.94: Let Lucan now fall silent where he tells
EN.95: of poor Sabellus and Nasidius,
EN.96: and let him wait to hear what comes forth now!
EN.97: Let Ovid not speak of Cadmus or Arethusa,
EN.98: for if his poem turns him into a serpent
EN.99: and her into a fountain, I grudge it not,
EN.100: for never did he change two natures, face to face,
EN.101: in such a way that both their forms
EN.102: were quite so quick exchanging substance.
EN.103: Their corresponding changes went like this:
EN.104: the reptile split its tail into a fork
EN.105: and he that was wounded drew his feet together.
EN.106: First his calves and then his thighs began
EN.107: to knit so that in but a moment
EN.108: no sign of a division could be seen.
EN.109: The cloven tail assumed the shapes
EN.110: the other one was losing, and his skin
EN.111: was turning soft while the other's hardened.
EN.112: I saw the man's arms shrinking toward the armpits
EN.113: and the brute's forepaws, which had been short,
EN.114: lengthen, precisely as the other's dwindled.
EN.115: Then the hind-paws, twisting together,
EN.116: became the member that a man conceals,
EN.117: and from his own the wretch had grown two paws.
EN.118: While the smoke veils one and now the other
EN.119: with new color and grows hair here
EN.120: and elsewhere strips it off,
EN.121: one of them rose to his feet, the other fell,
EN.122: but neither turned aside his baleful glare
EN.123: under which each muzzle changed its shape.
EN.124: In the one erect it shrank in to the temples,
EN.125: and, from the excess flesh absorbed,
EN.126: two ears extruded from smooth cheeks.
EN.127: That which did not recede, the remnant
EN.128: of that excess, made a nose for the face
EN.129: and gave the lips a proper thickness.
EN.130: The one prone on the ground shoves out his snout
EN.131: and draws his ears into his head
EN.132: as a snail draws in its horns,
EN.133: and his tongue, till now a single thing
EN.134: and fit for speech, divides, and the other's
EN.135: forked tongue joins, and the smoke stops.
EN.136: The soul just now become a brute takes flight,
EN.137: hissing through the hollow, and the other,
EN.138: by way of speaking, spits after him.
EN.139: Then he turned his new-made shoulders and he said
EN.140: to the third: 'I want Buoso to run, as I have done,
EN.141: down on all fours along this road.'
EN.142: Thus I saw the seventh rabble change
EN.143: and change again, and let the newness of it
EN.144: be my excuse if my pen has gone astray.
EN.145: And though my eyes were dazed
EN.146: and my mind somewhat bewildered,
EN.147: these sinners could not flee so stealthily
EN.148: but I with ease discerned that Puccio Lameshanks,
EN.149: and he alone, of the three companions
EN.151: The other, Gaville, was the one whom you lament.

IT.1: Godi, Fiorenza, poi che se' sì grande
IT.2: che per mare e per terra batti l'ali,
IT.3: e per lo 'nferno tuo nome si spande!
IT.4: Tra li ladron trovai cinque cotali
IT.5: tuoi cittadini onde mi ven vergogna,
IT.6: e tu in grande orranza non ne sali.
IT.7: Ma se presso al mattin del ver si sogna,
IT.8: tu sentirai, di qua da picciol tempo,
IT.9: di quel che Prato, non ch'altri, t'agogna.
IT.10: E se già fosse, non saria per tempo.
IT.11: Così foss' ei, da che pur esser dee!
IT.12: ché più mi graverà, com' più m'attempo.
IT.13: Noi ci partimmo, e su per le scalee
IT.14: che n'avea fatto iborni a scender pria,
IT.15: rimontò 'l duca mio e trasse mee;
IT.16: e proseguendo la solinga via,
IT.17: tra le schegge e tra ' rocchi de lo scoglio
IT.18: lo piè sanza la man non si spedia.
IT.19: Allor mi dolsi, e ora mi ridoglio
IT.20: quando drizzo la mente a ciò ch'io vidi,
IT.21: e più lo 'ngegno affreno ch'i' non soglio,
IT.22: perché non corra che virtù nol guidi;
IT.23: sì che, se stella bona o miglior cosa
IT.24: m'ha dato 'l ben, ch'io stessi nol m'invidi.
IT.25: Quante 'l villan ch'al poggio si riposa,
IT.26: nel tempo che colui che 'l mondo schiara
IT.27: la faccia sua a noi tien meno ascosa,
IT.28: come la mosca cede a la zanzara,
IT.29: vede lucciole giù per la vallea,
IT.30: forse colà dov' e' vendemmia e ara:
IT.31: di tante fiamme tutta risplendea
IT.32: l'ottava bolgia, sì com' io m'accorsi
IT.33: tosto che fui là 've 'l fondo parea.
IT.34: E qual colui che si vengiò con li orsi
IT.35: vide 'l carro d'Elia al dipartire,
IT.36: quando i cavalli al cielo erti levorsi,
IT.37: che nol potea sì con li occhi seguire,
IT.38: ch'el vedesse altro che la fiamma sola,
IT.39: sì come nuvoletta, in sù salire:
IT.40: tal si move ciascuna per la gola
IT.41: del fosso, ché nessuna mostra 'l furto,
IT.42: e ogne fiamma un peccatore invola.
IT.43: Io stava sovra 'l ponte a veder surto,
IT.44: sì che s'io non avessi un ronchion preso,
IT.45: caduto sarei giù sanz' esser urto.
IT.46: E 'l duca, che mi vide tanto atteso,
IT.47: disse: "Dentro dai fuochi son li spirti;
IT.48: catun si fascia di quel ch'elli è inceso."
IT.49: "Maestro mio," rispuos' io, "per udirti
IT.50: son io più certo; ma già m'era avviso
IT.51: che così fosse, e già voleva dirti:
IT.52: chi è 'n quel foco che vien sì diviso
IT.53: di sopra, che par surger de la pira
IT.54: dov' Eteòcle col fratel fu miso?"
IT.55: Rispuose a me: "Là dentro si martira
IT.56: Ulisse e Dïomede, e così insieme
IT.57: a la vendetta vanno come a l'ira;
IT.58: e dentro da la lor fiamma si geme
IT.59: l'agguato del caval che fé la porta
IT.60: onde uscì de' Romani il gentil seme.
IT.61: Piangevisi entro l'arte per che, morta,
IT.62: Deïdamìa ancor si duol d'Achille,
IT.63: e del Palladio pena vi si porta."
IT.64: "S'ei posson dentro da quelle faville
IT.65: parlar," diss' io, "maestro, assai ten priego
IT.66: e ripriego, che 'l priego vaglia mille,
IT.67: che non mi facci de l'attender niego
IT.68: fin che la fiamma cornuta qua vegna;
IT.69: vedi che del disio ver' lei mi piego!"
IT.70: Ed elli a me: "La tua preghiera è degna
IT.71: di molta loda, e io però l'accetto;
IT.72: ma fa che la tua lingua si sostegna.
IT.73: Lascia parlare a me, ch'i' ho concetto
IT.74: ciò che tu vuoi; ch'ei sarebbero schivi,
IT.75: perch' e' fuor greci, forse del tuo detto."
IT.76: Poi che la fiamma fu venuta quivi
IT.77: dove parve al mio duca tempo e loco,
IT.78: in questa forma lui parlare audivi:
IT.79: "O voi che siete due dentro ad un foco,
IT.80: s'io meritai di voi mentre ch'io vissi,
IT.81: s'io meritai di voi assai o poco
IT.82: quando nel mondo li alti versi scrissi,
IT.83: non vi movete; ma l'un di voi dica
IT.84: dove, per lui, perduto a morir gissi."
IT.85: Lo maggior corno de la fiamma antica
IT.86: cominciò a crollarsi mormorando,
IT.87: pur come quella cui vento affatica;
IT.88: indi la cima qua e là menando,
IT.89: come fosse la lingua che parlasse,
IT.90: gittò voce di fuori e disse: "Quando
IT.91: mi diparti' da Circe, che sottrasse
IT.92: me più d'un anno là presso a Gaeta,
IT.93: prima che sì Enëa la nomasse,
IT.94: né dolcezza di figlio, né la pieta
IT.95: del vecchio padre, né 'l debito amore
IT.96: lo qual dovea Penelopè far lieta,
IT.97: vincer potero dentro a me l'ardore
IT.98: ch'i' ebbi a divenir del mondo esperto
IT.99: e de li vizi umani e del valore;
IT.100: ma misi me per l'alto mare aperto
IT.101: sol con un legno e con quella compagna
IT.102: picciola da la qual non fui diserto.
IT.103: L'un lito e l'altro vidi infin la Spagna,
IT.104: fin nel Morrocco, e l'isola d'i Sardi,
IT.105: e l'altre che quel mare intorno bagna.
IT.106: Io e ' compagni eravam vecchi e tardi
IT.107: quando venimmo a quella foce stretta
IT.108: dov' Ercule segnò li suoi riguardi
IT.109: acció che l'uom più oltre non si metta;
IT.110: da la man destra mi lasciai Sibilia,
IT.111: da l'altra già m'avea lasciata Setta.
IT.112: 'O frati,' dissi, 'che per cento milia
IT.113: perigli siete giunti a l'occidente,
IT.114: a questa tanto picciola vigilia
IT.115: d'i nostri sensi ch'è del rimanente
IT.116: non vogliate negar l'esperïenza,
IT.117: di retro al sol, del mondo sanza gente.
IT.118: Considerate la vostra semenza:
IT.119: fatti non foste a viver come bruti,
IT.120: ma per seguir virtute e canoscenza.'
IT.121: Li miei compagni fec' io sì aguti,
IT.122: con questa orazion picciola, al cammino,
IT.123: che a pena poscia li avrei ritenuti;
IT.124: e volta nostra poppa nel mattino,
IT.125: de' remi facemmo ali al folle volo,
IT.126: sempre acquistando dal lato mancino.
IT.127: Tutte le stelle già de l'altro polo
IT.128: vedea la notte, e 'l nostro tanto basso,
IT.129: che non surgëa fuor del marin suolo.
IT.130: Cinque volte racceso e tante casso
IT.131: lo lume era di sotto da la luna,
IT.132: poi che 'ntrati eravam ne l'alto passo,
IT.133: quando n'apparve una montagna, bruna
IT.134: per la distanza, e parvemi alta tanto
IT.135: quanto veduta non avëa alcuna.
IT.136: Noi ci allegrammo, e tosto tornò in pianto;
IT.137: ché de la nova terra un turbo nacque
IT.138: e percosse del legno il primo canto.
IT.139: Tre volte il fé girar con tutte l'acque;
IT.140: a la quarta levar la poppa in suso
IT.141: e la prora ire in giù, com' altrui piacque,
IT.142: infin che 'l mar fu sovra noi richiuso."

EN.1: Take joy, O Florence, for you are so great
EN.2: your wings beat over land and sea,
EN.3: your fame resounds through Hell!
EN.4: Among the thieves, I found five citizens of yours
EN.5: who make me feel ashamed, and you
EN.6: are raised by them to no great praise.
EN.7: But if as morning nears we dream the truth,
EN.8: it won't be long before you feel the pain
EN.9: that Prato, to name but one, desires for you.
EN.10: Were it already come, it would not be too soon.
EN.11: But let it come, since come indeed it must,
EN.12: and it will weigh the more on me the more I age.
EN.13: We left that place and, on those stairs
EN.14: that turned us pale when we came down,
EN.15: my leader now climbed back and drew me up.
EN.16: And as we took our solitary way
EN.17: among the juts and crags of the escarpment,
EN.18: our feet could not advance without our hands.
EN.19: I grieved then and now I grieve again
EN.20: as my thoughts turn to what I saw,
EN.21: and more than is my way, I curb my powers
EN.22: lest they run on where virtue fail to guide them,
EN.23: so that, if friendly star or something better still
EN.24: has granted me its boon, I don't misuse the gift.
EN.25: As when a peasant, resting on a hillside --
EN.26: in the season when he who lights the world
EN.27: least hides his face from us,
EN.28: at the hour when the fly gives way to the mosquito --
EN.29: sees fireflies that glimmer in the valley
EN.30: where perhaps he harvests grapes and ploughs his fields,
EN.31: with just so many flames the eighth crevasse
EN.32: was everywhere aglow, as I became aware
EN.33: once I arrived where I could see the bottom.
EN.34: And as the one who was avenged by bears
EN.35: could see Elijah's chariot taking flight,
EN.36: when the horses reared and rose to Heaven,
EN.37: but made out nothing with his eyes
EN.38: except the flame alone
EN.39: ascending like a cloud into the sky,
EN.40: so each flame moves along the gullet
EN.41: of the trench and -- though none reveals the theft --
EN.42: each flame conceals a sinner.
EN.43: Rising to my feet to look, I stood up
EN.44: on the bridge. Had I not grasped a jutting crag,
EN.45: I would have fallen in without a shove.
EN.46: My leader, when he saw me so intent, said:
EN.47: 'These spirits stand within the flames.
EN.48: Each one is wrapped in that in which he burns.'
EN.49: 'Master,' I replied, 'I am the more convinced
EN.50: to hear you say it. That is what I thought,
EN.51: and had it in my mind to ask you this:
EN.52: 'Who is in the flame so riven at the tip
EN.53: it could be rising from the pyre
EN.54: on which Etèocles was laid out with his brother?'
EN.55: He replied: 'Within this flame find torment
EN.56: Ulysses and Diomed. They are paired
EN.57: in God's revenge as once they earned his wrath.
EN.58: 'In their flame they mourn the stratagem
EN.59: of the horse that made a gateway
EN.60: through which the noble seed of Rome came forth.
EN.61: 'There they lament the wiles for which, in death,
EN.62: Deidamìa mourns Achilles still,
EN.63: and there they make amends for the Palladium.'
EN.64: 'If they can speak within those flames,'
EN.65: I said, 'I pray you, master, and I pray again --
EN.66: and may my prayer be a thousand strong --
EN.67: 'do not forbid my lingering awhile
EN.68: until the twin-forked flame arrives.
EN.69: You see how eagerly I lean in its direction.'
EN.70: And he to me: 'Your prayer deserves
EN.71: much praise. Therefore, I grant it,
EN.72: but on condition that you hold your tongue.
EN.73: 'Leave speech to me, for I have understood
EN.74: just what you want. And, since they were Greeks,
EN.75: they might disdain your words.'
EN.76: Once the flame had neared, when he thought
EN.77: the time and moment right,
EN.78: I heard my leader speaking in this way:
EN.79: 'O you who are twinned within a single fire,
EN.80: if I have earned your favor while I lived,
EN.81: if I have earned your favor -- in whatever measure --
EN.82: 'when, in the world, I wrote my lofty verses,
EN.83: then do not move away. Let one of you relate
EN.84: just where, having lost his way, he went to die.'
EN.85: And the larger horn of that ancient flame
EN.86: began to murmur and to tremble,
EN.87: like a flame that is worried by the wind.
EN.88: Then, brandishing its tip this way and that,
EN.89: as if it were the tongue of fire that spoke,
EN.90: it brought forth a voice and said: 'When I
EN.91: 'took leave of Circe, who for a year and more
EN.92: beguiled me there, not far from Gaëta,
EN.93: before Aeneas gave that name to it,
EN.94: 'not tenderness for a son, nor filial duty
EN.95: toward my agèd father, nor the love I owed
EN.96: Penelope that would have made her glad,
EN.97: 'could overcome the fervor that was mine
EN.98: to gain experience of the world
EN.99: and learn about man's vices, and his worth.
EN.100: 'And so I set forth upon the open deep
EN.101: with but a single ship and that small band
EN.102: of shipmates who had not deserted me.
EN.103: 'One shore and the other I saw as far as Spain,
EN.104: Morocco, the island of Sardegna,
EN.105: and other islands set into that sea.
EN.106: 'I and my shipmates had grown old and slow
EN.107: before we reached the narrow strait
EN.108: where Hercules marked off the limits,
EN.109: 'warning all men to go no farther.
EN.110: On the right-hand side I left Seville behind,
EN.111: on the other I had left Ceüta.
EN.112: '"O brothers," I said, "who, in the course
EN.113: of a hundred thousand perils, at last
EN.114: have reached the west, to such brief wakefulness
EN.115: '"of our senses as remains to us,
EN.116: do not deny yourselves the chance to know --
EN.117: following the sun -- the world where no one lives.
EN.118: '"Consider how your souls were sown:
EN.119: you were not made to live like brutes or beasts,
EN.120: but to pursue virtue and knowledge."
EN.121: 'With this brief speech I had my companions
EN.122: so ardent for the journey
EN.123: I could scarce have held them back.
EN.124: 'And, having set our stern to sunrise,
EN.125: in our mad flight we turned our oars to wings,
EN.126: always gaining on the left.
EN.127: 'Now night was gazing on the stars that light
EN.128: the other pole, the stars of our own so low
EN.129: they did not rise above the ocean floor.
EN.130: 'Five times the light beneath the moon
EN.131: had been rekindled and as often been put out
EN.132: since we began our voyage on the deep,
EN.133: 'when we could see a mountain, distant,
EN.134: dark and dim. In my sight it seemed
EN.135: higher than any I had ever seen.
EN.136: 'We rejoiced, but joy soon turned to grief:
EN.137: for from that unknown land there came
EN.138: a whirlwind that struck the ship head-on.
EN.139: 'Three times it turned her and all the waters
EN.140: with her. At the fourth our stern reared up,
EN.141: the prow went down -- as pleased Another --
EN.142: until the sea closed over us.'

IT.1: Già era dritta in sù la fiamma e queta
IT.2: per non dir più, e già da noi sen gia
IT.3: con la licenza del dolce poeta,
IT.4: quand' un'altra, che dietro a lei venìa,
IT.5: ne fece volger li occhi a la sua cima
IT.6: per un confuso suon che fuor n'uscia.
IT.7: Come 'l bue cicilian che mugghiò prima
IT.8: col pianto di colui, e ciò fu dritto,
IT.9: che l'avea temperato con sua lima,
IT.10: mugghiava con la voce de l'afflitto,
IT.11: sì che, con tutto che fosse di rame,
IT.12: pur el pareva dal dolor trafitto;
IT.13: così, per non aver via né forame
IT.14: dal principio nel foco, in suo linguaggio
IT.15: si convertïan le parole grame.
IT.16: Ma poscia ch'ebber colto lor vïaggio
IT.17: su per la punta, dandole quel guizzo
IT.18: che dato avea la lingua in lor passaggio,
IT.19: udimmo dire: "O tu a cu' io drizzo
IT.20: la voce e che parlavi mo lombardo,
IT.21: dicendo 'Istra ten va, più non t'adizzo,'
IT.22: perch' io sia giunto forse alquanto tardo,
IT.23: non t'incresca restare a parlar meco;
IT.24: vedi che non incresce a me, e ardo!
IT.25: Se tu pur mo in questo mondo cieco
IT.26: caduto se' di quella dolce terra
IT.27: latina ond' io mia colpa tutta reco,
IT.28: dimmi se Romagnuoli han pace o guerra;
IT.29: ch'io fui d'i monti là intra Orbino
IT.30: e 'l giogo di che Tever si diserra."
IT.31: Io era in giuso ancora attento e chino,
IT.32: quando il mio duca mi tentò di costa,
IT.33: dicendo: "Parla tu; questi è latino."
IT.34: E io, ch'avea già pronta la risposta,
IT.35: sanza indugio a parlare incominciai:
IT.36: "O anima che se' là giù nascosta,
IT.37: Romagna tua non è, e non fu mai,
IT.38: sanza guerra ne' cuor de' suoi tiranni;
IT.39: ma 'n palese nessuna or vi lasciai.
IT.40: Ravenna sta come stata è molt' anni:
IT.41: l'aguglia da Polenta la si cova,
IT.42: sì che Cervia ricuopre co' suoi vanni.
IT.43: La terra che fé già la lunga prova
IT.44: e di Franceschi sanguinoso mucchio,
IT.45: sotto le branche verdi si ritrova.
IT.46: E 'l mastin vecchio e 'l nuovo da Verrucchio,
IT.47: che fecer di Montagna il mal governo,
IT.48: là dove soglion fan d'i denti succhio.
IT.49: Le città di Lamone e di Santerno
IT.50: conduce il lïoncel dal nido bianco,
IT.51: che muta parte da la state al verno.
IT.52: E quella cu' il Savio bagna il fianco,
IT.53: così com' ella sie' tra 'l piano e 'l monte,
IT.54: tra tirannia si vive e stato franco.
IT.55: Ora chi se', ti priego che ne conte;
IT.56: non esser duro più ch'altri sia stato,
IT.57: se 'l nome tuo nel mondo tegna fronte."
IT.58: Poscia che 'l foco alquanto ebbe rugghiato
IT.59: al modo suo, l'aguta punta mosse
IT.60: di qua, di là, e poi diè cotal fiato:
IT.61: "S'i' credesse che mia risposta fosse
IT.62: a persona che mai tornasse al mondo,
IT.63: questa fiamma staria sanza più scosse;
IT.64: ma però che già mai di questo fondo
IT.65: non tornò vivo alcun, s'i' odo il vero,
IT.66: sanza tema d'infamia ti rispondo.
IT.67: Io fui uom d'arme, e poi fui cordigliero,
IT.68: credendomi, sì cinto, fare ammenda;
IT.69: e certo il creder mio venìa intero,
IT.70: se non fosse il gran prete, a cui mal prenda!,
IT.71: che mi rimise ne le prime colpe;
IT.72: e come e quare, voglio che m'intenda.
IT.73: Mentre ch'io forma fui d'ossa e di polpe
IT.74: che la madre mi diè, l'opere mie
IT.75: non furon leonine, ma di volpe.
IT.76: Li accorgimenti e le coperte vie
IT.77: io seppi tutte, e sì menai lor arte,
IT.78: ch'al fine de la terra il suono uscie.
IT.79: Quando mi vidi giunto in quella parte
IT.80: di mia etade ove ciascun dovrebbe
IT.81: calar le vele e raccoglier le sarte,
IT.82: ciò che pria mi piacëa, allor m'increbbe,
IT.83: e pentuto e confesso mi rendei;
IT.84: ahi miser lasso! e giovato sarebbe.
IT.85: Lo principe d'i novi Farisei,
IT.86: avendo guerra presso a Laterano,
IT.87: e non con Saracin né con Giudei,
IT.88: ché ciascun suo nimico era Cristiano,
IT.89: e nessun era stato a vincer Acri
IT.90: né mercatante in terra di Soldano,
IT.91: né sommo officio né ordini sacri
IT.92: guardò in sé, né in me quel capestro
IT.93: che solea fare i suoi cinti più macri.
IT.94: Ma come Costantin chiese Silvestro
IT.95: d'entro Siratti a guerir de la lebbre,
IT.96: così mi chiese questi per maestro
IT.97: a guerir de la sua superba febbre;
IT.98: domandommi consiglio, e io tacetti
IT.99: perché le sue parole parver ebbre.
IT.100: E' poi ridisse: 'Tuo cuor non sospetti;
IT.101: finor t'assolvo, e tu m'insegna fare
IT.102: sì come Penestrino in terra getti.
IT.103: Lo ciel poss' io serrare e diserrare,
IT.104: come tu sai; però son due le chiavi
IT.105: che 'l mio antecessor non ebbe care.'
IT.106: Allor mi pinser li argomenti gravi
IT.107: là 've 'l tacer mi fu avviso 'l peggio,
IT.108: e dissi: 'Padre, da che tu mi lavi
IT.109: di quel peccato ov' io mo cader deggio,
IT.110: lunga promessa con l'attender corto
IT.111: ti farà trïunfar ne l'alto seggio.'
IT.112: Francesco venne poi, com' io fu' morto,
IT.113: per me; ma un d'i neri cherubini
IT.114: li disse: 'Non portar; non mi far torto.
IT.115: Venir se ne dee giù tra ' miei meschini
IT.116: perché diede 'l consiglio frodolente,
IT.117: dal quale in qua stato li sono a' crini;
IT.118: ch'assolver non si può chi non si pente,
IT.119: né pentere e volere insieme puossi
IT.120: per la contradizion che nol consente.'
IT.121: Oh me dolente! come mi riscossi
IT.122: quando mi prese dicendomi: 'Forse
IT.123: tu non pensavi ch'io löico fossi!'
IT.124: A Minòs mi portò; e quelli attorse
IT.125: otto volte la coda al dosso duro;
IT.126: e poi che per gran rabbia la si morse,
IT.127: disse: 'Questi è d'i rei del foco furo';
IT.128: per ch'io là dove vedi son perduto,
IT.129: e sì vestito, andando, mi rancuro."
IT.130: Quand' elli ebbe 'l suo dir così compiuto,
IT.131: la fiamma dolorando si partio,
IT.132: torcendo e dibattendo 'l corno aguto.
IT.133: Noi passamm' oltre, e io e 'l duca mio,
IT.134: su per lo scoglio infino in su l'altr' arco
IT.135: che cuopre 'l fosso in che si paga il fio
IT.136: a quei che scommettendo acquistan carco.

EN.1: The flame now stood erect and still,
EN.2: meaning to speak no more, and was departing
EN.3: with the gentle poet's leave,
EN.4: when another flame, coming close behind,
EN.5: caused our eyes to fix upon its tip,
EN.6: drawn by the gibberish that came from it.
EN.7: As the Sicilian bull that bellowed first
EN.8: with the cries of him whose instrument
EN.9: had fashioned it -- and that was only just --
EN.10: used to bellow with the victim's voice
EN.11: so that, although the bull was made of brass,
EN.12: it seemed transfixed by pain,
EN.13: thus, having first no course or outlet
EN.14: through the flame, the mournful words
EN.15: were changed into a language all their own.
EN.16: But once the words had made their way
EN.17: up to the tip, making it flicker
EN.18: as the voice had done when it had formed them,
EN.19: we heard it say: 'O you at whom I aim my voice
EN.20: and who, just now, said in the Lombard tongue:
EN.21: "Now go your way, I ask you nothing more,"
EN.22: 'though I've arrived, perhaps, a little late,
EN.23: let it not trouble you to stay and speak with me.
EN.24: Though I am in the flame, as you can see, it irks me not.
EN.25: 'If you are only a short while fallen
EN.26: into this blind world from that sweet land
EN.27: of Italy, from which I bring down all my sins,
EN.28: 'tell me if Romagna lives in peace or war.
EN.29: I came from where the mountains stand between
EN.30: Urbino and the ridge from which the Tiber springs.'
EN.31: I still stood bending down to hear,
EN.32: when my leader nudged my side and said:
EN.33: 'It's up to you to speak -- this one is Italian.'
EN.34: And I, who had my answer ready,
EN.35: without delay began to speak:
EN.36: 'O soul that is hidden from my sight down there,
EN.37: 'your Romagna is not, and never was,
EN.38: free of warfare in her rulers' hearts.
EN.39: Still, no open warfare have I left behind.
EN.40: 'Ravenna remains as it has been for years.
EN.41: The eagle of Polenta broods over it
EN.42: so that he covers Cervia with his wings.
EN.43: 'The town that once withstood the lengthy siege,
EN.44: making of the French a bloody heap,
EN.45: is now again beneath the green claws of the lion.
EN.46: 'The elder mastiff of Verrucchio and the younger,
EN.47: who between them had harsh dealing with Montagna,
EN.48: sharpen their teeth to augers in the customary place.
EN.49: 'The young lion on a field of white,
EN.50: who rules Lamone's and Santerno's cities,
EN.51: changes sides between the summer and the snows.
EN.52: 'And the city whose flank the Savio bathes:
EN.53: as she lives between tyranny and freedom,
EN.54: so she lies between the mountain and the plain.
EN.55: 'But now, I beg you, tell us who you are.
EN.56: Be no more grudging than another's been to you,
EN.57: so may your name continue in the world.'
EN.58: When the fire had done its roaring for a while,
EN.59: after its fashion, the point began to quiver
EN.60: this way and that, and then gave breath to this:
EN.61: 'If I but thought that my response were made
EN.62: to one perhaps returning to the world,
EN.63: this tongue of flame would cease to flicker.
EN.64: 'But since, up from these depths, no one has yet
EN.65: returned alive, if what I hear is true,
EN.66: I answer without fear of being shamed.
EN.67: 'A warrior was I, and then a corded friar,
EN.68: thinking, cinctured so, to make amends.
EN.69: And surely would my hopes have come to pass
EN.70: 'but for the Great Priest -- the devil take him! --
EN.71: who drew me back to my old ways.
EN.72: And I would like to tell you how and why.
EN.73: 'While I still kept the form in flesh and bones
EN.74: my mother gave me, my deeds were not
EN.75: a lion's but the actions of a fox.
EN.76: 'Cunning stratagems and covert schemes,
EN.77: I knew them all, and was so skilled in them
EN.78: my fame rang out to the far confines of the earth.
EN.79: 'When I saw I had reached that stage of life
EN.80: when all men ought to think
EN.81: of lowering sail and coiling up the ropes,
EN.82: 'I grew displeased with what had pleased me once.
EN.83: Repentant and shriven, I became a friar.
EN.84: And woe is me! it would have served.
EN.85: 'But he, Prince of the latter-day Pharisees,
EN.86: engaged in battle near the Lateran
EN.87: and not with either Saracen or Jew,
EN.88: 'for all his enemies were Christian --
EN.89: not one of them had gone to conquer Acre
EN.90: or traffic in the Sultan's lands --
EN.91: 'paid no heed, for his part, to the highest office
EN.92: or his holy orders, nor, for mine,
EN.93: to the cord that used to keep its wearers lean.
EN.94: 'As Constantine once had Sylvester summoned
EN.95: from Soracte to cure his leprous sores,
EN.96: so this man called on me to be his doctor
EN.97: 'and cure him of the fever of his pride.
EN.98: He asked me for advice, but I kept silent
EN.99: because his words were like a drunkard's words.
EN.100: 'And then he spoke again: "Let not your heart mistrust:
EN.101: I absolve you here and now if you will teach me
EN.102: how I can bring Praeneste to the ground.
EN.103: '"I have the power, as well you know, to lock
EN.104: and unlock Heaven, because the keys are two
EN.105: for which the pope before me had no care."
EN.106: 'His threatening tactics brought me to the point
EN.107: at which the worse course seemed the one of silence.
EN.108: And so I said: "Father, since you cleanse me
EN.109: '"of the sin that I must even now commit:
EN.110: Promising much with scant observance
EN.111: will seal your triumph on the lofty throne."
EN.112: 'The moment I was dead, Francis came for me.
EN.113: But one of the dark Cherubim cried out:
EN.114: "No, wrong me not by bearing that one off.
EN.115: '"He must come down to serve among my minions
EN.116: because he gave that fraudulent advice.
EN.117: From then till now I've dogged his footsteps.
EN.118: '"One may not be absolved without repentance,
EN.119: nor repent and wish to sin concurrently --
EN.120: a simple contradiction not allowed."
EN.121: 'Oh, wretch that I am, how I shuddered
EN.122: when he seized me and said: "Perhaps
EN.123: you didn't reckon I'd be versed in logic."
EN.124: 'He carried me to Minos, who coiled his tail
EN.125: eight times around his scaly back
EN.126: and, having gnawed it in his awful rage,
EN.127: 'said: "Here comes a sinner for the thieving fire."
EN.128: And so, just as you see me, I am damned,
EN.129: cloaked as I am. And as I go, I grieve.'
EN.130: Once he had brought his words to this conclusion,
EN.131: the weeping flame departed,
EN.132: twisting and tossing its pointed horn.
EN.133: We continued on our way, my guide and I,
EN.134: over the ridge and up the arch that spans
EN.135: the ditch where those are paid their due
EN.136: who, for disjoining, gather up their load.
