EN.1: Who, even in words not bound by meter,
EN.2: and having told the tale many times over,
EN.3: could tell the blood and wounds that I saw now?
EN.4: Surely every tongue would fail,
EN.5: for neither thought nor speech
EN.6: has the capacity to hold so much.
EN.7: Could all the wounded troops again assemble:
EN.8: first from Apulia, land laid low by war,
EN.9: who grieved for their lost blood
EN.10: shed by the Trojans, then all those
EN.11: of the long war, whose corpses were despoiled
EN.12: of piles of rings -- as Livy writes, who does not err --
EN.13: together with the ones who felt the agony of blows
EN.14: fighting in the fields against Guiscard,
EN.15: and those whose bones still lie in heaps
EN.16: at Ceperano, where each Apulian played it false,
EN.17: and those near Tagliacozzo,
EN.18: where old Alardo conquered without force of arms:
EN.19: and should one show his limb pierced through,
EN.20: another his, where it has been cut off,
EN.21: it would be nothing to the ninth pit's filth.
EN.22: No cask ever gapes so wide for loss
EN.23: of mid- or side-stave as the soul I saw
EN.24: cleft from the chin right down to where men fart.
EN.25: Between the legs the entrails dangled. I saw
EN.26: the innards and the loathsome sack
EN.27: that turns what one has swallowed into shit.
EN.28: While I was caught up in the sight of him,
EN.29: he looked at me and, with his hands, ripped apart
EN.30: his chest, saying: 'See how I rend myself,
EN.31: 'see how mangled is Mohammed!
EN.32: Ahead of me proceeds Alì, in tears,
EN.33: his face split open from his chin to forelock.
EN.34: 'And all the others whom you see
EN.35: sowed scandal and schism while they lived,
EN.36: and that is why they here are hacked asunder.
EN.37: 'A devil's posted there behind us
EN.38: who dresses us so cruelly,
EN.39: putting each of this crew again to the sword
EN.40: 'as soon as we have done our doleful round.
EN.41: For all our wounds have closed
EN.42: when we appear again before him.
EN.43: 'But who are you to linger on the ridge? --
EN.44: perhaps you put off going to the torment
EN.45: pronounced on your own accusation.'
EN.46: 'Death does not have him yet nor does his guilt
EN.47: lead him to torment,' replied my master,
EN.48: 'but to give him greater knowledge
EN.49: 'I, who am dead indeed, must shepherd him
EN.50: from circle to circle, through this Hell down here.
EN.51: And this is as true as that I speak to you.'
EN.52: On hearing this, more than a hundred souls
EN.53: halted in the ditch to stare at me
EN.54: in wonder, each forgetful of his pain.
EN.55: 'You, who perhaps will shortly see the sun,
EN.56: warn Fra Dolcino to provide himself --
EN.57: unless he'd like to join me here quite soon --
EN.58: 'with stocks of victuals, lest the siege of snow
EN.59: hand the Novarese the victory
EN.60: not otherwise so easy to attain.'
EN.61: One foot raised, halted in mid-stride,
EN.62: Mohammed spoke these words,
EN.63: then setting down that foot, went on his way.
EN.64: Another, with his throat pierced through
EN.65: and nose hacked off just where the brows begin,
EN.66: and only one ear left upon his head,
EN.67: stopped with the rest of them to gape in wonder
EN.68: and, before the others did, opened his windpipe,
EN.69: scarlet on the skin side as it was,
EN.70: to say: 'O you whom guilt does not condemn
EN.71: and whom I saw above in Italy,
EN.72: if in your likeness I am not deceived,
EN.73: 'should you ever see that gentle plain again
EN.74: that slopes from Vercelli down to Marcabò,
EN.75: for Pier da Medicina spare a thought.
EN.76: 'And let the two chief men of Fano know,
EN.77: both messer Guido and Angiolello,
EN.78: that, unless our foresight here is vain,
EN.79: 'through a brutal tyrant's treachery
EN.80: near La Cattolica they shall be heaved
EN.81: from their ship with weights to hold them down.
EN.82: 'Between the islands of Cyprus and Majorca
EN.83: Neptune never witnessed so terrible a crime,
EN.84: whether one committed by pirates or by Greeks.
EN.85: 'That traitor, who sees through one eye only
EN.86: and rules the city that another down here with me
EN.87: would take delight in never having seen,
EN.88: 'will have the men of Fano come to parley
EN.89: and he will so deal with them that, to ply
EN.90: Focara's wind, they'll need no vows or prayers.'
EN.91: And I: 'Point out to me and make him known,
EN.92: if you would have me carry news of you above,
EN.93: the one to whom that city's sight was bitter.'
EN.94: Then he laid his hand upon the jaw
EN.95: of one of his companions, pried his lips apart,
EN.96: and cried: 'Here he is, but he won't speak.
EN.97: 'Banished, he quenched the doubt in Caesar,
EN.98: affirming that, to a man prepared,
EN.99: delay was always harmful.'
EN.100: Ah, how distressed he seemed to me,
EN.101: with his tongue sliced off so deep in his throat,
EN.102: Curio, who had been so bold in speech!
EN.103: And then another whose hands had been chopped off,
EN.104: raising his stumps up in the murky air
EN.105: so that the blood from them befouled his face,
EN.106: cried out: 'Surely you'll remember Mosca also,
EN.107: who said, alas: "A done deed finds its purpose."
EN.108: For Tuscany, that was an evil seed.'
EN.109: 'And death to your own stock,' I added then.
EN.110: At that, one sorrow piled upon another,
EN.111: he made off, like a man berserk with grief.
EN.112: But I stayed on to watch the troop
EN.113: and saw a thing I would be loath
EN.114: to mention without further proof,
EN.115: were I not comforted by conscience,
EN.116: the bosom friend that fortifies a man
EN.117: beneath the armor of an honest heart.
EN.118: I truly saw, and seem to see it still,
EN.119: a headless body make its way
EN.120: like all the others in that dismal flock.
EN.121: And by its hair he held his severed head
EN.122: swinging in his hand as if it were a lantern,
EN.123: the head that stared at us and said: 'Oh, woe!'
EN.124: Of himself he made himself a lamp,
EN.125: and they were two in one and one in two.
EN.126: How this can be He knows who so ordains it.
EN.127: When he was just at the foot of the bridge
EN.128: he raised his arm high and, with it, that head,
EN.129: so as to make his words sound more distinct:
EN.130: 'You, who view the dead with breath yet in your body,
EN.131: look upon my grievous punishment.
EN.132: Is any other terrible as this?
EN.133: 'So you may carry back the news of me,
EN.134: know I am Bertran de Born, the one
EN.135: who urged the young king on with bad advice.
EN.136: 'Father and son I set to enmity.
EN.137: Ahithophel stirred no worse ill between
EN.138: Absalom and David with his wicked goading.
EN.139: 'Because I severed persons thus conjoined,
EN.140: severed, alas, I carry my own brain
EN.141: from its starting-point here in my body.
EN.142: In me you may observe fit punishment.'

IT.1: La molta gente e le diverse piaghe
IT.2: avean le luci mie sì inebrïate,
IT.3: che de lo stare a piangere eran vaghe.
IT.4: Ma Virgilio mi disse: "Che pur guate?
IT.5: perché la vista tua pur si soffolge
IT.6: là giù tra l'ombre triste smozzicate?
IT.7: Tu non hai fatto sì a l'altre bolge;
IT.8: pensa, se tu annoverar le credi,
IT.9: che miglia ventidue la valle volge.
IT.10: E già la luna è sotto i nostri piedi;
IT.11: lo tempo è poco omai che n'è concesso,
IT.12: e altro è da veder che tu non vedi."
IT.13: "Se tu avessi," rispuos' io appresso,
IT.14: "atteso a la cagion per ch'io guardava,
IT.15: forse m'avresti ancor lo star dimesso."
IT.16: Parte sen giva, e io retro li andava,
IT.17: lo duca, già faccendo la risposta,
IT.18: e soggiugnendo: "Dentro a quella cava
IT.19: dov' io tenea or li occhi sì a posta,
IT.20: credo ch'un spirto del mio sangue pianga
IT.21: la colpa che là giù cotanto costa."
IT.22: Allor disse 'l maestro: "Non si franga
IT.23: lo tuo pensier da qui innanzi sovr' ello.
IT.24: Attendi ad altro, ed ei là si rimanga;
IT.25: ch'io vidi lui a piè del ponticello
IT.26: mostrarti e minacciar forte col dito,
IT.27: e udi' 'l nominar Geri del Bello.
IT.28: Tu eri allor sì del tutto impedito
IT.29: sovra colui che già tenne Altaforte,
IT.30: che non guardasti in là, sì fu partito."
IT.31: "O duca mio, la vïolenta morte
IT.32: che non li è vendicata ancor," diss' io,
IT.33: "per alcun che de l'onta sia consorte,
IT.34: fece lui disdegnoso; ond' el sen gio
IT.35: sanza parlarmi, sì com' ïo estimo:
IT.36: e in ciò m'ha el fatto a sé più pio."
IT.37: Così parlammo infino al loco primo
IT.38: che de lo scoglio l'altra valle mostra,
IT.39: se più lume vi fosse, tutto ad imo.
IT.40: Quando noi fummo sor l'ultima chiostra
IT.41: di Malebolge, sì che i suoi conversi
IT.42: potean parere a la veduta nostra,
IT.43: lamenti saettaron me diversi,
IT.44: che di pietà ferrati avean li strali;
IT.45: ond' io li orecchi con le man copersi.
IT.46: Qual dolor fora, se de li spedali
IT.47: di Valdichiana tra 'l luglio e 'l settembre
IT.48: e di Maremma e di Sardigna i mali
IT.49: fossero in una fossa tutti 'nsembre,
IT.50: tal era quivi, e tal puzzo n'usciva
IT.51: qual suol venir de le marcite membre.
IT.52: Noi discendemmo in su l'ultima riva
IT.53: del lungo scoglio, pur da man sinistra;
IT.54: e allor fu la mia vista più viva
IT.55: giù ver' lo fondo, là 've la ministra
IT.56: de l'alto Sire infallibil giustizia
IT.57: punisce i falsador che qui registra.
IT.58: Non credo ch'a veder maggior tristizia
IT.59: fosse in Egina il popol tutto infermo,
IT.60: quando fu l'aere sì pien di malizia,
IT.61: che li animali, infino al picciol vermo,
IT.62: cascaron tutti, e poi le genti antiche,
IT.63: secondo che i poeti hanno per fermo,
IT.64: si ristorar di seme di formiche;
IT.65: ch'era a veder per quella oscura valle
IT.66: languir li spirti per diverse biche.
IT.67: Qual sovra 'l ventre e qual sovra le spalle
IT.68: l'un de l'altro giacea, e qual carpone
IT.69: si trasmutava per lo tristo calle.
IT.70: Passo passo andavam sanza sermone,
IT.71: guardando e ascoltando li ammalati,
IT.72: che non potean levar le lor persone.
IT.73: Io vidi due sedere a sé poggiati,
IT.74: com' a scaldar si poggia tegghia a tegghia,
IT.75: dal capo al piè di schianze macolati;
IT.76: e non vidi già mai menare stregghia
IT.77: a ragazzo aspettato dal segnorso,
IT.78: né a colui che mal volontier vegghia,
IT.79: come ciascun menava spesso il morso
IT.80: de l'unghie sopra sé per la gran rabbia
IT.81: del pizzicor, che non ha più soccorso;
IT.82: e sì traevan giù l'unghie la scabbia,
IT.83: come coltel di scardova le scaglie
IT.84: o d'altro pesce che più larghe l'abbia.
IT.85: "O tu che con le dita ti dismaglie,"
IT.86: cominciò 'l duca mio a l'un di loro,
IT.87: "e che fai d'esse tal volta tanaglie,
IT.88: dinne s'alcun Latino è tra costoro
IT.89: che son quinc' entro, se l'unghia ti basti
IT.90: etternalmente a cotesto lavoro."
IT.91: "Latin siam noi, che tu vedi sì guasti
IT.92: qui ambedue," rispuose l'un piangendo;
IT.93: "ma tu chi se' che di noi dimandasti?"
IT.94: E 'l duca disse: "I' son un che discendo
IT.95: con questo vivo giù di balzo in balzo,
IT.96: e di mostrar lo 'nferno a lui intendo."
IT.97: Allor si ruppe lo comun rincalzo;
IT.98: e tremando ciascuno a me si volse
IT.99: con altri che l'udiron di rimbalzo.
IT.100: Lo buon maestro a me tutto s'accolse,
IT.101: dicendo: "Dì a lor ciò che tu vuoli";
IT.102: e io incominciai, poscia ch'ei volse:
IT.103: "Se la vostra memoria non s'imboli
IT.104: nel primo mondo da l'umane menti,
IT.105: ma s'ella viva sotto molti soli,
IT.106: ditemi chi voi siete e di che genti;
IT.107: la vostra sconcia e fastidiosa pena
IT.108: di palesarvi a me non vi spaventi."
IT.109: "Io fui d'Arezzo, e Albero da Siena,"
IT.110: rispuose l'un, "mi fé mettere al foco;
IT.111: ma quel per ch'io mori' qui non mi mena.
IT.112: Vero è ch'i' dissi lui, parlando a gioco:
IT.113: 'I' mi saprei levar per l'aere a volo';
IT.114: e quei, ch'avea vaghezza e senno poco,
IT.115: volle ch'i' li mostrassi l'arte; e solo
IT.116: perch' io nol feci Dedalo, mi fece
IT.117: ardere a tal che l'avea per figliuolo.
IT.118: Ma ne l'ultima bolgia de le diece
IT.119: me per l'alchìmia che nel mondo usai
IT.120: dannò Minòs, a cui fallar non lece."
IT.121: E io dissi al poeta: "Or fu già mai
IT.122: gente sì vana come la sanese?
IT.123: Certo non la francesca sì d'assai!"
IT.124: Onde l'altro lebbroso, che m'intese,
IT.125: rispuose al detto mio: "Tra'mene Stricca
IT.126: che seppe far le temperate spese,
IT.127: e Niccolò che la costuma ricca
IT.128: del garofano prima discoverse
IT.129: ne l'orto dove tal seme s'appicca;
IT.130: e tra'ne la brigata in che disperse
IT.131: Caccia d'Ascian la vigna e la gran fonda,
IT.132: e l'Abbagliato suo senno proferse.
IT.133: Ma perché sappi chi sì ti seconda
IT.134: contra i Sanesi, aguzza ver' me l'occhio,
IT.135: sì che la faccia mia ben ti risponda:
IT.136: sì vedrai ch'io son l'ombra di Capocchio,
IT.137: che falsai li metalli con l'alchìmia;
IT.138: e te dee ricordar, se ben t'adocchio,
IT.139: com' io fui di natura buona scimia."

EN.1: The many people and their ghastly wounds
EN.2: did so intoxicate my eyes
EN.3: that I was moved to linger there and weep.
EN.4: But Virgil said: 'What are you staring at?
EN.5: Why is your gaze so fixed upon the depths
EN.6: that hold those mournful, mutilated shades?
EN.7: 'You have not done so at the other pits.
EN.8: In case you plan to count the sinners one by one,
EN.9: think: this hollow circles twenty-two miles round.
EN.10: 'The moon already lies beneath our feet.
EN.11: The time we are allotted soon expires
EN.12: and there is more to see than you see here.'
EN.13: 'Had you understood,' I was quick to answer,
EN.14: 'the reason for my close inspection,
EN.15: perhaps you would have let me stay there longer.'
EN.16: All the while my guide was moving on,
EN.17: with me, intent on my reply, behind him.
EN.18: And then I added: 'Within that hole
EN.19: 'where I had fixed my gaze, I do believe I saw
EN.20: someone of my own blood lament
EN.21: the sin that costs so dear down there.'
EN.22: Then the master said: 'Trouble your mind
EN.23: no more because of him.
EN.24: Turn it to other things and let him be,
EN.25: 'for I saw him there below the bridge,
EN.26: pointing his finger at you, fierce with threats,
EN.27: and I heard him called Geri del Bello.
EN.28: 'Just then you were so thoroughly engrossed
EN.29: in him who once was lord of Hautefort
EN.30: you did not glance that way before your kinsman left.'
EN.31: 'O my leader, the violent death he died,
EN.32: for which no vengeance has been taken yet,'
EN.33: I said, 'by any person partner to his shame,
EN.34: 'made him indignant. That is why he went away
EN.35: without addressing me -- or so I think --
EN.36: and why he's made me pity him the more.'
EN.37: Thus we continued talking till we reached
EN.38: the first point on the ridge that could have shown
EN.39: the next pit's bottom, had there been more light.
EN.40: When we stood above the final cloister
EN.41: of Malebolge and all of its lay brothers
EN.42: became discernible to us,
EN.43: strange arrows of lament, their shafts,
EN.44: with pity at their tips, pierced me,
EN.45: so that I pressed my hands against my ears.
EN.46: If the contagion of every hospital
EN.47: in Valdichiana, from July until September,
EN.48: and in the Maremma and Sardegna, were amassed
EN.49: in one malarial ditch, just such suffering
EN.50: was in that place. And from it rose
EN.51: the stench of festering limbs.
EN.52: We came down, always to our left, and reached
EN.53: the last bank of the lengthy crag.
EN.54: And then my eyes could have a better view
EN.55: into the pit, there where the minister
EN.56: of God on high, unerring justice, punishes
EN.57: the counterfeiters whom she here records.
EN.58: I think it could have been no greater sorrow
EN.59: to see the people of Aegina stricken,
EN.60: with such corruption in the very air
EN.61: that every animal, even the smallest worm,
EN.62: perished, and, later, as the poets hold for certain,
EN.63: these ancient people were restored to life,
EN.64: hatched from the eggs of ants --
EN.65: no greater sorrow, than in that somber valley
EN.66: to see those spirits, heaped on one another, languishing.
EN.67: Some lay upon the bellies or the backs
EN.68: of others, still others dragged themselves
EN.69: on hands and knees along that gloomy path.
EN.70: Step by step we went ahead in silence,
EN.71: looking and listening to the stricken spirits,
EN.72: who could not raise their bodies from the ground.
EN.73: Two I saw seated, propped against each other
EN.74: as pans are propped to warm before the fire,
EN.75: each of them blotched with scabs from head to foot.
EN.76: And never did I see a stable-boy,
EN.77: with his master waiting, nor youth whose chore
EN.78: keeps him from sleep, ply his curry-comb
EN.79: more hurriedly than each one clawed his nails
EN.80: across his skin because of that mad itch,
EN.81: which knows no other remedy,
EN.82: and their nails tore off those scabs
EN.83: as a knife strips scales from bream
EN.84: or other fish with even larger scales.
EN.85: 'You there, stripping off your coat of mail,'
EN.86: began my leader, addressing one of them,
EN.87: 'and sometimes making pincers of your fingers,
EN.88: 'tell us whether, among those gathered here,
EN.89: any are Italian, so may your nails
EN.90: last you in this task for all eternity.'
EN.91: 'We whom you see so blasted are Italian,'
EN.92: answered one of them, through his tears,
EN.93: 'but who are you, that you inquire of us?'
EN.94: And my leader: 'I am one who makes his way
EN.95: down with this living man from ledge to ledge.
EN.96: And my intention is to show him Hell.'
EN.97: They stopped propping one another up
EN.98: and each one, trembling, turned in my direction,
EN.99: as others did who'd overheard those words.
EN.100: The good master drew up close to me,
EN.101: saying, 'Ask them what you will.'
EN.102: And I began, since this had been his wish:
EN.103: 'So that your memory may not fade away
EN.104: from minds of men in the world above
EN.105: but live on yet for many suns to come,
EN.106: 'tell me who you are, and where you hail from.
EN.107: Do not let your foul and sickening torment
EN.108: keep you from telling me your names.'
EN.109: And one of them replied: 'I was of Arezzo.
EN.110: Albero of Siena had me burned alive.
EN.111: But what I died for does not bring me here.
EN.112: 'It is true I said to him in jest:
EN.113: "I do know how to rise into the air and fly!"
EN.114: And he, who had the will but not the wit,
EN.115: 'asked me to show him how. And just because
EN.116: I failed to make him Daedalus, he had me set
EN.117: on fire by one who took him as his son.
EN.118: 'But Minos, incapable of error,
EN.119: damned me to the last of these ten ditches
EN.120: for the alchemy I practiced in the world.'
EN.121: And I said to the poet: 'Were people ever
EN.122: quite so fatuous as are the Sienese?
EN.123: Why, not even the French can match them!'
EN.124: Whereupon the other leper, hearing me,
EN.125: replied: 'Except, of course for Stricca --
EN.126: he knew how to moderate his spending --
EN.127: 'and for Niccolò -- the first one to devise
EN.128: a costly use for cloves,
EN.129: there in the garden where such seeds take root --
EN.130: 'and for that band in whose company
EN.131: Caccia d'Asciano squandered his vineyards
EN.132: and his fields, and Abbagliato showed his wit.
EN.133: 'But, to let you know who's in your camp
EN.134: against the Sienese, look close at me
EN.135: so that my face itself may answer you.
EN.136: 'You will see I am the shade of Capocchio,
EN.137: who altered metal by means of alchemy.
EN.138: And, if you are the man I take you for,
EN.139: you will recall how good an ape I was of nature.'

IT.1: Nel tempo che Iunone era crucciata
IT.2: per Semelè contra 'l sangue tebano,
IT.3: come mostrò una e altra fïata,
IT.4: Atamante divenne tanto insano,
IT.5: che veggendo la moglie con due figli
IT.6: andar carcata da ciascuna mano,
IT.7: gridò: "Tendiam le reti, sì ch'io pigli
IT.8: la leonessa e ' leoncini al varco";
IT.9: e poi distese i dispietati artigli,
IT.10: prendendo l'un ch'avea nome Learco,
IT.11: e rotollo e percosselo ad un sasso;
IT.12: e quella s'annegò con l'altro carco.
IT.13: E quando la fortuna volse in basso
IT.14: l'altezza de' Troian che tutto ardiva,
IT.15: sì che 'nsieme col regno il re fu casso,
IT.16: Ecuba trista, misera e cattiva,
IT.17: poscia che vide Polissena morta,
IT.18: e del suo Polidoro in su la riva
IT.19: del mar si fu la dolorosa accorta,
IT.20: forsennata latrò sì come cane;
IT.21: tanto il dolor le fé la mente torta.
IT.22: Ma né di Tebe furie né troiane
IT.23: si vider mäi in alcun tanto crude,
IT.24: non punger bestie, nonché membra umane,
IT.25: quant' io vidi in due ombre smorte e nude,
IT.26: che mordendo correvan di quel modo
IT.27: che 'l porco quando del porcil si schiude.
IT.28: L'una giunse a Capocchio, e in sul nodo
IT.29: del collo l'assannò, sì che, tirando,
IT.30: grattar li fece il ventre al fondo sodo.
IT.31: E l'Aretin che rimase, tremando
IT.32: mi disse: "Quel folletto è Gianni Schicchi,
IT.33: e va rabbioso altrui così conciando."
IT.34: "Oh," diss' io lui, "se l'altro non ti ficchi
IT.35: li denti a dosso, non ti sia fatica
IT.36: a dir chi è, pria che di qui si spicchi."
IT.37: Ed elli a me: "Quell' è l'anima antica
IT.38: di Mirra scellerata, che divenne
IT.39: al padre, fuor del dritto amore, amica.
IT.40: Questa a peccar con esso così venne,
IT.41: falsificando sé in altrui forma,
IT.42: come l'altro che là sen va, sostenne,
IT.43: per guadagnar la donna de la torma,
IT.44: falsificare in sé Buoso Donati,
IT.45: testando e dando al testamento norma."
IT.46: E poi che i due rabbiosi fuor passati
IT.47: sovra cu' io avea l'occhio tenuto,
IT.48: rivolsilo a guardar li altri mal nati.
IT.49: Io vidi un, fatto a guisa di lëuto,
IT.50: pur ch'elli avesse avuta l'anguinaia
IT.51: tronca da l'altro che l'uomo ha forcuto.
IT.52: La grave idropesì, che sì dispaia
IT.53: le membra con l'omor che mal converte,
IT.54: che 'l viso non risponde a la ventraia,
IT.55: faceva lui tener le labbra aperte
IT.56: come l'etico fa, che per la sete
IT.57: l'un verso 'l mento e l'altro in sù rinverte.
IT.58: "O voi che sanz' alcuna pena siete,
IT.59: e non so io perché, nel mondo gramo,"
IT.60: diss' elli a noi, "guardate e attendete
IT.61: a la miseria del maestro Adamo;
IT.62: io ebbi, vivo, assai di quel ch'i' volli,
IT.63: e ora, lasso!, un gocciol d'acqua bramo.
IT.64: Li ruscelletti che d'i verdi colli
IT.65: del Casentin discendon giuso in Arno,
IT.66: faccendo i lor canali freddi e molli,
IT.67: sempre mi stanno innanzi, e non indarno,
IT.68: ché l'imagine lor vie più m'asciuga
IT.69: che 'l male ond' io nel volto mi discarno.
IT.70: La rigida giustizia che mi fruga
IT.71: tragge cagion del loco ov' io peccai
IT.72: a metter più li miei sospiri in fuga.
IT.73: Ivi è Romena, là dov' io falsai
IT.74: la lega suggellata del Batista;
IT.75: per ch'io il corpo sù arso lasciai.
IT.76: Ma s'io vedessi qui l'anima trista
IT.77: di Guido o d'Alessandro o di lor frate,
IT.78: per Fonte Branda non darei la vista.
IT.79: Dentro c'è l'una già, se l'arrabbiate
IT.80: ombre che vanno intorno dicon vero;
IT.81: ma che mi val, c'ho le membra legate?
IT.82: S'io fossi pur di tanto ancor leggero
IT.83: ch'i' potessi in cent' anni andare un'oncia,
IT.84: io sarei messo già per lo sentiero,
IT.85: cercando lui tra questa gente sconcia,
IT.86: con tutto ch'ella volge undici miglia,
IT.87: e men d'un mezzo di traverso non ci ha.
IT.88: Io son per lor tra sì fatta famiglia;
IT.89: e' m'indussero a batter li fiorini
IT.90: ch'avevan tre carati di mondiglia."
IT.91: E io a lui: "Chi son li due tapini
IT.92: che fumman come man bagnate 'l verno,
IT.93: giacendo stretti a' tuoi destri confini?"
IT.94: "Qui li trovai -- e poi volta non dierno --,"
IT.95: rispuose, "quando piovvi in questo greppo,
IT.96: e non credo che dieno in sempiterno.
IT.97: L'una è la falsa ch'accusò Gioseppo;
IT.98: l'altr' è 'l falso Sinon greco di Troia:
IT.99: per febbre aguta gittan tanto leppo."
IT.100: E l'un di lor, che si recò a noia
IT.101: forse d'esser nomato sì oscuro,
IT.102: col pugno li percosse l'epa croia.
IT.103: Quella sonò come fosse un tamburo;
IT.104: e mastro Adamo li percosse il volto
IT.105: col braccio suo, che non parve men duro,
IT.106: dicendo a lui: "Ancor che mi sia tolto
IT.107: lo muover per le membra che son gravi,
IT.108: ho io il braccio a tal mestiere sciolto."
IT.109: Ond' ei rispuose: "Quando tu andavi
IT.110: al fuoco, non l'avei tu così presto;
IT.111: ma sì e più l'avei quando coniavi."
IT.112: E l'idropico: "Tu di' ver di questo:
IT.113: ma tu non fosti sì ver testimonio
IT.114: là 've del ver fosti a Troia richesto."
IT.115: "S'io dissi falso, e tu falsasti il conio,"
IT.116: disse Sinon; "e son qui per un fallo,
IT.117: e tu per più ch'alcun altro demonio!"
IT.118: "Ricorditi, spergiuro, del cavallo,"
IT.119: rispuose quel ch'avëa infiata l'epa;
IT.120: "e sieti reo che tutto il mondo sallo!"
IT.121: "E te sia rea la sete onde ti crepa,"
IT.122: disse 'l Greco, "la lingua, e l'acqua marcia
IT.123: che 'l ventre innanzi a li occhi sì t'assiepa!"
IT.124: Allora il monetier: "Così si squarcia
IT.125: la bocca tua per tuo mal come suole;
IT.126: ché s'i' ho sete e omor mi rinfarcia,
IT.127: tu hai l'arsura e 'l capo che ti duole,
IT.128: e per leccar lo specchio di Narcisso,
IT.129: non vorresti a 'nvitar molte parole."
IT.130: Ad ascoltarli er' io del tutto fisso,
IT.131: quando 'l maestro mi disse: "Or pur mira,
IT.132: che per poco che teco non mi risso!"
IT.133: Quand' io 'l senti' a me parlar con ira,
IT.134: volsimi verso lui con tal vergogna,
IT.135: ch'ancor per la memoria mi si gira.
IT.136: Qual è colui che suo dannaggio sogna,
IT.137: che sognando desidera sognare,
IT.138: sì che quel ch'è, come non fosse, agogna,
IT.139: tal mi fec' io, non possendo parlare,
IT.140: che disïava scusarmi, e scusava
IT.141: me tuttavia, e nol mi credea fare.
IT.142: "Maggior difetto men vergogna lava,"
IT.143: disse 'l maestro, "che 'l tuo non è stato;
IT.144: però d'ogne trestizia ti disgrava.
IT.145: E fa ragion ch'io ti sia sempre allato,
IT.146: se più avvien che fortuna t'accoglia
IT.147: dove sien genti in simigliante piato:
IT.148: ché voler ciò udire è bassa voglia."

EN.1: Once when Juno, furious with Semele,
EN.2: vented her rage against the house of Thebes,
EN.3: as she had done on more than one occasion,
EN.4: Athamas went so raving mad that when he saw
EN.5: his wife come near with both their children,
EN.6: holding one on this arm, one on that,
EN.7: he shouted: "Let's spread the nets so I can trap
EN.8: the lioness with her cubs as they go past!"
EN.9: Then he reached out and with pitiless claws
EN.10: he seized the one who was called Learchus,
EN.11: whirled him round and dashed him on a rock.
EN.12: At that she drowned herself with her other burden.
EN.13: And when Fortune had subdued the haughty,
EN.14: all-daring spirit of the Trojans,
EN.15: so that both king and kingdom were brought low,
EN.16: Hecuba -- wretched, sorrowing, a captive --
EN.17: when she saw Polyxena slaughtered and,
EN.18: grieving woman, when she saw
EN.19: Polydorus lying dead upon the shore,
EN.20: went mad and started barking like a dog,
EN.21: so greatly had her grief deranged her mind.
EN.22: But no Theban crazed with rage --
EN.23: or Trojan -- did ever seem as cruel
EN.24: in rending beasts, much less human parts,
EN.25: as did two pallid, naked shades I saw,
EN.26: snapping their jaws as they rushed up
EN.27: like swine charging from an opened sty.
EN.28: The one came at Capocchio, set its tusks
EN.29: into his neck, then dragged him
EN.30: so his belly scraped the rock-hard ground.
EN.31: And the Aretine, who stood there, trembling,
EN.32: said to me: 'That demon's Gianni Schicchi,
EN.33: and in his rabid rage he mauls the others.'
EN.34: 'Oh,' I said, 'so may that other not fix
EN.35: its teeth in you, be kind enough to tell me
EN.36: just who it is before it runs away.'
EN.37: And he answered: 'That is the ancient soul
EN.38: of wicked Myrrha, who became enamored
EN.39: of her father with more than lawful love.
EN.40: 'She contrived to sin with him
EN.41: by taking on another person's shape,
EN.42: as did that other, eager to decamp,
EN.43: 'to gain the queen mule of the herd,
EN.44: take on the shape of Buoso Donati,
EN.45: drawing up a will and giving it due form.'
EN.46: When those two frenzied shades, on whom
EN.47: I'd fixed my eyes, had hurried off,
EN.48: I turned to look at others born for sorrow.
EN.49: One I saw, fashioned like a lute --
EN.50: had he been sundered at the groin
EN.51: from the joining where a man goes forked.
EN.52: The heavy dropsy, which afflicts the body
EN.53: with its ill-digesting humor
EN.54: so that the face and belly do not match,
EN.55: forced his lips to draw apart
EN.56: as a person parched with hectic fever curls
EN.57: one lip to his chin and twists the other up.
EN.58: 'O you who go unpunished here -- I know not why --
EN.59: through this world of misery,'
EN.60: he said, 'behold and then consider
EN.61: 'the suffering of Master Adam.
EN.62: Alive, I had in plenty all I wanted.
EN.63: And now I crave a single drop of water!
EN.64: 'The streams that, in the Casentino,
EN.65: run down along green hillsides to the Arno,
EN.66: keeping their channels cool and moist,
EN.67: 'flow before my eyes forever, and not in vain,
EN.68: because their image makes me thirst still more
EN.69: than does the malady that wastes my features.
EN.70: 'The rigid justice that torments me
EN.71: employs the landscape where I sinned
EN.72: to make my sighs come faster.
EN.73: 'In those parts lies Romena, where I forged
EN.74: the coinage stamped with John the Baptist.
EN.75: For that I left my body burned above.
EN.76: 'If I could only see down here the wretched souls
EN.77: of Guido, Alessandro, or their brother,
EN.78: I'd not give up that sight for Fonte Branda.
EN.79: 'One of them is here with us already,
EN.80: if the furious shades who move about don't lie.
EN.81: What good is that to me whose limbs are bound?
EN.82: 'If I were only light enough to budge
EN.83: a single inch each hundred years,
EN.84: I would by now have started on my way
EN.85: 'to seek him out in this pit's bloated shapes,
EN.86: even though it runs eleven miles around
EN.87: and spreads not less than half a mile across.
EN.88: 'It is their fault that I have such companions,
EN.89: for it was they who made me strike the florins
EN.90: that held three carats' worth of dross.'
EN.91: And I to him: 'Who are these two wretches
EN.92: who steam as wet hands do in winter
EN.93: and lie so very near you on your right?'
EN.94: 'I found them when I rained into this trough,'
EN.95: he said, 'and even then they did not move about,
EN.96: nor do I think they will for all eternity.
EN.97: 'One is the woman who lied accusing Joseph,
EN.98: the other is false Sinon, the lying Greek from Troy.
EN.99: Putrid fever makes them reek with such a stench.'
EN.100: And one of them, who took offense, perhaps
EN.101: at being named so vilely, hit him
EN.102: with a fist right on his rigid paunch.
EN.103: It boomed out like a drum. Then Master Adam,
EN.104: whose arm seemed just as sturdy,
EN.105: used it, striking Sinon in the face,
EN.106: saying: 'Although I cannot move about
EN.107: because my legs are heavy,
EN.108: my arm is loose enough for such a task.'
EN.109: To which the other answered: 'When they put you
EN.110: to the fire, your arm was not so nimble,
EN.111: though it was quick enough when you were coining.'
EN.112: And the dropsied one: 'Well, that is true,
EN.113: but you were hardly such a truthful witness
EN.114: when you were asked to tell the truth at Troy.'
EN.115: 'If I spoke falsely, you falsified the coin,'
EN.116: said Sinon, 'and I am here for one offense alone,
EN.117: but you for more than any other devil!'
EN.118: 'You perjurer, keep the horse in mind,'
EN.119: replied the sinner with the swollen paunch,
EN.120: 'and may it pain you that the whole world knows.'
EN.121: 'And may you suffer from the thirst,' the Greek replied,
EN.122: 'that cracks your tongue, and from the fetid humor
EN.123: that turns your belly to a hedge before your eyes!'
EN.124: Then the forger: 'And so, as usual,
EN.125: your mouth gapes open from your fever.
EN.126: If I am thirsty, and swollen by this humor,
EN.127: 'you have your hot spells and your aching head.
EN.128: For you to lick the mirror of Narcissus
EN.129: would not take much by way of invitation.'
EN.130: I was all intent in listening to them,
EN.131: when the master said: 'Go right on looking
EN.132: and it is I who'll quarrel with you.'
EN.133: When I heard him speak to me in anger
EN.134: I turned and faced him with a shame
EN.135: that circles in my memory even now.
EN.136: As a man who dreams that he is being harmed
EN.137: and, even as he dreams, hopes he is dreaming,
EN.138: longing for what is, as though it weren't --
EN.139: so it was with me, deprived of speech:
EN.140: I longed to seek his pardon -- and all the while
EN.141: I did so without knowing that I did.
EN.142: 'Less shame would cleanse a greater fault than yours,'
EN.143: my master said, 'and that is why
EN.144: you may set down the load of such remorse.
EN.145: 'Do not forget I'm always at your side
EN.146: should it fall out again that fortune take you
EN.147: where people are in wrangles such as this.
EN.148: For the wish to hear such things is base.'

IT.1: Una medesma lingua pria mi morse,
IT.2: sì che mi tinse l'una e l'altra guancia,
IT.3: e poi la medicina mi riporse;
IT.4: così od' io che solea far la lancia
IT.5: d'Achille e del suo padre esser cagione
IT.6: prima di trista e poi di buona mancia.
IT.7: Noi demmo il dosso al misero vallone
IT.8: su per la ripa che 'l cinge dintorno,
IT.9: attraversando sanza alcun sermone.
IT.10: Quiv' era men che notte e men che giorno,
IT.11: sì che 'l viso m'andava innanzi poco;
IT.12: ma io senti' sonare un alto corno,
IT.13: tanto ch'avrebbe ogne tuon fatto fioco,
IT.14: che, contra sé la sua via seguitando,
IT.15: dirizzò li occhi miei tutti ad un loco.
IT.16: Dopo la dolorosa rotta, quando
IT.17: Carlo Magno perdé la santa gesta,
IT.18: non sonò sì terribilmente Orlando.
IT.19: Poco portäi in là volta la testa,
IT.20: che me parve veder molte alte torri;
IT.21: ond' io: "Maestro, dì, che terra è questa?"
IT.22: Ed elli a me: "Però che tu trascorri
IT.23: per le tenebre troppo da la lungi,
IT.24: avvien che poi nel maginare abborri.
IT.25: Tu vedrai ben, se tu là ti congiungi,
IT.26: quanto 'l senso s'inganna di lontano;
IT.27: però alquanto più te stesso pungi."
IT.28: Poi caramente mi prese per mano
IT.29: e disse: "Pria che noi siam più avanti,
IT.30: acciò che 'l fatto men ti paia strano,
IT.31: sappi che non son torri, ma giganti,
IT.32: e son nel pozzo intorno da la ripa
IT.33: da l'umbilico in giuso tutti quanti."
IT.34: Come quando la nebbia si dissipa,
IT.35: lo sguardo a poco a poco raffigura
IT.36: ciò che cela 'l vapor che l'aere stipa,
IT.37: così forando l'aura grossa e scura,
IT.38: più e più appressando ver' la sponda,
IT.39: fuggiemi errore e crescémi paura;
IT.40: però che, come su la cerchia tonda
IT.41: Montereggion di torri si corona,
IT.42: così la proda che 'l pozzo circonda
IT.43: torreggiavan di mezza la persona
IT.44: li orribili giganti, cui minaccia
IT.45: Giove del cielo ancora quando tuona.
IT.46: E io scorgeva già d'alcun la faccia,
IT.47: le spalle e 'l petto e del ventre gran parte,
IT.48: e per le coste giù ambo le braccia.
IT.49: Natura certo, quando lasciò l'arte
IT.50: di sì fatti animali, assai fé bene
IT.51: per tòrre tali essecutori a Marte.
IT.52: E s'ella d'elefanti e di balene
IT.53: non si pente, chi guarda sottilmente,
IT.54: più giusta e più discreta la ne tene;
IT.55: ché dove l'argomento de la mente
IT.56: s'aggiugne al mal volere e a la possa,
IT.57: nessun riparo vi può far la gente.
IT.58: La faccia sua mi parea lunga e grossa
IT.59: come la pina di San Pietro a Roma,
IT.60: e a sua proporzione eran l'altre ossa;
IT.61: sì che la ripa, ch'era perizoma
IT.62: dal mezzo in giù, ne mostrava ben tanto
IT.63: di sovra, che di giugnere a la chioma
IT.64: tre Frison s'averien dato mal vanto;
IT.65: però ch'i' ne vedea trenta gran palmi
IT.66: dal loco in giù dov' omo affibbia 'l manto.
IT.67: "Raphèl maì amècche zabì almi,"
IT.68: cominciò a gridar la fiera bocca,
IT.69: cui non si convenia più dolci salmi.
IT.70: E 'l duca mio ver' lui: "Anima sciocca,
IT.71: tienti col corno, e con quel ti disfoga
IT.72: quand' ira o altra passïon ti tocca!
IT.73: Cércati al collo, e troverai la soga
IT.74: che 'l tien legato, o anima confusa,
IT.75: e vedi lui che 'l gran petto ti doga."
IT.76: Poi disse a me: "Elli stessi s'accusa;
IT.77: questi è Nembrotto per lo cui mal coto
IT.78: pur un linguaggio nel mondo non s'usa.
IT.79: Lasciànlo stare e non parliamo a vòto;
IT.80: ché così è a lui ciascun linguaggio
IT.81: come 'l suo ad altrui, ch'a nullo è noto."
IT.82: Facemmo adunque più lungo vïaggio,
IT.83: vòlti a sinistra; e al trar d'un balestro
IT.84: trovammo l'altro assai più fero e maggio.
IT.85: A cigner lui qual che fosse 'l maestro,
IT.86: non so io dir, ma el tenea soccinto
IT.87: dinanzi l'altro e dietro il braccio destro
IT.88: d'una catena che 'l tenea avvinto
IT.89: dal collo in giù, sì che 'n su lo scoperto
IT.90: si ravvolgëa infino al giro quinto.
IT.91: "Questo superbo volle esser esperto
IT.92: di sua potenza contra 'l sommo Giove,"
IT.93: disse 'l mio duca, "ond' elli ha cotal merto.
IT.94: Fïalte ha nome, e fece le gran prove
IT.95: quando i giganti fer paura a' dèi;
IT.96: le braccia ch'el menò, già mai non move."
IT.97: E io a lui: "S'esser puote, io vorrei
IT.98: che de lo smisurato Brïareo
IT.99: esperïenza avesser li occhi mei."
IT.100: Ond' ei rispuose: "Tu vedrai Anteo
IT.101: presso di qui che parla ed è disciolto,
IT.102: che ne porrà nel fondo d'ogne reo.
IT.103: Quel che tu vuo' veder, più là è molto
IT.104: ed è legato e fatto come questo,
IT.105: salvo che più feroce par nel volto."
IT.106: Non fu tremoto già tanto rubesto,
IT.107: che scotesse una torre così forte,
IT.108: come Fïalte a scuotersi fu presto.
IT.109: Allor temett' io più che mai la morte,
IT.110: e non v'era mestier più che la dotta,
IT.111: s'io non avessi viste le ritorte.
IT.112: Noi procedemmo più avante allotta,
IT.113: e venimmo ad Anteo, che ben cinque alle,
IT.114: sanza la testa, uscia fuor de la grotta.
IT.115: "O tu che ne la fortunata valle
IT.116: che fece Scipïon di gloria reda,
IT.117: quand' Anibàl co' suoi diede le spalle,
IT.118: recasti già mille leon per preda,
IT.119: e che, se fossi stato a l'alta guerra
IT.120: de' tuoi fratelli, ancor par che si creda
IT.121: ch'avrebber vinto i figli de la terra:
IT.122: mettine giù, e non ten vegna schifo,
IT.123: dove Cocito la freddura serra.
IT.124: Non ci fare ire a Tizio né a Tifo:
IT.125: questi può dar di quel che qui si brama;
IT.126: però ti china e non torcer lo grifo.
IT.127: Ancor ti può nel mondo render fama,
IT.128: ch'el vive, e lunga vita ancor aspetta
IT.129: se 'nnanzi tempo grazia a sé nol chiama."
IT.130: Così disse 'l maestro; e quelli in fretta
IT.131: le man distese, e prese 'l duca mio,
IT.132: ond' Ercule sentì già grande stretta.
IT.133: Virgilio, quando prender si sentio,
IT.134: disse a me: "Fatti qua, sì ch'io ti prenda";
IT.135: poi fece sì ch'un fascio era elli e io.
IT.136: Qual pare a riguardar la Carisenda
IT.137: sotto 'l chinato, quando un nuvol vada
IT.138: sovr' essa sì, ched ella incontro penda:
IT.139: tal parve Antëo a me che stava a bada
IT.140: di vederlo chinare, e fu tal ora
IT.141: ch'i' avrei voluto ir per altra strada.
IT.142: Ma lievemente al fondo che divora
IT.143: Lucifero con Giuda, ci sposò;
IT.144: né, sì chinato, li fece dimora,
IT.145: e come albero in nave si levò.

EN.1: The same tongue that had stung me
EN.2: so that both my cheeks turned red,
EN.3: had also brought my cure,
EN.4: just as the spear of Achilles and his father --
EN.5: so I have heard it told -- would be the cause
EN.6: first of a painful, then a welcome, gift.
EN.7: We turned our backs upon that dismal valley,
EN.8: first climbing up the bank that circles it,
EN.9: then crossing over, while speaking not a word.
EN.10: Here it was less than night and less than day --
EN.11: I could not see too far ahead.
EN.12: But I heard a horn-blast that would have made
EN.13: the loudest thunderclap seem faint.
EN.14: To find its source I turned my eyes
EN.15: back to the place from which the din had come.
EN.16: After the woeful rout when Charlemagne
EN.17: had lost his holy band of knights,
EN.18: Roland did not sound so terrible a blast.
EN.19: I had not looked that way for long
EN.20: when I saw what seemed a range of lofty towers,
EN.21: and I said: 'Master, tell me, what city is this?'
EN.22: And he to me: 'Because you try to pierce
EN.23: the darkness from too far away,
EN.24: it follows that you err in your perception.
EN.25: 'When you are nearer, you will understand
EN.26: how much your eyesight is deceived by distance.
EN.27: Therefore, push yourself a little harder.'
EN.28: Then with affection he took me by the hand
EN.29: and said: 'Before we travel farther,
EN.30: and so the fact may seem to you less strange,
EN.31: 'you should be told: these are not towers,
EN.32: but giants and, from the navel down,
EN.33: each stands behind the bank that rings the pit.'
EN.34: As, when the mist is lifting,
EN.35: little by little we discern things
EN.36: hidden in the air made thick by fog,
EN.37: so, when my eyes saw through the heavy dark
EN.38: and I got nearer to the brink,
EN.39: error left me and fear came in its place.
EN.40: For, as all around her ring of walls
EN.41: Monteriggioni is crowned with towers,
EN.42: so at the cliff-edge that surrounds the pit
EN.43: loomed up like towers half the body bulk
EN.44: of horrifying giants, those whom Jove
EN.45: still threatens from the heavens when he thunders.
EN.46: Now I could discern the face of one,
EN.47: his chest and shoulders, a portion of his paunch,
EN.48: and, hanging at his sides, his arms.
EN.49: Surely nature did well when she renounced
EN.50: the craft of making creatures such as these,
EN.51: depriving Mars of such practitioners.
EN.52: If she does not repent her elephants
EN.53: and whales, when one reviews the matter closely
EN.54: she will be found more cautious and more just.
EN.55: For when the power of thought
EN.56: is coupled with ill will and naked force
EN.57: there is no refuge from it for mankind.
EN.58: His face appeared to me as long and broad
EN.59: as is, in Rome, the pine cone at St. Peter's,
EN.60: his other parts as large in like degree,
EN.61: so that the bank, which hid him like an apron
EN.62: from his middle downwards, still showed
EN.63: so much of him above that quite in vain
EN.64: three Frieslanders might boast of having reached
EN.65: his hair. For I saw thirty spans of him
EN.66: beneath the place where men make fast their cloaks.
EN.67: 'Raphèl maì amècche zabì almi,'
EN.68: the savage mouth, for which no sweeter
EN.69: psalms were fit, began to shout.
EN.70: And, in response, my leader: 'You muddled soul,
EN.71: stick to your horn! Vent yourself with that
EN.72: when rage or other passion takes you.
EN.73: 'Search at your neck, you creature of confusion,
EN.74: and you will find the rope that holds the horn
EN.75: aslant your mammoth chest.'
EN.76: Then he to me: 'He is his own accuser.
EN.77: This is Nimrod, because of whose vile plan
EN.78: the world no longer speaks a single tongue.
EN.79: 'Let us leave him and not waste our speech,
EN.80: for every language is to him as his
EN.81: to others, and his is understood by none.'
EN.82: Then, turning to our left, we continued
EN.83: with our journey. A bowshot farther on
EN.84: we found the next one, bigger and more savage.
EN.85: Now who had plied his craft to bind him so
EN.86: I cannot say, but his right arm
EN.87: was bound behind him, the other one in front,
EN.88: by chains that from the neck down held him fixed.
EN.89: They wound five times around his bulk
EN.90: on the part of him that we could see.
EN.91: 'This prideful spirit chose to test his strength
EN.92: against almighty Jove,' my leader said,
EN.93: 'and this is his reward.
EN.94: 'He is Ephialtes. He joined the great assault
EN.95: when giants put the gods in fear.
EN.96: Those arms he brandished he can move no more.'
EN.97: And I to him: 'If it is allowed,
EN.98: I'd like to see with my own eyes
EN.99: Briareus and his immeasurable bulk.'
EN.100: He replied: 'It is Antaeus you shall see.
EN.101: He is close by, he speaks, he is not fettered.
EN.102: And he shall set us down into the very depth of sin.
EN.103: 'The one you want to see is farther on,
EN.104: in fetters also, shaped like this one here,
EN.105: except that from his looks he seems more fierce.'
EN.106: Never did mighty earthquake shake a tower
EN.107: with such great speed and force
EN.108: as Ephialtes shook himself at that.
EN.109: Then more than ever I was afraid of dying:
EN.110: my fear alone would have sufficed to bring it on,
EN.111: had I not noted how tightly he was bound.
EN.112: Going farther on, we came upon Antaeus.
EN.113: Without the added measure of his head,
EN.114: he stood a full five ells above the pit.
EN.115: 'O you, who -- in the fateful valley
EN.116: that made Scipio an heir to glory,
EN.117: when Hannibal with all his men displayed their backs--
EN.118: 'you, who took as prey a thousand lions,
EN.119: and by whose strength, it seems some do believe,
EN.120: had you been at the war on Heaven with your brethren,
EN.121: 'the sons of earth would have prevailed --
EN.122: pray set us down, do not disdain to do so,
EN.123: upon Cocytus, shackled by the cold.
EN.124: 'Don't make us go to Tityus or Typhon.
EN.125: This man can give what everyone here longs for.
EN.126: Therefore bend down and do not curl your lip.
EN.127: 'He still can make you famous in the world,
EN.128: because he lives, and hopes for years of living,
EN.129: if Grace does not recall him sooner than his time.'
EN.130: Thus spoke the master. The other was quick
EN.131: to reach out with his hands -- the mighty grip
EN.132: once felt by Hercules -- and seized my guide.
EN.133: Virgil, when he felt himself secured, said:
EN.134: 'Here, let me take hold of you!'
EN.135: Then he made a single bundle of himself and me.
EN.136: As when one sees the tower called Garisenda
EN.137: from underneath its leaning side, and then a cloud
EN.138: passes over and it seems to lean the more,
EN.139: thus did Antaeus seem to my fixed gaze
EN.140: as I watched him bend -- that was indeed a time
EN.141: I wished that I had gone another road.
EN.142: Even so, he set us gently on the bottom
EN.143: that swallows Lucifer with Judas.
EN.144: Nor in stooping did he linger
EN.145: but, like a ship's mast rising, so he rose.

IT.1: S'ïo avessi le rime aspre e chiocce,
IT.2: come si converrebbe al tristo buco
IT.3: sovra 'l qual pontan tutte l'altre rocce,
IT.4: io premerei di mio concetto il suco
IT.5: più pienamente; ma perch' io non l'abbo,
IT.6: non sanza tema a dicer mi conduco;
IT.7: ché non è impresa da pigliare a gabbo
IT.8: discriver fondo a tutto l'universo,
IT.9: né da lingua che chiami mamma o babbo.
IT.10: Ma quelle donne aiutino il mio verso
IT.11: ch'aiutaro Anfïone a chiuder Tebe,
IT.12: sì che dal fatto il dir non sia diverso.
IT.13: Oh sovra tutte mal creata plebe
IT.14: che stai nel loco onde parlare è duro,
IT.15: mei foste state qui pecore o zebe!
IT.16: Come noi fummo giù nel pozzo scuro
IT.17: sotto i piè del gigante assai più bassi,
IT.18: e io mirava ancora a l'alto muro,
IT.19: dicere udi'mi: "Guarda come passi:
IT.20: va sì, che tu non calchi con le piante
IT.21: le teste de' fratei miseri lassi."
IT.22: Per ch'io mi volsi, e vidimi davante
IT.23: e sotto i piedi un lago che per gelo
IT.24: avea di vetro e non d'acqua sembiante.
IT.25: Non fece al corso suo sì grosso velo
IT.26: di verno la Danoia in Osterlicchi,
IT.27: né Tanaï là sotto 'l freddo cielo,
IT.28: com' era quivi; che se Tambernicchi
IT.29: vi fosse sù caduto, o Pietrapana,
IT.30: non avria pur da l'orlo fatto cricchi.
IT.31: E come a gracidar si sta la rana
IT.32: col muso fuor de l'acqua, quando sogna
IT.33: di spigolar sovente la villana,
IT.34: livide, insin là dove appar vergogna
IT.35: eran l'ombre dolenti ne la ghiaccia,
IT.36: mettendo i denti in nota di cicogna.
IT.37: Ognuna in giù tenea volta la faccia;
IT.38: da bocca il freddo, e da li occhi il cor tristo
IT.39: tra lor testimonianza si procaccia.
IT.40: Quand' io m'ebbi dintorno alquanto visto,
IT.41: volsimi a' piedi, e vidi due sì stretti,
IT.42: che 'l pel del capo avieno insieme misto.
IT.43: "Ditemi, voi che sì strignete i petti,"
IT.44: diss' io, "chi siete?" E quei piegaro i colli;
IT.45: e poi ch'ebber li visi a me eretti,
IT.46: li occhi lor, ch'eran pria pur dentro molli,
IT.47: gocciar su per le labbra, e 'l gelo strinse
IT.48: le lagrime tra essi e riserrolli.
IT.49: Con legno legno spranga mai non cinse
IT.50: forte così; ond' ei come due becchi
IT.51: cozzaro insieme, tanta ira li vinse.
IT.52: E un ch'avea perduti ambo li orecchi
IT.53: per la freddura, pur col viso in giùe,
IT.54: disse: "Perché cotanto in noi ti specchi?
IT.55: Se vuoi saper chi son cotesti due,
IT.56: la valle onde Bisenzo si dichina
IT.57: del padre loro Alberto e di lor fue.
IT.58: D'un corpo usciro; e tutta la Caina
IT.59: potrai cercare, e non troverai ombra
IT.60: degna più d'esser fitta in gelatina:
IT.61: non quelli a cui fu rotto il petto e l'ombra
IT.62: con esso un colpo per la man d'Artù;
IT.63: non Focaccia; non questi che m'ingombra
IT.64: col capo sì, ch'i' non veggio oltre più,
IT.65: e fu nomato Sassol Mascheroni;
IT.66: se tosco se', ben sai omai chi fu.
IT.67: E perché non mi metti in più sermoni,
IT.68: sappi ch'i' fu' il Camiscion de' Pazzi;
IT.69: e aspetto Carlin che mi scagioni."
IT.70: Poscia vid' io mille visi cagnazzi
IT.71: fatti per freddo; onde mi vien riprezzo,
IT.72: e verrà sempre, de' gelati guazzi.
IT.73: E mentre ch'andavamo inver' lo mezzo
IT.74: al quale ogne gravezza si rauna,
IT.75: e io tremava ne l'etterno rezzo;
IT.76: se voler fu o destino o fortuna,
IT.77: non so; ma, passeggiando tra le teste,
IT.78: forte percossi 'l piè nel viso ad una.
IT.79: Piangendo mi sgridò: "Perché mi peste?
IT.80: se tu non vieni a crescer la vendetta
IT.81: di Montaperti, perché mi moleste?"
IT.82: E io: "Maestro mio, or qui m'aspetta,
IT.83: sì ch'io esca d'un dubbio per costui;
IT.84: poi mi farai, quantunque vorrai, fretta."
IT.85: Lo duca stette, e io dissi a colui
IT.86: che bestemmiava duramente ancora:
IT.87: "Qual se' tu che così rampogni altrui?"
IT.88: "Or tu chi se' che vai per l'Antenora,
IT.89: percotendo," rispuose, "altrui le gote,
IT.90: sì che, se fossi vivo, troppo fora?"
IT.91: "Vivo son io, e caro esser ti puote,"
IT.92: fu mia risposta, "se dimandi fama,
IT.93: ch'io metta il nome tuo tra l'altre note."
IT.94: Ed elli a me: "Del contrario ho io brama.
IT.95: Lèvati quinci e non mi dar più lagna,
IT.96: ché mal sai lusingar per questa lama!"
IT.97: Allor lo presi per la cuticagna
IT.98: e dissi: "El converrà che tu ti nomi,
IT.99: o che capel qui sù non ti rimagna."
IT.100: Ond' elli a me: "Perché tu mi dischiomi,
IT.101: né ti dirò ch'io sia, né mosterrolti
IT.102: se mille fiate in sul capo mi tomi."
IT.103: Io avea già i capelli in mano avvolti,
IT.104: e tratti glien' avea più d'una ciocca,
IT.105: latrando lui con li occhi in giù raccolti,
IT.106: quando un altro gridò: "Che hai tu, Bocca?
IT.107: non ti basta sonar con le mascelle,
IT.108: se tu non latri? qual diavol ti tocca?"
IT.109: "Omai," diss' io, "non vo' che più favelle,
IT.110: malvagio traditor; ch'a la tua onta
IT.111: io porterò di te vere novelle."
IT.112: "Va via," rispuose, "e ciò che tu vuoi conta;
IT.113: ma non tacer, se tu di qua entro eschi,
IT.114: di quel ch'ebbe or così la lingua pronta.
IT.115: El piange qui l'argento de' Franceschi:
IT.116: 'Io vidi,' potrai dir, 'quel da Duera
IT.117: là dove i peccatori stanno freschi.'
IT.118: Se fossi domandato 'Altri chi v'era?'
IT.119: tu hai dallato quel di Beccheria
IT.120: di cui segò Fiorenza la gorgiera.
IT.121: Gianni de' Soldanier credo che sia
IT.122: più là con Ganellone e Tebaldello,
IT.123: ch'aprì Faenza quando si dormia."
IT.124: Noi eravam partiti già da ello,
IT.125: ch'io vidi due ghiacciati in una buca,
IT.126: sì che l'un capo a l'altro era cappello;
IT.127: e come 'l pan per fame si manduca,
IT.128: così 'l sovran li denti a l'altro pose
IT.129: là 've 'l cervel s'aggiugne con la nuca:
IT.130: non altrimenti Tidëo si rose
IT.131: le tempie a Menalippo per disdegno,
IT.132: che quei faceva il teschio e l'altre cose.
IT.133: "O tu che mostri per sì bestial segno
IT.134: odio sovra colui che tu ti mangi,
IT.135: dimmi 'l perché," diss' io, "per tal convegno,
IT.136: che se tu a ragion di lui ti piangi,
IT.137: sappiendo chi voi siete e la sua pecca,
IT.138: nel mondo suso ancora io te ne cangi,
IT.139: se quella con ch'io parlo non si secca."

EN.1: If I had verses harsh enough and rasping
EN.2: as would befit this dismal hole
EN.3: upon which all the other rocks weigh down,
EN.4: more fully would I press out the juice
EN.5: of my conception. But, since I lack them,
EN.6: with misgiving do I bring myself to speak.
EN.7: It is no enterprise undertaken lightly --
EN.8: to describe the very bottom of the universe --
EN.9: nor for a tongue that still cries 'mommy' and 'daddy.'
EN.10: But may those ladies who aided Amphion
EN.11: to build the walls of Thebes now aid my verse,
EN.12: that the telling be no different from the fact.
EN.13: O you misgotten rabble, worse than all the rest,
EN.14: who fill that place so hard to speak of,
EN.15: better had you here been sheep or goats!
EN.16: When we were down in that ditch's darkness,
EN.17: well below the giant's feet,
EN.18: my gaze still drawn by the wall above us,
EN.19: I heard a voice say: 'Watch where you walk.
EN.20: Step so as not to tread upon our heads,
EN.21: the heads of wretched, weary brothers.'
EN.22: At that I turned to look about.
EN.23: Under my feet I saw a lake
EN.24: so frozen that it seemed more glass than water.
EN.25: Never in winter did the Austrian Danube
EN.26: nor the far-off Don, under its frigid sky,
EN.27: cover their currents with so thick a veil
EN.28: as I saw there. For had Tambernic fallen on it,
EN.29: or Pietrapana, the ice would not
EN.30: have creaked, not even at the edge.
EN.31: And as frogs squat and croak,
EN.32: their snouts out of the water, in the season
EN.33: when peasant women often dream of gleaning,
EN.34: so shades, ashen with cold, were grieving, trapped
EN.35: in ice up to the place the hue of shame appears,
EN.36: their teeth a-clatter like the bills of storks.
EN.37: Downturned were all their faces, their mouths
EN.38: gave witness to the cold, while from their eyes
EN.39: came testimony of their woeful hearts.
EN.40: I gazed around a while; then I looked down
EN.41: and saw two shades so shackled to each other
EN.42: their two heads' hair made but a single skein.
EN.43: 'Tell me, you with chests pressed close,' I said,
EN.44: 'who are you?' They strained their necks,
EN.45: and, when they had raised their faces,
EN.46: their eyes, till then moist only to the rims,
EN.47: dripped tears down to their lips, and icy air
EN.48: then froze those tears -- and them to one another.
EN.49: Clamp never gripped together board to board
EN.50: so tight, at which such anger overcame them
EN.51: they butted at each other like two rams.
EN.52: And one of the others, who'd lost both ears
EN.53: to the cold, and kept his face averted, said:
EN.54: 'Why do you reflect yourself so long in us?
EN.55: 'If you would like to know who these two are,
EN.56: the valley out of which Bisenzio flows
EN.57: belonged once to their father, Albert, and to them.
EN.58: 'From a single womb they sprang, and though you seek
EN.59: throughout Caïna, you will find no shade
EN.60: more fit to be fixed in aspic,
EN.61: 'not him whose breast and shadow were pierced
EN.62: by a single blow from Arthur's hand,
EN.63: nor Focaccia, nor the one whose head so blocks
EN.64: 'my view that I cannot see past him
EN.65: and whose name was Sassol Mascheroni --
EN.66: if you are Tuscan you know well who he was.
EN.67: 'And, so you coax no further words from me,
EN.68: know that I was Camiscion de' Pazzi,
EN.69: and I await Carlino for my exculpation.'
EN.70: After that I saw a thousand faces purple
EN.71: with the cold, so that I shudder still --
EN.72: and always will -- when I come to a frozen ford.
EN.73: Then, while we made our way toward the center,
EN.74: where all things that have weight converge,
EN.75: and I was shivering in the eternal chill,
EN.76: if it was will or fate or chance
EN.77: I do not know, but, walking among the heads,
EN.78: I struck my foot hard in the face of one.
EN.79: Wailing, he cried out: 'Why trample me?
EN.80: Unless you come to add to the revenge
EN.81: for Montaperti, why pick on me?'
EN.82: And I: 'Master, would you wait for just a moment
EN.83: so that I may resolve a doubt about this person.
EN.84: And then I'll make what haste you like.'
EN.85: My leader stopped, and I said to the shade,
EN.86: who was still shouting bitter curses:
EN.87: 'And who are you, so to reproach another?'
EN.88: 'No, who are you to go through Antenora,'
EN.89: he answered, 'buffeting another's cheeks?
EN.90: Were I alive, this still would be an outrage.'
EN.91: 'Well, I'm alive,' I said, 'and if it's fame you seek,
EN.92: it might turn out to your advantage
EN.93: if I put your name among the others I have noted.'
EN.94: And he: 'I long for just the opposite.
EN.95: Take yourself off and trouble me no more --
EN.96: you ill know how to flatter at this depth.'
EN.97: Then I grabbed him by the scruff of the neck
EN.98: and said: 'Either you name yourself
EN.99: or I'll leave you without a single hair.'
EN.100: And he: 'You can peel me bald and I
EN.101: won't tell you who I am, nor give a hint,
EN.102: even if you jump upon my head a thousand times.'
EN.103: I now had his hair twisted in my hand
EN.104: and had already plucked a tuft or two,
EN.105: while he howled on, keeping his eyes cast down,
EN.106: when another cried: 'What ails you, Bocca?
EN.107: Isn't it enough, making noise with your jaws,
EN.108: without that howling too? What devil's at you?'
EN.109: 'Now you no longer need to say a word,
EN.110: vile traitor,' said I, 'to your shame
EN.111: shall I bring back true news of you.'
EN.112: 'Be off,' he answered, 'and tell what tale you will.
EN.113: But don't be silent, if you escape from here,
EN.114: about the one whose tongue was now so nimble.
EN.115: 'Here he laments the Frenchmen's silver.
EN.116: "I saw him of Duera," you can say,
EN.117: "there where they set the sinners out to cool."
EN.118: 'And if someone were to ask you: "Who else was there?"
EN.119: beside you is the one from Beccherìa --
EN.120: Florence sawed his throat in two.
EN.121: 'I think Gianni de' Soldanier is farther on,
EN.122: with Ganelon and Tebaldello,
EN.123: who opened up Faenza while it slept.'
EN.124: We had left him behind when I took note
EN.125: of two souls so frozen in a single hole
EN.126: the head of one served as the other's hat.
EN.127: As a famished man will bite into his bread,
EN.128: the one above had set his teeth into the other
EN.129: just where the brain's stem leaves the spinal cord.
EN.130: Tydeus gnawed the temples of Melanippus
EN.131: with bitter hatred just as he was doing
EN.132: to the skull and to the other parts.
EN.133: 'O you, who by so bestial a sign
EN.134: show loathing for the one whom you devour,
EN.135: tell me why,' I said, 'and let the pact be this:
EN.136: 'if you can give just cause for your complaint,
EN.137: then I, knowing who you are and what his sin is,
EN.138: may yet requite you in the world above,
EN.139: if that with which I speak does not go dry.'

EN.1: He raised his mouth from his atrocious meal,
EN.2: that sinner, and wiped it on the hair
EN.3: of the very head he had been ravaging.
EN.4: Then he began: 'You ask me to revive
EN.5: the desperate grief that racks my heart
EN.6: even in thought, before I tell it.
EN.7: 'But if my words shall be the seeds that bear
EN.8: infamous fruit to the traitor I am gnawing,
EN.9: then you will see me speak and weep together.
EN.10: 'I don't know who you are, nor by what means
EN.11: you have come down here, but when I listen to you speak,
EN.12: it seems to me you are indeed from Florence.
EN.13: 'Take note that I was Count Ugolino,
EN.14: and he Archbishop Ruggieri. Let me
EN.15: tell you why I'm such a neighbor to him.
EN.16: 'How, as consummation of his malicious schemes,
EN.17: after I'd lodged my trust in him, he had me seized
EN.18: and put to death, there is no need to tell.
EN.19: 'But when you learn what you cannot have heard --
EN.20: that is to say, the cruelty of my death --
EN.21: then you shall know if he has wronged me.
EN.22: 'A little spyhole in the Mew, which now
EN.23: on my account is called the Tower of Hunger,
EN.24: where others yet shall be imprisoned,
EN.25: 'had through its opening shown me several moons,
EN.26: when, in a dreadful dream,
EN.27: the veil was rent, and I foresaw the future.
EN.28: 'This man appeared to be the lord and master,
EN.29: hunting the wolf and wolfcubs on the mountain
EN.30: that hides Lucca from the sight of Pisans.
EN.31: 'Along with well-trained hounds, lean and eager,
EN.32: he had ranged in his front rank
EN.33: Gualandi, Sismondi, and Lanfranchi.
EN.34: 'Father and sons, after a brief pursuit,
EN.35: seemed to be flagging, and it seemed to me I saw
EN.36: the flesh torn from their flanks by sharp incisors.
EN.37: 'When I awoke before the dawn of day
EN.38: I heard my children, in that prison with me,
EN.39: weep in their sleep and ask for bread.
EN.40: 'You are cruel indeed, thinking what my heart
EN.41: foretold, if you remain untouched by grief,
EN.42: and if you weep not, what can make you weep?
EN.43: 'Now they were awake, and the hour drew near
EN.44: at which our food was brought to us.
EN.45: Each of us was troubled by his dream.
EN.46: 'Down below I heard them nailing shut
EN.47: the entry to the dreadful tower. I looked
EN.48: my children in the face, without a word.
EN.49: 'I was so turned to stone inside I did not weep.
EN.50: But they were weeping, and my little Anselm
EN.51: said: "You look so strange, father, what's wrong?"
EN.52: 'Even then I shed no tear, and made no answer
EN.53: all that day, and all the night that followed
EN.54: until the next day's sun came forth upon the world.
EN.55: 'As soon as some few rays had made their way
EN.56: into the woeful prison, and I discerned
EN.57: four other faces stamped with my expression,
EN.58: 'the sorrow of it made me gnaw my hands.
EN.59: And they, imagining I was doing this
EN.60: from hunger, rose at once, saying:
EN.61: '"Father, we would suffer less
EN.62: if you would feed on us: you clothed us
EN.63: in this wretched flesh -- now strip it off."
EN.64: 'Then, not to increase their grief, I calmed myself.
EN.65: That day and the next we did not speak a word.
EN.66: O hard earth, why did you not engulf us?
EN.67: 'When we had come as far as the fourth day
EN.68: my Gaddo threw himself on the ground before me,
EN.69: crying, "O father, why won't you help me?"
EN.70: 'There he died; and even as you see me now
EN.71: I watched the other three die, one by one,
EN.72: on the fifth day and the sixth. And I began,
EN.73: 'already blind, to grope over their bodies,
EN.74: and for two days called to them, though they were dead.
EN.75: Then fasting had more power than grief.'
EN.76: Having said this, with maddened eyes he seized
EN.77: that wretched skull again between his teeth
EN.78: and clenched them on the bone just like a dog.
EN.79: Ah Pisa, how you shame the people
EN.80: of that fair land where 'sì' is heard!
EN.81: Since your neighbors are so slow to punish you,
EN.82: may the islands of Capraia and Gorgona
EN.83: move in to block the Arno at its mouth
EN.84: and so drown every living soul in you!
EN.85: Even if Count Ugolino bore the name
EN.86: of traitor to your castles, you still
EN.87: should not have put his children to such torture.
EN.88: Their tender years, you modern Thebes,
EN.89: made Uguiccione and Brigata innocent,
EN.90: and the other two this canto names above.
EN.91: We went on farther, to where the ice-crust
EN.92: rudely wraps another sort of souls,
EN.93: their faces not turned down but up.
EN.94: The very weeping there prevents their weeping,
EN.95: for the grief that meets a barrier at the eyelids
EN.96: turns inward to augment their anguish,
EN.97: since their first tears become a crust
EN.98: that like a crystal visor fills
EN.99: the cups beneath the eyebrows.
EN.100: Although the cold had made
EN.101: all feeling leave my face
EN.102: as though it were a callus,
EN.103: I still could feel a breath of wind.
EN.104: And I said: 'Master, who sets this in motion?
EN.105: Are not all winds banished here below?'
EN.106: Thus he to me: 'You will come soon enough
EN.107: to where your eyes will give an answer,
EN.108: seeing the source that puts out such a blast.'
EN.109: And one of the wretches in the icy crust
EN.110: cried out: 'O souls, so hard of heart
EN.111: you are assigned the lowest station,
EN.112: 'lift from my face these rigid veils
EN.113: so I can vent a while the grief that swells
EN.114: my heart, until my tears freeze up again.'
EN.115: 'If you want my help, let me know your name,'
EN.116: I answered. 'Then, if I do not relieve you,
EN.117: may I have to travel to the bottom of the ice.'
EN.118: He spoke: 'I am Fra Alberigo. I am he
EN.119: who harvested the evil orchard,
EN.120: and here, for figs, I am repaid in dates.'
EN.121: 'Oh,' said I to him, 'are you already dead?'
EN.122: And he to me: 'I have no knowledge
EN.123: how my body fares in the world above.
EN.124: 'Such privilege has this Ptolomea,
EN.125: that many times a soul may fall down here
EN.126: well before Atropos has cut it loose.
EN.127: 'So that you may be all the more inclined
EN.128: to scrape these tear-drops glazed upon my face,
EN.129: know that the moment when a soul betrays
EN.130: 'as I did, its body is taken by a devil,
EN.131: who has it then in his control
EN.132: until the time allotted it has run.
EN.133: 'The soul falls headlong to this cesspool.
EN.134: Perhaps the body of this shade, who spends
EN.135: the winter with me here, still walks the earth,
EN.136: 'as you must know, if you've come down just now.
EN.137: He is Branca d'Oria. Quite some years
EN.138: have passed since he was thus confined.'
EN.139: 'I think,' I said to him, 'you're fooling me.
EN.140: For Branca d'Oria is not yet dead: he eats
EN.141: and drinks and sleeps and puts on clothes.'
EN.142: 'In the ditch above, of the Malebranche,'
EN.143: he said, 'where the clingy pitch is at the boil,
EN.144: Michel Zanche had not yet arrived
EN.145: 'when this man left a devil in his stead
EN.146: to own his body, as did his kinsman,
EN.147: his partner in the treacherous act.
EN.148: 'But now extend your hand and open
EN.149: my eyes for me.' I did not open them.
EN.150: And to be rude to him was courtesy.
EN.151: O men of Genoa, race estranged
EN.152: from every virtue, crammed with every vice,
EN.153: why have you not been driven from the earth?
EN.154: With the most heinous spirit of Romagna
EN.155: I found a son of yours who, for his evil deeds,
EN.156: even now in Cocytus bathes his soul
EN.157: while yet his body moves among the living.
