IT.9: al duca mio, ché non lì era altra grotta.
IT.10: Già era, e con paura il metto in metro,
IT.11: là dove l'ombre tutte eran coperte,
IT.12: e trasparien come festuca in vetro.
IT.13: Altre sono a giacere; altre stanno erte,
IT.14: quella col capo e quella con le piante;
IT.15: altra, com' arco, il volto a' piè rinverte.
IT.16: Quando noi fummo fatti tanto avante,
IT.17: ch'al mio maestro piacque di mostrarmi
IT.18: la creatura ch'ebbe il bel sembiante,
IT.19: d'innanzi mi si tolse e fé restarmi,
IT.20: "Ecco Dite," dicendo, "ed ecco il loco
IT.21: ove convien che di fortezza t'armi."
IT.22: Com' io divenni allor gelato e fioco,
IT.23: nol dimandar, lettor, ch'i' non lo scrivo,
IT.24: però ch'ogne parlar sarebbe poco.
IT.25: Io non mori' e non rimasi vivo;
IT.26: pensa oggimai per te, s'hai fior d'ingegno,
IT.27: qual io divenni, d'uno e d'altro privo.
IT.28: Lo 'mperador del doloroso regno
IT.29: da mezzo 'l petto uscia fuor de la ghiaccia;
IT.30: e più con un gigante io mi convegno,
IT.31: che i giganti non fan con le sue braccia:
IT.32: vedi oggimai quant' esser dee quel tutto
IT.33: ch'a così fatta parte si confaccia.
IT.34: S'el fu sì bel com' elli è ora brutto,
IT.35: e contra 'l suo fattore alzò le ciglia,
IT.36: ben dee da lui procedere ogne lutto.
IT.37: Oh quanto parve a me gran maraviglia
IT.38: quand' io vidi tre facce a la sua testa!
IT.39: L'una dinanzi, e quella era vermiglia;
IT.40: l'altr' eran due, che s'aggiugnieno a questa
IT.41: sovresso 'l mezzo di ciascuna spalla,
IT.42: e sé giugnieno al loco de la cresta:
IT.43: e la destra parea tra bianca e gialla;
IT.44: la sinistra a vedere era tal, quali
IT.45: vegnon di là onde 'l Nilo s'avvalla.
IT.46: Sotto ciascuna uscivan due grand' ali,
IT.47: quanto si convenia a tanto uccello:
IT.48: vele di mar non vid' io mai cotali.
IT.49: Non avean penne, ma di vispistrello
IT.50: era lor modo; e quelle svolazzava,
IT.51: sì che tre venti si movean da ello:
IT.52: quindi Cocito tutto s'aggelava.
IT.53: Con sei occhi piangëa, e per tre menti
IT.54: gocciava 'l pianto e sanguinosa bava.
IT.55: Da ogne bocca dirompea co' denti
IT.56: un peccatore, a guisa di maciulla,
IT.57: sì che tre ne facea così dolenti.
IT.58: A quel dinanzi il mordere era nulla
IT.59: verso 'l graffiar, che tal volta la schiena
IT.60: rimanea de la pelle tutta brulla.
IT.61: "Quell' anima là sù c'ha maggior pena,"
IT.62: disse 'l maestro, "è Giuda Scarïotto,
IT.63: che 'l capo ha dentro e fuor le gambe mena.
IT.64: De li altri due c'hanno il capo di sotto,
IT.65: quel che pende dal nero ceffo è Bruto:
IT.66: vedi come si storce, e non fa motto!;
IT.67: e l'altro è Cassio, che par sì membruto.
IT.68: Ma la notte risurge, e oramai
IT.69: è da partir, ché tutto avem veduto."
IT.70: Com' a lui piacque, il collo li avvinghiai;
IT.71: ed el prese di tempo e loco poste,
IT.72: e quando l'ali fuoro aperte assai,
IT.73: appigliò sé a le vellute coste;
IT.74: di vello in vello giù discese poscia
IT.75: tra 'l folto pelo e le gelate croste.
IT.76: Quando noi fummo là dove la coscia
IT.77: si volge, a punto in sul grosso de l'anche,
IT.78: lo duca, con fatica e con angoscia,
IT.79: volse la testa ov' elli avea le zanche,
IT.80: e aggrappossi al pel com' om che sale,
IT.81: sì che 'n inferno i' credea tornar anche.
IT.82: "Attienti ben, ché per cotali scale,"
IT.83: disse 'l maestro, ansando com' uom lasso,
IT.84: "conviensi dipartir da tanto male."
IT.85: Poi uscì fuor per lo fóro d'un sasso
IT.86: e puose me in su l'orlo a sedere;
IT.87: appresso porse a me l'accorto passo.
IT.88: Io levai li occhi e credetti vedere
IT.89: Lucifero com' io l'avea lasciato,
IT.90: e vidili le gambe in sù tenere;
IT.91: e s'io divenni allora travagliato,
IT.92: la gente grossa il pensi, che non vede
IT.93: qual è quel punto ch'io avea passato.
IT.94: "Lèvati sù," disse 'l maestro, "in piede:
IT.95: la via è lunga e 'l cammino è malvagio,
IT.96: e già il sole a mezza terza riede."
IT.97: Non era camminata di palagio
IT.98: là 'v' eravam, ma natural burella
IT.99: ch'avea mal suolo e di lume disagio.
IT.100: "Prima ch'io de l'abisso mi divella,
IT.101: maestro mio," diss' io quando fui dritto,
IT.102: "a trarmi d'erro un poco mi favella:
IT.103: ov' è la ghiaccia? e questi com' è fitto
IT.104: sì sottosopra? e come, in sì poc' ora,
IT.105: da sera a mane ha fatto il sol tragitto?"
IT.106: Ed elli a me: "Tu imagini ancora
IT.107: d'esser di là dal centro, ov' io mi presi
IT.108: al pel del vermo reo che 'l mondo fóra.
IT.109: Di là fosti cotanto quant' io scesi;
IT.110: quand' io mi volsi, tu passasti 'l punto
IT.111: al qual si traggon d'ogne parte i pesi.
IT.112: E se' or sotto l'emisperio giunto
IT.113: ch'è contraposto a quel che la gran secca
IT.114: coverchia, e sotto 'l cui colmo consunto
IT.115: fu l'uom che nacque e visse sanza pecca;
IT.116: tu haï i piedi in su picciola spera
IT.117: che l'altra faccia fa de la Giudecca.
IT.118: Qui è da man, quando di là è sera;
IT.119: e questi, che ne fé scala col pelo,
IT.120: fitto è ancora sì come prim' era.
IT.121: Da questa parte cadde giù dal cielo;
IT.122: e la terra, che pria di qua si sporse,
IT.123: per paura di lui fé del mar velo,
IT.124: e venne a l'emisperio nostro; e forse
IT.125: per fuggir lui lasciò qui loco vòto
IT.126: quella ch'appar di qua, e sù ricorse."
IT.127: Luogo è là giù da Belzebù remoto
IT.128: tanto quanto la tomba si distende,
IT.129: che non per vista, ma per suono è noto
IT.130: d'un ruscelletto che quivi discende
IT.131: per la buca d'un sasso, ch'elli ha roso,
IT.132: col corso ch'elli avvolge, e poco pende.
IT.133: Lo duca e io per quel cammino ascoso
IT.134: intrammo a ritornar nel chiaro mondo;
IT.135: e sanza cura aver d'alcun riposo,
IT.136: salimmo sù, el primo e io secondo,
IT.137: tanto ch'i' vidi de le cose belle
IT.138: che porta 'l ciel, per un pertugio tondo.
IT.139: E quindi uscimmo a riveder le stelle.

EN.1: 'Vexilla regis prodeunt inferni
EN.2: toward us. Look straight before you
EN.3: and see if you can make him out,' my master said.
EN.4: As when a thick mist rises, or when our hemisphere
EN.5: darkens to night, one may discern
EN.6: a distant windmill by its turning sails,
EN.7: it seemed to me I saw such a contrivance.
EN.8: And, to avoid the wind, I drew in close
EN.9: behind my leader: there was nowhere else to hide.
EN.10: Now -- and I shudder as I write it out in verse --
EN.11: I was where the shades were wholly covered,
EN.12: showing through like bits of straw in glass.
EN.13: Some are lying down, still others stand erect:
EN.14: some with their heads, and some their footsoles, up,
EN.15: some bent like bows, their faces to their toes.
EN.16: When we had gotten far enough along
EN.17: that my master was pleased to let me see
EN.18: the creature who was once so fair of face,
EN.19: he took a step aside, then brought me to a halt:
EN.20: 'Look there at Dis! And see the place
EN.21: where you must arm yourself with fortitude.'
EN.22: Then how faint and frozen I became,
EN.23: reader, do not ask, for I do not write it,
EN.24: since any words would fail to be enough.
EN.25: It was not death, nor could one call it life.
EN.26: Imagine, if you have the wit,
EN.27: what I became, deprived of either state.
EN.28: The emperor of the woeful kingdom
EN.29: rose from the ice below his breast,
EN.30: and I in size am closer to a giant
EN.31: than giants are when measured to his arms.
EN.32: Judge, then, what the whole must be
EN.33: that is proportional to such a part.
EN.34: If he was fair as he is hideous now,
EN.35: and raised his brow in scorn of his creator,
EN.36: he is fit to be the source of every sorrow.
EN.37: Oh, what a wonder it appeared to me
EN.38: when I perceived three faces on his head.
EN.39: The first, in front, was red in color.
EN.40: Another two he had, each joined with this,
EN.41: above the midpoint of each shoulder,
EN.42: and all the three united at the crest.
EN.43: The one on the right was a whitish yellow,
EN.44: while the left-hand one was tinted like the people
EN.45: living at the sources of the Nile.
EN.46: Beneath each face two mighty wings emerged,
EN.47: such as befit so vast a bird:
EN.48: I never saw such massive sails at sea.
EN.49: They were featherless and fashioned
EN.50: like a bat's wings. When he flapped them,
EN.51: he sent forth three separate winds,
EN.52: the sources of the ice upon Cocytus.
EN.53: Out of six eyes he wept and his three chins
EN.54: dripped tears and drooled blood-red saliva.
EN.55: With his teeth, just like a hackle
EN.56: pounding flax, he champed a sinner
EN.57: in each mouth, tormenting three at once.
EN.58: For the one in front the gnawing was a trifle
EN.59: to the clawing, for from time to time
EN.60: his back was left with not a shred of skin.
EN.61: 'That soul up there who bears the greatest pain,'
EN.62: said the master, 'is Judas Iscariot, who has
EN.63: his head within and outside flails his legs.
EN.64: 'As for the other two, whose heads are dangling down,
EN.65: Brutus is hanging from the swarthy snout --
EN.66: see how he writhes and utters not a word! --
EN.67: 'and from the other, Cassius, so large of limb.
EN.68: But night is rising in the sky. It is time
EN.69: for us to leave, for we have seen it all.'
EN.70: At his request I clasped him round the neck.
EN.71: When the wings had opened wide enough
EN.72: he chose the proper time and place
EN.73: and took a handhold on those hairy flanks.
EN.74: Then from hank to hank he clambered down
EN.75: between the thick pelt and the crusted ice.
EN.76: When we had come to where the thighbone
EN.77: swivels, at the broad part of the hips,
EN.78: my leader, with much strain of limb and breath,
EN.79: turned his head where Satan had his shanks
EN.80: and clung to the hair like a man who climbed upward,
EN.81: so that I thought we were heading back to Hell.
EN.82: 'Hold on tight, for by such rungs as these,'
EN.83: said my master, panting like a man exhausted,
EN.84: 'must we take leave of so much evil.'
EN.85: Then out through an opening in the rock he went,
EN.86: setting me down upon its edge to rest.
EN.87: And then, with quick and cautious steps, he joined me.
EN.88: I raised my eyes, thinking I would see
EN.89: Lucifer still the same as I had left him,
EN.90: but saw him with his legs held upward.
EN.91: And if I became confused, let those dull minds
EN.92: who fail to see what point I'd passed
EN.93: comprehend what I felt then.
EN.94: The master said to me: 'Get to your feet,
EN.95: for the way is long and the road not easy,
EN.96: and the sun returns to middle tierce.'
EN.97: It was not the great hall of a palace,
EN.98: where we were, but a natural dungeon,
EN.99: rough underfoot and wanting light.
EN.100: 'Master, before I tear myself from this abyss,'
EN.101: I said once I had risen,
EN.102: 'say a few words to rid me of my doubt.
EN.103: 'Where is the ice? Why is this one fixed now
EN.104: upside down? And how in so few hours
EN.105: has the sun moved from evening into morning?'
EN.106: And he to me: 'You imagine you are still
EN.107: beyond the center, where I grasped the hair
EN.108: of the guilty worm by whom the world is pierced.
EN.109: 'So you were, as long as I descended,
EN.110: but, when I turned around, you passed the point
EN.111: to which all weights are drawn from every side.
EN.112: 'You are now beneath the hemisphere
EN.113: opposite the one that canopies the landmass --
EN.114: and underneath its zenith that Man was slain
EN.115: 'who without sin was born and sinless lived.
EN.116: You have your feet upon a little sphere
EN.117: that forms Judecca's other face.
EN.118: 'Here it is morning when it is evening there,
EN.119: and the one whose hair provided us a ladder
EN.120: is fixed exactly as he was before.
EN.121: 'It was on this side that he fell from Heaven.
EN.122: And the dry land that used to stand, above,
EN.123: in fear of him immersed itself in water
EN.124: 'and fled into our hemisphere. And perhaps
EN.125: to escape from him the land we'll find above
EN.126: created this lacuna when it rushed back up.'
EN.127: As far as one can get from Beelzebub,
EN.128: in the remotest corner of this cavern,
EN.129: there is a place one cannot find by sight,
EN.130: but by the sound of a narrow stream that trickles
EN.131: through a channel it has cut into the rock
EN.132: in its meanderings, making a gentle slope.
EN.133: Into that hidden passage my guide and I
EN.134: entered, to find again the world of light,
EN.135: and, without thinking of a moment's rest,
EN.136: we climbed up, he first and I behind him,
EN.137: far enough to see, through a round opening,
EN.138: a few of those fair things the heavens bear.
EN.139: Then we came forth, to see again the stars.

IT.1: Per correr miglior acque alza le vele
IT.2: omai la navicella del mio ingegno,
IT.3: che lascia dietro a sé mar sì crudele;
IT.4: e canterò di quel secondo regno
IT.5: dove l'umano spirito si purga
IT.6: e di salire al ciel diventa degno.
IT.7: Ma qui la morta poesì resurga,
IT.8: o sante Muse, poi che vostro sono;
IT.9: e qui Calïopè alquanto surga,
IT.10: seguitando il mio canto con quel suono
IT.11: di cui le Piche misere sentiro
IT.12: lo colpo tal, che disperar perdono.
IT.13: Dolce color d'orïental zaffiro,
IT.14: che s'accoglieva nel sereno aspetto
IT.15: del mezzo, puro infino al primo giro,
IT.16: a li occhi miei ricominciò diletto,
IT.17: tosto ch'io usci' fuor de l'aura morta
IT.18: che m'avea contristati li occhi e 'l petto.
IT.19: Lo bel pianeto che d'amar conforta
IT.20: faceva tutto rider l'orïente,
IT.21: velando i Pesci ch'erano in sua scorta.
IT.22: I' mi volsi a man destra, e puosi mente
IT.23: a l'altro polo, e vidi quattro stelle
IT.24: non viste mai fuor ch'a la prima gente.
IT.25: Goder pareva 'l ciel di lor fiammelle:
IT.26: oh settentrïonal vedovo sito,
IT.27: poi che privato se' di mirar quelle!
IT.28: Com' io da loro sguardo fui partito,
IT.29: un poco me volgendo a l'altro polo,
IT.30: là onde 'l Carro già era sparito,
IT.31: vidi presso di me un veglio solo,
IT.32: degno di tanta reverenza in vista,
IT.33: che più non dee a padre alcun figliuolo.
IT.34: Lunga la barba e di pel bianco mista
IT.35: portava, a' suoi capelli simigliante,
IT.36: de' quai cadeva al petto doppia lista.
IT.37: Li raggi de le quattro luci sante
IT.38: fregiavan sì la sua faccia di lume,
IT.39: ch'i' 'l vedea come 'l sol fosse davante.
IT.40: "Chi siete voi che contro al cieco fiume
IT.41: fuggita avete la pregione etterna?"
IT.42: diss' el, movendo quelle oneste piume.
IT.43: "Chi v'ha guidati, o che vi fu lucerna,
IT.44: uscendo fuor de la profonda notte
IT.45: che sempre nera fa la valle inferna?
IT.46: Son le leggi d'abisso così rotte?
IT.47: o è mutato in ciel novo consiglio,
IT.48: che, dannati, venite a le mie grotte?"
IT.49: Lo duca mio allor mi diè di piglio,
IT.50: e con parole e con mani e con cenni
IT.51: reverenti mi fé le gambe e 'l ciglio.
IT.52: Poscia rispuose lui: "Da me non venni:
IT.53: donna scese del ciel, per li cui prieghi
IT.54: de la mia compagnia costui sovvenni.
IT.55: Ma da ch'è tuo voler che più si spieghi
IT.56: di nostra condizion com' ell' è vera,
IT.57: esser non puote il mio che a te si nieghi.
IT.58: Questi non vide mai l'ultima sera;
IT.59: ma per la sua follia le fu sì presso,
IT.60: che molto poco tempo a volger era.
IT.61: Sì com' io dissi, fui mandato ad esso
IT.62: per lui campare; e non lí era altra via
IT.63: che questa per la quale i' mi son messo.
IT.64: Mostrata ho lui tutta la gente ria;
IT.65: e ora intendo mostrar quelli spirti
IT.66: che purgan sé sotto la tua balìa.
IT.67: Com' io l'ho tratto, saria lungo a dirti;
IT.68: de l'alto scende virtù che m'aiuta
IT.69: conducerlo a vederti e a udirti.
IT.70: Or ti piaccia gradir la sua venuta:
IT.71: libertà va cercando, ch'è sì cara,
IT.72: come sa chi per lei vita rifiuta.
IT.73: Tu 'l sai, ché non ti fu per lei amara
IT.74: in Utica la morte, ove lasciasti
IT.75: la vesta ch'al gran dì sarà sì chiara.
IT.76: Non son li editti etterni per noi guasti,
IT.77: ché questi vive e Minòs me non lega;
IT.78: ma son del cerchio ove son li occhi casti
IT.79: di Marzia tua, che 'n vista ancor ti priega,
IT.80: o santo petto, che per tua la tegni:
IT.81: per lo suo amore adunque a noi ti piega.
IT.82: Lasciane andar per li tuoi sette regni;
IT.83: grazie riporterò di te a lei,
IT.84: se d'esser mentovato là giù degni."
IT.85: "Marzïa piacque tanto a li occhi miei
IT.86: mentre ch'i' fu' di là," diss' elli allora,
IT.87: "che quante grazie volse da me, fei.
IT.88: Or che di là dal mal fiume dimora,
IT.89: più muover non mi può, per quella legge
IT.90: che fatta fu quando me n'usci' fora.
IT.91: Ma se donna del ciel ti move e regge,
IT.92: come tu di', non c'è mestier lusinghe:
IT.93: bastisi ben che per lei mi richegge.
IT.94: Va dunque, e fa che tu costui ricinghe
IT.95: d'un giunco schietto e che li lavi 'l viso,
IT.96: sì ch'ogne sucidume quindi stinghe;
IT.97: ché non si converria, l'occhio sorpriso
IT.98: d'alcuna nebbia, andar dinanzi al primo
IT.99: ministro, ch'è di quei di paradiso.
IT.100: Questa isoletta intorno ad imo ad imo,
IT.101: là giù colà dove la batte l'onda,
IT.102: porta di giunchi sovra 'l molle limo:
IT.103: null' altra pianta che facesse fronda
IT.104: o indurasse, vi puote aver vita,
IT.105: però ch'a le percosse non seconda.
IT.106: Poscia non sia di qua vostra reddita;
IT.107: lo sol vi mosterrà, che surge omai,
IT.108: prendere il monte a più lieve salita."
IT.109: Così sparì; e io sù mi levai
IT.110: sanza parlare, e tutto mi ritrassi
IT.111: al duca mio, e li occhi a lui drizzai.
IT.112: El cominciò: "Figliuol, segui i miei passi:
IT.113: volgianci in dietro, ché di qua dichina
IT.114: questa pianura a' suoi termini bassi."
IT.115: L'alba vinceva l'ora mattutina
IT.116: che fuggia innanzi, sì che di lontano
IT.117: conobbi il tremolar de la marina.
IT.118: Noi andavam per lo solingo piano
IT.119: com' om che torna a la perduta strada,
IT.120: che 'nfino ad essa li pare ire in vano.
IT.121: Quando noi fummo là 've la rugiada
IT.122: pugna col sole, per essere in parte
IT.123: dove, ad orezza, poco si dirada,
IT.124: ambo le mani in su l'erbetta sparte
IT.125: soavemente 'l mio maestro pose:
IT.126: ond' io, che fui accorto di sua arte,
IT.127: porsi ver' lui le guance lagrimose;
IT.128: ivi mi fece tutto discoverto
IT.129: quel color che l'inferno mi nascose.
IT.130: Venimmo poi in sul lito diserto,
IT.131: che mai non vide navicar sue acque
IT.132: omo, che di tornar sia poscia esperto.
IT.133: Quivi mi cinse sì com' altrui piacque:
IT.134: oh maraviglia! ché qual elli scelse
IT.135: l'umile pianta, cotal si rinacque
IT.136: subitamente là onde l'avelse.

EN.1: To run its course through smoother water
EN.2: the small bark of my wit now hoists its sail,
EN.3: leaving that cruel sea behind.
EN.4: Now I shall sing the second kingdom,
EN.5: there where the soul of man is cleansed,
EN.6: made worthy to ascend to Heaven.
EN.7: Here from the dead let poetry rise up,
EN.8: O sacred Muses, since I am yours.
EN.9: Here let Calliope arise
EN.10: to accompany my song with those same chords
EN.11: whose force so struck the miserable magpies
EN.12: that, hearing it, they lost all hope of pardon.
EN.13: Sweet color of oriental sapphire,
EN.14: hovering in the calm and peaceful aspect
EN.15: of intervening air, pure to the horizon,
EN.16: pleased my eyes once more
EN.17: as soon as I had left the morbid air
EN.18: that had afflicted both my chest and eyes.
EN.19: The fair planet that emboldens love,
EN.20: smiling, lit up the east,
EN.21: veiling the Fishes in her train.
EN.22: I turned to the right and, fixing my attention
EN.23: on the other pole, I saw four stars
EN.24: not seen but by those first on earth.
EN.25: The very sky seemed to rejoice
EN.26: in their bright glittering. O widowed
EN.27: region of the north, denied that sight!
EN.28: Once I had drawn my gaze from them,
EN.29: barely turning toward the other pole
EN.30: where the constellation of the Wain had set,
EN.31: I saw beside me an old man, alone,
EN.32: who by his looks was so deserving of respect
EN.33: that no son owes his father more.
EN.34: His beard was long and streaked with white,
EN.35: as was his hair, which fell
EN.36: in double strands down to his chest.
EN.37: The rays of those four holy stars
EN.38: adorned his face with so much light
EN.39: he seemed to shine with brightness of the sun.
EN.40: 'What souls are you to have fled the eternal prison,
EN.41: climbing against the dark and hidden stream?'
EN.42: he asked, shaking those venerable locks.
EN.43: 'Who was your guide or who your lantern
EN.44: to lead you forth from that deep night

EN.1: I had already parted from those shades,
EN.2: following the footsteps of my guide,
EN.3: when one behind me, pointing with his finger,
EN.4: cried: 'Look how the sun's rays on the ground
EN.5: are cut off to his left
EN.6: and how he moves and seems like one alive.'
EN.7: Hearing these words, I turned to look at them
EN.8: and saw that they were staring in amazement
EN.9: at me, at me and at the interrupted light.
EN.10: 'Is your mind so distracted,' asked the master,
EN.11: 'that you have slowed your pace?
EN.12: Why do you care what they are whispering?
EN.13: 'Just follow me and let the people talk.
EN.14: Why can't you be like a sturdy tower
EN.15: that does not tremble in the fiercest wind.
EN.16: 'For any man who lets one thought--
EN.17: and then another--take him over
EN.18: will soon lose track of his first goal.'
EN.19: What could I answer but 'I come'?
EN.20: I said it, blushing with such shame
EN.21: as might make one worthy of his pardon.
EN.22: And all this time in front of us
EN.23: a group of shades advanced across the slope,
EN.24: chanting Miserere line by line.
EN.25: When they perceived my body stopped
EN.26: the rays of the sun from shining through,
EN.27: their voices faded to a hoarse and drawn-out 'Oh!'
EN.28: and two of them, as messengers,
EN.29: ran out to meet us and insisted:
EN.30: 'Tell us what you can of your condition.'
EN.31: My master answered: 'When you go back
EN.32: you may report to those who sent you:
EN.33: this man's body is true flesh.
EN.34: 'If they stopped because they saw his shadow,
EN.35: as I suppose, they have their answer.
EN.36: It may profit them to do him honor.'
EN.37: Never have I seen falling stars streak
EN.38: across the placid sky nor, at nightfall,
EN.39: lightning pulse within the clouds of August
EN.40: as swiftly as these two ran upward
EN.41: and, when they reached the others, they all,
EN.42: like an unruly band, turned and charged toward us.
EN.43: 'These people crowding us are many
EN.44: and they have come to seek your favor,' said the poet,
EN.45: 'but keep on walking, listening as you go.'
EN.46: 'O soul who go to blessedness
EN.47: in the body you were born to,' they called
EN.48: as they came up, 'here pause a while
EN.49: 'to see if one of us is known to you
EN.50: that you may carry news of him into the world.
EN.51: Ah, why do you go on? Why don't you stop?
EN.52: 'Sinners to the final hour,
EN.53: we were all at the point of violent death
EN.54: when a light from Heaven brought us understanding,
EN.55: 'so that, repenting and forgiving,
EN.56: we parted from our lives at peace with God,
EN.57: who with desire to see Him wrings our hearts.'
EN.58: And I replied: 'However hard I gaze into your faces,
EN.59: none do I recognize. But if in anything
EN.60: I can please you, spirits born for bliss,
EN.61: 'by the very peace I seek
EN.62: from world to world, following the steps
EN.63: of such a guide, that I will do.'
EN.64: And one of them began: 'Each of us trusts
EN.65: in your good offices without your oath,
EN.66: provided lack of power does not thwart your will.
EN.67: 'Therefore, speaking before the others do,
EN.68: I beg you, should you ever see the region
EN.69: between Romagna and King Charles's land,
EN.70: 'that you be kind enough to seek in Fano
EN.71: heartfelt prayers for me
EN.72: to help me purge my grievous sins.
EN.73: 'There I was born, but the deep wounds
EN.74: that poured my blood out with my life
EN.75: were given me among the sons of Antenor,
EN.76: 'where I most thought myself secure.
EN.77: He of Este had it done, who was incensed
EN.78: against me more than justice warranted.
EN.79: 'Had I but gone on to La Mira,
EN.80: leaving Oriago, where I was found and taken,
EN.81: I would still be back there where men breathe.
EN.82: 'I fled to the marsh. Entrapped in reeds
EN.83: and mire I fell, and in that mud
EN.84: I watched a pool of blood form from my veins.'
EN.85: Then another spoke: 'Pray, so may the desire
EN.86: be satisfied that draws you to this mountain,
EN.87: do you with gracious pity help with mine.
EN.88: 'I was of Montefeltro, I am Buonconte.
EN.89: Not Giovanna nor another has a care for me,
EN.90: so that I move among the rest with downcast brow.'
EN.91: And I to him: 'What force or chance
EN.92: took you so far from Campaldino
EN.93: that your burial-place was never found?'
EN.94: 'Ah,' he replied, 'at Casentino's border
EN.95: runs a stream called Archiano
EN.96: that springs above the Hermitage among the Apennines.
EN.97: 'To where its name is lost I made my way,
EN.98: wounded in the throat, fleeing on foot,
EN.99: and dripping blood across the plain.
EN.100: 'There I lost sight and speech.
EN.101: I ended on the name of Mary and there I fell,
EN.102: and only my flesh remained.
EN.103: 'I will tell the truth--you tell it to the living.
EN.104: God's angel took me, and he from Hell cried out:
EN.105: "O you from Heaven, why do you rob me?
EN.106: '"You carry off with you this man's eternal part.
EN.107: For a little tear he's taken from me,
EN.108: but with the remains I'll deal in my own way."
EN.109: 'Surely you know how a column of moist air,
EN.110: rising to colder heights, condenses
EN.111: and once again is changed to water.
EN.112: 'That evil will, seeking only evil, he joined
EN.113: with intellect, and with his natural powers
EN.114: he roused the fog and wind.
EN.115: 'Then, when the day was spent, he shrouded
EN.116: the valley from Pratomagno to the alps
EN.117: in mist, and darkened the sky with clouds
EN.118: 'so that the pregnant air was turned to water.
EN.119: The rain fell and the overflow that earth
EN.120: could not absorb rushed to the gullies
EN.121: 'and, gathering in surging torrents, poured
EN.122: headlong down the seaward stream
EN.123: with so much rage nothing could hold it back.
EN.124: 'At its mouth the blood-red Archiano found
EN.125: my frozen corpse and swept it down the Arno,
EN.126: undoing at my chest the cross
EN.127: 'my arms had made when I was overcome by pain.
EN.128: It spun me past its banks and to the bottom,
EN.129: then covered and enclosed me with its spoils.'
EN.130: 'Pray, once you have gone back into the world
EN.131: and are rested from the long road,'
EN.132: the third spirit followed on the second,
EN.133: 'please remember me. I am La Pia.
EN.134: Siena made me, in Maremma I was undone.
EN.135: He knows how, the one who, to marry me,
EN.136: first gave the ring that held his stone.'

IT.1: Quando si parte il gioco de la zara,
IT.2: colui che perde si riman dolente,
IT.3: repetendo le volte, e tristo impara;
IT.4: con l'altro se ne va tutta la gente;
IT.5: qual va dinanzi, e qual di dietro il prende,
IT.6: e qual dallato li si reca a mente;
IT.7: el non s'arresta, e questo e quello intende;
IT.8: a cui porge la man, più non fa pressa;
IT.9: e così da la calca si difende.
IT.10: Tal era io in quella turba spessa,
IT.11: volgendo a loro, e qua e là, la faccia,
IT.12: e promettendo mi sciogliea da essa.
IT.13: Quiv' era l'Aretin che da le braccia
IT.14: fiere di Ghin di Tacco ebbe la morte,
IT.15: e l'altro ch'annegò correndo in caccia.
IT.16: Quivi pregava con le mani sporte
IT.17: Federigo Novello, e quel da Pisa
IT.18: che fé parer lo buon Marzucco forte.
IT.19: Vidi conte Orso e l'anima divisa
IT.20: dal corpo suo per astio e per inveggia,
IT.21: com' e' dicea, non per colpa commisa;
IT.22: Pier da la Broccia dico; e qui proveggia,
IT.23: mentr' è di qua, la donna di Brabante,
IT.24: sì che però non sia di peggior greggia.

IT.26: quell' ombre che pregar pur ch'altri prieghi,
IT.27: sì che s'avacci lor divenir sante,
IT.28: io cominciai: "El par che tu mi nieghi,
IT.29: o luce mia, espresso in alcun testo
IT.30: che decreto del cielo orazion pieghi;
IT.31: e questa gente prega pur di questo:
IT.32: sarebbe dunque loro speme vana,
IT.33: o non m'è 'l detto tuo ben manifesto?"
IT.34: Ed elli a me: "La mia scrittura è piana;
IT.35: e la speranza di costor non falla,
IT.36: se ben si guarda con la mente sana;
IT.37: ché cima di giudicio non s'avvalla
IT.38: perché foco d'amor compia in un punto
IT.39: ciò che de' sodisfar chi qui s'astalla;
IT.40: e là dov' io fermai cotesto punto,
IT.41: non s'ammendava, per pregar, difetto,
IT.42: perché 'l priego da Dio era disgiunto.
IT.43: Veramente a così alto sospetto
IT.44: non ti fermar, se quella nol ti dice
IT.45: che lume fia tra 'l vero e lo 'ntelletto.
IT.46: Non so se 'ntendi: io dico di Beatrice;
IT.47: tu la vedrai di sopra, in su la vetta
IT.48: di questo monte, ridere e felice."
IT.49: E io: "Segnore, andiamo a maggior fretta,
IT.50: ché già non m'affatico come dianzi,
IT.51: e vedi omai che 'l poggio l'ombra getta."
IT.52: "Noi anderem con questo giorno innanzi,"
IT.53: rispuose, "quanto più potremo omai;
IT.54: ma 'l fatto è d'altra forma che non stanzi.
IT.55: Prima che sie là sù, tornar vedrai
IT.56: colui che già si cuopre de la costa,
IT.57: sì che ' suoi raggi tu romper non fai.
IT.58: Ma vedi là un'anima che, posta
IT.59: sola soletta, inverso noi riguarda:
IT.60: quella ne 'nsegnerà la via più tosta."
IT.61: Venimmo a lei: o anima lombarda,
IT.62: come ti stavi altera e disdegnosa
IT.63: e nel mover de li occhi onesta e tarda!
IT.64: Ella non ci dicëa alcuna cosa,
IT.65: ma lasciavane gir, solo sguardando
IT.66: a guisa di leon quando si posa.
IT.67: Pur Virgilio si trasse a lei, pregando
IT.68: che ne mostrasse la miglior salita;
IT.69: e quella non rispuose al suo dimando,
IT.70: ma di nostro paese e de la vita
IT.71: ci 'nchiese; e 'l dolce duca incominciava
IT.72: "Mantüa ...," e l'ombra, tutta in sé romita,
IT.73: surse ver' lui del loco ove pria stava,
IT.74: dicendo: "O Mantoano, io son Sordello

IT.77: nave sanza nocchiere in gran tempesta,
IT.78: non donna di province, ma bordello!

IT.80: sol per lo dolce suon de la sua terra,
IT.81: di fare al cittadin suo quivi festa;

IT.86: le tue marine, e poi ti guarda in seno,

IT.88: Che val perché ti racconciasse il freno
IT.89: Iustinïano, se la sella è vòta?
IT.90: Sanz' esso fora la vergogna meno.
IT.91: Ahi gente che dovresti esser devota,
IT.92: e lasciar seder Cesare in la sella,

IT.97: O Alberto tedesco ch'abbandoni
IT.98: costei ch'è fatta indomita e selvaggia,
IT.99: e dovresti inforcar li suoi arcioni,
IT.100: giusto giudicio da le stelle caggia
IT.101: sovra 'l tuo sangue, e sia novo e aperto,
IT.102: tal che 'l tuo successor temenza n'aggia!
IT.103: Ch'avete tu e 'l tuo padre sofferto,
IT.104: per cupidigia di costà distretti,
IT.105: che 'l giardin de lo 'mperio sia diserto.

IT.107: Monaldi e Filippeschi, uom sanza cura:

IT.110: d'i tuoi gentili, e cura lor magagne;

IT.113: vedova e sola, e dì e notte chiama:

IT.116: e se nulla di noi pietà ti move,
IT.117: a vergognar ti vien de la tua fama.

IT.119: che fosti in terra per noi crucifisso,

IT.122: del tuo consiglio fai per alcun bene
IT.123: in tutto de l'accorger nostro scisso?

IT.125: son di tiranni, e un Marcel diventa
IT.126: ogne villan che parteggiando viene.

IT.128: di questa digression che non ti tocca,
IT.129: mercé del popol tuo che si argomenta.

IT.139: Atene e Lacedemona, che fenno

IT.141: fecero al viver bene un picciol cenno

EN.1: When the game of dice breaks up,
EN.2: the loser, left dejected,
EN.3: rehearses every throw and sadly learns,
EN.4: while all the others crowd around the winner.
EN.5: One goes in front, one grabs him from the back,
EN.6: and, at his side, another calls himself to mind.
EN.7: The winner does not stop, but listens first to one
EN.8: and then another. Those to whom he gives his hand
EN.9: then let him be, and so he gets away.
EN.10: Such was I among that pressing throng,
EN.11: turning my face this way and that,
EN.12: and through my promises I freed myself of them.
EN.13: The Aretine was there who met his death
EN.14: at the fierce hands of Ghino di Tacco,
EN.15: and the other who was drowned in the frenzied chase.
EN.16: There Federico Novello was beseeching
EN.17: with outstretched hands, and he of Pisa
EN.18: who made the good Marzucco show his strength.
EN.19: I saw Count Orso, and that soul severed
EN.20: from its body both by spite and envy,
EN.21: or so he said, and not for any crime--
EN.22: Pierre de la Brosse. And let the Lady
EN.23: of Brabant be mindful, while she remains on earth,
EN.24: lest she be made to join a flock far worse.
EN.25: As soon as I was free of all those shades,
EN.26: whose only prayer it was that others pray
EN.27: and speed them on to blessedness,
EN.28: I began: 'O my light, it seems to me
EN.29: that in one passage you explicitly deny
EN.30: that prayer can bend decrees of Heaven,
EN.31: 'and yet these people pray for that alone.

EN.33: before they could be cleansed of mortal guilt.

EN.42: with you and be your guide as far as I'm allowed.

EN.44: and we may not ascend by night.

IT.74: poscia che trasmutò le bianche bende,
IT.75: le quai convien che, misera!, ancor brami.
IT.76: Per lei assai di lieve si comprende
IT.77: quanto in femmina foco d'amor dura,
IT.78: se l'occhio o 'l tatto spesso non l'accende.
IT.79: Non le farà sì bella sepultura
IT.80: la vipera che Melanesi accampa,
IT.81: com' avria fatto il gallo di Gallura."
IT.82: Così dicea, segnato de la stampa,
IT.83: nel suo aspetto, di quel dritto zelo
IT.84: che misuratamente in core avvampa.
IT.85: Li occhi miei ghiotti andavan pur al cielo,
IT.86: pur là dove le stelle son più tarde,
IT.87: sì come rota più presso a lo stelo.
IT.88: E 'l duca mio: "Figliuol, che là sù guarde?"
IT.89: E io a lui: "A quelle tre facelle
IT.90: di che 'l polo di qua tutto quanto arde."
IT.91: Ond' elli a me: "Le quattro chiare stelle
IT.92: che vedevi staman, son di là basse,
IT.93: e queste son salite ov' eran quelle."
IT.94: Com' ei parlava, e Sordello a sé il trasse
IT.95: dicendo: "Vedi là 'l nostro avversaro";
IT.96: e drizzò il dito perché 'n là guardasse.
IT.97: Da quella parte onde non ha riparo
IT.98: la picciola vallea, era una biscia,
IT.99: forse qual diede ad Eva il cibo amaro.
IT.100: Tra l'erba e ' fior venìa la mala striscia,
IT.101: volgendo ad ora ad or la testa, e 'l dosso
IT.102: leccando come bestia che si liscia.
IT.103: Io non vidi, e però dicer non posso,
IT.104: come mosser li astor celestïali;
IT.105: ma vidi bene e l'uno e l'altro mosso.
IT.106: Sentendo fender l'aere a le verdi ali,
IT.107: fuggì 'l serpente, e li angeli dier volta,
IT.108: suso a le poste rivolando iguali.
IT.109: L'ombra che s'era al giudice raccolta
IT.110: quando chiamò, per tutto quello assalto
IT.111: punto non fu da me guardare sciolta.
IT.112: "Se la lucerna che ti mena in alto
IT.113: truovi nel tuo arbitrio tanta cera
IT.114: quant' è mestiere infino al sommo smalto,"
IT.115: cominciò ella, "se novella vera
IT.116: di Val di Magra o di parte vicina
IT.117: sai, dillo a me, che già grande là era.
IT.118: Fui chiamato Currado Malaspina;
IT.119: non son l'antico, ma di lui discesi;
IT.120: a' miei portai l'amor che qui raffina."
IT.121: "Oh!" diss' io lui, "per li vostri paesi
IT.122: già mai non fui; ma dove si dimora
IT.123: per tutta Europa ch'ei non sien palesi?
IT.124: La fama che la vostra casa onora,
IT.125: grida i segnori e grida la contrada,
IT.126: sì che ne sa chi non vi fu ancora;
IT.127: e io vi giuro, s'io di sopra vada,
IT.128: che vostra gente onrata non si sfregia
IT.129: del pregio de la borsa e de la spada.
IT.130: Uso e natura sì la privilegia,
IT.131: che, perché il capo reo il mondo torca,
IT.132: sola va dritta e 'l mal cammin dispregia."
IT.133: Ed elli: "Or va; che 'l sol non si ricorca
IT.134: sette volte nel letto che 'l Montone
IT.135: con tutti e quattro i piè cuopre e inforca,
IT.136: che cotesta cortese oppinïone
IT.137: ti fia chiavata in mezzo de la testa
IT.138: con maggior chiovi che d'altrui sermone,
IT.139: se corso di giudicio non s'arresta."

EN.1: It was now the hour that melts a sailor's heart
EN.2: and saddens him with longing on the day
EN.3: he's said farewell to his belovèd friends,
EN.4: and when a traveler, starting out,
EN.5: is pierced with love if far away he hears
EN.6: a bell that seems to mourn the dying light,
EN.7: and I began to listen less and fix my gaze,
EN.8: intent upon a soul who suddenly stood up
EN.9: and signaled for attention with his hand.
EN.10: He lifted his clasped palms and fixed his eyes
EN.11: upon the east as if he said to God:
EN.12: 'For nothing else do I have any care.'
EN.13: 'Te lucis ante' came forth from his lips
EN.14: with such devotion and with notes so sweet
EN.15: it drew me out from all thoughts of myself.
EN.16: The others joined him then and sang
EN.17: the whole hymn through with sweet devotion,
EN.18: keeping their eyes upon the heavenly wheels.
EN.19: Here, reader, set your gaze upon the truth,
EN.20: for now the veil is drawn so thin
EN.21: that piercing it is surely easy.
EN.22: I watched that noble gathering
EN.23: grow silent as they raised their eyes,
EN.24: humble and pale with expectation.
EN.25: And I saw issue from above and then descend
EN.26: two angels holding flaming swords,
EN.27: their pointed blade-tips broken off.
EN.28: Green as newly opened leaves, their garments,
EN.29: stirred and fanned by their green wings,
EN.30: swirled and billowed out behind them.
EN.31: One came and took his stand there just above us
EN.32: and one alighted on the other bank,
EN.33: so that the company was set between them.
EN.34: I could discern the angels' flaxen hair,
EN.35: but looking at their faces dazzled me,
EN.36: my power of sight undone by so much brightness.
EN.37: 'Both come from Mary's bosom,'
EN.38: said Sordello, 'to guard the valley
EN.39: from the serpent that will soon appear.'
EN.40: Not knowing by what path,
EN.41: I turned around, all chilled with fear,
EN.42: and huddled closer to the trusted shoulders.
EN.43: Sordello continued: 'Let us now go down
EN.44: into the valley and speak with those great shades.
EN.45: They will be pleased to have you join them.'
EN.46: It seemed I had taken only three steps down
EN.47: when I saw one who stared at me alone,
EN.48: as if he tried to bring my name to mind.
EN.49: It was now the hour when the air grows dark,
EN.50: yet had not turned so dark it failed to show
EN.51: his eyes and mine what had been hidden.
EN.52: He moved toward me and I moved toward him.
EN.53: Noble Judge Nino, what joy it was to me
EN.54: when I saw that you were not among the damned!
EN.55: Between us no fair greeting went unsaid.
EN.56: Then he asked: 'How long is it since you came
EN.57: over far waters to this mountain?'
EN.58: 'Oh,' I said to him, 'I came this morning
EN.59: from the doleful regions. I am in my first life,
EN.60: though by coming here I gain the other.'
EN.61: And when they heard my answer
EN.62: Sordello and he drew back,
EN.63: like men suddenly bewildered.
EN.64: One turned to Virgil, and the other called
EN.65: to someone seated there: 'Rise, Currado,
EN.66: come and see what God by His good grace has willed,'
EN.67: then, turning to me: 'By that special gratitude
EN.68: you owe to Him who hides His primal purpose
EN.69: so deep we cannot fathom it,
EN.70: 'when you are far from these wide waters,
EN.71: ask my Giovanna to direct her prayers for me
EN.72: to where the innocent are heard.
EN.73: 'I think her mother has not loved me
EN.74: since she stopped wearing her white wimple,
EN.75: which, in her coming misery, she may long for.
EN.76: 'There is an easy lesson in her conduct:
EN.77: how short a time the fire of love endures in woman
EN.78: if frequent sight and touch do not rekindle it.
EN.79: 'The viper that leads the Milanese afield
EN.80: will hardly ornament her tomb as handsomely
EN.81: as the cock of Gallura would have done.'
EN.82: He spoke these words, his face stamped
EN.83: with a look of righteous indignation
EN.84: that burns with proper measure in the heart.
EN.85: My hungry eyes were lifted toward the sky,
EN.86: to that zone where the stars move slowest,
EN.87: as does the spoke of a wheel close to the axle.
EN.88: And my leader: 'Son, what are you staring at?'
EN.89: And I replied: 'At those three torches
EN.90: with which this pole is all aflame.'
EN.91: 'The four bright stars you saw this morning,'
EN.92: he said, 'are low upon the unseen sky
EN.93: and these have risen where those others were.'
EN.94: As he spoke, Sordello drew him closer,
EN.95: saying: 'Behold our adversary,'
EN.96: and pointed with his finger where to look.
EN.97: In that place where the little valley
EN.98: has no rampart, a snake appeared,
EN.99: perhaps the one that gave to Eve the bitter fruit.
EN.100: Through grass and flowers slid the evil streak,
EN.101: turning its head from time to time to lick its back
EN.102: like a beast that sleeks itself.
EN.103: I did not see and therefore cannot tell
EN.104: how the celestial falcons started up,
EN.105: but I could plainly see them both in motion.
EN.106: Hearing the green wings cleave the air,
EN.107: the serpent fled. The angels wheeled around
EN.108: and flew back up together to their posts.
EN.109: The shade, who had drawn closer to the judge
EN.110: when he called out, had not through that assault
EN.111: at any time removed his gaze from me.
EN.112: 'So may the lantern leading you above
EN.113: have ample wax in the candle of your will
EN.114: to bring you to the enameled summit,'
EN.115: he said, 'if you have true news of Valdimagra
EN.116: or of the parts around, please tell me,
EN.117: for there I once was great.
EN.118: 'I was called Currado Malaspina,
EN.119: not the old Currado but descended from him.
EN.120: To my own I bore the love that here is purified.'
EN.121: 'Oh,' I said to him, 'never have I been there,
EN.122: in your country. But where do men dwell,
EN.123: anywhere in Europe, that it is not renowned?
EN.124: 'The fame that crowns your house with honor
EN.125: proclaims alike its lords and lands--
EN.126: even those who have not been there know them,
EN.127: 'and, as I hope to go above, I swear to you
EN.128: your honored race does not disgrace
EN.129: the glory of its purse and of its sword.
EN.130: 'No matter how a wicked chief may warp the world,
EN.131: privileged both by nature and by custom,
EN.132: your race alone goes straight and scorns the evil path.'
EN.133: Then he said: 'Enough. Not seven times
EN.134: shall the sun return to rest in the bed
EN.135: the Ram covers and bestrides with all four feet
EN.136: 'before this courteous opinion
EN.137: shall be nailed within your brain
EN.138: by stronger nails than the words of others,
EN.139: if the course of Judgment is not stayed.'

IT.1: La concubina di Titone antico
IT.2: già s'imbiancava al balco d'orïente,
IT.3: fuor de le braccia del suo dolce amico;
IT.4: di gemme la sua fronte era lucente,
IT.5: poste in figura del freddo animale
IT.6: che con la coda percuote la gente;
IT.7: e la notte, de' passi con che sale,
IT.8: fatti avea due nel loco ov' eravamo,
IT.9: e 'l terzo già chinava in giuso l'ale;
IT.10: quand' io, che meco avea di quel d'Adamo,
IT.11: vinto dal sonno, in su l'erba inchinai
IT.12: là 've già tutti e cinque sedavamo.
IT.13: Ne l'ora che comincia i tristi lai
IT.14: la rondinella presso a la mattina,
IT.15: forse a memoria de' suo' primi guai,
IT.16: e che la mente nostra, peregrina
IT.17: più da la carne e men da' pensier presa,
IT.18: a le sue visïon quasi è divina,
IT.19: in sogno mi parea veder sospesa
IT.20: un'aguglia nel ciel con penne d'oro,
IT.21: con l'ali aperte e a calare intesa;
IT.22: ed esser mi parea là dove fuoro
IT.23: abbandonati i suoi da Ganimede,
IT.24: quando fu ratto al sommo consistoro.
IT.25: Fra me pensava: "Forse questa fiede
IT.26: pur qui per uso, e forse d'altro loco
IT.27: disdegna di portarne suso in piede."
IT.28: Poi mi parea che, poi rotata un poco,
IT.29: terribil come folgor discendesse,
IT.30: e me rapisse suso infino al foco.
IT.31: Ivi parea che ella e io ardesse;
IT.32: e sì lo 'ncendio imaginato cosse,
IT.33: che convenne che 'l sonno si rompesse.
IT.34: Non altrimenti Achille si riscosse,
IT.35: li occhi svegliati rivolgendo in giro
IT.36: e non sappiendo là dove si fosse,
IT.37: quando la madre da Chirón a Schiro
IT.38: trafuggò lui dormendo in le sue braccia,
IT.39: là onde poi li Greci il dipartiro;
IT.40: che mi scoss' io, sì come da la faccia
IT.41: mi fuggì 'l sonno, e diventa' ismorto,
IT.42: come fa l'uom che, spaventato, agghiaccia.
IT.43: Dallato m'era solo il mio conforto,
IT.44: e 'l sole er' alto già più che due ore,
IT.45: e 'l viso m'era a la marina torto.
IT.46: "Non aver tema," disse il mio segnore;
IT.47: "fatti sicur, ché noi semo a buon punto;
IT.48: non stringer, ma rallarga ogne vigore.
IT.49: Tu se' omai al purgatorio giunto:
IT.50: vedi là il balzo che 'l chiude dintorno;
IT.51: vedi l'entrata là 've par digiunto.
IT.52: Dianzi, ne l'alba che procede al giorno,
IT.53: quando l'anima tua dentro dormia,
IT.54: sovra li fiori ond' è là giù addorno
IT.55: venne una donna, e disse: 'I' son Lucia;
IT.56: lasciatemi pigliar costui che dorme;
IT.57: sì l'agevolerò per la sua via.'
IT.58: Sordel rimase e l'altre genti forme;
IT.59: ella ti tolse, e come 'l dì fu chiaro,
IT.60: sen venne suso; e io per le sue orme.
IT.61: Qui ti posò, ma pria mi dimostraro
IT.62: li occhi suoi belli quella intrata aperta;
IT.63: poi ella e 'l sonno ad una se n'andaro."
IT.64: A guisa d'uom che 'n dubbio si raccerta
IT.65: e che muta in conforto sua paura,
IT.66: poi che la verità li è discoperta,
IT.67: mi cambia' io; e come sanza cura
IT.68: vide me 'l duca mio, su per lo balzo
IT.69: si mosse, e io di rietro inver' l'altura.
IT.70: Lettor, tu vedi ben com' io innalzo
IT.71: la mia matera, e però con più arte
IT.72: non ti maravigliar s'io la rincalzo.
IT.73: Noi ci appressammo, ed eravamo in parte
IT.74: che là dove pareami prima rotto,
IT.75: pur come un fesso che muro diparte,
IT.76: vidi una porta, e tre gradi di sotto
IT.77: per gire ad essa, di color diversi,
IT.78: e un portier ch'ancor non facea motto.
IT.79: E come l'occhio più e più v'apersi,
IT.80: vidil seder sovra 'l grado sovrano,
IT.81: tal ne la faccia ch'io non lo soffersi;
IT.82: e una spada nuda avëa in mano,
IT.83: che reflettëa i raggi sì ver' noi,
IT.84: ch'io dirizzava spesso il viso in vano.
IT.85: "Dite costinci: che volete voi?"
IT.86: cominciò elli a dire, "ov' è la scorta?
IT.87: Guardate che 'l venir sù non vi nòi."
IT.88: "Donna del ciel, di queste cose accorta,"
IT.89: rispuose 'l mio maestro a lui, "pur dianzi
IT.90: ne disse: 'Andate là: quivi è la porta.'"
IT.91: "Ed ella i passi vostri in bene avanzi,"
IT.92: ricominciò il cortese portinaio:
IT.93: "Venite dunque a' nostri gradi innanzi."
IT.94: Là ne venimmo; e lo scaglion primaio
IT.95: bianco marmo era sì pulito e terso,
IT.96: ch'io mi specchiai in esso qual io paio.
IT.97: Era il secondo tinto più che perso,
IT.98: d'una petrina ruvida e arsiccia,
IT.99: crepata per lo lungo e per traverso.
IT.100: Lo terzo, che di sopra s'ammassiccia,
IT.101: porfido mi parea, sì fiammeggiante
IT.102: come sangue che fuor di vena spiccia.
IT.103: Sovra questo tenëa ambo le piante
IT.104: l'angel di Dio sedendo in su la soglia
IT.105: che mi sembiava pietra di diamante.
IT.106: Per li tre gradi sù di buona voglia
IT.107: mi trasse il duca mio, dicendo: "Chiedi
IT.108: umilemente che 'l serrame scioglia."
IT.109: Divoto mi gittai a' santi piedi;
IT.110: misericordia chiesi e ch'el m'aprisse,
IT.111: ma tre volte nel petto pria mi diedi.
IT.112: Sette P ne la fronte mi descrisse
IT.113: col punton de la spada, e "Fa che lavi,
IT.114: quando se' dentro, queste piaghe" disse.
IT.115: Cenere, o terra che secca si cavi,
IT.116: d'un color fora col suo vestimento;
IT.117: e di sotto da quel trasse due chiavi.
IT.118: L'una era d'oro e l'altra era d'argento;
IT.119: pria con la bianca e poscia con la gialla
IT.120: fece a la porta sì, ch'i' fu' contento.
IT.121: "Quandunque l'una d'este chiavi falla,
IT.122: che non si volga dritta per la toppa,"
IT.123: diss' elli a noi, "non s'apre questa calla.
IT.124: Più cara è l'una; ma l'altra vuol troppa
IT.125: d'arte e d'ingegno avanti che diserri,
IT.126: perch' ella è quella che 'l nodo digroppa.
IT.127: Da Pier le tegno; e dissemi ch'i' erri
IT.128: anzi ad aprir ch'a tenerla serrata,
IT.129: pur che la gente a' piedi mi s'atterri."
IT.130: Poi pinse l'uscio a la porta sacrata,
IT.131: dicendo: "Intrate; ma facciovi accorti
IT.132: che di fuor torna chi 'n dietro si guata."
IT.133: E quando fuor ne' cardini distorti
IT.134: li spigoli di quella regge sacra,
IT.135: che di metallo son sonanti e forti,
IT.136: non rugghiò sì né si mostrò sì acra
IT.137: Tarpëa, come tolto le fu il buono
IT.138: Metello, per che poi rimase macra.
IT.139: Io mi rivolsi attento al primo tuono,
IT.140: e "Te Deum laudamus" mi parea
IT.141: udire in voce mista al dolce suono.
IT.142: Tale imagine a punto mi rendea
IT.143: ciò ch'io udiva, qual prender si suole
IT.144: quando a cantar con organi si stea;
IT.145: ch'or sì or no s'intendon le parole.

EN.1: The concubine of old Tithonus,
EN.2: fresh from her doting lover's arms,
EN.3: was glowing white at the window of the east,
EN.4: her forehead glittering with gems
EN.5: set in the shape of that cold-blooded creature
EN.6: that strikes men with its tail.
EN.7: Where we were, night had climbed
EN.8: two steps of her ascent and now the wings
EN.9: of the third were already drooping,
EN.10: when I, who had with me something of Adam,
EN.11: lay down, overcome by sleep, there on the grass
EN.12: where the five of us were seated.
EN.13: At the hour near the verge of morning,
EN.14: when the swallow begins her plaintive song,
EN.15: remembering, perhaps, her woes of long ago,
EN.16: and when our mind, more pilgrim
EN.17: from the flesh and less caught up in thoughts,
EN.18: is more prophetic in its visions,
EN.19: in a dream I seemed to see an eagle,
EN.20: with golden feathers, hovering in the sky,
EN.21: his wings spread wide, ready to swoop.
EN.22: And to me it seemed I was in the very place
EN.23: where Ganymede abandoned his own kind
EN.24: when he was carried up to the highest council.
EN.25: And I pondered: --'Perhaps it is its habit
EN.26: to strike only here, disdaining to pluck
EN.27: from elsewhere any in its talons.'
EN.28: Then it seemed to me that after wheeling awhile
EN.29: it plunged down terrible as lightning,
EN.30: and carried me straight to the sphere of fire.
EN.31: There it seemed that it and I were both aflame,
EN.32: and the imagined burning was so hot
EN.33: my sleep was broken and gave way.
EN.34: Not otherwise Achilles started up,
EN.35: moving his startled eyes in a wide circle,
EN.36: not knowing where he was
EN.37: that time his mother carried him,
EN.38: sleeping in her arms, from Chiron to Scyros,
EN.39: where later the Greeks would take him away--
EN.40: than I awoke, the sleep gone from my eyes,
EN.41: and then went pale,
EN.42: like a man frozen in his terror.
EN.43: At my side there was no one but my comfort,
EN.44: the sun more than two hours high.
EN.45: My face was turned toward the sea.
EN.46: 'Do not be frightened,' said my lord,
EN.47: 'have confidence, for all is well with us.
EN.48: Do not hold back, but rally all your strength.
EN.49: 'Now you have come to Purgatory:
EN.50: there you see the rock wall that encloses it
EN.51: and, where that seems breached, the entrance.
EN.52: 'A short time ago, in the early light of dawn,
EN.53: when your soul was asleep within you,
EN.54: on the flowers that adorn the place below
EN.55: 'there came a lady who said: "I am Lucy.
EN.56: Let me gather up this sleeping man
EN.57: so I may speed him on his way."
EN.58: 'Sordello stayed, as did the other noble souls,
EN.59: and she took you and, as soon as it was day,
EN.60: went up, and I then followed in her steps.
EN.61: 'Here she set you down, but first her lovely eyes
EN.62: showed me that entrance, standing open.
EN.63: Then she and sleep, as one, departed.'
EN.64: Like a man who comes to see the truth
EN.65: when he has been in doubt and now is reassured,
EN.66: confidence replacing what in him was fear,
EN.67: so was I changed. When my leader saw
EN.68: that I was free of care, he started up the path,
EN.69: and I behind him, heading for the height.
EN.70: Reader, you surely understand that I am raising
EN.71: the level of my subject here. Do not wonder,
EN.72: therefore, if I sustain it with more artifice.
EN.73: We drew closer until we reached a place
EN.74: where what at first had seemed a gap,
EN.75: a breach that rends a wall,
EN.76: I now saw was a gate, with three steps leading
EN.77: up to it, each one of a different color.
EN.78: The keeper of that gate as yet said not a word.
EN.79: And, when my eyes could make him out more clearly,
EN.80: I saw that he was seated above the topmost step,
EN.81: his face so bright I could not bear to look.
EN.82: In his hand he held a naked sword,
EN.83: which so reflected his bright rays
EN.84: I often had to turn my eager eyes away.
EN.85: 'Say it from there, what do you want,'
EN.86: he began, 'and where is your escort?
EN.87: Beware lest your arrival cause you grief.'
EN.88: 'A lady from Heaven, who knows about such things,'
EN.89: my master replied, 'said to us just now,
EN.90: "Go that way, that way lies the gate."'
EN.91: 'And may she speed your steps to good,'
EN.92: continued the courteous keeper of the gate.
EN.93: 'Come forward, then, to these our stairs.'
EN.94: At that we moved ahead. The first step
EN.95: was of clear white marble, so polished
EN.96: that my image was reflected in true likeness.
EN.97: The second was darker than the deepest purple,
EN.98: of unhewn stone, looking as if it had been burned,
EN.99: cracked through its length and breadth.
EN.100: The third, resting its heavy mass above,
EN.101: seemed to me porphyry, as flaming red
EN.102: as blood that spurts out from a vein.
EN.103: On this, seated on the threshold,
EN.104: which seemed to be of adamant,
EN.105: the angel of God rested both his feet.
EN.106: Up the three steps my leader drew me
EN.107: and I was glad for that. Then he said:
EN.108: 'Humbly petition him to slide the bolt.'
EN.109: Devoutly I cast myself down at his holy feet.
EN.110: I begged him for mercy and to let me enter,
EN.111: but first, three times, I smote my breast.
EN.112: With the point of his sword he traced seven P's
EN.113: upon my forehead, then said: 'Once you are inside,
EN.114: see that you wash away these wounds.'

EN.4: 'praised be your name and power
EN.5: by every creature, as is fitting
EN.6: to render thanks for your sweet breath.
EN.7: 'May the peace of your kingdom come to us,
EN.8: for we cannot attain it of ourselves
EN.9: if it come not, for all our striving.
EN.10: 'As your angels make sacrifice to you
EN.11: of their free wills, singing hosanna,
EN.12: so let men make an offering of theirs.
EN.13: 'Give us this day the daily manna
EN.14: without which he who labors to advance
EN.15: goes backward through this bitter wilderness.
EN.16: 'And, as we forgive those who have wronged us,
EN.17: do you forgive us in your loving kindness--
EN.18: measure us not as we deserve.
EN.19: 'Do not put to proof our powers,
EN.20: which yield so lightly to the ancient foe,
EN.21: but deliver us from him who tempts them.
EN.22: 'This last petition, our dear Lord, is made
EN.23: now not for ourselves--for us there is no need--
EN.24: but for the ones whom we have left behind.'
EN.25: Thus praying for safe haven for themselves and us,
EN.26: those shades trudged on beneath their burden,
EN.27: the kind that sometimes weighs us down in dreams,
EN.28: as they, unequally distressed,
EN.29: plodded their weary round on that first ledge,
EN.30: purging away the darkness of the world.
EN.31: If good is always said of us up there,
EN.32: what can be said and done for them on earth
EN.33: by those whose wills have roots in good?
EN.34: Surely we should help them wash away the stains
EN.35: they carried with them, so that pure and light
EN.36: they may approach the star-hung spheres.
EN.37: 'Please, so may justice and mercy soon
EN.38: unburden you and give you wings
EN.39: to lift you up as high as you desire,
EN.40: 'show us the shortest crossing to the stairs,
EN.41: and if there is more than one ascent,
EN.42: let us know where the drop is not so steep,
EN.43: 'for he that comes along with me,
EN.44: burdened with the weight of Adam's flesh,
EN.45: though eager to ascend, is slow at climbing.'
EN.46: It was not clear from whom now came
EN.47: words spoken in response to those
EN.48: voiced by the man I followed,
EN.49: but we heard: 'Come with us on the bank,
EN.50: keeping to the right, to find the stairs
EN.51: a living man can climb.
EN.52: 'If I were not encumbered by the stone
EN.53: that serves to bend my stiff-necked pride
EN.54: so that I cannot lift my face,
EN.55: 'I would look at this man, still alive
EN.56: but nameless, to see if he is known to me
EN.57: and make him feel pity for my heavy load.
EN.58: 'I was Italian, a noble Tuscan's son.
EN.59: Guglielmo Aldobrandesco was my father--
EN.60: I do not know if you have ever heard his name.
EN.61: 'The ancient blood and gallant deeds
EN.62: done by my forebears raised such arrogance in me
EN.63: that, forgetful of our common mother,
EN.64: 'I held all men in such great scorn
EN.65: it caused my death--how, all in Siena know,
EN.66: and every child in Campagnatico.
EN.67: 'I am Omberto. Pride has undone
EN.68: not only me but all my kinsmen,
EN.69: whom it has dragged into calamity.
EN.70: 'And for this pride, I must here bear this load--
EN.71: here among the dead, since I did not
EN.72: among the living--until God is satisfied.'
EN.73: Listening, I bent down my face, and one of them,
EN.74: not he who spoke, twisted himself
EN.75: beneath the load that weighed him down,
EN.76: saw me and knew me and called out,
EN.77: with difficulty keeping his eyes fixed on me,
EN.78: as I, all hunched, trudged on beside them.
EN.79: 'Oh,' I said to him, 'are you not Oderisi,
EN.80: the honor of Gubbio and of that art
EN.81: which they in Paris call illumination?'
EN.82: 'Brother,' he said, 'the pages smile brighter
EN.83: from the brush of Franco of Bologna.
EN.84: The honor is all his now--and only mine in part.
EN.85: 'Indeed, I hardly would have been so courteous
EN.86: while I still lived--an overwhelming need
EN.87: to excel at any cost held fast my heart.
EN.88: 'For such pride here we pay our debt.
EN.89: I would not be here yet, except, while living,
EN.90: and with the means to sin, I turned to God.
EN.91: 'O vanity of human powers,
EN.92: how briefly lasts the crowning green of glory,
EN.93: unless an age of darkness follows!
EN.94: 'In painting Cimabue thought he held the field
EN.95: but now it's Giotto has the cry,
EN.96: so that the other's fame is dimmed.
EN.97: 'Thus has one Guido taken from the other
EN.98: the glory of our tongue, and he, perhaps, is born
EN.99: who will drive one and then the other from the nest.
EN.100: 'Worldly fame is nothing but a gust of wind,
EN.101: first blowing from one quarter, then another,
EN.102: changing name with every new direction.
EN.103: 'Will greater fame be yours if you put off
EN.104: your flesh when it is old than had you died
EN.105: with pappo and dindi still upon your lips
EN.106: 'after a thousand years have passed? To eternity,
EN.107: that time is shorter than the blinking of an eye
EN.108: is to one circling of the slowest-moving sphere.
EN.109: 'All Tuscany resounded with the name--
EN.110: now barely whispered even in Siena--
EN.111: of him who moves so slow in front of me.
EN.112: 'He was the ruler there when they put down
EN.113: the insolence of Florence,
EN.114: a city then as proud as now she is a whore.
EN.115: 'Your renown is but the hue of grass, which comes
EN.116: and goes, and the same sun that makes it spring
EN.117: green from the ground will wither it.'
EN.118: And I to him: 'Your true words pierce my heart
EN.119: with fit humility and ease a heavy swelling there.
EN.120: But who is he of whom you spoke just now?'
EN.121: 'That,' he replied, 'is Provenzan Salvani,
EN.122: and he is here because in his presumption
EN.123: he sought to have all Siena in his grasp.
EN.124: 'Thus burdened he has gone, and goes on without rest,
EN.125: ever since he died. Such coin he pays,
EN.126: who is too bold on earth, in recompense.'
EN.127: And I said: 'If the spirit that puts off
EN.128: repentance to the very edge of life
EN.129: must stay below, before he comes up here,
EN.130: 'as long as he has lived--
EN.131: unless he's helped by holy prayers--
EN.132: how was his coming here allowed?'
EN.133: 'While he was living in his greatest glory,' he said,
EN.134: 'he willingly sat in the marketplace
EN.135: of Siena, putting aside all shame,
EN.136: 'and there, to redeem his friend
EN.137: from the torment he endured in Charles's prison,
EN.138: he was reduced to trembling in every vein.
EN.139: 'I say no more, and know my speech obscure.
EN.140: It won't be long before they act, your townsmen,
EN.141: in such a way that you'll know how to gloss it.
EN.142: It was that deed which brought him past those confines.'

EN.1: As oxen go beneath their yoke
EN.2: that overladen soul and I went side by side
EN.3: as long as my dear escort granted.
EN.4: But when he said: 'Leave him and hurry on,
EN.5: for it is fitting here, with all your strength,
EN.6: to speed your ship with wings and oars,'
EN.7: I straightened up, erect,
EN.8: as one should walk, but still my thoughts
EN.9: remained bowed down and shrunken.
EN.10: I set out, following gladly
EN.11: in my master's steps, and our easy stride
EN.12: made clear how light we felt.
EN.13: And he to me: 'Cast down your eyes.
EN.14: It will be good for you and calm you on your way
EN.15: to look down at the bed beneath your feet.'
EN.16: As gravestones set above the buried dead
EN.17: bear witness to what once they were,
EN.18: their carven images recalling them to mind,
EN.19: making us grieve with frequent tears
EN.20: when recollection pricks and spurs
EN.21: the faithful heart with memories,
EN.22: so were these figures sculpted there
EN.23: along that road carved from the mountainside,
EN.24: but in their artistry more true in their resemblance.
EN.25: My eyes beheld the one, created nobler
EN.26: than any other creature, fall like lightning
EN.27: from the sky, over to one side.
EN.28: My eyes beheld Briarèus, on the other,
EN.29: transfixed by the celestial bolt,
EN.30: now heavy on the earth in chill of death.
EN.31: My eyes beheld Thymbraeus, Pallas, and Mars,
EN.32: still armed, together with their father,
EN.33: astounded by the giants' scattered limbs.
EN.34: My eyes beheld Nimrod at the base of his great work,
EN.35: as though bewildered, and the people,
EN.36: who in Shinar shared his pride, all looking on.
EN.37: Ah, Niobe, I saw you sculpted in the roadway,
EN.38: your eyes welling up with grief,
EN.39: amidst your dead, seven sons and seven daughters.
EN.40: Ah, Saul, you too appeared there, dead
EN.41: on your own sword in the mountains of Gilboa,
EN.42: which never after knew the rain or dew.
EN.43: Ah, mad Arachne, I saw you all but turned
EN.44: to spider, wretched on the strands
EN.45: you spun, which did you so much harm.
EN.46: Ah, Rehoboam, now your image does not seem
EN.47: to menace but to cower. A chariot bears it off--
EN.48: and there is no one giving chase.
EN.49: Now was shown, on that hard floor,
EN.50: how Alcmaeon made that necklace, ill-omened,
EN.51: seem not worth the price his mother paid.
EN.52: Now was shown how his sons fell upon
EN.53: Sennacherib inside the temple,
EN.54: and how, slain, they left him there.
EN.55: Now was shown the destruction and cruel slaughter
EN.56: wrought by Tomyris when she said to Cyrus:
EN.57: 'You thirsted for blood. Now drink your fill.'
EN.58: Now was shown the Assyrians routed and in flight
EN.59: after the slaying of Holofernes
EN.60: and the leavings of that slaughter.
EN.61: My eyes beheld Troy in ashes and in ruins.
EN.62: Ah, Ilion, how reduced and shamed you were
EN.63: now was shown within the carving.
EN.64: What master of the brush and stylus
EN.65: could have designed these forms and outlines
EN.66: that would astound even the truest talent?
EN.67: Dead seemed the dead, living seemed the living.
EN.68: He who beheld the real events on which I walked,
EN.69: head bent, saw them no better than did I.
EN.70: Wax proud then, go your way with head held high,
EN.71: you sons of Eve, and no, do not bend down your face
EN.72: and so reflect upon your evil path!
EN.73: We had done more of the mountain's circle
EN.74: and the sun had sped along its track
EN.75: more than my mind, being bound, had reckoned,
EN.76: when he, who always looked before him
EN.77: as he went, spoke out: 'Raise your head!
EN.78: This is not the time for walking so absorbed.
EN.79: 'See the angel over there, preparing
EN.80: to approach. See the sixth handmaid who returns
EN.81: from her service of the day.
EN.82: 'Show reverence in your face and bearing
EN.83: so that he may be pleased to send us upward.
EN.84: Consider that this day will never dawn again.'
EN.85: I was accustomed to his admonitions
EN.86: not to waste my time, so that on this matter
EN.87: his speech was not obscure.
EN.88: The fair creature, garbed in white,
EN.89: came toward us. In his face there was what seemed
EN.90: the shimmering of the morning star.
EN.91: Opening his arms, he spread his wings
EN.92: and said: 'Come, the steps are here at hand.
EN.93: From here on up the climb is easy.
EN.94: 'They are very few who answer to this bidding.
EN.95: O race of man, born to fly on high,
EN.96: why does a puff of wind cause you to fall?'
EN.97: He brought us where the rock was cleft,
EN.98: there tapped my forehead with his wings,
EN.99: then promised me that going on I would be safe.
EN.100: Just as, to climb the hillside where the church is set
EN.101: which, over Rubaconte, dominates
EN.102: the justly governed city, there on the right
EN.103: the sheer slope of the steep ascent is cut
EN.104: by stairs that were constructed in a time
EN.105: when registers and measures could be trusted,
EN.106: even so the bank that sharply falls away
EN.107: from the higher circle is made gentler, except
EN.108: that here and there the towering rock scrapes close.
EN.109: While we were moving off in that direction,
EN.110: 'Beati pauperes spiritu' a voice was singing
EN.111: in tones that speech could not express.
EN.112: Ah, how different these entrances from those of Hell,
EN.113: for here one's coming in is met with songs
EN.114: but there with savage lamentation!
EN.115: Now we were climbing on the hallowed stairs
EN.116: and I felt so much lighter than before,
EN.117: when the ground I trod was level,
EN.118: that I said: 'Master, tell me,
EN.119: what weight has been lifted from me
EN.120: that going on is hardly any effort?'
EN.121: He answered: 'When the P's that still remain
EN.122: upon your brow, though very faint, shall be,
EN.123: as one already is, erased,
EN.124: 'your legs shall be so mastered by good will,
EN.125: not only will they feel no effort going up,
EN.126: but they will take delight in being urged to.'
EN.127: Then I did as those who go along,
EN.128: with something on their head, unknown to them,
EN.129: except the acts of others make them wonder,
EN.130: so that they reach up with their hand for answers.
EN.131: Touching and searching they accomplish
EN.132: the task that sight cannot achieve,
EN.133: and, spreading the fingers of my right hand,
EN.134: I found that, of the seven letters he of the keys
EN.135: had traced upon my forehead, only six remained.
EN.136: Observing this, my leader smiled.
