IT.60: e tutti da la ripa eran sofferti.
IT.61: Così li ciechi a cui la roba falla,
IT.62: stanno a' perdoni a chieder lor bisogna,
IT.63: e l'uno il capo sopra l'altro avvalla,
IT.64: perché 'n altrui pietà tosto si pogna,
IT.65: non pur per lo sonar de le parole,
IT.66: ma per la vista che non meno agogna.
IT.67: E come a li orbi non approda il sole,
IT.68: così a l'ombre quivi, ond' io parlo ora,
IT.69: luce del ciel di sé largir non vole;
IT.70: ché a tutti un fil di ferro i cigli fóra
IT.71: e cusce sì, come a sparvier selvaggio
IT.72: si fa però che queto non dimora.
IT.73: A me pareva, andando, fare oltraggio,
IT.74: veggendo altrui, non essendo veduto:
IT.75: per ch'io mi volsi al mio consiglio saggio.
IT.76: Ben sapev' ei che volea dir lo muto;
IT.77: e però non attese mia dimanda,
IT.78: ma disse: "Parla, e sie breve e arguto."
IT.79: Virgilio mi venìa da quella banda
IT.80: de la cornice onde cader si puote,
IT.81: perché da nulla sponda s'inghirlanda;
IT.82: da l'altra parte m'eran le divote
IT.83: ombre, che per l'orribile costura
IT.84: premevan sì, che bagnavan le gote.
IT.85: Volsimi a loro e: "O gente sicura,"
IT.86: incominciai, "di veder l'alto lume
IT.87: che 'l disio vostro solo ha in sua cura,
IT.88: se tosto grazia resolva le schiume
IT.89: di vostra coscïenza sì che chiaro
IT.90: per essa scenda de la mente il fiume,
IT.91: ditemi, ché mi fia grazioso e caro,
IT.92: s'anima è qui tra voi che sia latina;
IT.93: e forse lei sarà buon s'i' l'apparo."
IT.94: "O frate mio, ciascuna è cittadina
IT.95: d'una vera città; ma tu vuo' dire
IT.96: che vivesse in Italia peregrina."
IT.97: Questo mi parve per risposta udire
IT.98: più innanzi alquanto che là dov' io stava,
IT.99: ond' io mi feci ancor più là sentire.
IT.100: Tra l'altre vidi un'ombra ch'aspettava
IT.101: in vista; e se volesse alcun dir "Come?"
IT.102: lo mento a guisa d'orbo in sù levava.
IT.103: "Spirto," diss' io, "che per salir ti dome,
IT.104: se tu se' quelli che mi rispondesti,
IT.105: fammiti conto o per luogo o per nome."
IT.106: "Io fui sanese," rispuose, "e con questi
IT.107: altri rimendo qui la vita ria,
IT.108: lagrimando a colui che sé ne presti.
IT.109: Savia non fui, avvegna che Sapìa
IT.110: fossi chiamata, e fui de li altrui danni
IT.111: più lieta assai che di ventura mia.
IT.112: E perché tu non creda ch'io t'inganni,
IT.113: odi s'i' fui, com' io ti dico, folle,
IT.114: già discendendo l'arco d'i miei anni.
IT.115: Eran li cittadin miei presso a Colle
IT.116: in campo giunti co' loro avversari,
IT.117: e io pregava Iddio di quel ch'e' volle.
IT.118: Rotti fuor quivi e vòlti ne li amari
IT.119: passi di fuga; e veggendo la caccia,
IT.120: letizia presi a tutte altre dispari,
IT.121: tanto ch'io volsi in sù l'ardita faccia,
IT.122: gridando a Dio: 'Omai più non ti temo!'
IT.123: come fé 'l merlo per poca bonaccia.
IT.124: Pace volli con Dio in su lo stremo
IT.125: de la mia vita; e ancor non sarebbe
IT.126: lo mio dover per penitenza scemo,
IT.127: se ciò non fosse, ch'a memoria m'ebbe
IT.128: Pier Pettinaio in sue sante orazioni,
IT.129: a cui di me per caritate increbbe.
IT.130: Ma tu chi se', che nostre condizioni
IT.131: vai dimandando, e porti li occhi sciolti,
IT.132: sì com' io credo, e spirando ragioni?"
IT.133: "Li occhi," diss' io, "mi fieno ancor qui tolti,
IT.134: ma picciol tempo, ché poca è l'offesa
IT.135: fatta per esser con invidia vòlti.
IT.136: Troppa è più la paura ond' è sospesa
IT.137: l'anima mia del tormento di sotto,
IT.138: che già lo 'ncarco di là giù mi pesa."
IT.139: Ed ella a me: "Chi t'ha dunque condotto
IT.140: qua sù tra noi, se giù ritornar credi?"
IT.141: E io: "Costui ch'è meco e non fa motto.
IT.142: E vivo sono; e però mi richiedi,
IT.143: spirito eletto, se tu vuo' ch'i' mova
IT.144: di là per te ancor li mortai piedi."
IT.145: "Oh, questa è a udir sì cosa nuova,"
IT.146: rispuose, "che gran segno è che Dio t'ami;
IT.147: però col priego tuo talor mi giova.
IT.148: E cheggioti, per quel che tu più brami,
IT.149: se mai calchi la terra di Toscana,
IT.150: che a' miei propinqui tu ben mi rinfami.
IT.151: Tu li vedrai tra quella gente vana
IT.152: che spera in Talamone, e perderagli
IT.153: più di speranza ch'a trovar la Diana;
IT.154: ma più vi perderanno li ammiragli."

EN.1: We were at the summit of the stair
EN.2: where the mountain that unsins us as we climb
EN.3: is for the second time cut back.
EN.4: There another terrace carves the hill,
EN.5: just like the first, except its arc
EN.6: is shorter and it makes a tighter curve.
EN.7: There are no shades nor any carvings--
EN.8: only the bank and the bare road
EN.9: with the livid color of the stone.
EN.10: 'If we linger here to ask directions,'
EN.11: the poet reasoned, 'before we choose our way,
EN.12: I fear we may be long delayed.'
EN.13: Then he fixed his eyes upon the sun
EN.14: and made a pivot of the right side of his body
EN.15: on which he swung his left side forward.
EN.16: 'O sweet light, in whose help I trust
EN.17: as I set out upon this unknown road,' he said,
EN.18: 'give us whatever guidance here is needed.
EN.19: 'You shed your light upon the world and warm it.
EN.20: Unless we find good reason to do other,
EN.21: your rays must always be our guide.'
EN.22: We had already gone as far
EN.23: as here on earth would count a mile--
EN.24: but quickly, for our will was eager--
EN.25: when, flying toward us, spirits could be heard,
EN.26: not seen, sounding courteous invitation
EN.27: to the table readied for the feast of love.
EN.28: The first voice, flying by,
EN.29: called loudly: 'Vinum non habent'
EN.30: and, having passed, called out the same again.
EN.31: Before it was quite out of hearing
EN.32: in the distance, there came another, crying:
EN.33: 'I am Orestes,' and it also did not stay.
EN.34: 'O father,' I said, 'what voices are these?'
EN.35: And as I asked there came a third voice, saying:
EN.36: 'Love him who has done you wrong.'
EN.37: And the good master said: 'This circle
EN.38: scourges the sin of envy, and thus
EN.39: the cords of the scourge are drawn from love.
EN.40: 'To rein in envy requires opposing notes.
EN.41: Such other voices you will hear, I think,
EN.42: before you reach the pass of pardon.
EN.43: 'Now fix your sight more steady through the air
EN.44: and you will make out figures seated
EN.45: in front of us along the rock.'
EN.46: Then, opening my eyes still wider,
EN.47: I looked ahead and now could see
EN.48: shades wearing cloaks the color of the stone.
EN.49: We had gone a little farther on,
EN.50: when I heard voices crying: 'Mary, pray for us,'
EN.51: then 'Michael,' 'Peter,' and 'All saints.'
EN.52: I do not think there walks on earth today
EN.53: a man so hard that he would not have been
EN.54: transfixed by pity at what I saw next,
EN.55: for when I had drawn close enough
EN.56: so that their state grew clear to me
EN.57: my eyes were overwhelmed by grief.
EN.58: They appeared covered with coarse haircloth.
EN.59: Each propped up another with his shoulder,
EN.60: and all of them were propped against the rock.
EN.61: Just so the blind who lack for daily bread
EN.62: at pardons take their place to beg for what they need,
EN.63: one letting his head fall on another's shoulder
EN.64: so that he may more quickly prompt to pity,
EN.65: not only with the words that he is saying
EN.66: but with his looks, which plead no less.
EN.67: And as the sun is of no profit to the blind,
EN.68: so Heaven's light denies its bounty
EN.69: to the shades in the place of which I speak,
EN.70: for iron wire pierces all their eyelids,
EN.71: stitching them together, as is done
EN.72: to the untrained falcon because it won't be calmed.
EN.73: As I went on, it seemed to me that seeing others,
EN.74: without my being seen, offended them,
EN.75: so that I turned to my wise counsel.
EN.76: Well he knew what my silence meant to say
EN.77: and did not wait to hear me ask, but said:
EN.78: 'Speak, yet be brief and to the point.'
EN.79: Virgil, moving along beside me on the terrace,
EN.80: was at the edge, where one might fall
EN.81: because no parapet encircled it.
EN.82: At my other side were the shades in prayer
EN.83: who, through those dreadful seams,
EN.84: were wringing tears that bathed their cheeks.
EN.85: I turned to them and I began:
EN.86: 'O people assured of seeing light on high--
EN.87: sole object stirring your desire--
EN.88: 'so grace may soon dissolve the scum
EN.89: that fouls your conscience, and the stream
EN.90: of memory flow through it pure,
EN.91: 'tell me, for I shall hold it courteous and dear,
EN.92: if any soul among you is Italian.
EN.93: Perhaps for me to know might profit such a one.'
EN.94: 'O my brother, all of us are citizens
EN.95: of the one true city. What you mean to say is,
EN.96: "who, while still a pilgrim, lived in Italy."'
EN.97: This it seemed to me I heard in answer
EN.98: farther along from where I stood,
EN.99: and I made myself heard by moving closer.
EN.100: Among the rest I saw a shade that looked expectant,
EN.101: and if any should ask 'how?', it was raising
EN.102: its chin the way a blind man does.
EN.103: 'Spirit,' I said, 'who abase yourself to climb,
EN.104: if you were the one who answered me,
EN.105: make yourself known by your city or your name.'
EN.106: 'I was of Siena,' replied the shade,
EN.107: 'and with these others here I mend my sinful life,
EN.108: weeping to Him that He may lend Himself to us.
EN.109: 'Sapìa was my name, though I was far from wise,
EN.110: for I rejoiced much more at harm done others
EN.111: than at my own good fortune.
EN.112: 'And, so that you know I do not lie,
EN.113: hear me out when I tell how mad I was,
EN.114: with the arc of my years already in decline.
EN.115: 'My townsmen were near Colle,
EN.116: engaged in battle with their enemies, and I prayed
EN.117: that God let happen what in fact He willed.
EN.118: 'When they were routed and turned back
EN.119: in bitter steps of flight, I watched the chase,
EN.120: my heart filled with such boundless joy
EN.121: 'that recklessly I turned my face to God,
EN.122: crying: "Now I do not fear you any more,"
EN.123: as the blackbird said after a glint of sunshine.
EN.124: 'I sought my peace with God
EN.125: at the very last, and penitence
EN.126: would not have yet reduced the debt
EN.127: 'had it not been for Peter the comb-seller
EN.128: who in his charity was grieved for me
EN.129: and remembered me in his devout petitions.
EN.130: 'But who are you who walk about inquiring
EN.131: of our condition, with your eyes not sewn,
EN.132: as I suspect, and speak with breath?'
EN.133: 'My eyes,' I said, 'will yet be taken
EN.134: from me here, but for a short while only,
EN.135: for small is their offense in looks of envy.
EN.136: 'Greater is the fear, which fills my soul with dread,
EN.137: of torments lower down, those heavy loads--
EN.138: I can almost feel their weight upon me now.'
EN.139: And she: 'Who has led you here among us,
EN.140: if you think that you'll return below?' And I:
EN.141: 'He that is with me here and does not speak.
EN.142: 'I am alive, and therefore ask of me,
EN.143: you chosen spirit, if you would have me move
EN.144: my mortal feet for your sake back on earth.'
EN.145: 'Oh,' she replied, 'how wonderful it is to hear
EN.146: of this great token of God's love for you.
EN.147: Since it is so, aid me sometime with a prayer.
EN.148: 'And I entreat you by what you most desire,
EN.149: if ever you tread the soil of Tuscany,
EN.150: to restore my name among my kinfolk.
EN.151: 'You will find them part of that vain people
EN.152: who pinned their hopes on Talamone and will lose
EN.153: more hope thereby than in their search for the Diana--
EN.154: but it is their admirals who shall lose still more.'

IT.1: "Chi è costui che 'l nostro monte cerchia
IT.2: prima che morte li abbia dato il volo,
IT.3: e apre li occhi a sua voglia e coverchia?"
IT.4: "Non so chi sia, ma so ch'e' non è solo;
IT.5: domandal tu che più li t'avvicini,
IT.6: e dolcemente, sì che parli, acco'lo."
IT.7: Così due spirti, l'uno a l'altro chini,
IT.8: ragionavan di me ivi a man dritta;
IT.9: poi fer li visi, per dirmi, supini;
IT.10: e disse l'uno: "O anima che fitta
IT.11: nel corpo ancora inver' lo ciel ten vai,
IT.12: per carità ne consola e ne ditta
IT.13: onde vieni e chi se'; ché tu ne fai
IT.14: tanto maravigliar de la tua grazia,
IT.15: quanto vuol cosa che non fu più mai."
IT.16: E io: "Per mezza Toscana si spazia
IT.17: un fiumicel che nasce in Falterona,
IT.18: e cento miglia di corso nol sazia.
IT.19: Di sovr' esso rech' io questa persona:
IT.20: dirvi ch'i' sia, saria parlare indarno,
IT.21: ché 'l nome mio ancor molto non suona."
IT.22: "Se ben lo 'ntendimento tuo accarno
IT.23: con lo 'ntelletto," allora mi rispuose
IT.24: quei che diceva pria, "tu parli d'Arno."
IT.25: E l'altro disse lui: "Perché nascose
IT.26: questi il vocabol di quella riviera,
IT.27: pur com' om fa de l'orribili cose?"
IT.28: E l'ombra che di ciò domandata era,
IT.29: si sdebitò così: "Non so; ma degno
IT.30: ben è che 'l nome di tal valle pèra;
IT.31: ché dal principio suo, ov' è sì pregno
IT.32: l'alpestro monte ond' è tronco Peloro,
IT.33: che 'n pochi luoghi passa oltra quel segno,
IT.34: infin là 've si rende per ristoro
IT.35: di quel che 'l ciel de la marina asciuga,
IT.36: ond' hanno i fiumi ciò che va con loro,
IT.37: vertù così per nimica si fuga
IT.38: da tutti come biscia, o per sventura
IT.39: del luogo, o per mal uso che li fruga:
IT.40: ond' hanno sì mutata lor natura
IT.41: li abitator de la misera valle,
IT.42: che par che Circe li avesse in pastura.
IT.43: Tra brutti porci, più degni di galle
IT.44: che d'altro cibo fatto in uman uso,
IT.45: dirizza prima il suo povero calle.
IT.46: Botoli trova poi, venendo giuso,
IT.47: ringhiosi più che non chiede lor possa,
IT.48: e da lor disdegnosa torce il muso.
IT.49: Vassi caggendo; e quant ella più 'ngrossa,
IT.50: tanto più trova di can farsi lupi
IT.51: la maladetta e sventurata fossa.
IT.52: Discesa poi per più pelaghi cupi,
IT.53: trova le volpi sì piene di froda,
IT.54: che non temono ingegno che le occùpi.
IT.55: Né lascerò di dir perch' altri m'oda;
IT.56: e buon sarà costui, s'ancor s'ammenta
IT.57: di ciò che vero spirto mi disnoda.
IT.58: Io veggio tuo nepote che diventa
IT.59: cacciator di quei lupi in su la riva
IT.60: del fiero fiume, e tutti li sgomenta.
IT.61: Vende la carne loro essendo viva;
IT.62: poscia li ancide come antica belva;
IT.63: molti di vita e sé di pregio priva.
IT.64: Sanguinoso esce de la trista selva;
IT.65: lasciala tal, che di qui a mille anni
IT.66: ne lo stato primaio non si rinselva."
IT.67: Com' a l'annunzio di dogliosi danni
IT.68: si turba il viso di colui ch'ascolta,
IT.69: da qual che parte il periglio l'assanni,
IT.70: così vid' io l'altr' anima, che volta
IT.71: stava a udir, turbarsi e farsi trista,
IT.72: poi ch'ebbe la parola a sé raccolta.
IT.73: Lo dir de l'una e de l'altra la vista
IT.74: mi fer voglioso di saper lor nomi,
IT.75: e dimanda ne fei con prieghi mista;
IT.76: per che lo spirto che di pria parlòmi
IT.77: ricominciò: "Tu vuo' ch'io mi deduca
IT.78: nel fare a te ciò che tu far non vuo'mi.
IT.79: Ma da che Dio in te vuol che traluca
IT.80: tanto sua grazia, non ti sarò scarso;
IT.81: però sappi ch'io fui Guido del Duca.
IT.82: Fu il sangue mio d'invidia sì rïarso,
IT.83: che se veduto avesse uom farsi lieto,
IT.84: visto m'avresti di livore sparso.
IT.85: Di mia semente cotal paglia mieto;
IT.86: o gente umana, perché poni 'l core
IT.87: là 'v' è mestier di consorte divieto?
IT.88: Questi è Rinier; questi è 'l pregio e l'onore
IT.89: de la casa da Calboli, ove nullo
IT.90: fatto s'è reda poi del suo valore.
IT.91: E non pur lo suo sangue è fatto brullo,
IT.92: tra 'l Po e 'l monte e la marina e 'l Reno,
IT.93: del ben richesto al vero e al trastullo;
IT.94: ché dentro a questi termini è ripieno
IT.95: di venenosi sterpi, sì che tardi
IT.96: per coltivare omai verrebber meno.
IT.97: Ov' è 'l buon Lizio e Arrigo Mainardi?
IT.98: Pier Traversaro e Guido di Carpigna?
IT.99: Oh Romagnuoli tornati in bastardi!
IT.100: Quando in Bologna un Fabbro si ralligna?
IT.101: quando in Faenza un Bernardin di Fosco,
IT.102: verga gentil di picciola gramigna?
IT.103: Non ti maravigliar s'io piango, Tosco,
IT.104: quando rimembro, con Guido da Prata,
IT.105: Ugolin d'Azzo che vivette nosco,
IT.106: Federigo Tignoso e sua brigata,
IT.107: la casa Traversara e li Anastagi
IT.108: (e l'una gente e l'altra è diretata),
IT.109: le donne e ' cavalier, li affanni e li agi
IT.110: che ne 'nvogliava amore e cortesia
IT.111: là dove i cuor son fatti sì malvagi.
IT.112: O Bretinoro, ché non fuggi via,
IT.113: poi che gita se n'è la tua famiglia
IT.114: e molta gente per non esser ria?
IT.115: Ben fa Bagnacaval, che non rifiglia;
IT.116: e mal fa Castrocaro, e peggio Conio,
IT.117: che di figliar tai conti più s'impiglia.
IT.118: Ben faranno i Pagan, da che 'l demonio
IT.119: lor sen girà; ma non però che puro
IT.120: già mai rimagna d'essi testimonio.
IT.121: O Ugolin de' Fantolin, sicuro
IT.122: è 'l nome tuo, da che più non s'aspetta
IT.123: chi far lo possa, tralignando, scuro.
IT.124: Ma va via, Tosco, omai; ch'or mi diletta
IT.125: troppo di pianger più che di parlare,
IT.126: sì m'ha nostra ragion la mente stretta."
IT.127: Noi sapavam che quell' anime care
IT.128: ci sentivano andar; però, tacendo,
IT.129: facëan noi del cammin confidare.
IT.130: Poi fummo fatti soli procedendo,
IT.131: folgore parve quando l'aere fende,
IT.132: voce che giunse di contra dicendo:
IT.133: "Anciderammi qualunque m'apprende";
IT.134: e fuggì come tuon che si dilegua,
IT.135: se sùbito la nuvola scoscende.
IT.136: Come da lei l'udir nostro ebbe triegua,
IT.137: ed ecco l'altra con sì gran fracasso,
IT.138: che somigliò tonar che tosto segua:
IT.139: "Io sono Aglauro che divenni sasso";
IT.140: e allor, per ristrignermi al poeta,
IT.141: in destro feci, e non innanzi, il passo.
IT.142: Già era l'aura d'ogne parte queta;
IT.143: ed el mi disse: "Quel fu 'l duro camo
IT.144: che dovria l'uom tener dentro a sua meta.
IT.145: Ma voi prendete l'esca, sì che l'amo
IT.146: de l'antico avversaro a sé vi tira;
IT.147: e però poco val freno o richiamo.
IT.148: Chiamavi 'l cielo e 'ntorno vi si gira,
IT.150: e l'occhio vostro pur a terra mira;
IT.151: onde vi batte chi tutto discerne."

EN.1: 'Who is this, circling our mountain
EN.2: before he has been given wings by death,
EN.3: who can open his eyes at will and shut them?'
EN.4: 'I don't know who he is but know he's not alone.
EN.5: Question him, since you are closer,
EN.6: and greet him courteously that he may answer.'
EN.7: Thus two spirits, their faces almost touching,
EN.8: conversed about me over to the right,
EN.9: then turned their faces up to speak to me.
EN.10: One said: 'O soul still rooted in the body,
EN.11: making your way toward Heaven,
EN.12: for the sake of charity relieve us, let us know
EN.13: 'where you come from and who you are,
EN.14: for the grace bestowed on you has so amazed us
EN.15: as something must that never was before.'
EN.16: And I: 'Through the middle of Tuscany there flows
EN.17: a winding stream that springs in Falterona--
EN.18: a hundred miles of flowing do not slake its thirst.
EN.19: 'From somewhere on its banks I bring this form.
EN.20: To tell you who I am would be to speak in vain,
EN.21: for my name as yet does not resound.'
EN.22: 'If my wit has truly grasped your meaning,'
EN.23: he who had spoken first then answered,
EN.24: 'it is the Arno that you speak of.'
EN.25: And the other asked him:
EN.26: 'Why did he conceal that river's name
EN.27: just as one hides some dreadful thing?'
EN.28: And the interrogated shade thus paid his debt:
EN.29: 'I do not know, but it is only fitting
EN.30: that the name of such a valley perish,
EN.31: 'for from its source, where the wild mountain range,
EN.32: from which Pelorus was broken off, rises to such height
EN.33: that higher places are but few,
EN.34: 'down to where it surrenders to restore
EN.35: what the sky draws from the sea,
EN.36: so that the rivers are supplied in turn,
EN.37: 'all flee from virtue as if it were a snake,
EN.38: an enemy to all, whether some curse
EN.39: is on the place or evil habits goad them on,
EN.40: 'and those who live in that unhappy valley
EN.41: are so altered in their nature it is as though
EN.42: Circe were grazing them at pasture.
EN.43: 'Among filthy hogs, more fit to feed on acorns
EN.44: than on any food that is prepared for men,
EN.45: the water first directs its feeble course.
EN.46: 'Then, coming lower, it finds whelps that snarl
EN.47: more than their powers warrant,
EN.48: and so in scorn the river turns its snout from them.
EN.49: 'It goes on falling and the more it swells
EN.50: the more does the accursed, ill-omened ditch
EN.51: find that these dogs have been transformed to wolves.
EN.52: 'Having fallen through dark and deep-cut gorges,
EN.53: it then finds foxes so very full of fraud
EN.54: they have no fear that any trap can take them.
EN.55: 'Nor will I hold my peace because another hears me.
EN.56: It will be wise of him to keep in mind
EN.57: the truth the Spirit has revealed.
EN.58: 'I see your grandson, who becomes a hunter
EN.59: of the wolves that gather on the banks
EN.60: of that wild stream and puts them all in terror.
EN.61: 'He sells their living flesh,
EN.62: then slaughters them like old and useless cattle.
EN.63: Many he robs of life and robs himself of honor.
EN.64: 'Covered in blood, he leaves that wretched wood
EN.65: in such a state that not one thousand years
EN.66: will make the trees grow green as once they were.'
EN.67: As at the forecast of impending harm
EN.68: the face of one who hears it shows distress,
EN.69: no matter where the threat may bare its fangs,
EN.70: the other soul, who had turned to listen,
EN.71: became troubled and disheartened
EN.72: once he had listened to these words.
EN.73: The speech of one and the expression of the other
EN.74: made me wish to know their names
EN.75: and I asked, entreating their response.
EN.76: The spirit that had spoken first began again:
EN.77: 'You would have me do for you
EN.78: what you do not consent to do for me.
EN.79: 'But since God wills His grace shine forth in you,
EN.80: I will no longer hoard my answer:
EN.81: Know, then, I was Guido del Duca.
EN.82: 'My blood was so consumed by envy
EN.83: that, had I seen a man take joy in life,
EN.84: you would have seen my skin turn livid.
EN.85: 'As I sowed, so now I reap such straw.
EN.86: O race of men, why do you set your hearts
EN.87: on things that of necessity cannot be shared?
EN.88: 'This man is Rinier, this is the pride and honor
EN.89: of the house of Càlboli, where no one since
EN.90: has made himself an heir to his true worth.
EN.91: 'And not his blood alone--between Po and the mountains,
EN.92: between Reno and the sea--is stripped of virtues
EN.93: consonant with deeper thought and courtly pastime.
EN.94: 'For the land within these boundaries
EN.95: is grown so dense with poisonous shoots
EN.96: that even proper tillage now would come too late.
EN.97: 'Where is good Lizio, where Arrigo Mainardi,
EN.98: Pier Traversaro and Guido di Carpigna?
EN.99: O people of Romagna, how you've turned to bastards!
EN.100: 'When, in Bologna, will another Fabbro grow?
EN.101: When, in Faenza, a Bernardin di Fosco,
EN.102: noble branch sprung from a lowly weed?
EN.103: 'Do not marvel, Tuscan, if I weep
EN.104: when, along with Guido da Prata, I recall
EN.105: Ugolin d'Azzo, who lived among us,
EN.106: 'Federico Tignoso and his companions,
EN.107: the house of Traversaro and of Anastagi--
EN.108: both families now spent, without an heir--
EN.109: 'the ladies and the knights, the toils and sport
EN.110: that love and courtesy inspired,
EN.111: where now is found a waste of evil hearts.
EN.112: 'O Bertinoro, why do you not disappear,
EN.113: since your best family, along with many others,
EN.114: has fled you to escape corruption?
EN.115: 'Bagnacavallo does well to breed no more,
EN.116: Castrocaro poorly and Conio worse,
EN.117: obstinate in breeding such degenerate counts.
EN.118: 'The Pagani will do better when their "Devil"
EN.119: shuffles off, yet not so well
EN.120: that they will leave behind a stainless slate.
EN.121: O Ugolin de' Fantolin, your name is safe,
EN.122: since no more sons are looked for
EN.123: who might blacken it with their depravity.
EN.124: 'But now, Tuscan, be on your way,
EN.125: for I would rather weep than speak,
EN.126: so has our discourse wrung my mind.'
EN.127: We knew those kindly spirits heard us moving off.
EN.128: Their silence, for that reason,
EN.129: confirmed that we were keeping to our path.
EN.130: As we moved on by ourselves, a voice,
EN.131: like lightning when it cleaves the air,
EN.132: came down upon us, saying:
EN.133: 'Whoever finds me shall slay me,'
EN.134: and fled, as thunder fades away,
EN.135: after the sudden rending of its cloud.
EN.136: As soon as our ears had some relief
EN.137: a new voice followed with such clamor that it seemed
EN.138: a thunderclap, delayed but for an instant:
EN.139: 'I am Aglauros who was turned to stone.'
EN.140: At that, to draw closer to the poet,
EN.141: I took a step to my right and not ahead.
EN.142: Now that the air was quiet all around us,
EN.143: he said to me: 'That was the bit and bridle
EN.144: to keep a man within his bounds.
EN.145: 'But you mortals take the bait, so that the hook
EN.146: of your old adversary draws you to him,
EN.147: and then of little use is curb or lure.
EN.148: 'The heavens call to you and wheel about you,
EN.150: but your eyes are fixed upon the earth.
EN.151: For that, He, seeing all, does smite you.'

IT.1: Quanto tra l'ultimar de l'ora terza
IT.2: e 'l principio del dì par de la spera
IT.3: che sempre a guisa di fanciullo scherza,
IT.4: tanto pareva già inver' la sera
IT.5: essere al sol del suo corso rimaso;
IT.6: vespero là, e qui mezza notte era.
IT.7: E i raggi ne ferien per mezzo 'l naso,
IT.8: perché per noi girato era sì 'l monte,
IT.9: che già dritti andavamo inver' l'occaso,
IT.10: quand' io senti' a me gravar la fronte
IT.11: a lo splendore assai più che di prima,
IT.12: e stupor m'eran le cose non conte;
IT.13: ond' io levai le mani inver' la cima
IT.14: de le mie ciglia, e fecimi 'l solecchio,
IT.15: che del soverchio visibile lima.
IT.16: Come quando da l'acqua o da lo specchio
IT.17: salta lo raggio a l'opposita parte,
IT.18: salendo sù per lo modo parecchio
IT.19: a quel che scende, e tanto si diparte
IT.20: dal cader de la pietra in igual tratta,
IT.21: sì come mostra esperïenza e arte;
IT.22: così mi parve da luce rifratta
IT.23: quivi dinanzi a me esser percosso;
IT.24: per che a fuggir la mia vista fu ratta.
IT.25: "Che è quel, dolce padre, a che non posso
IT.26: schermar lo viso tanto che mi vaglia,"
IT.27: diss' io, "e pare inver' noi esser mosso?"
IT.28: "Non ti maravigliar s'ancor t'abbaglia
IT.29: la famiglia del cielo," a me rispuose:
IT.30: "messo è che viene ad invitar ch'om saglia.
IT.31: Tosto sarà ch'a veder queste cose
IT.32: non ti fia grave, ma fieti diletto
IT.33: quanto natura a sentir ti dispuose."
IT.34: Poi giunti fummo a l'angel benedetto,
IT.35: con lieta voce disse: "Intrate quinci
IT.36: ad un scaleo vie men che li altri eretto."
IT.37: Noi montavam, già partiti di linci,
IT.38: e "Beati misericordes!" fue
IT.39: cantato retro, e "Godi tu che vinci!"
IT.40: Lo mio maestro e io soli amendue
IT.41: suso andavamo; e io pensai, andando,
IT.42: prode acquistar ne le parole sue;
IT.43: e dirizza'mi a lui sì dimandando:
IT.44: "Che volse dir lo spirto di Romagna,
IT.45: e 'divieto' e 'consorte' menzionando?"
IT.46: Per ch'elli a me: "Di sua maggior magagna
IT.47: conosce il danno; e però non s'ammiri
IT.48: se ne riprende perché men si piagna.
IT.49: Perché s'appuntano i vostri disiri
IT.50: dove per compagnia parte si scema,
IT.51: invidia move il mantaco a' sospiri.
IT.52: Ma se l'amor de la spera supprema
IT.53: torcesse in suso il disiderio vostro,
IT.54: non vi sarebbe al petto quella tema;
IT.55: ché, per quanti si dice più lì 'nostro,'
IT.56: tanto possiede più di ben ciascuno,
IT.57: e più di caritate arde in quel chiostro."
IT.58: "Io son d'esser contento più digiuno,"
IT.59: diss' io, "che se mi fosse pria taciuto,
IT.60: e più di dubbio ne la mente aduno.
IT.61: Com' esser puote ch'un ben, distributo
IT.62: in più posseditor, faccia più ricchi
IT.63: di sé che se da pochi è posseduto?"
IT.64: Ed elli a me: "Però che tu rificchi
IT.65: la mente pur a le cose terrene,
IT.66: di vera luce tenebre dispicchi.
IT.67: Quello infinito e ineffabil bene
IT.68: che là sù è, così corre ad amore
IT.69: com' a lucido corpo raggio vene.
IT.70: Tanto si dà quanto trova d'ardore;
IT.71: sì che, quantunque carità si stende,
IT.72: cresce sovr' essa l'etterno valore.
IT.73: E quanta gente più là sù s'intende,
IT.74: più v'è da bene amare, e più vi s'ama,
IT.75: e come specchio l'uno a l'altro rende.
IT.76: E se la mia ragion non ti disfama,
IT.77: vedrai Beatrice, ed ella pienamente
IT.78: ti torrà questa e ciascun' altra brama.
IT.79: Procaccia pur che tosto sieno spente,
IT.80: come son già le due, le cinque piaghe,
IT.81: che si richiudon per esser dolente."
IT.82: Com' io voleva dicer "Tu m'appaghe,"
IT.83: vidimi giunto in su l'altro girone,
IT.84: sì che tacer mi fer le luci vaghe.
IT.85: Ivi mi parve in una visïone
IT.86: estatica di sùbito esser tratto,
IT.87: e vedere in un tempio più persone;
IT.88: e una donna, in su l'entrar, con atto
IT.89: dolce di madre dicer: "Figliuol mio,
IT.90: perché hai tu così verso noi fatto?
IT.91: Ecco, dolenti, lo tuo padre e io
IT.92: ti cercavamo." E come qui si tacque,
IT.93: ciò che pareva prima, dispario.
IT.94: Indi m'apparve un'altra con quell' acque
IT.95: giù per le gote che 'l dolor distilla
IT.96: quando di gran dispetto in altrui nacque,
IT.97: e dir: "Se tu se' sire de la villa
IT.98: del cui nome ne' dèi fu tanta lite,
IT.99: e onde ogne scïenza disfavilla,
IT.100: vendica te di quelle braccia ardite
IT.101: ch'abbracciar nostra figlia, o Pisistràto."
IT.102: E 'l segnor mi parea, benigno e mite,
IT.103: risponder lei con viso temperato:
IT.104: "Che farem noi a chi mal ne disira,
IT.105: se quei che ci ama è per noi condannato?"
IT.106: Poi vidi genti accese in foco d'ira
IT.107: con pietre un giovinetto ancider, forte
IT.108: gridando a sé pur: "Martira, martira!"
IT.109: E lui vedea chinarsi, per la morte
IT.110: che l'aggravava già, inver' la terra,
IT.111: ma de li occhi facea sempre al ciel porte,
IT.112: orando a l'alto Sire, in tanta guerra,
IT.113: che perdonasse a' suoi persecutori,
IT.114: con quello aspetto che pietà diserra.
IT.115: Quando l'anima mia tornò di fori
IT.116: a le cose che son fuor di lei vere,
IT.117: io riconobbi i miei non falsi errori.
IT.118: Lo duca mio, che mi potea vedere
IT.119: far sì com' om che dal sonno si slega,
IT.120: disse: "Che hai che non ti puoi tenere,
IT.121: ma se' venuto più che mezza lega
IT.122: velando li occhi e con le gambe avvolte,
IT.123: a guisa di cui vino o sonno piega?"
IT.124: "O dolce padre mio, se tu m'ascolte,
IT.125: io ti dirò," diss' io, "ciò che m'apparve
IT.126: quando le gambe mi furon sì tolte."
IT.127: Ed ei: "Se tu avessi cento larve
IT.128: sovra la faccia, non mi sarian chiuse
IT.129: le tue cogitazion, quantunque parve.
IT.130: Ciò che vedesti fu perché non scuse
IT.131: d'aprir lo core a l'acque de la pace
IT.132: che da l'etterno fonte son diffuse.
IT.133: Non dimandai 'Che hai?' per quel che face
IT.134: chi guarda pur con l'occhio che non vede,
IT.135: quando disanimato il corpo giace;
IT.136: ma dimandai per darti forza al piede:
IT.137: così frugar conviensi i pigri, lenti
IT.138: ad usar lor vigilia quando riede."
IT.139: Noi andavam per lo vespero, attenti
IT.140: oltre quanto potean li occhi allungarsi
IT.141: contra i raggi serotini e lucenti.
IT.142: Ed ecco a poco a poco un fummo farsi
IT.143: verso di noi come la notte oscuro;
IT.144: né da quello era loco da cansarsi.
IT.145: Questo ne tolse li occhi e l'aere puro.

EN.1: As much as between the end of the third hour
EN.2: and the first of day is seen of the sphere
EN.3: that like a child is always darting here and there,
EN.4: so much appeared now to remain
EN.5: of the sun's course toward nightfall:
EN.6: it was vespers there and midnight here on earth.
EN.7: The rays were striking full into our faces,
EN.8: for we had circled so much of the mountain
EN.9: that we were heading straight into the west,
EN.10: when such great splendor overwhelmed my sight,
EN.11: greater than any I had seen before,
EN.12: that I was dazed by its unfamiliar brightness.
EN.13: I raised one hand above my brow
EN.14: and gave my eyes sufficient shade
EN.15: to temper this excess of light.
EN.16: As, when from water or a mirror, a reflected beam
EN.17: leaps back the other way, rising
EN.18: at the angle it took in its descent,
EN.19: and from the plumb line of a stone
EN.20: will deviate an equal distance,
EN.21: as shown by science and experiment,
EN.22: it seemed to me that I was struck
EN.23: by such bright light reflected there before me
EN.24: that my eyes were quick to turn away.
EN.25: 'What is that, gentle father,' I asked,
EN.26: 'from which I cannot even screen my eyes?
EN.27: It seems to be moving toward us.'
EN.28: 'Don't be surprised,' he answered me,
EN.29: 'if those who live in Heaven still can blind you:
EN.30: this messenger invites us to ascend.
EN.31: 'Soon the sight of beings such as these
EN.32: will not be burdensome, will give as much delight
EN.33: as nature made you fit to feel.'
EN.34: When we had reached the blessèd angel
EN.35: he called out in a joyful voice: 'Now enter here
EN.36: on a stairway far less steep than were the others.'
EN.37: As we ascended, moving on from there,
EN.38: we heard 'Beati misericordes' sung behind us
EN.39: and 'Rejoice, you who conquer.'
EN.40: My master and I, alone again,
EN.41: were climbing, and as we went along,
EN.42: hoping to take some profit from his words,
EN.43: I turned to him and asked:
EN.44: 'What did the spirit from Romagna mean
EN.45: when he spoke of things that can't be shared?'
EN.46: He replied: 'Of his worst fault he knows the cost.
EN.47: Thus it is no wonder he condemns it, in the hope
EN.48: that fewer souls will have a reason to lament.
EN.49: 'Because your appetites are fixed on things
EN.50: that, divided, lessen each one's share,
EN.51: envy's bellows pushes breath into your sighs.
EN.52: 'But if love for the highest sphere
EN.53: could turn your longings toward heavenly things,
EN.54: then fear of sharing would pass from your hearts.
EN.55: 'For there above, when more souls speak of ours,
EN.56: the more of goodness each one owns,
EN.57: the more of love burning in that cloister.'
EN.58: 'I am more starved for answers,' I said,
EN.59: 'than if before I had kept silent,
EN.60: since now my mind is filled with greater doubt.
EN.61: 'How can it be that a good, distributed,
EN.62: can enrich a greater number of possessors
EN.63: than if it were possessed by few?'
EN.64: And he to me: 'Because you still
EN.65: have your mind fixed on earthly things,
EN.66: you harvest darkness from the light itself.
EN.67: 'That infinite and ineffable Good,
EN.68: which dwells on high, speeds toward love
EN.69: as a ray of sunlight to a shining body.
EN.70: 'It returns the love it finds in equal measure,
EN.71: so that, if more of ardor is extended,
EN.72: eternal Goodness will augment Its own.
EN.73: 'And the more souls there are who love on high,
EN.74: the more there is to love, the more of loving,
EN.75: for like a mirror each returns it to the other.
EN.76: 'And if my words do not requite your hunger,
EN.77: you shall see Beatrice. She will deliver you
EN.78: entirely from this and every other craving.
EN.79: 'Seek only that the five wounds healed
EN.80: by being painful soon may be closed up,
EN.81: as the other two already are.'
EN.82: I was about to say: 'You give me satisfaction,'
EN.83: when I saw that I had reached another terrace,
EN.84: and my eager eyes made me keep silent.
EN.85: There it seemed to me I was caught up
EN.86: in an ecstatic, sudden vision
EN.87: in which I saw a temple full of people
EN.88: and, at the door, about to enter, a woman,
EN.89: with the sweet demeanor of a mother, who said:
EN.90: 'My son, why have you dealt with us like this?
EN.91: 'Behold, your father and I have searched
EN.92: for you in sorrow.' Just as she now was silent,
EN.93: so did that which brought her leave my sight.
EN.94: Then there appeared to me another woman,
EN.95: tears of grief still running down her cheeks
EN.96: from anger at the one whom she disdained.
EN.97: She said: 'If you are indeed lord of this city,
EN.98: whose naming caused such strife among the gods
EN.99: and from which so much knowledge lights the world,
EN.100: 'avenge yourself on those bold arms
EN.101: that dared embrace our daughter, Pisistratus.'
EN.102: And it seemed to me that lord gave gracious answer,
EN.103: offered gently and with tranquil look:
EN.104: 'What shall we do to one who seeks our harm
EN.105: if we condemn the one who loves us?'
EN.106: Then I saw people, aflame with burning wrath,
EN.107: stoning a youth to death,
EN.108: and each was screaming to himself, "Kill, kill."
EN.109: And I saw him sinking to the ground--
EN.110: for death was heavy on him now--
EN.111: but keeping his eyes open to Heaven,
EN.112: as he begged the Lord on high to pardon
EN.113: his persecutors, from the depth of his agony,
EN.114: with a look that unlocks compassion.
EN.115: When my soul made its way back
EN.116: to the things that are real outside it,
EN.117: I came to know my errors were not false.
EN.118: My leader, who could see that I was acting
EN.119: like one who shakes himself from sleep, said:
EN.120: 'What's wrong with you that you can't walk straight
EN.121: 'but have come now more than half a league
EN.122: with your eyes veiled and your legs entangled,
EN.123: like a man overcome by wine or sleep?'
EN.124: 'O my dear father,' I said, 'if you'll but listen,
EN.125: I will tell you exactly what I saw
EN.126: when my legs were taken from me.'
EN.127: And he: 'If over your face you wore
EN.128: a hundred masks, even your faintest thoughts
EN.129: would not be hidden from my sight.
EN.130: 'These things were shown so you would not refuse
EN.131: to open your heart to the waters of peace
EN.132: that pour from the eternal fountain.
EN.133: 'I did not ask "What's wrong?" for your resemblance
EN.134: to a man who stares with but unseeing eyes
EN.135: when his body lies insensate,
EN.136: 'but asked to put fresh vigor in your step.
EN.137: So must the sluggard, slow to use his waking hours
EN.138: even once these come, be spurred to act.'
EN.139: We went along through the evening hour,
EN.140: forcing our eyes to seek the farthest point ahead
EN.141: against the bright late beams,
EN.142: when, little by little, a smoke moved toward us,
EN.143: black as night, and there was nowhere
EN.144: we could escape from it. And first it took away
EN.145: the pureness of the air and then our sight.

IT.1: Buio d'inferno e di notte privata
IT.2: d'ogne pianeto, sotto pover cielo,
IT.3: quant' esser può di nuvol tenebrata,
IT.4: non fece al viso mio sì grosso velo
IT.5: come quel fummo ch'ivi ci coperse,
IT.6: né a sentir di così aspro pelo,
IT.7: che l'occhio stare aperto non sofferse;
IT.8: onde la scorta mia saputa e fida
IT.9: mi s'accostò e l'omero m'offerse.
IT.10: Sì come cieco va dietro a sua guida
IT.11: per non smarrirsi e per non dar di cozzo
IT.12: in cosa che 'l molesti, o forse ancida,
IT.13: m'andava io per l'aere amaro e sozzo,
IT.14: ascoltando il mio duca che diceva
IT.15: pur: "Guarda che da me tu non sia mozzo."
IT.16: Io sentia voci, e ciascuna pareva
IT.17: pregar per pace e per misericordia
IT.18: l'Agnel di Dio che le peccata leva.
IT.19: Pur "Agnus Dei" eran le loro essordia;
IT.20: una parola in tutte era e un modo,
IT.21: sì che parea tra esse ogne concordia.
IT.22: "Quei sono spirti, maestro, ch'i' odo?"
IT.23: diss' io. Ed elli a me: "Tu vero apprendi,
IT.24: e d'iracundia van solvendo il nodo."
IT.25: "Or tu chi se' che 'l nostro fummo fendi,
IT.26: e di noi parli pur come se tue
IT.27: partissi ancor lo tempo per calendi?"
IT.28: Così per una voce detto fue;
IT.29: onde 'l maestro mio disse: "Rispondi,
IT.30: e domanda se quinci si va sùe."
IT.31: E io: "O creatura che ti mondi
IT.32: per tornar bella a colui che ti fece,
IT.33: maraviglia udirai, se mi secondi."
IT.34: "Io ti seguiterò quanto mi lece,"
IT.35: rispuose; "e se veder fummo non lascia
IT.36: l'udir ci terrà giunti in quella vece."
IT.37: Allora incominciai: "Con quella fascia
IT.38: che la morte dissolve men vo suso,
IT.39: e venni qui per l'infernale ambascia.
IT.40: E se Dio m'ha in sua grazia rinchiuso,
IT.41: tanto che vuol ch'i' veggia la sua corte
IT.42: per modo tutto fuor del moderno uso,
IT.43: non mi celar chi fosti anzi la morte,
IT.44: ma dilmi, e dimmi s'i' vo bene al varco;
IT.45: e tue parole fier le nostre scorte."
IT.46: "Lombardo fui, e fu' chiamato Marco;
IT.47: del mondo seppi, e quel valore amai
IT.48: al quale ha or ciascun disteso l'arco.
IT.49: Per montar sù dirittamente vai."
IT.50: Così rispuose, e soggiunse: "I' ti prego
IT.51: che per me prieghi quando sù sarai."
IT.52: E io a lui: "Per fede mi ti lego
IT.53: di far ciò che mi chiedi; ma io scoppio
IT.54: dentro ad un dubbio, s'io non me ne spiego.
IT.55: Prima era scempio, e ora è fatto doppio
IT.56: ne la sentenza tua, che mi fa certo
IT.57: qui, e altrove, quello ov' io l'accoppio.
IT.58: Lo mondo è ben così tutto diserto
IT.59: d'ogne virtute, come tu mi sone,
IT.60: e di malizia gravido e coverto;
IT.61: ma priego che m'addite la cagione,
IT.62: sì ch'i' la veggia e ch'i' la mostri altrui;
IT.63: ché nel cielo uno, e un qua giù la pone."
IT.64: Alto sospir, che duolo strinse in "uhi!"
IT.65: mise fuor prima; e poi cominciò: "Frate,
IT.66: lo mondo è cieco, e tu vien ben da lui.
IT.67: Voi che vivete ogne cagion recate
IT.68: pur suso al cielo, pur come se tutto
IT.69: movesse seco di necessitate.
IT.70: Se così fosse, in voi fora distrutto
IT.71: libero arbitrio, e non fora giustizia
IT.72: per ben letizia, e per male aver lutto.
IT.73: Lo cielo i vostri movimenti inizia;
IT.74: non dico tutti, ma, posto ch'i' 'l dica,
IT.75: lume v'è dato a bene e a malizia,

EN.1: Gloom of hell or of a night deprived
EN.2: of all the stars, beneath a barren sky
EN.3: which everywhere was overcast with clouds,
EN.4: had never put so dark a veil across my eyes
EN.5: or been so harsh and stinging to my sight
EN.6: as was the smoke that covered us
EN.7: so that I could not keep my eyelids open.
EN.8: And then my wise and trusted escort
EN.9: came up and offered me his shoulder.
EN.10: Just as the blind man walks behind his guide
EN.11: so that he does not stray or strike against
EN.12: something that might hurt or even kill him,
EN.13: thus did I move through that foul, bitter air
EN.14: and listened to my leader, who kept urging:
EN.15: 'Make sure that you are not cut off from me.'
EN.16: I heard voices and each seemed to pray
EN.17: for peace and mercy to the Lamb of God
EN.18: who bears away our sins.
EN.19: They all began with Agnus Dei,
EN.20: and with one voice and intonation sang the words
EN.21: so that they seemed to share complete accord.
EN.22: I asked, 'Master, are these spirits that I hear?'
EN.23: And he: 'You have it right. Here they undo
EN.24: the knot that was their wrath.'
EN.25: 'But who are you that cleave our smoke?
EN.26: You speak of us as though, even now,
EN.27: you measured time in months and days,'
EN.28: I heard a voice say.
EN.29: Then my master urged: 'Answer him,
EN.30: and ask him if the way goes up from here.'
EN.31: And I: 'O creature who purify yourself
EN.32: to return in beauty to the One who made you,
EN.33: you'll hear a wondrous story if you follow me.'
EN.34: 'I will follow as far as is permitted,'
EN.35: he replied, 'and if the smoke keeps us from seeing,
EN.36: hearing will keep us joined instead.'
EN.37: And I began: 'With the very swaddling clothes
EN.38: that death unwinds I make my way above,
EN.39: and I have come through agony of Hell.
EN.40: 'Since God has so received me in His grace
EN.41: that He has willed that I shall see His court
EN.42: in ways unknown to modern custom,
EN.43: 'do not conceal from me the life you led
EN.44: before you died: tell it, and tell me if I'm headed
EN.45: for the passage--your words shall be our escort.'
EN.46: 'I was a Lombard, known as Marco.
EN.47: I knew the world and loved that valor
EN.48: at which today all aim a slackened bow.
EN.49: 'You are on the path that leads you up.'
EN.50: Thus he replied, then added: 'I pray you,
EN.51: say a prayer for me once you are above.'
EN.52: And I to him: 'I pledge to do your bidding.
EN.53: But I will burst with my unspoken doubts
EN.54: if I don't speak and free myself of them.
EN.55: 'A single doubt before, it now is paired
EN.56: by what you said, which here confirms
EN.57: what elsewhere I have heard, to which I couple it.
EN.58: 'The world is barren now
EN.59: of every virtue, as you state,
EN.60: and heavy with and overgrown by evil.
EN.61: 'Please point out to me the cause
EN.62: that I may know it and make it known to others,
EN.63: for both the heavens and the earth receive the blame.'
EN.64: First he heaved a heavy sigh, which grief wrung
EN.65: to a groan, and then began: 'Brother,
EN.66: the world is blind and indeed you come from it.
EN.67: 'You who are still alive assign each cause
EN.68: only to the heavens, as though they drew
EN.69: all things along upon their necessary paths.
EN.70: 'If that were so, free choice would be denied you,
EN.71: and there would be no justice when one feels
EN.72: joy for doing good or misery for evil.
EN.73: 'Yes, the heavens give motion to your inclinations.
EN.74: I don't say all of them, but, even if I did,
EN.75: you still possess a light to winnow good from evil,
EN.76: 'and you have free will. Should it bear the strain
EN.77: in its first struggles with the heavens,
EN.78: then, rightly nurtured, it will conquer all.
EN.79: 'To a greater power and a better nature you, free,
EN.80: are subject, and these create the mind in you
EN.81: the heavens have not in their charge.
EN.82: 'Therefore, if the world around you goes astray,
EN.83: in you is the cause and in you let it be sought.
EN.84: In this I will now be your informant.
EN.85: 'From the hand of Him who looks on it with love
EN.86: before it lives, comes forth, like a little girl
EN.87: who weeps one moment and as quickly laughs,
EN.88: 'the simple infant soul that has no knowledge
EN.89: but, moved by a joyous maker,
EN.90: gladly turns to what delights it.
EN.91: 'At first it tastes the savor of a trifling good.
EN.92: It is beguiled by that and follows in pursuit
EN.93: if guide or rein do not deflect its love.
EN.94: 'Therefore, there was need that laws be set
EN.95: to act as curbs, need for a ruler to discern
EN.96: at least the tower above the one true city.
EN.97: 'Yes, there are laws, but who takes them in hand?
EN.98: No one, because the shepherd who precedes
EN.99: may chew his cud, but does not have cleft hooves.
EN.100: 'The people, then, who see their leader lunge
EN.101: only at the good for which they themselves are greedy,
EN.102: graze on that and ask for nothing more.
EN.103: 'As you can plainly see, failed guidance
EN.104: is the cause the world is steeped in vice,
EN.105: and not your inner nature that has grown corrupt.
EN.106: 'Rome, which formed the world for good,
EN.107: once held two suns that lit the one road
EN.108: and the other, the world's and that to God.
EN.109: 'The one has snuffed the other out, the sword
EN.110: is fastened to the crook, and these two,
EN.111: forced to be together, must perforce go ill,
EN.112: 'since, joined, the one fears not the other.
EN.113: If you don't believe me, think of a grain of wheat,
EN.114: for by its seed each plant is known.
EN.115: 'In the land watered both by the Àdige and Po
EN.116: valor and courtesy could once be found
EN.117: before Frederick encountered opposition.
EN.118: 'Now it may with impunity be crossed by anyone
EN.119: who for shame would shun all discourse
EN.120: with the virtuous or even coming near them.
EN.121: 'Three old men are left on earth,
EN.122: longing for the better life when God will take them,
EN.123: in whom the ancient times rebuke the new:
EN.124: 'Currado da Palazzo and the good Gherardo
EN.125: and Guido da Castel, better called,
EN.126: as say the French, the simple, honest Lombard.
EN.127: 'Spread the word, then, that the Church of Rome,
EN.128: confounding in herself two governments, stumbles
EN.129: in the mud, befouling herself and her burden.'
EN.130: 'O Marco mine,' I said, 'you reason well,
EN.131: and now I understand just why the sons of Levi
EN.132: were disbarred from their inheritance.
EN.133: 'But who is this Gherardo who, you say,
EN.134: is left as an example of a race extinct,
EN.135: rebuking this barbaric age?'
EN.136: 'Either your speech deceives me,' he replied,
EN.137: 'or it puts me to the test, for, speaking Tuscan,
EN.138: how is it you know nothing of the good Gherardo?
EN.139: 'I know him by no other name unless
EN.140: I were to take one from his daughter, Gaia.
EN.141: May God be with you. I come with you no farther.
EN.142: 'You see the brightness shining through the smoke
EN.143: already whitens, and I must take my leave
EN.144: before the angel waiting there can see me.'
EN.145: Then he turned back and would not hear me more.

EN.1: Remember, reader, if ever in the mountains
EN.2: you were trapped in fog and could not see
EN.3: except as moles do, through their eyelids,
EN.4: how, when the strands of mist, humid and dense,
EN.5: began dispersing, the sun's disk
EN.6: dimly glimmered through,
EN.7: then you can readily imagine
EN.8: how, on my seeing it again, the sun appeared,
EN.9: now on the verge of setting.
EN.10: Measuring my steps to the trusted steps
EN.11: of my master, I came out of that haze
EN.12: to beams already vanished from the shores below.
EN.13: O imagination, which at times so rob us
EN.14: of outward things we pay no heed,
EN.15: though a thousand trumpets sound around us,
EN.16: who sets you into motion if the senses offer
EN.17: nothing? A light, formed in the heavens, moves you
EN.18: either of itself or by a will that sends it down.
EN.19: Of the impious deed of her whose shape was changed
EN.20: into the bird that most delights to sing
EN.21: a picture formed in my imagination.
EN.22: At this my mind had so withdrawn into itself
EN.23: there was no impulse from outside
EN.24: that could impinge upon my senses.
EN.25: Then there rained down into my lofty phantasy
EN.26: one fastened to a cross, scornful
EN.27: and fierce in looks, and in his death.
EN.28: With him were Ahasuerus, the great king,
EN.29: Esther, his wife, and Mordecai the just,
EN.30: so upright in his words and deeds.
EN.31: And as this image broke up of itself,
EN.32: just as a bubble does when it floats up
EN.33: above the water from which it takes its form,
EN.34: in my vision there arose a girl.
EN.35: She was weeping bitterly, crying: 'O Queen,
EN.36: why, in your anger, have you chosen not to be?
EN.37: 'Not to lose Lavinia have you killed yourself.
EN.38: Now you have lost me and I am left to mourn
EN.39: your death, mother, before the death of yet another.'
EN.40: As sleep is broken when a sudden light
EN.41: strikes on closed eyes and, broken,
EN.42: flickers before it dies,
EN.43: so my imaginings grew faint within me
EN.44: as soon as a light, far brighter
EN.45: than the light we know, struck my face.
EN.46: I was turning to discover where I was
EN.47: when a voice said: 'Here is your ascent,'
EN.48: and drew me away from any other thought.
EN.49: It raised in me the overwhelming wish--
EN.50: a wish that cannot rest short of its goal--
EN.51: to behold the one who spoke.
EN.52: But as before the sun, which weighs upon our eyes,
EN.53: veiling its form in an excess of light,
EN.54: so, before him, my power of sight fell short.
EN.55: 'This divine spirit is directing us
EN.56: toward the ascent without our even asking,
EN.57: concealed in his own shining.
EN.58: 'He cares for us as we do for ourselves,
EN.59: since one who, seeing another's need, awaits the asking
EN.60: maliciously has set his mind upon refusal.
EN.61: 'We should accept so kind an invitation with our feet,
EN.62: attempting the ascent before it darkens,
EN.63: for then we cannot, until day returns.'
EN.64: These were my leader's words, and we together
EN.65: turned our footsteps toward a stairway.
EN.66: As soon as I had reached the lowest step
EN.67: I sensed beside me something like the motion
EN.68: of a wing that fanned my face. I heard the words:
EN.69: 'Beati pacifici, those untouched by sinful wrath.'
EN.70: Already the sun's last rays before the night
EN.71: were slanting up so high above us
EN.72: that stars were showing here and there.
EN.73: 'O my strength, why do you drain away?'
EN.74: I said, but only to myself,
EN.75: because I felt my legs had lost their power.
EN.76: We had reached a point at which the stair
EN.77: ceased rising higher and we stopped,
EN.78: as does a ship that comes to shore.
EN.79: For a little while I waited to discover
EN.80: if my ears could make out sounds in this new circle.
EN.81: Then I turned to my master and I said:
EN.82: 'Sweet father, tell me, what is the offense
EN.83: made clean here in this circle that we've reached?
EN.84: If our feet must rest, do not arrest your words.'
EN.85: And he: 'A love of good that falls short
EN.86: of its duty is restored here in this place.
EN.87: Here the slackened oar is pulled with greater force.
EN.88: 'That you may understand more clearly,
EN.89: pay close attention. Then you shall pluck
EN.90: some good fruit from our stay.'
EN.91: 'Neither Creator nor His creature, my dear son,
EN.92: was ever without love, whether natural
EN.93: or of the mind,' he began, 'and this you know.
EN.94: 'The natural is always without error,
EN.95: but the other may err in its chosen goal
EN.96: or through excessive or deficient vigor.
EN.97: 'While it is directed to the primal good,
EN.98: knowing moderation in its lesser goals,
EN.99: it cannot be the cause of wrongful pleasure.
EN.100: 'But when it bends to evil, or pursues the good
EN.101: with more or less concern than needed,
EN.102: then the creature works against his Maker.
EN.103: 'From this you surely understand that love
EN.104: must be the seed in you of every virtue
EN.105: as well as of each deed that merits punishment.
EN.106: 'Now, since love cannot avert its face
EN.107: from the welfare of its subject,
EN.108: all creatures are secure against self-hatred,
EN.109: 'and since no being can conceive itself
EN.110: as severed, self-existing, from its Author,
EN.111: each creature is cut off from hating Him.
EN.112: 'It follows, if I'm right in these distinctions,
EN.113: that the evil that is loved must be a neighbor's.
EN.114: Three ways this love takes form within your clay.
EN.115: 'There is the one, hoping to excel by bringing down
EN.116: his neighbor, who, for that sole reason, longs
EN.117: that from his greatness his neighbor be brought low.
EN.118: 'There is the one who fears the loss of power, favor,
EN.119: honor, fame--should he be bettered by another.
EN.120: This so aggrieves him that he wants to see him fall.
EN.121: 'And there is the one who thinks himself offended
EN.122: and hungers after vengeance,
EN.123: and he must then contrive another's harm.
EN.124: 'All these three forms of love cause weeping down below.
EN.125: Now I would have you consider yet another,
EN.126: which pursues the good in faulty measure.
EN.127: 'Everyone can vaguely apprehend some good
EN.128: in which the mind may find its peace.
EN.129: With desire, each one strives to reach it.
EN.130: 'If the love that draws you on is laggard
EN.131: to know or have that peace, this terrace,
EN.132: after just remorse, torments you for it.
EN.133: 'There is another good that fails to make men happy,
EN.134: for it is not the essence or true source,
EN.135: the root of happiness or its proper fruit.
EN.136: 'The excessive love which gives itself to that
EN.137: is mourned above us in three circles.
EN.138: Exactly how its parts are three I do not say,
EN.139: so that you may consider for yourself.'

IT.1: Posto avea fine al suo ragionamento
IT.2: l'alto dottore, e attento guardava
IT.3: ne la mia vista s'io parea contento;
IT.4: e io, cui nova sete ancor frugava,
IT.5: di fuor tacea, e dentro dicea: "Forse
IT.6: lo troppo dimandar ch'io fo li grava."
IT.7: Ma quel padre verace, che s'accorse
IT.8: del timido voler che non s'apriva,
IT.9: parlando, di parlare ardir mi porse.
IT.10: Ond'io: "Maestro, il mio veder s'avviva
IT.11: sì nel tuo lume, ch'io discerno chiaro
IT.12: quanto la tua ragion parta o descriva.
IT.13: Però ti prego, dolce padre caro,
IT.14: che mi dimostri amore, a cui reduci
IT.15: ogne buono operare e 'l suo contraro."
IT.16: "Drizza," disse, "ver' me l'agute luci
IT.17: de lo 'ntelletto, e fieti manifesto
IT.18: l'error de' ciechi che si fanno duci.
IT.19: L'animo, ch'è creato ad amar presto,
IT.20: ad ogne cosa è mobile che piace,
IT.21: tosto che dal piacere in atto è desto.
IT.22: Vostra apprensiva da esser verace
IT.23: tragge intenzione, e dentro a voi la spiega,
IT.24: sì che l'animo ad essa volger face;
IT.25: e se, rivolto, inver' di lei si piega,
IT.26: quel piegare è amor, quell' è natura
IT.27: che per piacer di novo in voi si lega.
IT.28: Poi, come 'l foco movesi in altura
IT.29: per la sua forma ch'è nata a salire
IT.30: là dove più in sua matera dura,
IT.31: così l'animo preso entra in disire,
IT.32: ch'è moto spiritale, e mai non posa
IT.33: fin che la cosa amata il fa gioire.
IT.34: Or ti puote apparer quant' è nascosa
IT.35: la veritate a la gente ch'avvera
IT.36: ciascun amore in sé laudabil cosa;
IT.37: però che forse appar la sua matera
IT.38: sempre esser buona, ma non ciascun segno
IT.39: è buono, ancor che buona sia la cera."
IT.40: "Le tue parole e 'l mio seguace ingegno,"
IT.41: rispuos' io lui, "m'hanno amor discoverto,
IT.42: ma ciò m'ha fatto di dubbiar più pregno;
IT.43: ché, s'amore è di fuori a noi offerto
IT.44: e l'anima non va con altro piede,
IT.45: se dritta o torta va, non è suo merto."
IT.46: Ed elli a me: "Quanto ragion qui vede,
IT.47: dir ti poss' io; da indi in là t'aspetta
IT.48: pur a Beatrice, ch'è opra di fede.
IT.49: Ogne forma sustanzïal, che setta
IT.50: è da matera ed è con lei unita,
IT.51: specifica vertute ha in sé colletta,
IT.52: la qual sanza operar non è sentita,
IT.53: né si dimostra mai che per effetto,
IT.54: come per verdi fronde in pianta vita.
IT.55: Però, là onde vegna lo 'ntelletto

IT.57: e de' primi appetibili l'affetto,
IT.58: che sono in voi sì come studio in ape
IT.59: di far lo mele; e questa prima voglia
IT.60: merto di lode o di biasmo non cape.
IT.61: Or perché a questa ogn' altra si raccoglia,
IT.62: innata v'è la virtù che consiglia,
IT.63: e de l'assenso de' tener la soglia.
IT.64: Quest' è 'l principio là onde si piglia
IT.65: ragion di meritare in voi, secondo
IT.66: che buoni e rei amori accoglie e viglia.

IT.68: s'accorser d'esta innata libertate;
IT.69: però moralità lasciaro al mondo.
IT.70: Onde, poniam che di necessitate

IT.74: per lo libero arbitrio, e però guarda
IT.75: che l'abbi a mente, s'a parlar ten prende."

IT.77: facea le stelle a noi parer più rade,
IT.78: fatta com' un secchion che tuttor arda;
IT.79: e correa contra 'l ciel per quelle strade

IT.85: per ch'io, che la ragione aperta e piana
IT.86: sovra le mie quistioni avea ricolta,
IT.87: stava com' om che sonnolento vana.

IT.89: subitamente da gente che dopo
IT.90: le nostre spalle a noi era già volta.
IT.91: E quale Ismeno già vide e Asopo
IT.92: lungo di sé di notte furia e calca,
IT.93: pur che i Teban di Bacco avesser uopo,
IT.94: cotal per quel giron suo passo falca,
IT.95: per quel ch'io vidi di color, venendo,

IT.97: Tosto fur sovr' a noi, perché correndo
IT.98: si movea tutta quella turba magna;
IT.99: e due dinanzi gridavan piangendo:
IT.100: "Maria corse con fretta a la montagna;
IT.101: e Cesare, per soggiogare Ilerda,
IT.102: punse Marsilia e poi corse in Ispagna."
IT.103: "Ratto, ratto, che 'l tempo non si perda
IT.104: per poco amor," gridavan li altri appresso,
IT.105: "che studio di ben far grazia rinverda."
IT.106: "O gente in cui fervore aguto adesso
IT.107: ricompie forse negligenza e indugio
IT.108: da voi per tepidezza in ben far messo,
IT.109: questi che vive, e certo i' non vi bugio,
IT.110: vuole andar sù, pur che 'l sol ne riluca;

IT.112: Parole furon queste del mio duca;
IT.113: e un di quelli spirti disse: "Vieni
IT.114: di retro a noi, e troverai la buca.
IT.115: Noi siam di voglia a muoverci sì pieni,
IT.116: che restar non potem; però perdona,
IT.117: se villania nostra giustizia tieni.
IT.118: Io fui abate in San Zeno a Verona
IT.119: sotto lo 'mperio del buon Barbarossa,
IT.120: di cui dolente ancor Milan ragiona.
IT.121: E tale ha già l'un piè dentro la fossa,
IT.122: che tosto piangerà quel monastero,
IT.123: e tristo fia d'avere avuta possa;
IT.124: perché suo figlio, mal del corpo intero,
IT.125: e de la mente peggio, e che mal nacque,
IT.126: ha posto in loco di suo pastor vero."
IT.127: Io non so se più disse o s'ei si tacque,
IT.128: tant' era già di là da noi trascorso;
IT.129: ma questo intesi, e ritener mi piacque.
IT.130: E quei che m'era ad ogne uopo soccorso
IT.131: disse: "Volgiti qua: vedine due
IT.132: venir dando a l'accidïa di morso."
IT.133: Di retro a tutti dicean: "Prima fue
IT.134: morta la gente a cui il mar s'aperse,
IT.135: che vedesse Iordan le rede sue.
IT.136: E quella che l'affanno non sofferse
IT.137: fino a la fine col figlio d'Anchise
IT.138: sé stessa a vita sanza gloria offerse."
IT.139: Poi quando fuor da noi tanto divise
IT.140: quell' ombre, che veder più non potiersi,
IT.141: novo pensiero dentro a me si mise,
IT.142: del qual più altri nacquero e diversi;
IT.143: e tanto d'uno in altro vaneggiai,
IT.144: che li occhi per vaghezza ricopersi,
IT.145: e 'l pensamento in sogno trasmutai.

EN.1: My lofty teacher had brought his discourse
EN.2: to its end and was studying my face
EN.3: to see if I seemed satisfied,
EN.4: while I, spurred on by yet another thirst,
EN.5: kept silent, rehearsing in my mind the thought:
EN.6: 'Perhaps I trouble him with all these questions.'
EN.7: But that true father, mindful
EN.8: of the timid wish that I did not declare,
EN.9: spoke and gave me courage to speak out.
EN.10: Therefore I said: 'Master, your light so quickens
EN.11: my mental sight that I discern in full
EN.12: your argument's distinctions and its thesis.
EN.13: 'And thus I pray, dear, gentle father,
EN.14: that you expound this love, from which you say
EN.15: each good deed and its opposite derive.'
EN.16: 'Direct on me your intellect's keen eyes,'
EN.17: he said, 'and the error of the blind
EN.18: who set themselves as guides will be revealed.
EN.19: 'The mind, disposed to love at its creation,
EN.20: is readily moved toward anything that pleases
EN.21: as soon as by that pleasure it is roused to act.
EN.22: 'From real forms your perception draws
EN.23: an image it unfolds within you
EN.24: so that the mind considers it,
EN.25: 'and if the mind, so turned, inclines to it,
EN.26: that inclination is a natural love,
EN.27: which beauty binds in you at once.
EN.28: 'Then, as fire, born to rise,
EN.29: moves upward in its essence,
EN.30: to where its matter lives the longest,
EN.31: 'just so the mind, thus seized, achieves desire,
EN.32: a movement of the spirit never resting
EN.33: as long as it enjoys the thing it loves.
EN.34: 'Now you see how hidden is the truth
EN.35: from those who hold that every love
EN.36: is in itself deserving praise,
EN.37: 'perhaps because such love seems always good.
EN.38: But every seal is not a good one,
EN.39: even if imprinted in good wax.'
EN.40: 'Your words and my answering wit,' I said,
EN.41: 'have made love's nature clear to me,
EN.42: but that has left me even more perplexed.
EN.43: 'For if love is offered from outside us
EN.44: and if the soul moves on no other foot,
EN.45: it has no merit in going straight or crooked.'
EN.46: And he to me: 'As far as reason may see in this,
EN.47: I can tell you. To go farther you must look
EN.48: to Beatrice, for it depends on faith alone.
EN.49: 'Every substantial form that is at once distinct
EN.50: from matter and is, as well, united with it,
EN.51: contains its own defining disposition.
EN.52: 'This is not perceived except in operation,
EN.53: nor ever demonstrated except by its effect, as,
EN.54: in a plant, the force of life by its green leaves.
EN.55: 'In consequence, where we derive our knowledge
EN.56: of first principles and the inclination
EN.57: to universal objects of desire, no one knows.
EN.58: 'These are innate in you just like the zeal in bees
EN.59: for making honey, and this primal inclination
EN.60: admits no positing of praise or blame.
EN.61: 'So that to this will all others may conform
EN.62: there is innate in you the faculty that counsels
EN.63: and ought to guard the threshold of assent.
EN.64: 'This is the principle in which is found
EN.65: the measure of your merit, as it welcomes
EN.66: and then winnows good from guilty loves.
EN.67: 'Those who in their reasoning reached the root
EN.68: recognized this innate freedom
EN.69: and thus bequeathed their ethics to the world.
EN.70: 'Let us posit as a given: every love
EN.71: that's kindled in you arises necessarily.
EN.72: Still, the power to constrain it lies with you.
EN.73: 'That noble power is called free will by Beatrice,
EN.74: and so make sure that you remember this
EN.75: if she should ever speak of it to you.'
EN.76: Still brilliant after midnight, the moon,
EN.77: like a fiery bucket, was shining,
EN.78: making the stars seem fewer than they were,
EN.79: as in its course against the sky it followed
EN.80: the tracks the sun inflames when seen from Rome,
EN.81: setting between Sardegna and the Corsicans.
EN.82: That noble shade through whom Pietola
EN.83: is more renowned than any Mantuan town
EN.84: had doffed the weight with which I'd burdened him,
EN.85: so that I, having harvested his clear
EN.86: and forthright answers to my questions,
EN.87: remained like one who rambles in his drowsy mind.
EN.88: But suddenly this drowsiness was snatched away
EN.89: by a crowd who were approaching,
EN.90: having already rounded the terrace from behind us.
EN.91: As once the rivers Ismenus and Asopus
EN.92: saw a furious throng of revelers crowd their banks
EN.93: on any night the Thebans felt the need for Bacchus,
EN.94: such a throng cut their way, as does a sickle,
EN.95: around that circle, and I could tell
EN.96: that right will and just love drove them on.
EN.97: Soon they were upon us,
EN.98: for the whole turbulent mob was running,
EN.99: while two in front, weeping, cried out:
EN.100: 'Mary ran with haste into the mountains,'
EN.101: and 'Caesar, to subdue Lèrida, thrust at Marseilles
EN.102: and then raced on to Spain.'
EN.103: 'Quickly, quickly, lest time be lost for lack of love,'
EN.104: the others cried behind them. 'Let our zeal
EN.105: for doing good make grace grow green again.'
EN.106: 'O you who with keen fervor make amends,
EN.107: perhaps for your past negligence and sloth
EN.108: in being lukewarm to do good,
EN.109: 'this man, who is alive--indeed I do not lie--
EN.110: is eager to ascend at day's first light.
EN.111: Tell us, then, where the nearest opening is.'
EN.112: These were my leader's words,
EN.113: and one of those spirits answered:
EN.114: 'Follow us and you shall find the gap.
EN.115: 'We are so filled with our desire to keep moving
EN.116: we cannot rest. Pardon us, then,
EN.117: if our just penance seems discourteous.
EN.118: 'I was Abbot of San Zeno at Verona
EN.119: under the rule of worthy Barbarossa,
EN.120: of whom Milan still speaks with sorrow.
EN.121: 'And one there, with a foot already in the grave,
EN.122: will soon bemoan that monastery
EN.123: and regret his power over it,
EN.124: 'because he put his son, lame in body,
EN.125: deformed in mind, and base of birth,
EN.126: in the place of its true shepherd.'
EN.127: I know not if he said more or was still,
EN.128: he had already raced so far beyond us,
EN.129: but this I heard and chose to keep in mind.
EN.130: And he who was my help in every need said:
EN.131: 'Turn around and see these two
EN.132: who now come nipping at the heels of sloth.'
EN.133: Coming behind the rest they chanted:
EN.134: 'The people for whom the Red Sea opened
EN.135: were dead before the Jordan saw their heirs'
EN.136: and 'Those who chose not to endure the toil
EN.137: to its conclusion with Anchises' son
EN.138: gave themselves to a life without renown.'
EN.139: Then, when these shades were so far parted
EN.140: from us we could no longer see them,
EN.141: a new thought rose within me,
EN.142: from which others, many and diverse, were born.
EN.143: And I rambled so from one thought to another
EN.144: that my eyes closed in drowsy wandering
EN.145: and I transformed my musings into dream.

IT.1: Ne l'ora che non può 'l calor dïurno
IT.2: intepidar più 'l freddo de la luna,
IT.3: vinto da terra, e talor da Saturno
IT.4: --quando i geomanti lor Maggior Fortuna
IT.5: veggiono in orïente, innanzi a l'alba,
IT.6: surger per via che poco le sta bruna--,
IT.7: mi venne in sogno una femmina balba,
IT.8: ne li occhi guercia, e sovra i piè distorta,
IT.9: con le man monche, e di colore scialba.
IT.10: Io la mirava; e come 'l sol conforta
IT.11: le fredde membra che la notte aggrava,
IT.12: così lo sguardo mio le facea scorta
IT.13: la lingua, e poscia tutta la drizzava
IT.14: in poco d'ora, e lo smarrito volto,
IT.15: com' amor vuol, così le colorava.
IT.16: Poi ch'ell' avea 'l parlar così disciolto,
IT.17: cominciava a cantar sì, che con pena
IT.18: da lei avrei mio intento rivolto.
IT.19: "Io son," cantava, "io son dolce serena,
IT.20: che ' marinari in mezzo mar dismago;
IT.21: tanto son di piacere a sentir piena!
IT.22: Io volsi Ulisse del suo cammin vago
IT.23: al canto mio; e qual meco s'ausa,
IT.24: rado sen parte; sì tutto l'appago!"
IT.25: Ancor non era sua bocca richiusa,
IT.26: quand' una donna apparve santa e presta
IT.27: lunghesso me per far colei confusa.
IT.28: "O Virgilio, Virgilio, chi è questa?"
IT.29: fieramente dicea; ed el venìa
IT.30: con li occhi fitti pur in quella onesta.
IT.31: L'altra prendea, e dinanzi l'apria
IT.32: fendendo i drappi, e mostravami 'l ventre;
IT.33: quel mi svegliò col puzzo che n'uscia.
IT.34: Io mossi li occhi, e 'l buon maestro: "Almen tre
IT.35: voci t'ho messe!" dicea, "Surgi e vieni;
IT.36: troviam l'aperta per la qual tu entre."
IT.37: Sù mi levai, e tutti eran già pieni
IT.38: de l'alto dì i giron del sacro monte,
IT.39: e andavam col sol novo a le reni.
IT.40: Seguendo lui, portava la mia fronte
IT.41: come colui che l'ha di pensier carca,
IT.42: che fa di sé un mezzo arco di ponte;
IT.43: quand' io udi' "Venite; qui si varca"
IT.44: parlare in modo soave e benigno,
IT.45: qual non si sente in questa mortal marca.
IT.46: Con l'ali aperte, che parean di cigno,
IT.47: volseci in sù colui che sì parlonne
IT.48: tra due pareti del duro macigno.
IT.49: Mosse le penne poi e ventilonne,
IT.50: "Qui lugent" affermando esser beati,
IT.51: ch'avran di consolar l'anime donne.
IT.52: "Che hai che pur inver' la terra guati?"
IT.53: la guida mia incominciò a dirmi,

IT.55: E io: "Con tanta sospeccion fa irmi
IT.56: novella visïon ch'a sé mi piega,
IT.57: sì ch'io non posso dal pensar partirmi."
IT.58: "Vedesti," disse, "quell'antica strega
IT.59: che sola sovr' a noi omai si piagne;
IT.60: vedesti come l'uom da lei si slega.
IT.61: Bastiti, e batti a terra le calcagne;
IT.62: li occhi rivolgi al logoro che gira
IT.63: lo rege etterno con le rote magne."
IT.64: Quale 'l falcon, che prima a' piè si mira,
IT.65: indi si volge al grido e si protende
IT.66: per lo disio del pasto che là il tira,
IT.67: tal mi fec' io; e tal, quanto si fende
IT.68: la roccia per dar via a chi va suso,
IT.69: n'andai infin dove 'l cerchiar si prende.
IT.70: Com' io nel quinto giro fui dischiuso,
IT.71: vidi gente per esso che piangea,
IT.72: giacendo a terra tutta volta in giuso.
IT.73: "Adhaesit pavimento anima mea"
IT.74: sentia dir lor con sì alti sospiri,
IT.75: che la parola a pena s'intendea.
IT.76: "O eletti di Dio, li cui soffriri
IT.77: e giustizia e speranza fa men duri,
IT.78: drizzate noi verso li alti saliri."
IT.79: "Se voi venite dal giacer sicuri,
IT.80: e volete trovar la via più tosto,
IT.81: le vostre destre sien sempre di fori."
IT.82: Così pregò 'l poeta, e sì risposto
IT.83: poco dinanzi a noi ne fu; per ch'io
IT.84: nel parlare avvisai l'altro nascosto,
IT.85: e volsi li occhi a li occhi al segnor mio:
IT.86: ond' elli m'assentì con lieto cenno
IT.87: ciò che chiedea la vista del disio.
IT.88: Poi ch'io potei di me fare a mio senno,
IT.89: trassimi sovra quella creatura
IT.90: le cui parole pria notar mi fenno,
IT.91: dicendo: "Spirto in cui pianger matura
IT.92: quel sanza 'l quale a Dio tornar non pòssi,
IT.93: sosta un poco per me tua maggior cura.
IT.94: Chi fosti e perché vòlti avete i dossi
IT.95: al sù, mi dì, e se vuo' ch'io t'impetri
IT.96: cosa di là ond' io vivendo mossi."
IT.97: Ed elli a me: "Perché i nostri diretri
IT.98: rivolga il cielo a sé, saprai; ma prima
IT.99: scias quod ego fui successor Petri.
IT.100: Intra Sïestri e Chiaveri s'adima
IT.101: una fiumana bella, e del suo nome
IT.102: lo titol del mio sangue fa sua cima.
IT.103: Un mese e poco più prova' io come
IT.104: pesa il gran manto a chi dal fango il guarda,
IT.105: che piuma sembran tutte l'altre some.

IT.107: ma, come fatto fui roman pastore,
IT.108: così scopersi la vita bugiarda.

IT.110: né più salir potiesi in quella vita;
IT.111: per che di questa in me s'accese amore.
IT.112: Fino a quel punto misera e partita
IT.113: da Dio anima fui, del tutto avara;
IT.114: or, come vedi, qui ne son punita.
IT.115: Quel ch'avarizia fa, qui si dichiara
IT.116: in purgazion de l'anime converse;
IT.117: e nulla pena il monte ha più amara.

IT.119: in alto, fisso a le cose terrene,
IT.120: così giustizia qui a terra il merse.
IT.121: Come avarizia spense a ciascun bene
IT.122: lo nostro amore, onde operar perdési,
IT.123: così giustizia qui stretti ne tene,
IT.124: ne' piedi e ne le man legati e presi;
IT.125: e quanto fia piacer del giusto Sire,
IT.126: tanto staremo immobili e distesi."
IT.127: Io m'era inginocchiato e volea dire;

IT.129: solo ascoltando, del mio reverire,
