EN.1: In the hour when the heat of day,
EN.2: cooled by earth and at times by Saturn,
EN.3: can no longer temper the cold of the moon,
EN.4: when geomancers see their Fortuna Major
EN.5: rise in the east before the dawn,
EN.6: which does not long stay dark for it,
EN.7: there came to me a woman, in a dream,
EN.8: stammering, cross-eyed, splayfooted,
EN.9: with crippled hands and sickly pale complexion.
EN.10: I looked at her, and as the sun revives
EN.11: cold limbs benumbed by night,
EN.12: so my gaze gave her a ready tongue
EN.13: and then in very little time
EN.14: straightened her crooked limbs
EN.15: and tinged her sallow face as love desires.
EN.16: And with her speech set free
EN.17: she started singing in a way that would
EN.18: have made it hard for me to turn aside.
EN.19: 'I am,' she sang, 'I am the sweet siren
EN.20: who beguile mariners on distant seas,
EN.21: so great is their delight in hearing me.
EN.22: I drew Ulysses, eager for the journey,
EN.23: with my song. And those who dwell with me
EN.24: rarely depart, so much do I content them.'
EN.25: Her lips had not yet closed
EN.26: when there appeared a lady at my side,
EN.27: holy and alert, to confound her.
EN.28: 'O Virgil, Virgil, who is this?'
EN.29: she asked, indignant. And he came forward
EN.30: with his eyes fixed on that virtuous one.
EN.31: The other he seized and, ripping her garments,
EN.32: laid her front bare and exposed her belly.
EN.33: The stench that came from there awoke me.
EN.34: I was looking around, and the good master said:
EN.35: 'Three times at least I've called you. Arise and come.
EN.36: Let us find the opening through which you enter.'
EN.37: I stood up. All the circles of the holy mountain
EN.38: were already filled with the advancing day
EN.39: and we went on with the new sun at our backs.
EN.40: With furrowed brow I followed him,
EN.41: as though burdened with a thought that bent
EN.42: my body like the half-arch of a bridge,
EN.43: until I heard: 'Come, here is the passage,'
EN.44: spoken in such gentle, gracious tones
EN.45: as are not heard within these earthly confines.
EN.46: With open wings that seemed a swan's
EN.47: he that had spoken showed the way on up
EN.48: between two walls of flinty stone
EN.49: and, stirring his feathers, gently fanned us,
EN.50: declaring those qui lugent to be blessed,
EN.51: for their souls shall be comforted.
EN.52: 'What's wrong, that you keep staring at the ground?'
EN.53: my guide began, once we were on our way,
EN.54: leaving the angel just below.
EN.55: 'I am so distracted going on,' I said,
EN.56: because this strange new dream so weighs on me
EN.57: I cannot keep it from my mind.'
EN.58: 'You saw,' he said, 'that ancient witch
EN.59: who alone is purged with tears above us here.
EN.60: And you saw how man is freed from her.
EN.61: 'Let that be enough. Press your heels
EN.62: into the ground. Raise your eyes to the lure
EN.63: the Eternal King spins with His majestic spheres.'
EN.64: Like the falcon that at first looks at its feet,
EN.65: and only then turns to the call and stretches up
EN.66: in its desire for the food that draws it,
EN.67: such I became and, so impelled, I went
EN.68: as far as the cleft rock allowed for the ascent
EN.69: to where the circling starts again.
EN.70: When I came out onto the ledge
EN.71: of the fifth round, I saw people on it
EN.72: lying face down on the ground and weeping.
EN.73: 'Adhaesit pavimento anima mea'
EN.74: I heard them say with such deep sighs
EN.75: the words could hardly be distinguished.
EN.76: 'O chosen ones of God, whose sufferings
EN.77: both hope and justice make less hard,
EN.78: direct us to the steps that lead us up.'
EN.79: 'If you are here exempt from lying prostrate
EN.80: and wish to find the quickest way,
EN.81: keep to the right along the outer rim.'
EN.82: Thus the poet asked and thus came the response
EN.83: from a little way ahead, and I could tell who spoke
EN.84: although his face was hidden.
EN.85: I turned my eyes to the eyes of my lord.
EN.86: With a pleased sign he consented
EN.87: to what my pleading look had asked.
EN.88: When I was free to do what I desired
EN.89: I drew away and stood above that soul
EN.90: whose words had made me first aware of him,
EN.91: saying: 'Spirit in whom weeping ripens
EN.92: that without which there is no return to God,
EN.93: for my sake just a while neglect your greater care.
EN.94: 'Tell me who you were and why you lie face down
EN.95: and whether there is something I might do
EN.96: for you back there, where I set out alive.'
EN.97: And he to me: 'Why Heaven turns our backs
EN.98: against Itself, that you shall know, but first
EN.99: scias quod ego fui successor Petri.
EN.100: 'Between Sestri and Chiàvari there runs down
EN.101: a lovely stream and with its name
EN.102: the title of my line has marked its shield.
EN.103: 'In a month and little more I learned how heavy
EN.104: the mantle weighs on one who keeps it from the mud,
EN.105: making any other burden seem a feather.
EN.106: 'My conversion, alas, came late--
EN.107: when I was made the Roman shepherd,
EN.108: I discovered a life of lies.
EN.109: 'I saw that there the heart was not at peace,
EN.110: nor was preferment possible in that life,
EN.111: and for this higher state my love was kindled.
EN.112: 'Until that moment I was a wretched soul,
EN.113: cut off from God, and filled with avarice.
EN.114: Now, as you see, I am punished for that here.
EN.115: 'The work of avarice is here proclaimed
EN.116: in the purging of the down-turned souls,
EN.117: and the mountain gives no punishment more bitter.
EN.118: 'Just as we failed to lift our eyes on high
EN.119: because they were fixed on earthly things,
EN.120: so justice here has turned them to the earth.
EN.121: 'As avarice quenched our love of worthy things,
EN.122: wasting our chance to do good works,
EN.123: so justice here has bound us fast.
EN.124: 'Securely tied are our hands and feet.
EN.125: As long as it shall please the righteous Lord
EN.126: so long shall we, unmoving, lie here prone.'
EN.127: I had kneeled and was about to speak,
EN.128: but as soon as I began and he perceived,
EN.129: only by listening, that I did him reverence,
EN.130: 'Why,' he asked, 'did you bend down that way?'
EN.131: And I: 'Because the dignity of Your high office
EN.132: stung my conscience as I stood erect.'
EN.133: 'Straighten your legs, stand up, brother,'
EN.134: he replied, 'make no mistake. I am a fellow-servant
EN.135: with you, and with the others, of a single Power.
EN.136: 'If ever you did understand the holy passage
EN.137: in the Gospel where it says "Neque nubent,"
EN.138: you may well perceive just why I say this.
EN.139: 'Now go your way. I would not keep you longer,
EN.140: for your being here impedes the tears
EN.141: with which I ripen that of which you spoke.
EN.142: 'On earth I have a niece who is called Alàgia--
EN.143: she is still virtuous, if indeed our house
EN.144: has not by its example made her wicked,
EN.145: and she alone is left to me back there.'

EN.1: The will strives ill against a worthier will.
EN.2: Therefore, against my wish but granting his,
EN.3: I drew the sponge, not full yet, from the water.
EN.4: I moved on and my leader picked his way,
EN.5: keeping to the clear path near the rock
EN.6: as one must walk on ramparts, tight against the wall,
EN.7: for the people from whose eyes dissolves,
EN.8: drop by drop, the evil filling all the world
EN.9: were crowded near the rim of the outer edge.
EN.10: May you be cursed, you age-old wolf,
EN.11: who take more prey than any other beast
EN.12: to feed your bottomless appetite!
EN.13: O heavens, whose wheels transmute
EN.14: the state of those on earth, as some believe,
EN.15: when will he come from whom the wolf shall flee?
EN.16: We made our way with scant, slow steps,
EN.17: my attention fixed upon those weeping shades
EN.18: as I listened to their piteous lamentations,
EN.19: when by chance I heard one up ahead call out
EN.20: 'Sweet Mary!' through his tears,
EN.21: even as a woman does in labor,
EN.22: and I heard the voice go on:
EN.23: 'How poor you were is witnessed by the inn
EN.24: where you set down your holy burden.'
EN.25: After that I heard: 'O good Fabricius,
EN.26: you chose poverty with virtue
EN.27: rather than possess great wealth in wickedness.'
EN.28: These words gave me such pleasure
EN.29: that I pressed forward to encounter
EN.30: the spirit who I thought had spoken
EN.31: and he went on to tell the generous gifts
EN.32: that Nicholas conferred upon the maidens
EN.33: to guide their youthful innocence to honor.
EN.34: 'O soul that speak of so much goodness,
EN.35: tell me who you were,' I said, 'and why you alone
EN.36: rehearse these deeds so fit for praise.
EN.37: 'Your words shall not go unrewarded
EN.38: if I return to finish my brief journey
EN.39: in that life which rushes to its ending.'
EN.40: And he: 'I will tell you, not for any comfort
EN.41: I await from there, but for the grace that shines
EN.42: in you, reflected even short of death.
EN.43: 'I was the root of the evil tree
EN.44: that casts its shadow over all the Christian lands
EN.45: so that good fruit is rarely gathered there.
EN.46: 'If Douai, Lille, Ghent, and Bruges
EN.47: but had the power, there would soon be vengeance--
EN.48: and this I beg of Him who judges all.
EN.49: 'On earth I was known as Hugh Capet.
EN.50: Of me were born the Philips and the Louis
EN.51: who lately have been rulers over France.
EN.52: 'I was the son of a butcher of Paris.
EN.53: When the ancient line of kings had all died out,
EN.54: except for one, a gray-robed monk,
EN.55: 'I found the reins to govern all the kingdom
EN.56: firm in my hands, and soon had in possession
EN.57: such power and so very many friends
EN.58: 'that to the widowed crown
EN.59: my son's head was put forward.
EN.60: His issue is entombed as consecrated bones.
EN.61: 'As long as the great dowry of Provence
EN.62: had not yet stripped my house of feeling shame,
EN.63: it counted little, but at least it did no harm.
EN.64: 'Then, with fraud and pillage, the rape began
EN.65: and afterwards, to make amends,
EN.66: my heirs took Ponthieu, Normandy, and Gascony.
EN.67: 'Charles came into Italy and, to make amends,
EN.68: made Conradin a victim and then,
EN.69: to make amends, drove Thomas back to Heaven.
EN.70: 'I see a time, not very long from now,
EN.71: that brings another Charles away from France
EN.72: to make himself and then his kin more known.
EN.73: 'He comes alone, armed only with the lance
EN.74: that Judas used to joust. And with one thrust
EN.75: he bursts the swollen paunch of Florence.
EN.76: 'From this he shall acquire, not land,
EN.77: but sin and shame, so much the heavier for him
EN.78: the lighter he considers such disgrace.
EN.79: 'Still another Charles: once led, a prisoner,
EN.80: from his own ship, I see him sell his daughter
EN.81: after haggling, as pirates do for female slaves.
EN.82: 'O avarice, what more harm can you do us,
EN.83: since our blood is so attached to you
EN.84: it has no care for its own flesh?
EN.85: 'That past and future evil may seem less,
EN.86: I see the fleur-de-lis proceed into Anagni
EN.87: and, in His vicar, make a prisoner of Christ.
EN.88: 'I see Him mocked a second time.
EN.89: I see renewed the vinegar and gall--
EN.90: between two living thieves I see Him slain.
EN.91: 'I see that this new Pilate is so brutal
EN.92: this does not sate him, and, unsanctioned,
EN.93: I see him spread his greedy sails against the Temple.
EN.94: 'O my Lord, when shall I be gladdened
EN.95: at the sight of vengeance that, as yet concealed,
EN.96: hidden in your mind, makes sweet your wrath?
EN.97: 'What I have said of the one and only
EN.98: bride of the Holy Spirit,
EN.99: which made you turn to me for a gloss,
EN.100: 'is the response, as long as it is day,
EN.101: in all our prayers, but when night falls
EN.102: we then intone an opposite refrain.
EN.103: 'Then we recall Pygmalion,
EN.104: whose all-devouring lust for gold
EN.105: made him a traitor, thief, and parricide,
EN.106: 'and the misery of avaricious Midas
EN.107: that came on him for his intemperate demand
EN.108: and must always be a cause for laughter.
EN.109: 'Each then remembers reckless Achan
EN.110: and how he stole the spoils, so that the wrath
EN.111: of Joshua seems here to strike at him again.
EN.112: 'Then we accuse Sapphira with her husband.
EN.113: We celebrate the hoof-blows that Heliodorus bore.
EN.114: In disgrace the name of Polymnestor,
EN.115: 'for slaying Polydorus, circles all the mountain.
EN.116: Last, the cry is: "Tell us, Crassus,
EN.117: since you know, what is the taste of gold?"
EN.118: 'Sometimes one speaks loud, another low,
EN.119: according to the zeal that spurs our speech,
EN.120: at times with greater, at times with lesser force.
EN.121: 'Therefore, in giving voice to goodness,
EN.122: as here we do by day, I was not alone just now,
EN.123: even though no other raised his voice nearby.'
EN.124: We had already left him there behind us
EN.125: and strove to pick our way
EN.126: as nimbly as the narrow path allowed,
EN.127: when I felt the mountain tremble
EN.128: as though it might collapse, and a chill,
EN.129: like the chill of death, subdued me.
EN.130: Surely Delos was not so shaken
EN.131: before Latona built her nest
EN.132: and there gave birth to the twofold eyes of heaven.
EN.133: Then there rose up a great cry all around us
EN.134: so that my master drew up closer to me,
EN.135: saying: 'Have no fear while I'm your guide.'
EN.136: 'Gloria in excelsis Deo' all were shouting
EN.137: from what I understood from those nearby,
EN.138: where their outcry could be better heard.
EN.139: We stood stock still and in suspense,
EN.140: like the shepherds who first heard that song,
EN.141: until the trembling ceased and the song was done.
EN.142: Then we continued on our holy path,
EN.143: our eyes cast down to see the shades along the ground,
EN.144: who had returned to their accustomed weeping.
EN.145: Never did ignorance attack me with such fury
EN.146: against so great a need to know--
EN.147: if in this my memory does not err--
EN.148: as I felt then deep in my thoughts.
EN.149: But, since we had to hurry, I dared not ask,
EN.150: nor could I of myself find answers there.
EN.151: I went on, afraid to ask and full of thought.

EN.1: The natural thirst that never can be quenched
EN.2: except with that water the Samaritan woman
EN.3: begged to be given as a special grace
EN.4: tormented me. And in haste I followed my leader
EN.5: over bodies strewn along the way,
EN.6: still grieved at their just punishment.
EN.7: And lo, as Luke sets down for us that Christ,
EN.8: just risen from the cave that was his sepulcher,
EN.9: revealed himself to two He walked with on the road,
EN.10: there appeared a shade who had come up behind us
EN.11: while we, intent upon the crowd prone at our feet,
EN.12: were not aware of him until he spoke
EN.13: and said: 'O my brothers, may God grant you peace.'
EN.14: We turned at once and Virgil answered him
EN.15: with the gesture that befits this greeting
EN.16: and then began: 'May the unerring court
EN.17: that confines me in eternal exile
EN.18: bring you in peace to the assembly of the blessed.'
EN.19: 'What?' the other asked--even as we hurried on--
EN.20: 'if you are shades whom God does not deem worthy,
EN.21: who has led you up so far along His stairs?'
EN.22: And my teacher said: 'If you look at the signs
EN.23: that this man bears, traced by the angel,
EN.24: you will know that he must reign among the good.
EN.25: 'Since she that spins both day and night
EN.26: had not used up the flax that for each mortal
EN.27: Clotho loads and winds upon the distaff,
EN.28: 'his soul, which is your sister--mine as well,
EN.29: could not attempt the climb unaided
EN.30: because it cannot see things quite as we do.
EN.31: 'I, for this reason, was drawn from Hell's wide jaws
EN.32: to be his guide, and I shall guide him
EN.33: as far as my own teaching will allow.
EN.34: 'But tell us, if you can, why did the mountain shake
EN.35: so hard just now and why did it emit
EN.36: such clamor, down to its wave-washed base.'
EN.37: With this question he threaded the needle of my wish
EN.38: with such precision that, with but a hope
EN.39: for an answer, he made my thirst less parching.
EN.40: The other offered this response:
EN.41: 'The mountain's holy law does not allow
EN.42: anything disordered or that violates its rule.
EN.43: 'Here nothing ever changes.
EN.44: Only by that which Heaven gathers from Itself,
EN.45: and from nothing else, can any change be wrought,
EN.46: 'so that not rain nor hail nor snow
EN.47: nor dew nor hoarfrost falls above
EN.48: the gentle rise of those three steps below.
EN.49: 'Clouds, dense or broken, do not appear,
EN.50: nor lightning-flash, nor Thaumas' daughter,
EN.51: who appears in many places in the sky down there,
EN.52: 'nor does dry vapor rise beyond the highest
EN.53: of those three steps of which I spoke,
EN.54: where Peter's vicar sets his feet.
EN.55: 'Lower down, perhaps, it trembles more or less,
EN.56: but from the wind concealed in earth
EN.57: it has never, I know not why, trembled here above.
EN.58: 'Here it trembles when a soul feels it is pure,
EN.59: ready to rise, to set out on its ascent,
EN.60: and next there follows that great cry.
EN.61: 'Of its purity the will alone gives proof,
EN.62: and the soul, wholly free to change its convent,
EN.63: is taken by surprise and allows the will its way.
EN.64: 'It wills the same before, but holy Justice sets
EN.65: the soul's desire against its will,
EN.66: and, as once it longed to sin, it now seeks penance.
EN.67: 'And I, who have been prostrate in this pain
EN.68: five hundred years and more, just now felt
EN.69: my freed will seek a better threshold.
EN.70: 'That is why you felt the earth shake
EN.71: and heard the pious spirits of this mountain
EN.72: praise the Lord--may He soon raise them!'
EN.73: Thus he spoke to us, and since it is true that
EN.74: the greater the thirst the more the drinking pleases,
EN.75: I cannot begin to tell the benefit to me.
EN.76: And my wise leader said: 'Now I see the net
EN.77: that here ensnares you and how you are released,
EN.78: why the earth trembled and why you rejoiced.
EN.79: 'May it please you to tell me who you were
EN.80: and to let me understand from your own words
EN.81: why you have lain here for so many centuries.'
EN.82: 'In the time when worthy Titus,
EN.83: aided by the King most high, avenged the wounds
EN.84: from which had poured the blood that Judas sold,
EN.85: 'on earth I bore the name that most endures
EN.86: and honors most,' replied that spirit.
EN.87: 'Fame I had found, but not yet faith.
EN.88: 'So sweet was my poetic recitation that Rome
EN.89: drew me from Toulouse and deemed me worthy
EN.90: to have my brows adorned with myrtle.
EN.91: 'My name is Statius. On earth men often speak it.
EN.92: I sang of Thebes and then of great Achilles,
EN.93: but fell along the way with the second burden.
EN.94: 'The sparks that kindled the fire in me
EN.95: came from the holy flame
EN.96: from which more than a thousand have been lit--
EN.97: 'I mean the Aeneid. When I wrote poetry
EN.98: it was my mamma and my nurse.
EN.99: Without it, I would not have weighed a dram.
EN.100: 'To have lived on earth when Virgil lived
EN.101: I would have stayed one year's sun longer than I owed
EN.102: before I came forth from my exile.'
EN.103: These words made Virgil turn to me
EN.104: with a look that, silent, said: 'Keep silent.'
EN.105: But the power that wills cannot do all it wills,
EN.106: for laughter and tears so closely follow feelings
EN.107: from which they spring, they least can be controlled
EN.108: in those who are most truthful.
EN.109: I only smiled, like one who gives a hint,
EN.110: at which the shade was silent, probing my eyes,
EN.111: where the soul's expression is most clearly fixed.
EN.112: 'So your great labor may end in good,'
EN.113: he said, 'why did your face just now
EN.114: give off the sudden glimmer of a smile?'
EN.115: Now I am caught between one side and the other:
EN.116: one bids me hold my tongue,
EN.117: the other urges me to speak,
EN.118: so that I sigh and my master understands.
EN.119: 'Don't be afraid to speak,' he says to me,
EN.120: 'yes, speak--tell him what he is so keen to know.'
EN.121: And I begin: 'Perhaps you wonder,
EN.122: ancient spirit, at my smiling,
EN.123: but I would have a greater wonder seize you.
EN.124: 'This one who guides my eyes on high
EN.125: is the very Virgil from whom you took the power
EN.126: to sing of men and of the gods.
EN.127: 'If you believed another reason caused my smile,
EN.128: dismiss that as untrue and understand
EN.129: it was those words you spoke of him.'
EN.130: Already he was stooping to embrace my teacher's feet,
EN.131: but Virgil said: 'Brother, do not do so,
EN.132: for you are a shade and you behold a shade.'
EN.133: And the other, rising: 'Now you can understand
EN.134: the measure of the love for you that warms me,
EN.135: when I forget our emptiness
EN.136: and treat our shades as bodied things.'

IT.1: Già era l'angel dietro a noi rimaso,
IT.2: l'angel che n'avea vòlti al sesto giro,
IT.3: avendomi dal viso un colpo raso;
IT.4: e quei c'hanno a giustizia lor disiro
IT.5: detto n'avea beati, e le sue voci
IT.6: con 'sitiunt,' sanz'altro, ciò forniro.

IT.8: m'andava, sì che sanz'alcun labore
IT.9: seguiva in sù li spiriti veloci;

IT.11: acceso di virtù, sempre altro accese,
IT.12: pur che la fiamma sua paresse fore;
IT.13: onde da l'ora che tra noi discese
IT.14: nel limbo de lo 'nferno Giovenale,
IT.15: che la tua affezion mi fé palese,
IT.16: mia benvoglienza inverso te fu quale
IT.17: più strinse mai di non vista persona,
IT.18: sì ch'or mi parran corte queste scale.

IT.20: se troppo sicurtà m'allarga il freno,
IT.21: e come amico omai meco ragiona:

IT.23: loco avarizia, tra cotanto senno
IT.24: di quanto per tua cura fosti pieno?"
IT.25: Queste parole Stazio mover fenno
IT.26: un poco a riso pria; poscia rispuose:
IT.27: "Ogne tuo dir d'amor m'è caro cenno.
IT.28: Veramente più volte appaion cose
IT.29: che danno a dubitar falsa matera
IT.30: per le vere ragion che son nascose.
IT.31: La tua dimanda tuo creder m'avvera
IT.32: esser ch'i' fossi avaro in l'altra vita,
IT.33: forse per quella cerchia dov' io era.
IT.34: Or sappi ch'avarizia fu partita
IT.35: troppo da me, e questa dismisura
IT.36: migliaia di lunari hanno punita.
IT.37: E se non fosse ch'io drizzai mia cura,
IT.38: quand'io intesi là dove tu chiame,
IT.39: crucciato quasi a l'umana natura:
IT.40: 'Per che non reggi tu, o sacra fame
IT.41: de l'oro, l'appetito de' mortali?',
IT.42: voltando sentirei le giostre grame.
IT.43: Allor m'accorsi che troppo aprir l'ali
IT.44: potean le mani a spendere, e pente'mi
IT.45: così di quel come de li altri mali.
IT.46: Quanti risurgeran coi crini scemi
IT.47: per ignoranza, che di questa pecca
IT.48: toglie 'l penter vivendo e ne li stremi!
IT.49: E sappie che la colpa che rimbecca
IT.50: per dritta opposizione alcun peccato,
IT.51: con esso insieme qui suo verde secca;
IT.52: però, s'io son tra quella gente stato
IT.53: che piange l'avarizia, per purgarmi,
IT.54: per lo contrario suo m'è incontrato."
IT.55: "Or quando tu cantasti le crude armi
IT.56: de la doppia trestizia di Giocasta,"
IT.57: disse 'l cantor de' buccolici carmi,
IT.58: "per quello che Clïò teco lì tasta,
IT.59: non par che ti facesse ancor fedele
IT.60: la fede, sanza qual ben far non basta.
IT.61: Se così è, qual sole o quai candele
IT.62: ti stenebraron sì, che tu drizzasti
IT.63: poscia di retro al pescator le vele?"
IT.64: Ed elli a lui: "Tu prima m'invïasti
IT.65: verso Parnaso a ber ne le sue grotte,

IT.73: Per te poeta fui, per te cristiano:
IT.74: ma perché veggi mei ciò ch'io disegno,
IT.75: a colorare stenderò la mano.

IT.103: nel primo cinghio del carcere cieco;

EN.1: The angel who had shown the way
EN.2: to the sixth circling now was left behind,
EN.3: having erased another swordstroke from my brow
EN.4: as he declared that those who long for righteousness
EN.5: are blessed, ending on sitiunt
EN.6: without the other words he might have said.
EN.7: And now I could move on, lighter
EN.8: than at the other entrances, so that I followed
EN.9: the swifter spirits up with ease,
EN.10: when Virgil began: 'A love that is kindled by virtue
EN.11: has always ignited another, as long as its flame
EN.12: was shining where it could be seen.
EN.13: 'From the hour, therefore, when Juvenal descended
EN.14: into the Limbo of Hell, among us,
EN.15: and made your affection known to me,
EN.16: 'my good will toward you was as great
EN.17: as anyone has ever felt for someone never seen,
EN.18: so that to me these stairs will now seem short.
EN.19: 'But tell me--and as a friend forgive me
EN.20: if with too much assurance I relax the reins,
EN.21: and as a friend speak with me now--
EN.22: 'how could avarice find room
EN.23: amidst such wisdom in your breast,
EN.24: the wisdom that you nourished with such care.'
EN.25: These words made Statius smile a little
EN.26: before he answered: 'Every word of yours
EN.27: is to me a welcome token of your love.
EN.28: 'But, in truth, things often are misleading
EN.29: when their true causes remain hidden,
EN.30: thus leading us to false conclusions.
EN.31: 'Your question shows me you believe,
EN.32: perhaps because of the terrace I was on,
EN.33: that I was avaricious in the other life.
EN.34: 'Know then that avarice was much too far
EN.35: removed from me and that this lack of measure
EN.36: lunar months in thousands now have punished.
EN.37: 'And had I not reformed my inclination
EN.38: when I came to understand the lines in which,
EN.39: as if enraged at human nature, you cried out:
EN.40: '"To what end, O cursèd hunger for gold,
EN.41: do you not govern the appetite of mortals?"
EN.42: I would know the rolling weights and dismal jousts.
EN.43: 'Then I learned that we can spread
EN.44: our wings too wide with spending hands,
EN.45: and I repented that and other sins.
EN.46: 'How many more will have to rise again, hair shorn
EN.47: through ignorance, which takes away repentance
EN.48: of this sin in life and in the hour of death!
EN.49: 'Note, also, that the fault that moves
EN.50: directly opposite to a sin
EN.51: is here grouped with it and is withered of its green.
EN.52: 'Therefore, if I, to purge my sins, have been
EN.53: among those shades who weep for avarice,
EN.54: this has befallen me for the opposing fault.'
EN.55: 'But, when you sang the cruel warfare
EN.56: between the twofold sorrows of Jocasta,'
EN.57: said the singer of the Eclogues,
EN.58: 'it does not seem, from what you wrote with Clio's help,
EN.59: that you had found as yet the faith,
EN.60: that faith without which good works fail.
EN.61: 'If that is so, what sun, what candles
EN.62: dispelled your darkness so that afterwards
EN.63: you hoisted sail, following the fisherman?'
EN.64: And the other answered him: 'It was you who first
EN.65: set me toward Parnassus to drink in its grottoes,
EN.66: and you who first lit my way toward God.
EN.67: 'You were as one who goes by night, carrying
EN.68: the light behind him--it is no help to him,
EN.69: but instructs all those who follow--
EN.70: 'when you said: "The centuries turn new again.
EN.71: Justice returns with the first age of man,
EN.72: new progeny descends from Heaven."
EN.73: 'Through you I was a poet, through you a Christian.
EN.74: But, that you may see better what I outline,
EN.75: I will set my hand to fill the colors in.
EN.76: 'Already all the world was pregnant
EN.77: with the true faith, inseminated
EN.78: by the messengers of the eternal kingdom,
EN.79: 'and the words of yours I have just recited
EN.80: did so accord with the new preachers
EN.81: that I began to visit them.
EN.82: 'More and more they seemed to me so holy
EN.83: that when Domitian started with his persecutions
EN.84: their weeping did not lack my tears.
EN.85: 'While I remained on earth,
EN.86: I gave them comfort. Their upright ways
EN.87: made me despise all other sects.
EN.88: 'I was baptized before, in my verses,
EN.89: I had led the Greeks to the rivers of Thebes,
EN.90: but, from fear, I stayed a secret Christian,
EN.91: 'long pretending I was still a pagan.
EN.92: More than four centuries, because I was lukewarm,
EN.93: did I circle the fourth terrace.
EN.94: 'You, then, who have raised the veil
EN.95: that hid from me the great good I describe,
EN.96: tell me, while there is time in this ascent,
EN.97: 'where is our ancient Terence, where Cecilius,
EN.98: Plautus, Varius, if you know.
EN.99: Tell me if they are damned and in what place.'
EN.100: 'Those, Persius, and I, and many more,'
EN.101: replied my leader, 'are with that Greek
EN.102: the Muses suckled more than any other,
EN.103: 'in the first circle of the dark prison.
EN.104: We often talk about that mountain
EN.105: where those who nursed us ever dwell.
EN.106: 'Euripides is with us there and Antiphon,
EN.107: Simonides and Agathon and many other Greeks
EN.108: whose brows were once adorned with laurel.
EN.109: 'Among those from your works who may be seen
EN.110: are Antigone, Deïphyle, Argia,
EN.111: and Ismene, still sad as once she was.
EN.112: 'She that revealed Langìa also may be seen,
EN.113: as well as the daughter of Tiresias,
EN.114: and Thetis, and Deïdamìa with her sisters.'
EN.115: Both the poets now were silent,
EN.116: again intent on looking all around them,
EN.117: freed from the constraint of stairs and walls.
EN.118: Already four handmaids of the day were left behind
EN.119: and the fifth was at the chariot-shaft,
EN.120: guiding its gleaming tip still higher,
EN.121: when my leader said: 'It might be better if we turned
EN.122: our right side's shoulders to the outer edge,
EN.123: circling the mountain as we are accustomed.'
EN.124: Thus habit was our teacher there,
EN.125: and we took our way with less uncertainty
EN.126: because that other worthy soul encouraged us.
EN.127: They went along in front and I, alone,
EN.128: came on behind, listening to their discourse,
EN.129: which gave me understanding of the art of verse.
EN.130: But soon their pleasant talk was interrupted
EN.131: by a tree found in the middle of the path,
EN.132: with fruits that smelled both savory and good,
EN.133: and, as a fir tree narrows as it branches upward,
EN.134: this one tapered down from branch to branch,
EN.135: perhaps so that no one can climb it.
EN.136: On that side, where our way was blocked,
EN.137: from the high rock fell pellucid water,
EN.138: which was dispersed among the upper leaves.
EN.139: As the two poets neared the tree
EN.140: a voice from among the boughs called out:
EN.141: 'This is a food that you shall lack.'
EN.142: And then it said: 'Mary gave more thought
EN.143: that the marriage-feast be decorous and complete
EN.144: than for the mouth with which she pleads for you.
EN.145: 'The Roman matrons of antiquity
EN.146: were glad to have but water as their drink,
EN.147: and Daniel scorned banquets and acquired wisdom.
EN.148: 'The first age was as beautiful as gold.
EN.149: Its acorns were made savory by hunger
EN.150: and thirst made nectar flow in every brook.
EN.152: that nourished John the Baptist in the desert,
EN.153: for which he is glorious and as great
EN.154: as in the Gospel is revealed to you.'

IT.1: Mentre che li occhi per la fronda verde
IT.2: ficcava ïo sì come far suole
IT.3: chi dietro a li uccellin sua vita perde,
IT.4: lo più che padre mi dicea: "Figliuole,
IT.5: vienne oramai, ché 'l tempo che n'è imposto
IT.6: più utilmente compartir si vuole."
IT.7: Io volsi 'l viso, e 'l passo non men tosto,
IT.8: appresso i savi, che parlavan sìe,
IT.9: che l'andar mi facean di nullo costo.
IT.10: Ed ecco piangere e cantar s'udìe
IT.11: "Labïa mëa, Domine" per modo
IT.12: tal, che diletto e doglia parturìe.
IT.13: "O dolce padre, che è quel ch'i' odo?"
IT.14: comincia' io; ed elli: "Ombre che vanno
IT.15: forse di lor dover solvendo il nodo."
IT.16: Sì come i peregrin pensosi fanno,
IT.17: giugnendo per cammin gente non nota,
IT.18: che si volgono ad essa e non restanno,
IT.19: così di retro a noi, più tosto mota,
IT.20: venendo e trapassando ci ammirava
IT.21: d'anime turba tacita e devota.
IT.22: Ne li occhi era ciascuna oscura e cava,
IT.23: palida ne la faccia, e tanto scema
IT.24: che da l'ossa la pelle s'informava.
IT.25: Non credo che così a buccia strema
IT.26: Erisittone fosse fatto secco,
IT.27: per digiunar, quando più n'ebbe tema.
IT.28: Io dicea fra me stesso pensando: "Ecco
IT.29: la gente che perdé Ierusalemme,
IT.30: quando Maria nel figlio diè di becco!"
IT.31: Parean l'occhiaie anella sanza gemme:
IT.32: chi nel viso de li uomini legge "omo"
IT.33: ben avria quivi conosciuta l'emme.
IT.34: Chi crederebbe che l'odor d'un pomo
IT.35: sì governasse, generando brama,
IT.36: e quel d'un'acqua, non sappiendo como?
IT.37: Già era in ammirar che sì li affama,
IT.38: per la cagione ancor non manifesta
IT.39: di lor magrezza e di lor trista squama,
IT.40: ed ecco del profondo de la testa
IT.41: volse a me li occhi un'ombra e guardò fiso;
IT.42: poi gridò forte: "Qual grazia m'è questa?"
IT.43: Mai non l'avrei riconosciuto al viso;
IT.44: ma ne la voce sua mi fu palese
IT.45: ciò che l'aspetto in sé avea conquiso.
IT.46: Questa favilla tutta mi raccese
IT.47: mia conoscenza a la cangiata labbia,
IT.48: e ravvisai la faccia di Forese.
IT.49: "Deh, non contendere a l'asciutta scabbia
IT.50: che mi scolora," pregava, "la pelle,
IT.51: né a difetto di carne ch'io abbia;
IT.52: ma dimmi il ver di te, dì chi son quelle
IT.53: due anime che là ti fanno scorta;
IT.54: non rimaner che tu non mi favelle!"
IT.55: "La faccia tua, ch'io lagrimai già morta,
IT.56: mi dà di pianger mo non minor doglia,"
IT.57: rispuos' io lui, "veggendola sì torta.
IT.58: Però mi dì, per Dio, che sì vi sfoglia;
IT.59: non mi far dir mentr' io mi maraviglio,
IT.60: ché mal può dir chi è pien d'altra voglia."
IT.61: Ed elli a me: "De l'etterno consiglio
IT.62: cade vertù ne l'acqua e ne la pianta
IT.63: rimasa dietro, ond' io sì m'assottiglio.
IT.64: Tutta esta gente che piangendo canta
IT.65: per seguitar la gola oltra misura,
IT.66: in fame e 'n sete qui si rifà santa.
IT.67: Di bere e di mangiar n'accende cura
IT.68: l'odor ch'esce del pomo e de lo sprazzo
IT.69: che si distende su per sua verdura.
IT.70: E non pur una volta, questo spazzo
IT.71: girando, si rinfresca nostra pena:
IT.72: io dico pena, e dovria dir sollazzo,
IT.73: ché quella voglia a li alberi ci mena
IT.74: che menò Cristo lieto a dire 'Elì,'
IT.75: quando ne liberò con la sua vena."
IT.76: E io a lui: "Forese, da quel dì
IT.77: nel qual mutasti mondo a miglior vita,
IT.78: cinqu' anni non son vòlti infino a qui.
IT.79: Se prima fu la possa in te finita
IT.80: di peccar più, che sovvenisse l'ora
IT.81: del buon dolor ch'a Dio ne rimarita,
IT.82: come se' tu qua sù venuto ancora?
IT.83: Io ti credea trovar là giù di sotto,
IT.84: dove tempo per tempo si ristora."
IT.85: Ond' elli a me: "Sì tosto m'ha condotto
IT.86: a ber lo dolce assenzo d'i martìri
IT.87: la Nella mia con suo pianger dirotto.
IT.88: Con suoi prieghi devoti e con sospiri
IT.89: tratto m'ha de la costa ove s'aspetta,
IT.90: e liberato m'ha de li altri giri.
IT.91: Tanto è a Dio più cara e più diletta
IT.92: la vedovella mia, che molto amai,
IT.93: quanto in bene operare è più soletta;
IT.94: ché la Barbagia di Sardigna assai
IT.95: ne le femmine sue più è pudica
IT.96: che la Barbagia dov' io la lasciai.
IT.97: O dolce frate, che vuo' tu ch'io dica?
IT.98: Tempo futuro m'è già nel cospetto,
IT.99: cui non sarà quest' ora molto antica,
IT.100: nel qual sarà in pergamo interdetto
IT.101: a le sfacciate donne fiorentine
IT.102: l'andar mostrando con le poppe il petto.
IT.103: Quai barbare fuor mai, quai saracine,
IT.104: cui bisognasse, par farle ir coperte,
IT.105: o spiritali o altre discipline?
IT.106: Ma se le svergognate fosser certe
IT.107: di quel che 'l ciel veloce loro ammanna,
IT.108: già per urlare avrian le bocche aperte;
IT.109: ché, se l'antiveder qui non m'inganna,
IT.110: prima fien triste che le guance impeli
IT.111: colui che mo si consola con nanna.
IT.112: Deh, frate, or fa che più non mi ti celi!
IT.113: vedi che non pur io, ma questa gente
IT.114: tutta rimira là dove 'l sol veli."
IT.115: Per ch'io a lui: "Se tu riduci a mente
IT.116: qual fosti meco, e qual io teco fui,
IT.117: ancor fia grave il memorar presente.
IT.118: Di quella vita mi volse costui
IT.119: che mi va innanzi, l'altr' ier, quando tonda
IT.120: vi si mostrò la suora di colui,"
IT.121: e 'l sol mostrai; "costui per la profonda
IT.122: notte menato m'ha d'i veri morti
IT.123: con questa vera carne che 'l seconda.
IT.124: Indi m'han tratto sù li suoi conforti,
IT.125: salendo e rigirando la montagna
IT.126: che drizza voi che 'l mondo fece torti.
IT.127: Tanto dice di farmi sua compagna
IT.128: che io sarò là dove fia Beatrice;
IT.129: quivi convien che sanza lui rimagna.
IT.130: Virgilio è questi che così mi dice,"
IT.131: e addita'lo; "e quest' altro è quell' ombra
IT.132: per cuï scosse dianzi ogne pendice
IT.133: lo vostro regno, che da sé lo sgombra."

EN.1: While I was peering through green boughs,
EN.2: even as do men who waste their lives
EN.3: in hunting after birds,
EN.4: my more than father said to me: 'My son,
EN.5: come along, for the time we are allowed
EN.6: should be apportioned to a better use.'
EN.7: I turned my face, and my steps as quickly,
EN.8: to follow my two sages, whose discourse
EN.9: made my going on seem easy,
EN.10: when with weeping we heard voices sing
EN.11: 'Labïa mëa, Domine' in tones
EN.12: that brought at once delight and grief.
EN.13: 'O sweet father, what is that I hear?' I asked,
EN.14: and he: 'Shades, perhaps, who go their way
EN.15: loosening the knot of what they owe.'
EN.16: Just as pilgrims, absorbed in thought,
EN.17: overtaking strangers on the road,
EN.18: turn toward them without coming to a halt,
EN.19: so, coming up behind us at a quicker pace than ours
EN.20: and passing on, a group of souls,
EN.21: silent and devout, gazed at us with wonder.
EN.22: Their eyes were dark and sunken,
EN.23: their faces pale, their flesh so wasted
EN.24: that the skin took all its shape from bones.
EN.25: I do not believe that Erysichthon had become
EN.26: so consumed, to the very skin, by hunger
EN.27: when he was most in terror of it.
EN.28: I said to myself in thought:
EN.29: 'Behold the people who lost Jerusalem
EN.30: when Mary set her beak into her son!'
EN.31: The sockets of their eyes resembled rings
EN.32: without their gems. He who reads 'omo'
EN.33: in men's faces would have easily made out the 'm.'
EN.34: Who, if he did not know the reason, would believe
EN.35: the scent of fruit and smell of water
EN.36: could cause such craving, reducing shades to this?
EN.37: I was wondering what makes them so famished,
EN.38: since what had made them gaunt, with wretched,
EN.39: scaling skin, was still unknown to me,
EN.40: when out of the deep-set sockets in his head
EN.41: a shade fixed me with his eyes and cried aloud:
EN.42: 'What grace is granted to me now!'
EN.43: I never would have known him by his features,
EN.44: but the sound of his voice made plain to me
EN.45: what from his looks had been erased.
EN.46: That spark relit the memory
EN.47: of his changed features
EN.48: and I knew Forese's face.
EN.49: 'Ah,' he begged, 'pay no attention
EN.50: to the withered scab discoloring my skin
EN.51: nor to this lack of flesh on me,
EN.52: 'but give me news about yourself
EN.53: and tell me of the two souls over there,
EN.54: escorting you. Do not hold back your answer.'
EN.55: 'Your face, over which I wept when you were dead,
EN.56: now gives me no less cause for tears,
EN.57: seeing it so disfigured,' I responded.
EN.58: 'In God's name, tell me what so withers you away.
EN.59: Don't make me speak while I am so astounded,
EN.60: for a man intent on other things speaks ill.'
EN.61: And he to me: 'From the eternal counsel
EN.62: a power falls onto the tree and on the water
EN.63: there behind us. By it am I made so thin.
EN.64: 'All these people who weep while they are singing
EN.65: followed their appetites beyond all measure,
EN.66: and here regain, in thirst and hunger, holiness.
EN.67: 'The fragrance coming from the fruit
EN.68: and from the water sprinkled on green boughs
EN.69: kindles our craving to eat and drink,
EN.70: 'and not once only, circling in this space,
EN.71: is our pain renewed.
EN.72: I speak of pain but should say solace,
EN.73: 'for the same desire leads us to the trees
EN.74: that led Christ to utter Elì with such bliss
EN.75: when with the blood from His own veins He made us free.'
EN.76: And I to him: 'Forese, from that day
EN.77: when you exchanged the world for better life,
EN.78: not five years have wheeled by until this moment.
EN.79: 'If your power to keep on sinning ended
EN.80: just before the hour of blessèd sorrow
EN.81: that marries us once more to God,
EN.82: 'how did you come so far so fast?
EN.83: I thought that I might find you down below,
EN.84: where time must be repaid with equal time.'
EN.85: And he replied: 'It is my Nella
EN.86: whose flooding tears so quickly brought me
EN.87: to drink sweet wormwood in the torments.
EN.88: 'With her devoted prayers and with her sighs,
EN.89: she plucked me from the slope where one must wait
EN.90: and freed me from the other circles.
EN.91: 'So much more precious and beloved of God
EN.92: is my dear widow, whom I greatly loved,
EN.93: the more she is alone in her good works.
EN.94: 'For the Barbagia of Sardegna
EN.95: shelters many more modest women
EN.96: than does that Barbagia where I left her.
EN.97: 'O sweet brother, what would you have me say?
EN.98: In my vision even now I see a time,
EN.99: before this hour shall be very old,
EN.100: 'when from the pulpit it shall be forbidden
EN.101: for the brazen ladies of Florence
EN.102: to flaunt their nipples with their breasts.
EN.103: 'What barbarous women, what Saracens,
EN.104: have ever needed spiritual instruction
EN.105: or other rules, to walk about in proper dress?
EN.106: 'But if these shameless creatures knew
EN.107: what the swift heavens are preparing, even now
EN.108: their mouths would be spread open in a howl.
EN.109: 'For if our foresight here does not deceive me
EN.110: they shall be sorrowing before hair grows
EN.111: on cheeks of babes still soothed by lullabies.
EN.112: 'Pray, brother, conceal your tale no longer.
EN.113: Look, not only I but all these people
EN.114: gaze in wonder where you veil the sun.'
EN.115: At that I said to him: 'If you recall
EN.116: what you were with me and I was with you,
EN.117: that memory now would still be painful.
EN.118: 'He who precedes me made me renounce
EN.119: that life but several days ago, when the sister
EN.120: of him'--and I pointed to the sun--
EN.121: 'appeared round back there. It is he who led me
EN.122: through the deep night of the forever dead
EN.123: in this my very flesh that follows him.
EN.124: 'With his support I have left all that behind,
EN.125: climbing and circling each terrace of the mountain
EN.126: that straightens those made crooked by the world.
EN.127: 'He promises to keep me company
EN.128: until I shall encounter Beatrice.
EN.129: Then must I be left without him.
EN.130: It is Virgil who tells me this'--I pointed to him--
EN.131: 'and the other is the shade for whom just now
EN.132: your kingdom quaked in all its slopes,
EN.133: shaking him from itself to set him free.'

IT.1: Né il dir l' andar, né l' andar lui più lento
IT.2: facea, ma ragionando andavam forte,
IT.3: sì come nave pinta da buon vento;
IT.4: e l'ombre, che parean cose rimorte,
IT.5: per le fosse de li occhi ammirazione
IT.6: traean di me, di mio vivere accorte.
IT.7: E io, continüando al mio sermone,
IT.8: dissi: "Ella sen va sù forse più tarda
IT.9: che non farebbe, per altrui cagione.
IT.10: Ma dimmi, se tu sai, dov' è Piccarda;
IT.11: dimmi s'io veggio da notar persona
IT.12: tra questa gente che sì mi riguarda."
IT.13: "La mia sorella, che tra bella e buona
IT.14: non so qual fosse più, trïunfa lieta
IT.15: ne l'alto Olimpo già di sua corona."
IT.16: Sì disse prima; e poi: "Qui non si vieta
IT.17: di nominar ciascun, da ch'è sì munta
IT.18: nostra sembianza via per la dïeta.
IT.19: "Questi," e mostrò col dito, "è Bonagiunta,
IT.20: Bonagiunta da Lucca; e quella faccia
IT.21: di là da lui più che l'altre trapunta
IT.22: ebbe la Santa Chiesa in le sue braccia:
IT.23: dal Torso fu, e purga per digiuno
IT.24: l'anguille di Bolsena e la vernaccia."
IT.25: Molti altri mi nomò ad uno ad uno;
IT.26: e del nomar parean tutti contenti,
IT.27: sì ch'io però non vidi un atto bruno.
IT.28: Vidi per fame a vòto usar li denti
IT.29: Ubaldin da la Pila e Bonifazio
IT.30: che pasturò col rocco molte genti.
IT.31: Vidi messer Marchese, ch'ebbe spazio
IT.32: già di bere a Forlì con men secchezza,
IT.33: e sì fu tal, che non si sentì sazio.
IT.34: Ma come fa chi guarda e poi s'apprezza
IT.35: più d'un che d'altro, fei a quel da Lucca,
IT.36: che più parea di me aver contezza.
IT.37: El mormorava; e non so che "Gentucca"
IT.38: sentiv' io là, ov' el sentia la piaga
IT.39: de la giustizia che sì li pilucca.
IT.40: "O anima," diss' io, "che par sì vaga
IT.41: di parlar meco, fa sì ch'io t'intenda,
IT.42: e te e me col tuo parlare appaga."
IT.43: "Femmina è nata, e non porta ancor benda,"
IT.44: cominciò el, "che ti farà piacere
IT.45: la mia città, come ch'om la riprenda.
IT.46: Tu te n'andrai con questo antivedere:
IT.47: se nel mio mormorar prendesti errore,
IT.48: dichiareranti ancor le cose vere.
IT.49: Ma dì s'i'veggio qui colui che fore
IT.50: trasse le nove rime, cominciando
IT.51: 'Donne ch'avete intelletto d'amore.'"
IT.52: E io a lui: "I' mi son un che, quando
IT.53: Amor mi spira, noto, e a quel modo
IT.54: ch'e' ditta dentro vo significando."
IT.55: "O frate, issa vegg' io," diss' elli, "il nodo
IT.56: che 'l Notaro e Guittone e me ritenne
IT.57: di qua dal dolce stil novo ch'i' odo!
IT.58: Io veggio ben come le vostre penne
IT.59: di retro al dittator sen vanno strette,
IT.60: che de le nostre certo non avvenne;
IT.61: e qual più a gradire oltre si mette,
IT.62: non vede più da l'uno a l'altro stilo";
IT.63: e, quasi contentato, si tacette.
IT.64: Come li augei che vernan lungo 'l Nilo,
IT.65: alcuna volta in aere fanno schiera,
IT.66: poi volan più a fretta e vanno in filo,
IT.67: così tutta la gente che lì era,
IT.68: volgendo 'l viso, raffrettò suo passo,
IT.69: e per magrezza e per voler leggera.
IT.70: E come l'uom che di trottare è lasso,
IT.71: lascia andar li compagni, e sì passeggia
IT.72: fin che si sfoghi l'affollar del casso,
IT.73: sì lasciò trapassar la santa greggia
IT.74: Forese, e dietro meco sen veniva,
IT.75: dicendo: "Quando fia ch'io ti riveggia?"
IT.76: "Non so," rispuos' io lui, "quant' io mi viva;
IT.77: ma già non fïa il tornar mio tantosto,
IT.78: ch'io non sia col voler prima a la riva;
IT.79: però che 'l loco u' fui a viver posto,
IT.80: di giorno in giorno più di ben si spolpa,

EN.2: slow our motion, as conversing we moved swiftly,
EN.3: like ships that are driven by favoring winds.

EN.8: 'Perhaps he climbs more slowly than he'd like

EN.13: 'I cannot say whether my sister was more virtuous

EN.15: she already triumphs, rejoicing in her crown.'
EN.16: This he said first and then:

EN.21: just beyond him, the face more cracked and scaly

EN.25: He named many another, one by one,

EN.36: who clearly seemed to know me.

EN.39: where he felt most the justice that so wastes them.

EN.41: speak in a manner I can understand
EN.42: and with your speech thus satisfy us both.'
EN.43: 'A woman is born and wears not yet the wimple,'
EN.44: he said. 'She shall make my city please you,
EN.45: however men revile it.
EN.46: 'Take your way with this prophecy in mind
EN.47: and, if you have mistook my muttering,
EN.48: events themselves will make it plain to you.
EN.49: 'But tell me if I see before me
EN.50: the one who brought forth those new rhymes
EN.51: begun with Ladies that have intelligence of love.'
EN.52: And I to him: 'I am one who, when Love
EN.53: inspires me, take note and, as he dictates
EN.54: deep within me, so I set it forth.'
EN.55: 'O my brother,' he said, 'now I understand the knot
EN.56: that kept the Notary, Guittone, and me
EN.57: on this side of the sweet new style I hear.
EN.58: 'I clearly understand that your pens follow
EN.59: faithfully whatever Love may dictate,
EN.60: which, to be sure, was not the case with ours.
EN.61: 'And he who takes the next step sees in this
EN.62: what separates the one style from the other.'
EN.63: Then, as though with satisfaction, he was silent.
EN.64: As birds that spend the wintertime along the Nile
EN.65: sometimes gather in a flock high in the air,
EN.66: then, flying faster, form a line,
EN.67: so all the people gathered there
EN.68: turned from us, hurrying away,
EN.69: light as they were through leanness and desire.
EN.70: And, as one exhausted by his run
EN.71: lets his companions race ahead while he but walks
EN.72: until the heaving of his chest is eased,
EN.73: so Forese let the holy flock pass by
EN.74: and came along with me behind them. He asked:
EN.75: 'How long until I see you here again?'
EN.76: 'I do not know,' I said, 'how long I'll live.
EN.77: But my return could not occur so soon
EN.78: that I will not in thought return before,
EN.79: 'since the place where I was put to live
EN.80: day by day strips itself of every good

EN.85: 'The beast goes faster with each step,
EN.86: and faster, until it hurls him to the ground

EN.97: he went away from us with longer strides,

EN.100: And when he became a distant sight,
EN.101: my eyes kept following him,

EN.103: Suddenly a second tree, its branches green
EN.104: and weighted down with fruit,

EN.110: and, to make their longing even stronger,

EN.115: 'Pass on, do not come any closer.

EN.1: It was the hour when the ascent did not permit delay,
EN.2: for the sun had left the meridian to the Bull,
EN.3: and night had left it to the Scorpion.
EN.4: Therefore, like one who does not stop
EN.5: but, pricked by the spur of need,
EN.6: plods along his way no matter what,
EN.7: we thrust into the gap, one before the other,
EN.8: single file, up stairs so narrow
EN.9: they separate those who climb them.
EN.10: And as a baby stork may raise a wing,
EN.11: longing to fly, but does not dare
EN.12: to leave its nest and lowers it again,
EN.13: such was I, my desire to question kindled
EN.14: and then put out, moving my mouth
EN.15: as does a man who sets himself to speak.
EN.16: Despite our rapid pace, my gentle father said:
EN.17: 'Release the bent bow of your speech,
EN.18: now stretched to the arrow's iron point.'
EN.19: At that, with confidence I opened my mouth to ask:
EN.20: 'How can it be that one grows thin
EN.21: here where there is no need for nourishment?'
EN.22: 'If you recall how Meleager was consumed
EN.23: in the time it took to burn a log-end,' he said,
EN.24: 'this will not be difficult for you to understand.
EN.25: 'And if you consider how at your slightest motion
EN.26: your image moves within the glass,
EN.27: a concept that seems hard would then seem easy.
EN.28: 'But, to soothe you and to grant your wish,
EN.29: here is Statius. I call on him, I beg him,
EN.30: to be the healer of your wounds.'
EN.31: 'If I unfold the eternal plan before him
EN.32: in your presence,' answered Statius,
EN.33: 'let my excuse be that I cannot refuse you.'
EN.34: Then he began: 'Son, if your mind treasures
EN.35: and takes in my words,
EN.36: they will explain how what you ask may be.
EN.37: 'The perfect blood, which is never drunk
EN.38: by the thirsty veins and remains untouched,
EN.39: like the food one removes from the table,
EN.40: 'gathers in the heart and carries
EN.41: formative power to all members, like the blood
EN.42: that, flowing through, becomes a part of them.
EN.43: 'Again digested, it descends where silence
EN.44: is more fit than speech and from there later
EN.45: drops into the natural vessel on another's blood.
EN.46: 'There the one is mingled with the other,
EN.47: one fitted to be passive and the other active,
EN.48: owing to the perfect place from which it springs,
EN.49: 'and this one, so conjoined, begins to function,
EN.50: first coagulating, then quickening that which,
EN.51: as its future matter, it has already thickened.
EN.52: 'The active force, having now become a soul--
EN.53: like a plant's but differing in this: it is still
EN.54: on its way, while the plant has come to shore--
EN.55: 'next functions, moving now and feeling,
EN.56: like a sea-sponge, and from that goes on, producing
EN.57: organs for the faculties of which it is the seed.
EN.58: 'Now unfurls, now spreads the force, my son,
EN.59: that comes straight from the heart of the begetter,
EN.60: there where nature makes provision for all members.
EN.61: 'But how from animal it turns to human
EN.62: you do not see as yet. This is the point
EN.63: at which a wiser man than you has stumbled
EN.64: 'in that his teaching rendered separate
EN.65: the possible intellect from the soul,
EN.66: because he could not find the organ it could live in.
EN.67: 'Open your heart to the truth that follows
EN.68: and know that, once the brain's articulation
EN.69: in the embryo arrives at its perfection,
EN.70: 'the First Mover turns to it, rejoicing
EN.71: in such handiwork of nature, and breathes
EN.72: into it a spirit, new and full of power,
EN.73: 'which then draws to its substance
EN.74: all it there finds active and becomes a single soul
EN.75: that lives, and feels, and reflects upon itself.
EN.76: 'And, that you may be less bewildered by my words,
EN.77: consider the sun's heat, which, blended with the sap
EN.78: pressed from the vine, turns into wine.
EN.79: 'When Lachesis runs short of thread, the soul
EN.80: unfastens from the flesh, carrying with it
EN.81: potential faculties, both human and divine.
EN.82: 'The lower faculties now inert,
EN.83: memory, intellect, and the will remain
EN.84: in action, and are far keener than before.
EN.85: 'Without pausing, the soul falls, miraculously,
EN.86: of itself, to one or to the other shore.
EN.87: There first it comes to know its road.
EN.88: 'As soon as space surrounds it there,
EN.89: the formative force radiates upon it,
EN.90: giving shape and measure as though to living members.
EN.91: 'And as the air, when it is full of rain,
EN.92: is adorned with rainbow hues not of its making
EN.93: but reflecting the brightness of another,
EN.94: 'so here the neighboring air is shaped
EN.95: into that form the soul, which stays with it,
EN.96: imprints upon it by its powers.
EN.97: 'And, like the flame that imitates its fire,
EN.98: wherever that may shift and flicker,
EN.99: its new form imitates the spirit.
EN.100: 'A shade we call it, since the insubstantial soul
EN.101: is visible this way, which from the same air forms

EN.1: One before the other, we walked along the edge,
EN.2: and often the good master said to me:
EN.3: 'Be careful now, pay attention to my warnings.'
EN.4: The sun was beating down on my right shoulder,
EN.5: for now its beams were changing
EN.6: the aspect of the west from blue to white
EN.7: and, as my shadow made the flames appear
EN.8: more glowing, I saw that many of the shades,
EN.9: as they went past, took note of that faint sign.
EN.10: It was this that made them speak of me,
EN.11: and they began by telling one another:
EN.12: 'This man's body does not seem made of air.'
EN.13: Then some of them came up as near me
EN.14: as they could, always careful not to venture
EN.15: beyond the burning of the flames.
EN.16: 'O you who go along behind the others,
EN.17: not from sloth but perhaps with reverence,
EN.18: answer me, since I burn with thirst and fire.
EN.19: 'It is not I alone who crave your answer.
EN.20: All these others thirst for it more than the Indian
EN.21: or Ethiopian who craves cold water.
EN.22: 'Tell us, how can it be your body makes
EN.23: a wall against the sun, as if you were
EN.24: not yet entangled in the net of death?'
EN.25: asked one of them. I would have then
EN.26: made myself known had I not been intent
EN.27: on another strange new sight that now appeared,
EN.28: for in the middle of the flaming road
EN.29: came people moving in the opposite direction
EN.30: who had me staring, all absorbed.
EN.31: There I can see that every shade of either group
EN.32: makes haste to kiss another, without stopping,
EN.33: and is content with such brief salutation,
EN.34: just as, within their dark-hued files,
EN.35: one ant will put its face up to the other's,
EN.36: perhaps to inquire of his path and fortune.
EN.37: When they have ceased their friendly greeting,
EN.38: before they take a new step to continue,
EN.39: each one makes an effort to outshout the rest.
EN.40: The new ones cry: 'Sodom and Gomorrah!'
EN.41: and the others: 'Pasiphaë crawls into the cow
EN.42: so that the bull may hasten to her lust.'
EN.43: Then, as though cranes were flying, some toward
EN.44: cool Riphaean mountains and some toward desert sands,
EN.45: these shunning frost and those the sun,
EN.46: the one crowd goes, the other nears,
EN.47: and all return, weeping, to their former song
EN.48: and to the cry that most befits them.
EN.49: Then the same shades who had entreated me
EN.50: drew nearer, as they had before,
EN.51: and seemed all eagerness to hear me out.
EN.52: Having twice been made aware of their desire,
EN.53: I began: 'O souls secure of gaining,
EN.54: whenever it may be, the state of peace,
EN.55: 'my limbs have not been left on earth,
EN.56: whether green or dried, but are here with me
EN.57: intact, in all their blood and joints.
EN.58: 'I climb from here no longer to be blind.
EN.59: A lady is above through whom I gained the grace
EN.60: to bring my mortal parts into your world.
EN.61: 'But, so may your greatest longing
EN.62: soon be satisfied and the heaven take you in
EN.63: that is so full of love and holds the widest space,
EN.64: 'tell me, that I may trace it on my pages,
EN.65: who you are and who is in that throng
EN.66: which is even now receding at your backs?'
EN.67: Not less astounded is the mountaineer,
EN.68: struck dumb and staring all around him
EN.69: when rough and rustic he comes into a town,
EN.70: than each shade seemed from its expression.
EN.71: But once they had recovered from amazement,
EN.72: which is quickly overcome in noble hearts,
EN.73: he who had questioned me began again:
EN.74: 'Blessed are you, who, to die a better death,
EN.75: here take on board the knowledge that you gain.
EN.76: 'Those, who come not with us, all offended
EN.77: the same way Caesar did, for which, in triumph,
EN.78: he once heard "queen" called out against him.
EN.79: 'Thus they move on crying "Sodom,"
EN.80: as you heard, in self-reproach.
EN.81: And with their shame they fan the flames.
EN.82: 'Hermaphroditic was our sin.
EN.83: Because we did not follow human law,
EN.84: but ran behind our appetites like beasts,
EN.85: 'when, in our disgrace, we move off from the others
EN.86: we shout her name who made herself a beast
EN.87: inside the beast-shaped rough-hewn wood.
EN.88: 'Now you know our deeds and know our guilt.
EN.89: If, perhaps, you would like to know our names,
EN.90: there is no time to tell and I would not know how.
EN.91: 'About myself, indeed, I'll satisfy your wish.
EN.92: I am Guido Guinizzelli, come so far in my purgation
EN.93: because I felt true sorrow well before the end.'
EN.94: As the two sons became on seeing their mother
EN.95: caught in Lycurgus' outraged grief,
EN.96: so I became, if with less abandon,
EN.97: when he gave his name and I knew he had been
EN.98: father to me and to others, my betters,
EN.99: who ever used love's sweet and graceful rhymes.
EN.100: And for a long time, deep in thought, I went on
EN.101: without listening or speaking as I gazed at him,
EN.102: but did not, for the fire, move closer.
EN.103: Once my eyes were satisfied,
EN.104: I owned myself ready to do him service
EN.105: with such assurance as compels belief.
EN.106: He answered: 'All that I hear you tell
EN.107: leaves so deep and clear a trace in me
EN.108: that Lethe cannot wipe it out or make it dim,
EN.109: 'but if your words just now have sworn the truth,
EN.110: tell me what has caused you to disclose
EN.111: by speech and look that you still hold me dear.'
EN.112: And I to him: 'Your sweet verses,
EN.113: which as long as modern custom lasts,
EN.114: will make their very ink seem precious.'
EN.115: 'O brother,' he said, 'that one whom I point out
EN.116: to you'--and he pointed to a spirit just ahead--
EN.117: 'was a better craftsman of the mother tongue.
EN.118: 'In verses of love and tales of romance
EN.119: he surpassed them all, and let the fools go on
EN.120: who think that fellow from Limoges was better.
EN.121: 'They favor hearsay over truth
EN.122: and thus arrive at their opinions
EN.123: without the use of skill or reason.
EN.124: 'The same was true of many long ago about Guittone,
EN.125: voice after voice shouting praise of him alone,
EN.126: until for most the truth at last prevailed.
EN.127: 'Now, if you possess such ample privilege
EN.128: that you are allowed into the cloister
EN.129: where Christ is abbot of the brothers,
EN.130: 'say a Paternoster there for me,
EN.131: as much of it as we have need in this our world,
EN.132: where we no longer have the power to sin.'
EN.133: Then, perhaps to make room for another
EN.134: who was near him, he vanished through the fire
EN.135: as a fish glides to the bottom through the water.
EN.136: I edged forward a little toward the other
EN.137: who had been pointed out and said that my desire
EN.138: prepared a place of welcome for his name,
EN.139: to which he readily made answer:
EN.140: 'Your courteous question pleases me so much
EN.141: I neither can nor would conceal myself from You.
EN.142: 'I am Arnaut, weeping and singing as I make my way.
EN.143: I see with grief past follies and I see,
EN.144: rejoicing, the joy I hope is coming.
EN.145: 'Now I pray You, by that power
EN.146: which guides You to the summit of the stairs,
EN.147: to remember, when the time is fit, my pain.'
EN.148: Then he vanished in the fire that refines them.

EN.1: As when it strikes with its first rays
EN.2: there where its Maker shed His blood,
EN.3: while the Ebro lies beneath the lofty Scales
EN.4: and noon burns down on the waters of the Ganges,
EN.5: so stood the sun. And thus day was departing
EN.6: when the blissful angel of the Lord appeared.
EN.7: He stood beyond the flames there on the terrace
EN.8: and sang 'Beati mundo corde!'
EN.9: with a voice more radiant than ours.
EN.10: 'There is no going on, you blessèd souls,
EN.11: without the fire's stinging bite. Enter,
EN.12: and do not stop your ears against the distant song,'
EN.13: he said to us once we were near,
EN.14: so that, hearing him, I felt
EN.15: like a man who has been put into his grave.
EN.16: I bent forward over my outstretched hands
EN.17: and stared into the fire, my mind fixed on the image
EN.18: of human bodies I once saw being burned.
EN.19: Then my kindly escorts turned to me
EN.20: and Virgil said: 'My son,
EN.21: here you may find torment, but not death.
EN.22: 'Remember, remember--
EN.23: if even on Geryon I conveyed you safely,
EN.24: what shall I do now we are nearer God?
EN.25: 'You must believe that if you were confined
EN.26: in the very belly of this flame a thousand years
EN.27: it would not singe a single hair upon your head.
EN.28: 'And if you think, perhaps, that I deceive you,
EN.29: go close to it and test it, holding out
EN.30: the hem of your garment in your hands.
EN.31: 'From now on put away, put away all fear.
EN.32: Turn in this direction, come, and boldly enter.'
EN.33: But, against my will, I stood stock still.
EN.34: When he saw me stay, unmoved and obstinate,
EN.35: he said, somewhat disturbed: 'Now look, my son,
EN.36: this wall stands between Beatrice and you.'
EN.37: As at the name of Thisbe, though on the point of death,
EN.38: Pyramus raised his lids and gazed at her,
EN.39: that time the mulberry turned red,
EN.40: just so, my stubbornness made pliant, I turned
EN.41: to my wise leader when I heard the name
EN.42: that ever blossoms in my mind,
EN.43: at which he shook his head and said: 'Well,
EN.44: are we going to stay on this side?' then smiled
EN.45: as one smiles at a child won over with a fruit.
EN.46: Then, ahead of me, he was immersed in the fire,
EN.47: asking Statius, who for a long way now
EN.48: had walked between us, to come through last.
EN.49: As soon as I was in I would have thrown myself
EN.50: straight into molten glass to cool myself,
EN.51: so beyond measure was the burning there,
EN.52: and my sweet father, to comfort me,
EN.53: kept speaking of Beatrice as he went,
EN.54: saying: 'Even now I can almost see her eyes.'
EN.55: Guiding us was a voice that sang beyond the flame.
EN.56: We gave it our rapt attention,
EN.57: and came forth from the fire where the ascent began.
EN.58: 'Venite, benedicti Patris mei' resounded
EN.59: from a dazzling light that blinded me
EN.60: so that I could not bear to look.
EN.61: 'The sun departs and evening comes,'
EN.62: it continued, 'do not stop, but hurry on
EN.63: before the west grows dark.'
EN.64: The way went straight up through the rock
EN.65: so that my body blocked the last rays of the sun,
EN.66: now low in the sky, from my path.
EN.67: We had tried only a few of the steps when we,
EN.68: I and my sages, understood, as my shadow faded,
EN.69: that the sun had set behind us.
EN.70: And before the horizon, in all its vast expanse,
EN.71: had taken on a single hue
EN.72: and night had claimed all parts of her domain,
EN.73: each of us made, of a step, a bed,
EN.74: for the nature of the mountain took from us
EN.75: the power and the urge for climbing higher.
EN.76: As goats that have been quick and reckless
EN.77: on the heights before they grazed
EN.78: now peacefully chew their cud,
EN.79: silent in the shade while the sun is burning,
EN.80: guarded by the shepherd, leaning on his staff,
EN.81: who lets them take their rest,
EN.82: and as the herdsman who lives out in the open
EN.83: passes the night beside his quiet flock,
EN.84: watching lest a beast should scatter them,
EN.85: such were the three of us,
EN.86: I like a goat and they like shepherds,
EN.87: shut in on all sides by walls of rock.
EN.88: Only a small space could be seen beyond them,
EN.89: but in that space I saw the stars
EN.90: bigger and brighter than usually they are.
EN.91: Amidst such sights and thoughts
EN.92: I was seized by sleep, which often knows
EN.93: what is to be before it happens.
EN.94: In the hour, I think, when Cytherea,
EN.95: who always seems aflame with fire of love,
EN.96: first shone on the mountain from the east,
EN.97: in a dream it seemed to me I saw a lady,
EN.98: young and lovely, passing through a meadow
EN.99: as she gathered flowers, singing:
EN.100: 'Let anyone who asks my name know I am Leah,
EN.101: and here I move about, using my fair hands
EN.102: to weave myself a garland.
EN.103: 'To be pleased at my reflection I adorn myself,
EN.104: but my sister Rachel never leaves her mirror,
EN.105: sitting before it all day long.
EN.106: 'She is as eager to gaze into her own fair eyes
EN.107: as I to adorn myself with my own hands.
EN.108: She in seeing, I in doing, find our satisfaction.'
EN.109: And now, along with the pre-dawn splendors
EN.110: that, rising, become more welcome to the traveler,
EN.111: as, returning, he lodges a little nearer home,
EN.112: the shadows all around were being put to flight
EN.113: and my sleep with them. And I rose up,
EN.114: seeing the great masters already risen.
EN.115: 'That sweet fruit which mortals seek
EN.116: and strive to find on many boughs
EN.117: today shall satisfy your cravings.'
EN.118: Such were Virgil's words to me,
EN.119: and never was there promise of a gift
EN.120: that might yield equal pleasure.
EN.121: Desire upon desire so seized me to ascend
EN.122: that with every stride
EN.123: I felt that I was growing wings for flight.
EN.124: When the stairs had all run past beneath us
EN.125: and we were on the topmost step,
EN.126: Virgil fixed his eyes on me
EN.127: and said: 'The temporal fire and the eternal
EN.128: you have seen, my son, and now have come to a place
EN.129: in which, unaided, I can see no farther.
EN.130: 'I have brought you here with intellect and skill.
EN.131: From now on take your pleasure as your guide.
EN.132: You are free of the steep way, free of the narrow.
EN.133: 'Look at the sun shining before you,
EN.134: look at the fresh grasses, flowers, and trees
EN.135: which here the earth produces of itself.
EN.136: 'You may sit down or move among these
EN.137: until the fair eyes come, rejoicing,
EN.138: which weeping bid me come to you.
EN.139: 'No longer wait for word or sign from me.
EN.140: Your will is free, upright, and sound.
EN.141: Not to act as it chooses is unworthy:
EN.142: over yourself I crown and miter you.'

EN.1: Eager to explore the sacred forest's boundaries
EN.2: and its depth, now that its thick and verdant foliage
EN.3: had softened the new day's glare before my eyes,
EN.4: I left the bank without delay
EN.5: and wandered oh so slowly through the countryside
EN.6: that filled the air around with fragrance.
EN.7: A steady gentle breeze,
EN.8: no stronger than the softest wind,
EN.9: caressed and fanned my brow.
EN.10: It made the trembling boughs
EN.11: bend eagerly toward the shade
EN.12: the holy mountain casts at dawn,
EN.13: yet they were not so much bent down
EN.14: that small birds in the highest branches
EN.15: were not still practicing their every craft,
EN.16: meeting the morning breeze
EN.17: with songs of joy among the leaves,

EN.23: so deep into the ancient forest
EN.24: I could not see where I had entered,
EN.25: when I was stopped from going farther by a stream.

EN.27: the grasses that sprang up along the bank.

EN.29: would seem defiled beside that stream,
EN.30: which reveals all that it contains,
EN.31: even though it flows in darkness,
EN.32: dark beneath perpetual shade
EN.33: that never lets the sun or moon shine through.

EN.35: beyond the rivulet to contemplate
EN.36: the great variety of blooming boughs,
EN.37: and there appeared to me, as suddenly appears
EN.38: a thing so marvelous
EN.39: it drives away all other thoughts,
EN.40: a lady, who went her way alone, singing
EN.41: and picking flowers from among the blossoms
EN.42: that were painted all along her way.
EN.43: 'Pray, fair lady, warming yourself in rays of love--
EN.44: if I am to believe the features
EN.45: that as a rule bear witness to the heart,'
EN.46: I said to her, 'may it please you
EN.47: to come closer to this stream,
EN.48: near enough that I may hear what you are singing.
EN.49: 'You make me remember where and what
EN.50: Proserpina was, there when her mother
EN.51: lost her and she lost the spring.'
EN.52: As a lady turns in the dance
EN.53: keeping her feet together on the ground,
EN.54: and hardly puts one foot before the other,
EN.55: on the red and yellow flowers
EN.56: she turned in my direction,
EN.57: lowering her modest eyes, as does a virgin,
EN.58: and, attending to my plea, came closer
EN.59: so that the sound of her sweet song
EN.60: reached me together with its meaning.
EN.61: As soon as she was where the grass is merely
EN.62: moistened by the waters of the lovely stream,
EN.63: she granted me the gift of raising up her eyes.
EN.64: I do not think such radiant light blazed out
EN.65: beneath the lids of Venus when her son by chance,
EN.66: against his custom, pierced her with his arrow.
EN.67: Straightening up, she smiled from the other shore,
EN.68: arranging in her hands the many colors
EN.69: that grow, unplanted, on that high terrain.
EN.70: The river kept us just three steps apart,
EN.71: yet the Hellespont where Xerxes crossed--
EN.72: a bridle still on human pride--
EN.73: was not more hated by Leander for its tossing waves
EN.74: between Sestos and Abydos than I did hate
EN.75: that rivulet for not parting then.
EN.76: 'You are new here,' she began, 'and,
EN.77: perhaps because I'm smiling in this place
EN.78: chosen for mankind as its nest,
EN.79: 'you are perplexed and filled with wonder,
EN.80: but the psalm Delectasti offers light
EN.81: that may disperse the clouds within your minds.
EN.82: 'And you who stand in front and who entreated me,
EN.83: say if you'd hear more, for I've come ready
EN.84: to give sufficient answer to your every question.'
EN.85: 'The water and the sound of wind among the trees
EN.86: contradict what I was told and had accepted,'
EN.87: I said, 'about the nature of this place.'
EN.88: And she: 'I will explain that what you marvel at
EN.89: has its own special cause
EN.90: and thus disperse the fog assailing you.
EN.91: 'Supreme Goodness, pleased in Itself alone,
EN.92: made man good and to do good only. This place
EN.93: He gave to him as token of eternal peace.
EN.94: 'Through his own fault his sojourn here was brief.
EN.95: Through his own fault he changed lighthearted frolic
EN.96: and unblemished joy for toil and tears.
EN.97: 'So that the turbulence below,
EN.98: created by the vapors rising both from land and sea
EN.99: toward the sun's heat as far as they can rise,
EN.100: 'should do no harm to man,
EN.101: this mountain rose just high enough toward heaven
EN.102: to tower free of it above the bolted gate.
EN.103: 'Now, since all the air revolves in a circuit
EN.104: with the first circling, unless
EN.105: its revolution is at some point blocked,
EN.106: 'that movement strikes upon this summit,
EN.107: standing free in the living air, and makes
EN.108: the forest, because it is so dense, resound.
EN.109: 'The wind-lashed plants have such fecundity
EN.110: that with their power they pollinate the air,
EN.111: which after, in its circling, scatters seed abroad.
EN.112: 'Your earth below, according to its qualities
EN.113: and climate, conceives and then brings forth
EN.114: from various properties its various plants.
EN.115: 'If this were understood, it would not seem
EN.116: so marvelous on earth each time a plant
EN.117: takes root without its seedling being known.
EN.118: 'And you should know the holy ground
EN.119: on which you stand is filled with every kind of seed
EN.120: and gives forth fruit that is not plucked on earth.
EN.121: 'The water you see here does not spring from a vein

EN.123: like a river that gains and loses flow,
EN.124: 'but issues from a sure, unchanging source,
EN.125: which by God's will regains as much
EN.126: as it pours forth to either side.

EN.128: to take from men the memory of sin.

EN.132: until they both are tasted.

EN.135: were I to reveal no more to you,
EN.136: 'I will offer a corollary as a further gift,

EN.138: if they extend beyond the promise that I made.
EN.139: 'Those who in ancient times called up in verse
EN.140: the age of gold and sang its happy state
EN.141: dreamed on Parnassus of perhaps this very place.

EN.143: here it is always spring, with every fruit in season.
