EN.1: My eyes were fixed and so intent
EN.2: to satisfy ten years of thirst
EN.3: that all my other senses were undone,
EN.4: walled off from anything around them, enclosed
EN.5: in their indifference, so did the holy smile
EN.6: ensnare them in its old, familiar net,
EN.7: when by the power of those goddesses
EN.8: my gaze was forced to travel left
EN.9: as they cried out: 'Too fixed!'
EN.10: And then I shared the temporary blindness
EN.11: of those whose eyes have just been smitten by the sun,
EN.12: leaving me sightless for a time.
EN.13: But after my eyes again became accustomed
EN.14: to lesser sights--lesser, I mean, when compared
EN.15: to the greater from which they'd been forced to turn--
EN.16: I noted that the glorious army had wheeled around
EN.17: on its right flank and now was facing east,
EN.18: with the seven candles and the sun before it.
EN.19: As under cover of its shields a squadron
EN.20: turns to save itself, following the colors,
EN.21: before the entire force can rearrange its ranks,
EN.22: the soldiers of the heavenly kingdom
EN.23: who were marching in the front passed by
EN.24: before the chariot turned upon its yoke.
EN.25: Then the ladies went back to their wheels
EN.26: and the griffin moved its blessèd load,
EN.27: but so that not a feather on it shook.
EN.28: The fair lady who had pulled me through the stream
EN.29: and Statius and I were following the wheel
EN.30: that in a smaller arc had made its turn.
EN.31: Then, passing on beneath a vaulting forest,
EN.32: emptied through fault of her who trusted in the snake,
EN.33: we measured our steps to an angelic song.
EN.34: We had proceeded perhaps as far as an arrow,
EN.35: loosed three times from the string, would carry,
EN.36: when Beatrice descended from the car.
EN.37: I heard all of them murmuring 'Adam.'
EN.38: Then they circled a tree stripped of its leaves
EN.39: and any other flowering on its branches.
EN.40: The higher its branches grew, the wider was their spread.
EN.41: Its height would cause even the Indian,
EN.42: in his towering forest, to gaze in wonder.
EN.43: 'Blessed are you, griffin, for not plundering
EN.44: with your beak this tree's sweet-tasting fruit
EN.45: that later wrenches bellies with its pain.'
EN.46: Thus did those around the mighty tree cry out,
EN.47: and the double-natured animal replied:
EN.48: 'This is how the seed of justice is preserved.'
EN.49: Turning to the shaft that he had pulled,
EN.50: he drew it to the foot of the widowed trunk
EN.51: and left it bound to the tree from which it came.
EN.52: As our plants, when the great light falls on them,
EN.53: mingled with the light that shines
EN.54: in the rays that follow the celestial carp,
EN.55: begin to swell their buds and are renewed,
EN.56: each in its proper color, before the sun
EN.57: hitches his steeds to other stars,
EN.58: so, taking on a hue less red than roses
EN.59: yet deeper than violets, the tree renewed itself
EN.60: where its branches just before had been so bare.
EN.61: The hymn that company then chanted
EN.62: is not sung on earth nor could I make it out,
EN.63: nor bear to hear that music to its end.
EN.64: Could I describe how those pitiless eyes,
EN.65: hearing of Syrinx, were lulled to sleep,
EN.66: the eyes whose lengthy vigil cost so dear,
EN.67: I would fashion, as a painter does
EN.68: when painting from a model, how I fell asleep.
EN.69: But let him, who can do it, portray his nodding off.
EN.70: I move along, therefore, to when I came awake
EN.71: and say a brightness broke my veil of sleep,
EN.72: as did the call: 'Arise, what are you doing?'
EN.73: As, when brought to see the blossoms on the apple-tree
EN.74: that makes the angels hungry for its fruit
EN.75: and celebrates perpetual marriage-feasts in Heaven,
EN.76: Peter and John and James were overcome,
EN.77: called back into themselves at the word
EN.78: by which still deeper sleep was broken,
EN.79: and saw their company diminished
EN.80: both by Moses and Elijah
EN.81: and their teacher's raiment changed,
EN.82: such did I become. I saw, standing above me,
EN.83: the same compassionate lady
EN.84: who had guided my steps along the river.
EN.85: All in doubt I asked: 'Where is Beatrice?'
EN.86: And she: 'Look there beneath the new-sprung blossoms
EN.87: of the tree where she is seated on the root.
EN.88: 'See the company encircling her.
EN.89: The others all ascend behind the griffin
EN.90: with a song more sweet and more profound.'
EN.91: I do not know if she had more to say,
EN.92: for now, before my eyes, appeared the one
EN.93: who had closed me off from any other thought.
EN.94: On the bare ground she sat alone,
EN.95: as if left behind to guard the chariot
EN.96: I had seen the twofold beast make fast.
EN.97: The seven nymphs encircled her as a cloister,
EN.98: holding up lights that would not waver
EN.99: should winds blow even from the north or south.
EN.100: 'Here for a time you shall be a woodsman
EN.101: and then forever a citizen with me
EN.102: of that Rome where Christ Himself is Roman.
EN.103: 'Therefore, to serve the world that lives so ill,

EN.107: prostrate at the feet of her commands,
EN.108: gave my mind and eyes to what she wished.

EN.110: out of thickened banks of clouds,
EN.111: plunging from the farthest zone of air,
EN.112: as I saw the bird of Jove swoop down and plummet
EN.113: through the tree, ripping the bark,
EN.114: shredding flowers and fresh leaves.
EN.115: It struck the chariot with its full force
EN.116: so that it reeled like a ship tossed in a tempest,
EN.117: now leeward, now windward, driven by the waves.

EN.119: of the triumphal car, a fox so wasted
EN.120: it seemed deprived of any nourishment.

EN.122: drove it back in such retreat
EN.123: as its fleshless bones allowed.

EN.125: I saw the eagle plummet to the chariot's floor

EN.131: between the wheels, and I saw a dragon issue,
EN.132: thrust its tail up through the car,

EN.137: as is fertile soil with weeds, by plumage,
EN.138: offered perhaps with kind and innocent intent,
EN.139: and both the wheels and shaft
EN.140: were completely covered over
EN.141: in less time than a sigh may part the lips.

EN.143: put forth heads on all its parts,
EN.144: three on the shaft and one at every corner--

EN.148: Secure, like a fortress on a towering mountain,
EN.149: I saw a disheveled harlot sitting there,

EN.151: I saw a giant who stood beside her,
EN.152: perhaps to prevent her being taken from him.

EN.155: her lustful, roving eye, that savage lover

EN.1: 'Deus, venerunt gentes,' the ladies,
EN.2: now three, now four, in alternation sang,
EN.3: beginning their sweet psalmody in tears,
EN.4: and Beatrice, sighing and compassionate,
EN.5: was listening, her face so changed in its expression
EN.6: that Mary's, at the cross, was hardly more transformed.
EN.7: But when the other virgins stopped their song,
EN.8: allowing her to speak, she answered, rising
EN.9: to her feet and blazing like a fire:
EN.10: 'Modicum, et non videbitis me; et iterum,
EN.11: my beloved sisters,
EN.12: modicum, et vos videbitis me.'
EN.13: Then she arranged the seven before her
EN.14: and, with a gesture, signaled me, the lady,
EN.15: and the sage who had remained, to follow.
EN.16: Thus she moved forward. I do not believe
EN.17: she had left her tenth step on the ground
EN.18: when her piercing eyes met mine
EN.19: and, with a calmer look, she said: 'Follow me
EN.20: more closely, so that, if I should speak to you,
EN.21: you will be able to hear me better.'
EN.22: And as soon as I, obeying, drew up near her,
EN.23: she asked: 'My brother, since we are together,
EN.24: why do you not dare to ask me questions?'
EN.25: As with those who are too shy
EN.26: when speaking to their betters and thus fail
EN.27: to bring their words distinctly to their lips,
EN.28: so it was with me, and in a failing voice
EN.29: I began: 'My lady, You know what I lack
EN.30: and exactly how You may provide it.'
EN.31: And she: 'Free yourself at once
EN.32: from the snares of fear and shame,
EN.33: no longer speaking as a man does from his dream.
EN.34: 'Know that the vessel which the serpent broke
EN.35: was and is not. Let those who are to blame
EN.36: take heed: God's vengeance fears no hindrance.
EN.37: 'The eagle that left its feathers on the car
EN.38: so that it first was monster and then prey
EN.39: shall not remain without an heir forever.
EN.40: 'For I see clearly and do thus declare:
EN.41: stars already near at hand promise us a time
EN.42: safe from all delay, from all impediment,
EN.43: 'when a Five Hundred Ten and Five,
EN.44: sent by God, shall slay the thieving wench
EN.45: and the giant sinning there beside her.
EN.46: 'Perhaps my words, obscure as those of Themis
EN.47: or the Sphinx, persuade you less
EN.48: because, like theirs, they cloud your mind.
EN.49: 'Events soon to occur shall be the Naiads
EN.50: that solve this hard enigma
EN.51: without the loss of flocks or ears of corn.
EN.52: 'Mark them, and, as they come from me,
EN.53: set these words down for those
EN.54: who live the life that is a race to death.
EN.55: 'And keep in mind, when you shall write them,
EN.56: not to conceal the story of the tree
EN.57: that now not once but twice has here been plundered.
EN.58: 'Whoever robs that tree or does it harm
EN.59: by blasphemous act gives great offense to God,

IT.106: Or, come ai colpi de li caldi rai
IT.107: de la neve riman nudo il suggetto
IT.108: e dal colore e dal freddo primai,
IT.109: così rimaso te ne l'intelletto
IT.110: voglio informar di luce sì vivace,
IT.111: che ti tremolerà nel suo aspetto.
IT.112: Dentro dal ciel de la divina pace
IT.113: si gira un corpo ne la cui virtute
IT.114: l'esser di tutto suo contento giace.

EN.1: O you, eager to hear more,
EN.2: who have followed in your little bark
EN.3: my ship that singing makes its way,
EN.4: turn back if you would see your shores again.
EN.5: Do not set forth upon the deep,
EN.6: for, losing sight of me, you would be lost.
EN.7: The seas I sail were never sailed before.
EN.8: Minerva fills my sails, Apollo is my guide,
EN.9: nine Muses point me toward the Bears.
EN.10: You other few who craned your necks in time
EN.11: to reach for angels' bread, which gives us life on earth,
EN.12: yet never leaves us satisfied,
EN.13: you may indeed set out, your ship afloat
EN.14: upon the salty deep, keeping to the furrow
EN.15: I have made, before the sea goes smooth again.
EN.16: Those famous men who made their way to Colchis,
EN.17: when they saw Jason had become a plowman,
EN.18: were not as stunned as you shall be.
EN.19: The innate and never-ending thirst for God
EN.20: in His own kingdom drew us up,
EN.21: almost as swiftly as you know the heavens turn.
EN.22: Beatrice was gazing upward, my gaze fixed on her,
EN.23: when, perhaps as quickly as a bolt strikes,
EN.24: flies, and releases from its catch,
EN.25: suddenly I found myself there
EN.26: where my eyes were drawn to an astounding sight.
EN.27: And she, from whom my thoughts could not be kept
EN.28: turned to me, as full of joy as she was fair,
EN.29: to say: 'Direct your grateful mind to God,
EN.30: who has conjoined us with the nearest star.'
EN.31: It seemed to me that we were in a cloud,
EN.32: shining, dense, solid, and unmarred,
EN.33: like a diamond struck by sunlight.
EN.34: The eternal pearl received us in itself,
EN.35: as water does a ray of light
EN.36: and yet remains unsundered and serene.
EN.37: If I was there in flesh -- on earth we can't conceive
EN.38: how matter may admit another matter to it,
EN.39: when body flows into, becomes another body –
EN.40: that, all the more, should kindle our desire
EN.41: to see the very One who lets us see
EN.42: the way our nature was conjoined with God.
EN.43: What now we take on faith will then be seen,
EN.44: not demonstrated but made manifest,
EN.45: like a priori truths, which we accept.
EN.46: I replied: 'My Lady, with absolute devotion
EN.47: I offer thanks to Him
EN.48: who has removed me from the world of death.
EN.49: 'But tell me, what are the dark spots
EN.50: on this body that make those down on earth
EN.51: repeat their preposterous tales of Cain?'
EN.52: She smiled a little, then: 'If the understanding
EN.53: of mortals errs,' she said, 'there where the key
EN.54: of the senses fails in its unlocking,
EN.55: 'surely the shafts of wonder should no longer
EN.56: strike you, since you see that, dependent
EN.57: on the senses, reason's wings fall short.
EN.58: 'But tell me what you make of this yourself.'
EN.59: And I: 'The different shadings here
EN.60: are caused, I think, by bodies rare or dense.'
EN.61: And she: 'No doubt but you shall see that this belief
EN.62: lies deep in error -- if you consider well
EN.63: the arguments that I shall lodge against it.
EN.64: 'The eighth sphere shows you many lights,
EN.65: which, both in magnitude and luminosity,
EN.66: may be seen as having different aspects.
EN.67: 'If this were caused by rare and dense alone,
EN.68: a single power would be in them all:
EN.69: here more, there less -- or equally.
EN.70: 'Different powers must be the fruit resulting from
EN.71: formative principles, but these, except for one,
EN.72: according to your reasoning, would be annulled.
EN.73: 'What is more, if that dark of which you ask
EN.74: had rareness as its cause, this planet
EN.75: would be lacking matter in some parts,
EN.76: 'or else, just as fat and lean
EN.77: alternate in mass upon a body, this planet
EN.78: would alternate the pages of its volume.
EN.79: 'Were the first case true, this would be shown
EN.80: in the sun's eclipse, when light showed through,
EN.81: as when it shines through any rarer medium.
EN.82: 'But such is not the case: therefore, let us consider
EN.83: your other argument and, if I show it to be false,
EN.84: then your opinion will be proven wrong.
EN.85: 'If this rarer substance does not go all the way,
EN.86: there must be a point at which its denser opposite
EN.87: would not allow the light to pass on throug
EN.88: 'and thus a ray of light would be thrown back
EN.89: just as color is reflected from the glass
EN.90: by the hidden layer of lead that lies beneath.
EN.91: 'Now, you will object, the ray shows dark there
EN.92: more than in the other parts
EN.93: because it is reflected from a farther source.
EN.94: 'From this objection, an experiment --
EN.95: should you ever try it -- may set you free, experiment,
EN.96: the source that feeds the streams of all your arts.
EN.97: 'Take three mirrors, placing two at equal distance
EN.98: from you, letting the third, from farther off,
EN.99: also meet your eyes, between the other two.
EN.100: 'Still turned to them, have someone set,
EN.101: well back of you, a light that, shining out,
EN.102: returns as bright reflection from all three.
EN.103: 'Although the light seen farthest off
EN.104: seems smaller in its size, still you will observe
EN.105: that it must shine with equal brightness.
EN.106: 'Now, as the substantial form of snow,
EN.107: if struck by warming rays, is then deprived
EN.108: both of its former color and its cold,
EN.109: 'I shall now reshape your intellect,
EN.110: thus deprived, with a light so vibrant
EN.111: that your mind will quiver at the sight.
EN.112: 'Beneath the heaven of divine repose
EN.113: revolves a body in whose power resides
EN.114: the being of all things contained in it.
EN.115: 'The next heaven, which holds so many sights,
EN.116: distributes its being among various forms,
EN.117: contained in it and yet distinct from it.
EN.118: 'All the other spheres, in varying ways,
EN.119: direct their distinctive qualities
EN.120: to their own purposes and influence.
EN.121: 'Thus do these organs of the universe proceed,
EN.122: as now you see, step by step,
EN.123: rendering below what they take from above.
EN.124: 'Observe well how I pass along this way
EN.125: to the truth you seek, so that in time
EN.126: you may know how to ford the stream alone.
EN.127: 'The motion and the power of the holy wheels
EN.128: must be derived from the blessèd movers,
EN.129: as the work of the hammer from the smith.
EN.130: 'And the heaven made fair by all these lights
EN.131: takes its stamp from the intellect that makes it turn,
EN.132: making of itself the very seal of that imprinting.
EN.133: 'And as the soul within your dust
EN.134: is distributed through the different members,
EN.135: conforming to their various faculties,
EN.136: 'so angelic intelligence unfolds its bounty,
EN.137: multiplied down through the stars,
EN.138: while revolving in its separate oneness.
EN.139: 'Each differentiated power makes a different alloy
EN.140: with each precious body that it quickens,
EN.141: with which, even as does life in you, it binds.
EN.142: 'From the joyous nature whence it springs,
EN.143: the mingled potency shines through its star,
EN.144: as joy shines in the living pupil of an eye.
EN.145: 'From this power is derived the difference seen
EN.146: from light to light, and not from dense and rare.
EN.147: This is the formative principle that creates,
EN.148: according to its worth, the dark and bright.'

IT.1: Quel sol che pria d'amor mi scaldò 'l petto,
IT.2: di bella verità m'avea scoverto,
IT.3: provando e riprovando, il dolce aspetto;
IT.4: e io, per confessar corretto e certo
IT.5: me stesso, tanto quanto si convenne
IT.6: leva' il capo a proferer più erto;
IT.7: ma visïone apparve che ritenne
IT.8: a sé me tanto stretto, per vedersi,
IT.9: che di mia confession non mi sovvenne.
IT.10: Quali per vetri trasparenti e tersi,
IT.11: o ver per acque nitide e tranquille,
IT.12: non sì profonde che i fondi sien persi,
IT.13: tornan d'i nostri visi le postille
IT.14: debili sì, che perla in bianca fronte
IT.15: non vien men forte a le nostre pupille;
IT.16: tali vid' io più facce a parlar pronte;
IT.17: per ch'io dentro a l'error contrario corsi
IT.18: a quel ch'accese amor tra l'omo e 'l fonte.
IT.19: Sùbito sì com' io di lor m'accorsi,
IT.20: quelle stimando specchiati sembianti,
IT.21: per veder di cui fosser, li occhi torsi;
IT.22: e nulla vidi, e ritorsili avanti
IT.23: dritti nel lume de la dolce guida,
IT.24: che, sorridendo, ardea ne li occhi santi.
IT.25: "Non ti maravigliar perch' io sorrida,"
IT.26: mi disse, "appresso il tuo püeril coto,
IT.27: poi sopra 'l vero ancor lo piè non fida,
IT.28: ma te rivolve, come suole, a vòto:
IT.29: vere sustanze son ciò che tu vedi,
IT.30: qui rilegate per manco di voto.
IT.31: Però parla con esse e odi e credi;
IT.32: ché la verace luce che le appaga
IT.33: da sé non lascia lor torcer li piedi."
IT.34: E io a l'ombra che parea più vaga
IT.35: di ragionar, drizza'mi, e cominciai,
IT.36: quasi com' uom cui troppa voglia smaga:
IT.37: "O ben creato spirito, che a' rai
IT.38: di vita etterna la dolcezza senti
IT.39: che, non gustata, non s'intende mai,
IT.40: grazïoso mi fia se mi contenti
IT.41: del nome tuo e de la vostra sorte."
IT.42: Ond' ella, pronta e con occhi ridenti:
IT.43: "La nostra carità non serra porte
IT.44: a giusta voglia, se non come quella
IT.45: che vuol simile a sé tutta sua corte.
IT.46: I' fui nel mondo vergine sorella;
IT.47: e se la mente tua ben sé riguarda,
IT.48: non mi ti celerà l'esser più bella,
IT.49: ma riconoscerai ch'i' son Piccarda,
IT.50: che, posta qui con questi altri beati,
IT.51: beata sono in la spera più tarda.
IT.52: Li nostri affetti, che solo infiammati
IT.53: son nel piacer de lo Spirito Santo,
IT.54: letizian del suo ordine formati.
IT.55: E questa sorte che par giù cotanto,
IT.56: però n'è data, perché fuor negletti
IT.57: li nostri voti, e vòti in alcun canto."
IT.58: Ond' io a lei: "Ne' mirabili aspetti
IT.59: vostri risplende non so che divino
IT.60: che vi trasmuta da' primi concetti:
IT.61: però non fui a rimembrar festino;
IT.62: ma or m'aiuta ciò che tu mi dici,
IT.63: sì che raffigurar m'è più latino.
IT.64: Ma dimmi: voi che siete qui felici,
IT.65: disiderate voi più alto loco
IT.66: per più vedere e per più farvi amici?"
IT.67: Con quelle altr' ombre pria sorrise un poco;
IT.68: da indi mi rispuose tanto lieta,
IT.69: ch'arder parea d'amor nel primo foco:
IT.70: "Frate, la nostra volontà quïeta
IT.71: virtù di carità, che fa volerne
IT.72: sol quel ch'avemo, e d'altro non ci asseta.
IT.73: Se disïassimo esser più superne,
IT.74: foran discordi li nostri disiri
IT.75: dal voler di colui che qui ne cerne;
IT.76: che vedrai non capere in questi giri,
IT.77: s'essere in carità è qui necesse,
IT.78: e se la sua natura ben rimiri.
IT.79: Anzi è formale ad esto beato esse
IT.80: tenersi dentro a la divina voglia,
IT.81: per ch'una fansi nostre voglie stesse;
IT.82: sì che, come noi sem di soglia in soglia
IT.83: per questo regno, a tutto il regno piace
IT.84: com' a lo re che 'n suo voler ne 'nvoglia.
IT.85: E 'n la sua volontade è nostra pace:
IT.86: ell' è quel mare al qual tutto si move
IT.87: ciò ch'ella crïa o che natura face."
IT.88: Chiaro mi fu allor come ogne dove
IT.89: in cielo è paradiso, etsi la grazia
IT.90: del sommo ben d'un modo non vi piove.
IT.91: Ma sì com' elli avvien, s'un cibo sazia
IT.92: e d'un altro rimane ancor la gola,
IT.93: che quel si chere e di quel si ringrazia,
IT.94: così fec' io con atto e con parola,
IT.95: per apprender da lei qual fu la tela
IT.96: onde non trasse infino a co la spuola.
IT.97: "Perfetta vita e alto merto inciela
IT.98: donna più sù," mi disse, "a la cui norma
IT.99: nel vostro mondo giù si veste e vela,
IT.100: perché fino al morir si vegghi e dorma
IT.101: con quello sposo ch'ogne voto accetta
IT.102: che caritate a suo piacer conforma.
IT.103: Dal mondo, per seguirla, giovinetta
IT.104: fuggi'mi, e nel suo abito mi chiusi
IT.105: e promisi la via de la sua setta.
IT.106: Uomini poi, a mal più ch'a bene usi,
IT.107: fuor mi rapiron de la dolce chiostra:
IT.108: Iddio si sa qual poi mia vita fusi.
IT.109: E quest' altro splendor che ti si mostra
IT.110: da la mia destra parte e che s'accende
IT.111: di tutto il lume de la spera nostra,
IT.112: ciò ch'io dico di me, di sé intende;
IT.113: sorella fu, e così le fu tolta
IT.114: di capo l'ombra de le sacre bende.
IT.115: Ma poi che pur al mondo fu rivolta
IT.116: contra suo grado e contra buona usanza,
IT.117: non fu dal vel del cor già mai disciolta.
IT.118: Quest' è la luce de la gran Costanza
IT.119: che del secondo vento di Soave
IT.120: generò 'l terzo e l'ultima possanza."
IT.121: Così parlommi, e poi cominciò " Ave,
IT.122: Maria" cantando, e cantando vanio
IT.123: come per acqua cupa cosa grave.
IT.124: La vista mia, che tanto lei seguio
IT.125: quanto possibil fu, poi che la perse,
IT.126: volsesi al segno di maggior disio,
IT.127: e a Beatrice tutta si converse;
IT.128: ma quella folgorò nel mïo sguardo
IT.129: sì che da prima il viso non sofferse;
IT.130: e ciò mi fece a dimandar più tardo.

EN.1: That sun which first made warm my breast with love
EN.2: had now disclosed, by proof and refutation,
EN.3: the sweet and lovely features of the truth.
EN.4: To confess myself corrected and convinced
EN.5: I raised my head no higher
EN.6: than saying so required,
EN.7: but then appeared a sight
EN.8: which so drew my attention
EN.9: that my confession quickly slipped from mind.
EN.10: As through clear, transparent glass
EN.11: or through still and limpid water,
EN.12: not so deep that its bed is lost from view,
EN.13: the outlines of our faces are returned
EN.14: so faint a pearl on a pallid forehead
EN.15: comes no less clearly to our eyes,
EN.16: I saw many such faces eager to speak,
EN.17: at which I fell into the error opposite to that
EN.18: which inflamed a man to love a fountain.
EN.19: As soon as I became aware of them,
EN.20: believing them to be reflections,
EN.21: I turned around to see from whom they came
EN.22: and, seeing nothing, I returned my gaze
EN.23: to the light of my sweet guide,
EN.24: whose holy eyes were glowing as she smiled.
EN.25: 'Be not surprised,' she said, 'if I am smiling
EN.26: at your childish thoughts, since they as yet trust not
EN.27: their steps to truth but turn you back,
EN.28: 'as is their custom, toward emptiness.
EN.29: These are real beings that you see,
EN.30: assigned this place for failing in their vows.
EN.31: 'Therefore speak with them, listen, and believe,
EN.32: for the true light that brings them peace
EN.33: does not allow their steps to stray.'
EN.34: And, addressing myself to the shade
EN.35: that seemed most keen to speak, I began,
EN.36: like a man muddled by excessive zeal:
EN.37: 'O spirit made for bliss, who in the beams
EN.38: of life eternal savor the sweetness
EN.39: that, untasted, cannot be understood,
EN.40: 'I shall take it as a kindness if you share with me
EN.41: your name and lot, and the lot of others here.'
EN.42: Then she, eager and with smiling eyes:
EN.43: 'Our love shuts not its doors against just will,
EN.44: any more than does the love of God, who wills
EN.45: that all His court be like Himself.
EN.46: 'In the world I was a virgin sister.
EN.47: If you search your memory,
EN.48: my having grown more fair will not conceal my name
EN.49: 'and you will recognize me as Piccarda,
EN.50: placed here among these other blessèd souls,
EN.51: and blessèd am I in the slowest of these spheres.
EN.52: 'Our affections, which are inflamed
EN.53: only when they please the Holy Spirit,
EN.54: take joy in their adherence to His plan,
EN.55: 'and this our lot, which seems so very low,
EN.56: is given us because of vows neglected
EN.57: and, in part, no longer valid.'
EN.58: Then I said to her: 'From your transfigured faces
EN.59: shines forth a divinity I do not know,
EN.60: and it transforms the images I can recall.
EN.61: 'That is why my memory worked so slowly,
EN.62: but now what you have said has helped me
EN.63: and I more readily recall your features.
EN.64: 'But tell me, do you, who are here content,
EN.65: desire to achieve a higher place, where you
EN.66: might see still more and make yourselves more dear?'
EN.67: Along with the other shades, she smiled,
EN.68: then answered me with so much gladness
EN.69: she seemed alight with love's first fire:
EN.70: 'Brother, the power of love subdues our will
EN.71: so that we long for only what we have
EN.72: and thirst for nothing else.
EN.73: 'If we desired to be more exalted,
EN.74: our desires would be discordant
EN.75: with His will, which assigns us to this place.
EN.76: 'That, as you will see, would not befit these circles
EN.77: if to be ruled by love is here required
EN.78: and if you consider well the nature of that love.
EN.79: 'No, it is the very essence of this blessèd state
EN.80: that we remain within the will of God,
EN.81: so that our wills combine in unity.
EN.82: 'Therefore our rank, from height to height,
EN.83: throughout this kingdom pleases all the kingdom,
EN.84: as it delights the King who wills us to His will.
EN.85: 'And in His will is our peace.
EN.86: It is to that sea all things move,
EN.87: both what His will creates and that which nature makes.'
EN.88: Then it was clear to me that everywhere in heaven
EN.89: is Paradise, even if the grace of the highest Good
EN.90: does not rain down in equal measure.
EN.91: But, as happens, when one food may satisfy
EN.92: while still we crave another, we give thanks
EN.93: for the one we have, while asking for the other,
EN.94: so did I with both word and gesture,
EN.95: to learn from her about the web through which
EN.96: she had not drawn her shuttle to completion.
EN.97: 'Perfect life and high desert,' she said to me,
EN.98: 'set in a higher sphere a lady by whose rule
EN.99: down in your world they take the robe and veil
EN.100: 'so that till death they wake and sleep
EN.101: in union with that Bridegroom who accepts each vow
EN.102: that love makes fitting for His pleasure.
EN.103: 'To follow her, still young, I fled the world
EN.104: and, cloaking myself in her habit,
EN.105: I promised to follow the rule of her order.
EN.106: 'Then men more used to evil than to good
EN.107: carried me off, away from the sweet cloister.
EN.108: God knows what after that my life became.
EN.109: 'And this other splendor who appears to you
EN.110: upon my right, who blazes up
EN.111: with all the brightness of this sphere:
EN.112: 'What I told of myself applies to her as well.
EN.113: She was a sister and, like me, she had the shadow
EN.114: of the holy veil torn from her head.
EN.115: 'But, even after she was cast into the world
EN.116: against her will and against all proper custom,
EN.117: the veil was never loosened from her heart.
EN.118: 'This is the light of the great Constance,
EN.119: who bore to the second blast of Swabia
EN.120: the third and final emperor.'
EN.121: Thus she spoke to me, and then began to sing
EN.122: Ave Maria, and, still singing, vanished,
EN.123: like something heavy through deep water.
EN.124: My eyes, which watched her as long as they could,
EN.125: turned, once she was lost to view,
EN.126: to the goal of their greater desire
EN.127: and were wholly bent on Beatrice.
EN.128: But she so blazed upon my sight
EN.129: at first my gaze could not sustain her light
EN.130: and that delayed my plying her with questions.

IT.1: Intra due cibi, distanti e moventi
IT.2: d'un modo, prima si morria di fame,
IT.3: che liber' omo l'un recasse ai denti;
IT.4: sì si starebbe un agno intra due brame
IT.5: di fieri lupi, igualmente temendo;
IT.6: sì si starebbe un cane intra due dame:
IT.7: per che, s'i' mi tacea, me non riprendo,
IT.8: da li miei dubbi d'un modo sospinto,
IT.9: poi ch'era necessario, né commendo.
IT.10: Io mi tacea, ma 'l mio disir dipinto
IT.11: m'era nel viso, e 'l dimandar con ello,
IT.12: più caldo assai che per parlar distinto.
IT.13: Fé sì Beatrice qual fé Danïello,
IT.14: Nabuccodonosor levando d'ira,
IT.15: che l'avea fatto ingiustamente fello;
IT.16: e disse: "Io veggio ben come ti tira
IT.17: uno e altro disio, sì che tua cura
IT.18: sé stessa lega sì che fuor non spira.
IT.19: Tu argomenti: 'Se 'l buon voler dura,
IT.20: la vïolenza altrui per qual ragione
IT.21: di meritar mi scema la misura?'
IT.22: Ancor di dubitar ti dà cagione
IT.23: parer tornarsi l'anime a le stelle,
IT.24: secondo la sentenza di Platone.
IT.25: Queste son le question che nel tuo velle
IT.26: pontano igualmente; e però pria
IT.27: tratterò quella che più ha di felle.
IT.28: D'i Serafin colui che più s'india,
IT.29: Moïsè, Samuel, e quel Giovanni
IT.30: che prender vuoli, io dico, non Maria,
IT.31: non hanno in altro cielo i loro scanni
IT.32: che questi spirti che mo t'appariro,
IT.33: né hanno a l'esser lor più o meno anni;
IT.34: ma tutti fanno bello il primo giro,
IT.35: e differentemente han dolce vita
IT.36: per sentir più e men l'etterno spiro.
IT.37: Qui si mostraro, non perché sortita
IT.38: sia questa spera lor, ma per far segno
IT.39: de la celestïal c'ha men salita.
IT.40: Così parlar conviensi al vostro ingegno,
IT.41: però che solo da sensato apprende
IT.42: ciò che fa poscia d'intelletto degno.
IT.43: Per questo la Scrittura condescende
IT.44: a vostra facultate, e piedi e mano
IT.45: attribuisce a Dio e altro intende;
IT.46: e Santa Chiesa con aspetto umano
IT.47: Gabrïel e Michel vi rappresenta,
IT.48: e l'altro che Tobia rifece sano.
IT.49: Quel che Timeo de l'anime argomenta
IT.50: non è simile a ciò che qui si vede,
IT.51: però che, come dice, par che senta.
IT.52: Dice che l'alma a la sua stella riede,
IT.53: credendo quella quindi esser decisa
IT.54: quando natura per forma la diede;
IT.55: e forse sua sentenza è d'altra guisa
IT.56: che la voce non suona, ed esser puote
IT.57: con intenzion da non esser derisa.
IT.58: S'elli intende tornare a queste ruote
IT.59: l'onor de la influenza e 'l biasmo, forse
IT.60: in alcun vero suo arco percuote.
IT.61: Questo principio, male inteso, torse
IT.62: già tutto il mondo quasi, sì che Giove,
IT.63: Mercurio e Marte a nominar trascorse.
IT.64: L'altra dubitazion che ti commove
IT.65: ha men velen, però che sua malizia
IT.66: non ti poria menar da me altrove.
IT.67: Parere ingiusta la nostra giustizia
IT.68: ne li occhi d'i mortali, è argomento
IT.69: di fede e non d'eretica nequizia.
IT.70: Ma perché puote vostro accorgimento
IT.71: ben penetrare a questa veritate,
IT.72: come disiri, ti farò contento.
IT.73: Se vïolenza è quando quel che pate
IT.74: nïente conferisce a quel che sforza,
IT.75: non fuor quest' alme per essa scusate:
IT.76: ché volontà, se non vuol, non s'ammorza,
IT.77: ma fa come natura face in foco,
IT.78: se mille volte vïolenza il torza.
IT.79: Per che, s'ella si piega assai o poco,
IT.80: segue la forza; e così queste fero
IT.81: possendo rifuggir nel santo loco.
IT.82: Se fosse stato lor volere intero,
IT.83: come tenne Lorenzo in su la grada,
IT.84: e fece Muzio a la sua man severo,
IT.85: così l'avria ripinte per la strada
IT.86: ond' eran tratte, come fuoro sciolte;
IT.87: ma così salda voglia è troppo rada.
IT.88: E per queste parole, se ricolte
IT.89: l'hai come dei, è l'argomento casso
IT.90: che t'avria fatto noia ancor più volte.
IT.91: Ma or ti s'attraversa un altro passo
IT.92: dinanzi a li occhi, tal che per te stesso
IT.93: non usciresti: pria saresti lasso.
IT.94: Io t'ho per certo ne la mente messo
IT.95: ch'alma beata non poria mentire,
IT.96: però ch'è sempre al primo vero appresso;
IT.97: e poi potesti da Piccarda udire
IT.98: che l'affezion del vel Costanza tenne;
IT.99: sì ch'ella par qui meco contradire.
IT.100: Molte fïate già, frate, addivenne
IT.101: che, per fuggir periglio, contra grato
IT.102: si fé di quel che far non si convenne;
IT.103: come Almeone, che, di ciò pregato
IT.104: dal padre suo, la propria madre spense,
IT.105: per non perder pietà si fé spietato.
IT.106: A questo punto voglio che tu pense
IT.107: che la forza al voler si mischia, e fanno
IT.108: sì che scusar non si posson l'offense.
IT.109: Voglia assoluta non consente al danno;
IT.110: ma consentevi in tanto in quanto teme,
IT.111: se si ritrae, cadere in più affanno.
IT.112: Però, quando Piccarda quello spreme,
IT.113: de la voglia assoluta intende, e io
IT.114: de l'altra; sì che ver diciamo insieme."
IT.115: Cotal fu l'ondeggiar del santo rio
IT.116: ch'uscì del fonte ond' ogne ver deriva;
IT.117: tal puose in pace uno e altro disio.
IT.118: "O amanza del primo amante, o diva,"
IT.119: diss' io appresso, "il cui parlar m'inonda
IT.120: e scalda sì, che più e più m'avviva,
IT.121: non è l'affezion mia tanto profonda,
IT.122: che basti a render voi grazia per grazia;
IT.123: ma quei che vede e puote a ciò risponda.
IT.124: Io veggio ben che già mai non si sazia
IT.125: nostro intelletto, se 'l ver non lo illustra
IT.126: di fuor dal qual nessun vero si spazia.
IT.127: Posasi in esso, come fera in lustra,
IT.128: tosto che giunto l'ha; e giugner puollo:
IT.129: se non, ciascun disio sarebbe frustra.
IT.130: Nasce per quello, a guisa di rampollo,
IT.131: a piè del vero il dubbio; ed è natura
IT.132: ch'al sommo pinge noi di collo in collo.
IT.133: Questo m'invita, questo m'assicura
IT.134: con reverenza, donna, a dimandarvi
IT.135: d'un'altra verità che m'è oscura.
IT.136: Io vo' saper se l'uom può sodisfarvi
IT.137: ai voti manchi sì con altri beni,
IT.138: ch'a la vostra statera non sien parvi."
IT.139: Beatrice mi guardò con li occhi pieni
IT.140: di faville d'amor così divini,
IT.141: che, vinta, mia virtute diè le reni,
IT.142: e quasi mi perdei con li occhi chini.

EN.1: Between two foods, equally near at hand and tempting,
EN.2: left free to choose, a man would die of hunger
EN.3: before he could bring either to his teeth --
EN.4: so would a lamb stand still, caught between the cravings
EN.5: of two ferocious wolves, in equal fear of both,
EN.6: so would a hound, stock-still between two does:
EN.7: just so, if I kept silent, urged in equal measure
EN.8: by my doubts, I merit neither praise nor blame,
EN.9: since my silence was forced, not freely chosen.
EN.10: I kept silent, but my longing
EN.11: and my questions all were painted on my face
EN.12: more ardently than words could have expressed.
EN.13: Beatrice did what Daniel did
EN.14: when he freed Nebuchadnezzar from his wrath,
EN.15: which had made him cruel unjustly,
EN.16: by her words: 'It is clear to me you feel the pull
EN.17: of two desires, so that your divided craving
EN.18: binds itself so tight it can't breathe out.
EN.19: 'You reason: "If the will does not even waver
EN.20: in devotion to the good, how can the violence
EN.21: of another reduce my measure of reward?"
EN.22: 'Still another cause for your perplexity
EN.23: is that you think, in accord with Plato's teaching,
EN.24: the souls return to their own stars.
EN.25: 'These are the questions that weigh equally
EN.26: upon your will. First I shall deal
EN.27: with the one that has more venom in it.
EN.28: 'Not the Seraph that most ingods himself,
EN.29: not Moses, Samuel, or whichever John you please --
EN.30: none of these, I say, not even Mary,
EN.31: 'have their seats in another heaven
EN.32: than do these spirits you have just now seen,
EN.33: nor does their bliss last fewer years or more.
EN.34: 'No, all adorn the highest circle --
EN.35: but they enjoy sweet life in differing measure
EN.36: as they feel less or more of God's eternal breath.
EN.37: 'Those souls put themselves on view here
EN.38: not because they are allotted to this sphere
EN.39: but as sign of less exalted rank in Heaven.
EN.40: 'It is necessary thus to address your faculties,
EN.41: since only in perceiving through the senses can they grasp
EN.42: that which they then make fit for intellect.
EN.43: 'For this reason Scripture condescends
EN.44: to your capacity when it attributes hands and feet
EN.45: to God, but has another meaning,
EN.46: 'and for your sake Holy Church portrays
EN.47: Gabriel and Michael with the faces of men
EN.48: and that other angel who made Tobit well again.
EN.49: 'What Timaeus has to say about the souls
EN.50: does not resemble what one here observes
EN.51: because he seems to take his words for facts.
EN.52: 'He claims the soul returns to its own star,
EN.53: from which he thinks that it was drawn
EN.54: when nature gave it bodily form.
EN.55: 'But perhaps his meaning differs
EN.56: from what his words seem to express
EN.57: and may have an intention not lightly mocked.
EN.58: 'If he intends to assign to these wheels
EN.59: the honor of their influence and the blame,
EN.60: then his shaft may strike a certain truth.
EN.61: 'This principle, wrongly understood, once misled
EN.62: nearly all the world so that it went astray
EN.63: and named stars Jupiter, Mercury, and Mars.
EN.64: 'The other doubt that troubles you
EN.65: contains less venom because its harm
EN.66: could not lead you away from me.
EN.67: 'For divine justice to appear unjust
EN.68: in mortal eyes is evidence of faith,
EN.69: not of heretical iniquity.
EN.70: 'Since your human understanding is quite able
EN.71: to penetrate this truth,
EN.72: I shall content you as you wish.
EN.73: 'Even if violence is done when the one who bears it
EN.74: in no way consents to the one who deals it out,
EN.75: these souls were not excused on that account.
EN.76: 'For the will, except by its own willing, is not spent,
EN.77: but does as by its nature fire does in flame,
EN.78: though violence may force it down one thousand times.
EN.79: 'Thus, if it stays bent, whether much or little,
EN.80: it then accepts that force, as indeed did these,
EN.81: since they could have retreated to their holy place.
EN.82: 'Had their will remained unbroken,
EN.83: as did the will that fastened Lawrence to the grate
EN.84: and which made Mucius harsh to his own hand,
EN.85: 'then, once freed, it would have drawn them back
EN.86: along the path from which they had been dragged.
EN.87: But will so firm is all too rare.
EN.88: 'And these words, if you have correctly understood them,
EN.89: have destroyed an argument
EN.90: that would have often troubled you again.
EN.91: 'But now before your eyes you find
EN.92: another obstacle, so vast that your attempt
EN.93: to overcome it on your own would leave you spent.
EN.94: 'Assuredly I have set it firmly in your mind
EN.95: that a soul in bliss could never tell a lie,
EN.96: since it is always near the primal Truth.
EN.97: 'But then you may have heard Piccarda say
EN.98: that Constance kept her true love for the veil,
EN.99: so that in this she seems to contradict me.
EN.100: 'Many times, brother, has it occurred
EN.101: that, if unwillingly, to escape from harm,
EN.102: one does a thing that had better not been done,
EN.103: 'as Alcmaeon, exhorted by his father,
EN.104: slew his own mother: so as not to fail
EN.105: in piety, he steeled himself to pity.
EN.106: 'At this point, I would ask you to reflect,
EN.107: the threat of violence so mingles with the will
EN.108: that these offenses cannot be excused.
EN.109: 'An absolute will consents not to the wrong,
EN.110: but the will does consent to the extent it fears,
EN.111: if it draws back, to fall into still greater harm.
EN.112: 'Piccarda, thus, in that which she affirms,
EN.113: speaks of the absolute will, while I refer
EN.114: to the other, so that we both maintain a truth.'
EN.115: Such was the rippling of the holy stream,
EN.116: issuing from the source from which all truth derives,
EN.117: that put each one of my desires at peace.
EN.118: 'O belovèd of the first Lover,' I said then,
EN.119: 'divine creature whose speech so floods and scalds me
EN.120: that I am more and more alive,
EN.121: 'not all the depth of my affection
EN.122: is enough to requite You grace for grace.
EN.123: But may He who sees, and has the power, reward You.
EN.124: 'I now see clearly that our intellect
EN.125: cannot be satisfied until that truth enlighten it
EN.126: beyond whose boundary no further truth extends.
EN.127: 'In that truth, like a wild beast in its den, it rests
EN.128: once it has made its way there -- and it can do that,
EN.129: or else its every wish would be in vain.
EN.130: 'Like a shoot, doubt springs
EN.131: from the root of truth, and its nature
EN.132: urges us toward the summit, from ridge to ridge.
EN.133: 'It is this, lady, that invites and assures me
EN.134: to ask You, with reverence, about another truth
EN.135: that still remains obscure to me.
EN.136: 'I would like to know if one can satisfy your court
EN.137: with such other works for vows left unfulfilled
EN.138: that in your scale their weight would not be scant.'
EN.139: Beatrice looked at me with eyes so full
EN.140: of the radiance of love and so divine
EN.141: that, overcome, my power of sight faded and fled,
EN.142: and, eyes cast down, I almost lost my senses.

IT.1: "S'io ti fiammeggio nel caldo d'amore
IT.2: di là dal modo che 'n terra si vede,
IT.3: sì che del viso tuo vinco il valore,
IT.4: non ti maravigliar, ché ciò procede
IT.5: da perfetto veder, che, come apprende,
IT.6: così nel bene appreso move il piede.
IT.7: Io veggio ben sì come già resplende
IT.8: ne l'intelletto tuo l'etterna luce,
IT.9: che, vista, sola e sempre amore accende;
IT.10: e s'altra cosa vostro amor seduce,
IT.11: non è se non di quella alcun vestigio,
IT.12: mal conosciuto, che quivi traluce.
IT.13: Tu vuo' saper se con altro servigio,
IT.14: per manco voto, si può render tanto
IT.15: che l'anima sicuri di letigio."
IT.16: Sì cominciò Beatrice questo canto;
IT.17: e sì com' uom che suo parlar non spezza,
IT.18: continüò così 'l processo santo:
IT.19: "Lo maggior don che Dio per sua larghezza
IT.20: fesse creando, e a la sua bontate
IT.21: più conformato, e quel ch'e' più apprezza,
IT.22: fu de la volontà la libertate;
IT.23: di che le creature intelligenti,
IT.24: e tutte e sole, fuoro e son dotate.
IT.25: Or ti parrà, se tu quinci argomenti,
IT.26: l'alto valor del voto, s'è sì fatto
IT.27: che Dio consenta quando tu consenti;
IT.28: ché, nel fermar tra Dio e l'omo il patto,
IT.29: vittima fassi di questo tesoro,
IT.30: tal quale io dico; e fassi col suo atto.
IT.31: Dunque che render puossi per ristoro?
IT.32: Se credi bene usar quel c'hai offerto,
IT.33: di maltolletto vuo' far buon lavoro.
IT.34: Tu se' omai del maggior punto certo;
IT.35: ma perché Santa Chiesa in ciò dispensa,
IT.36: che par contra lo ver ch'i' t'ho scoverto,
IT.37: convienti ancor sedere un poco a mensa,
IT.38: però che 'l cibo rigido c'hai preso,
IT.39: richiede ancora aiuto a tua dispensa.
IT.40: Apri la mente a quel ch'io ti paleso
IT.41: e fermalvi entro; ché non fa scïenza,
IT.42: sanza lo ritenere, avere inteso.
IT.43: Due cose si convegnono a l'essenza
IT.44: di questo sacrificio: l'una è quella
IT.45: di che si fa; l'altr' è la convenenza.
IT.46: Quest' ultima già mai non si cancella
IT.47: se non servata; e intorno di lei
IT.48: sì preciso di sopra si favella:
IT.49: però necessitato fu a li Ebrei
IT.50: pur l'offerere, ancor ch'alcuna offerta
IT.51: si permutasse, come saver dei.
IT.52: L'altra, che per materia t'è aperta,
IT.53: puote ben esser tal, che non si falla
IT.54: se con altra materia si converta.
IT.55: Ma non trasmuti carco a la sua spalla
IT.56: per suo arbitrio alcun, sanza la volta
IT.57: e de la chiave bianca e de la gialla;
IT.58: e ogne permutanza credi stolta,
IT.59: se la cosa dimessa in la sorpresa
IT.60: come 'l quattro nel sei non è raccolta.
IT.61: Però qualunque cosa tanto pesa
IT.62: per suo valor che tragga ogne bilancia,
IT.63: sodisfar non si può con altra spesa.
IT.64: Non prendan li mortali il voto a ciancia;
IT.65: siate fedeli, e a ciò far non bieci,
IT.66: come Ieptè a la sua prima mancia;
IT.67: cui più si convenia dicer 'Mal feci,'
IT.68: che, servando, far peggio; e così stolto
IT.69: ritrovar puoi il gran duca de' Greci,
IT.70: onde pianse Efigènia il suo bel volto,
IT.71: e fé pianger di sé i folli e i savi
IT.72: ch'udir parlar di così fatto cólto.
IT.73: Siate, Cristiani, a muovervi più gravi:
IT.74: non siate come penna ad ogne vento,
IT.75: e non crediate ch'ogne acqua vi lavi.
IT.76: Avete il novo e 'l vecchio Testamento,
IT.77: e 'l pastor de la Chiesa che vi guida;
IT.78: questo vi basti a vostro salvamento.
IT.79: Se mala cupidigia altro vi grida,
IT.80: uomini siate, e non pecore matte,
IT.81: sì che 'l Giudeo di voi tra voi non rida!
IT.82: Non fate com' agnel che lascia il latte
IT.83: de la sua madre, e semplice e lascivo
IT.84: seco medesmo a suo piacer combatte!"
IT.85: Così Beatrice a me com'ïo scrivo;
IT.86: poi si rivolse tutta disïante
IT.87: a quella parte ove 'l mondo è più vivo.
IT.88: Lo suo tacere e 'l trasmutar sembiante
IT.89: puoser silenzio al mio cupido ingegno,
IT.90: che già nuove questioni avea davante;
IT.91: e sì come saetta che nel segno
IT.92: percuote pria che sia la corda queta,
IT.93: così corremmo nel secondo regno.
IT.94: Quivi la donna mia vid' io sì lieta,
IT.95: come nel lume di quel ciel si mise,
IT.96: che più lucente se ne fé 'l pianeta.
IT.97: E se la stella si cambiò e rise,
IT.98: qual mi fec' io che pur da mia natura
IT.99: trasmutabile son per tutte guise!
IT.100: Come 'n peschiera ch'è tranquilla e pura
IT.101: traggonsi i pesci a ciò che vien di fori
IT.102: per modo che lo stimin lor pastura,
IT.103: sì vid' io ben più di mille splendori
IT.104: trarsi ver' noi, e in ciascun s'udia:
IT.105: "Ecco chi crescerà li nostri amori."
IT.106: E sì come ciascuno a noi venìa,
IT.107: vedeasi l'ombra piena di letizia
IT.108: nel folgór chiaro che di lei uscia.
IT.109: Pensa, lettor, se quel che qui s'inizia
IT.110: non procedesse, come tu avresti
IT.111: di più savere angosciosa carizia;
IT.112: e per te vederai come da questi
IT.113: m'era in disio d'udir lor condizioni,
IT.114: sì come a li occhi mi fur manifesti.
IT.115: "O bene nato a cui veder li troni
IT.116: del trïunfo etternal concede grazia
IT.117: prima che la milizia s'abbandoni,
IT.118: del lume che per tutto il ciel si spazia
IT.119: noi semo accesi; e però, se disii
IT.120: di noi chiarirti, a tuo piacer ti sazia."
IT.121: Così da un di quelli spirti pii
IT.122: detto mi fu; e da Beatrice: "Dì, dì
IT.123: sicuramente, e credi come a dii."
IT.124: "Io veggio ben sì come tu t'annidi
IT.125: nel proprio lume, e che de li occhi il traggi,
IT.126: perch' e' corusca sì come tu ridi;
IT.127: ma non so chi tu se', né perché aggi,
IT.128: anima degna, il grado de la spera
IT.129: che si vela a' mortai con altrui raggi."
IT.130: Questo diss' io diritto a la lumera
IT.131: che pria m'avea parlato; ond' ella fessi
IT.132: lucente più assai di quel ch'ell' era.
IT.133: Sì come il sol che si cela elli stessi
IT.134: per troppa luce, come 'l caldo ha róse
IT.135: le temperanze d'i vapori spessi,
IT.136: per più letizia sì mi si nascose
IT.137: dentro al suo raggio la figura santa;
IT.138: e così chiusa chiusa mi rispuose
IT.139: nel modo che 'l seguente canto canta.

EN.1: 'If I flame at you with a heat of love
EN.2: beyond all measure known on earth
EN.3: so that I overcome your power of sight,
EN.4: 'do not wonder, for this is the result
EN.5: of perfect vision, which, even as it apprehends,
EN.6: moves its foot toward the apprehended good.
EN.7: 'I see clearly how, reflected in your mind,
EN.8: the eternal light that, once beheld,
EN.9: alone and always kindles love, is shining.
EN.10: 'And, if anything else beguiles your mortal love,
EN.11: it is nothing but a remnant of that light, which,
EN.12: incompletely understood, still shines in it.
EN.13: 'You want to know if a vow left unfulfilled
EN.14: may be redeemed by some exchange
EN.15: that then secures the soul from challenge.'
EN.16: Thus did Beatrice begin this canto and,
EN.17: like a man who does not interrupt his speech,
EN.18: continued thus her holy discourse:
EN.19: 'The greatest gift that God in His largesse
EN.20: gave to creation, the most attuned
EN.21: to His goodness and that He accounts most dear,
EN.22: 'was the freedom of the will:
EN.23: all creatures possessed of intellect,
EN.24: all of them and they alone, were and are so endowed.
EN.25: 'Now will be clear to you, reasoning from this,
EN.26: the lofty worth of vows, as long as they are such
EN.27: that God consent when you consent.
EN.28: 'For when man makes a pact with God,
EN.29: this treasure, as I have suggested, then becomes
EN.30: the sacrificial pledge, an action freely chosen.
EN.31: 'What, then, may you render in its place?
EN.32: If you think of doing good with what you've offered,
EN.33: you would do good works with gains ill-gotten.
EN.34: 'Now you may be certain of the major point.
EN.35: Since Holy Church gives dispensation in this matter --
EN.36: which seems to contradict the truth I have declared --
EN.37: 'you'll have to linger longer over dinner,
EN.38: for the tough food that you have swallowed
EN.39: still requires some aid for your digesting.
EN.40: 'Open your mind to what I now explain
EN.41: and fix it in your memory, for to hear
EN.42: and not remember does not lead to knowledge.
EN.43: Two things compose the essence
EN.44: of this sacrificial act,
EN.45: first that which is promised, then the pact itself.
EN.46: 'This pact can never be annulled
EN.47: until it is fulfilled. It was of this
EN.48: I spoke just now with such precision.
EN.49: 'Thus it was incumbent on the Hebrews
EN.50: still to offer sacrifice, even if some offerings
EN.51: allowed for substitution, as surely you must know.
EN.52: 'The first part, as has been explained, is the object
EN.53: of the vow. It may indeed be such there is no fault
EN.54: in substituting other objects for it.
EN.55: 'But let no man shift the burden on his shoulders
EN.56: at the call of his own will, for such change requires
EN.57: that both the white and yellow keys be turned.
EN.58: 'Let each exchange be reckoned vain
EN.59: unless the burden laid aside is found,
EN.60: as four is found in six, in the one assumed.
EN.61: 'Whatever, therefore, has such worth
EN.62: as would unbalance any scale
EN.63: shall not be replaced, no matter what the cost.
EN.64: 'Let not mortals take vows lightly.
EN.65: Be faithful and, as well, not injudicious,
EN.66: as was Jephthah, offering up what first he saw,

EN.1: 'Once Constantine reversed the eagle's flight,
EN.2: counter to the course of heaven it had followed
EN.3: behind that ancient who took Lavinia to wife,
EN.4: 'for two hundred years and more the bird of God
EN.5: remained at Europe's borders,
EN.6: near the mountains from which it first came forth.
EN.7: 'There it ruled the world beneath the shadow
EN.8: of its sacred wings, passing from hand to hand
EN.9: and, changing in this way, at last came into mine.
EN.10: 'Caesar I was and am Justinian,
EN.11: who, by will of the Primal Love I feel,
EN.12: pruned from the laws what was superfluous and vain.
EN.13: 'Before I had set my mind to that hard task
EN.14: I believed Christ had but a single nature,
EN.15: and not a second, and was content in that belief.
EN.16: 'But the blessèd Agapetus,
EN.17: the most exalted of our shepherds,
EN.18: brought me to the true faith with his words.
EN.19: 'I believed him. What he held by faith
EN.20: I now see just as clearly as you understand
EN.21: that any contradiction is both false and true.
EN.22: 'As soon as my footsteps moved at the Church's side,
EN.23: it pleased God, in His grace, to grant me inspiration
EN.24: in the noble task to which I wholly gave myself,
EN.25: 'entrusting my weapons to Belisarius,
EN.26: with whom Heaven's right hand was so conjoined
EN.27: it was a sign for me to give them up.
EN.28: 'Here, then, ends my reply to your first question,
EN.29: but its nature still constrains me
EN.30: to follow up with something further
EN.31: 'so that you may consider if with reason some rebel
EN.32: against that sacred standard, both those opposed
EN.33: and those who take it as their own.
EN.34: 'Consider how much valor has made it worthy
EN.35: of reverence, beginning with the hour
EN.36: when Pallas gave his life to give it sway.
EN.37: 'You know it made its home in Alba
EN.38: for three hundred years and more until, at last,
EN.39: again for its sake, three made war on three.
EN.40: 'And you know what it accomplished under seven kings,
EN.41: from the wrongs done Sabine women to Lucretia's woes,
EN.42: conquering the nearby people all around.
EN.43: 'You know what it accomplished when it was held aloft
EN.44: by the noble Romans against Brennus, against Pyrrhus,
EN.45: against the other kingdoms and republics,
EN.46: 'so that Torquatus, Quintius -- named
EN.47: for his unkempt locks -- the Decii, the Fabii:
EN.48: all achieved the fame that I am glad to keep.
EN.49: 'It brought the pride of Arabs low
EN.50: when they followed Hannibal along the Alpine crags
EN.51: from which, O river Po, you fall.
EN.52: 'Under it triumphed youthful Scipio and Pompey,
EN.53: and to that hill beneath which you were born
EN.54: it seemed indeed a bitter sight.
EN.55: 'Then, as the time approached when Heaven willed
EN.56: to bring the world to its own state of peace,
EN.57: Caesar, by the will of Rome, laid hold on it.
EN.58: 'And what it accomplished, from the Var to the Rhine,
EN.59: the Isère and the Loire and the Seine beheld,
EN.60: as did all the valleys that supply the Rhone.
EN.61: 'What it accomplished when it issued from Ravenna
EN.62: and leapt the Rubicon was such a flight
EN.63: that neither tongue nor pen could follow it.
EN.64: 'Toward Spain it wheeled in arms,
EN.65: then toward Durazzo, and smote Pharsalia,
EN.66: thus bringing grief to the tepid waters of the Nile.
EN.67: 'Antandros and the Simois, where it had set out,
EN.68: it saw again, and the place where Hector lies.
EN.69: Then it roused itself -- at Ptolemy's expense.
EN.70: 'From there, like lightning, it fell on Juba,
EN.71: then turned toward the region to your west,
EN.72: where it heard the sound of Pompey's trumpet.
EN.73: 'For what it wrought with the one who bore it next
EN.74: Brutus and Cassius bark in Hell,
EN.75: and both Modena and Perugia were aggrieved.

EN.83: had done before and had yet to do

EN.89: allowed it, in the hand of him of whom I speak,
EN.90: the glory of the vengeance for His wrath.

EN.92: Afterwards it raced with Titus, doing vengeance
EN.93: upon the vengeance for the ancient sin.
EN.94: 'Then, beneath its wings,
EN.95: when Lombard tooth bit Holy Church,
EN.96: Charlemagne, in victory, gave her comfort.

EN.98: and consider their offenses,
EN.99: the very cause of all your ills.

EN.101: yellow lilies, while the other claims it for a party,
EN.102: so that it's hard to see which one offends the more.

EN.104: beneath another standard, for he follows
EN.105: this one poorly who severs it from justice.
EN.106: 'And let not this new Charles strive to fell it
EN.107: with his Guelphs, but let him fear its claws,
EN.108: which have ripped the hides from greater lions.
EN.109: 'Many a time have children wept
EN.110: for the father's sin, and let him not think
EN.111: that God will change His ensign for those lilies.
EN.112: 'This little star is ornamented
EN.113: with righteous spirits, those whose deeds were done
EN.114: for the honor and the glory that would follow.

EN.116: then the rays of the one true love
EN.117: must rise with less intensity.
EN.118: 'But noting how our merit equals our reward
EN.119: is part of our happiness,
EN.120: because we see them being neither less nor more.

EN.122: we cannot ever then take on
EN.123: the warp of wickedness.
EN.124: 'Differing voices make sweet music.

EN.126: create sweet harmony among these wheels.
EN.127: 'Within this very pearl shines
EN.128: the shining light of Romeo,
EN.129: whose great and noble work was poorly paid.
EN.130: 'But those of Provence who schemed against him
EN.131: have not had the last laugh -- he takes an evil road
EN.132: to whom another's good deed seems a wrong.
EN.133: 'Raymond Berenger had four daughters,
EN.134: each of them a queen, and Romeo, a man
EN.135: of little standing and a stranger, made that happen.
EN.136: 'And when malicious tongues moved Raymond
EN.137: to go over accounts with this just man,
EN.138: who had rendered him seven plus five for ten,
EN.139: 'Romeo left there, poor in his old age.
EN.140: And, if the world knew the heart he had within
EN.141: when, crust by crust, he begged his bread,
EN.142: much as it praises him, it would praise him more.'
