IT.107: da l'operante, quanto più appresenta
IT.108: de la bontà del core ond' ell' è uscita,
IT.109: la divina bontà che 'l mondo imprenta,
IT.110: di proceder per tutte le sue vie,
IT.111: a rilevarvi suso, fu contenta.
IT.112: Né tra l'ultima notte e 'l primo die
IT.113: sì alto o sì magnifico processo,
IT.114: o per l'una o per l'altra, fu o fie:
IT.115: ché più largo fu Dio a dar sé stesso
IT.116: per far l'uom sufficiente a rilevarsi,
IT.117: che s'elli avesse sol da sé dimesso;
IT.118: e tutti li altri modi erano scarsi
IT.119: a la giustizia, se 'l Figliuol di Dio
IT.120: non fosse umilïato ad incarnarsi.
IT.121: Or per empierti bene ogne disio,
IT.122: ritorno a dichiararti in alcun loco,
IT.123: perché tu veggi lì così com' io.
IT.124: Tu dici: 'Io veggio l'acqua, io veggio il foco,
IT.125: l'aere e la terra e tutte lor misture
IT.126: venire a corruzione, e durar poco;
IT.127: e queste cose pur furon creature;
IT.128: per che, se ciò ch'è detto è stato vero,
IT.129: esser dovrien da corruzion sicure.'
IT.130: Li angeli, frate, e 'l paese sincero
IT.131: nel qual tu se', dir si posson creati,
IT.132: sì come sono, in loro essere intero;
IT.133: ma li alimenti che tu hai nomati
IT.134: e quelle cose che di lor si fanno
IT.135: da creata virtù sono informati.
IT.136: Creata fu la materia ch'elli hanno;
IT.137: creata fu la virtù informante
IT.138: in queste stelle che 'ntorno a lor vanno.
IT.139: L'anima d'ogne bruto e de le piante
IT.140: di complession potenzïata tira
IT.141: lo raggio e 'l moto de le luci sante;
IT.142: ma vostra vita sanza mezzo spira
IT.143: la somma beninanza, e la innamora
IT.144: di sé sì che poi sempre la disira.
IT.145: E quinci puoi argomentare ancora
IT.146: vostra resurrezion, se tu ripensi
IT.147: come l'umana carne fessi allora
IT.148: che li primi parenti intrambo fensi."

EN.1: 'Osanna, sanctus Deus sabaoth,
EN.2: superillustrans claritate tua
EN.3: felices ignes horum malacoth!' --
EN.4: Thus, wheeling to the notes of his own melody,
EN.5: I saw that being, in whom a double light
EN.6: is twinned, caught up in song,
EN.7: he and the others moving in their dance
EN.8: and, like the fastest-flying sparks,
EN.9: veiled from me by their sudden distance.
EN.10: I was in doubt, saying to myself, 'Tell her,
EN.11: tell her,' saying to myself, 'tell this to my lady,
EN.12: who slakes my thirst with her sweet drops.'
EN.13: But the reverence that is mistress over me
EN.14: at the mere sound of Be or ice
EN.15: bowed down my head, as when a man nods off.
EN.16: Not long did Beatrice leave me in this state
EN.17: before she spoke, shining with the rays of such a smile
EN.18: as would content a man if he were set on fire:
EN.19: 'In my infallible opinion this idea,
EN.20: that just revenge itself perhaps deserves
EN.21: just punishment, has set you thinking.
EN.22: 'But I will quickly free your mind of doubt.
EN.23: Still, you must listen closely, for my words
EN.24: shall set before you things of great importance.
EN.25: 'By not enduring, for his own good, a rein
EN.26: upon his will, that man who was not born,
EN.27: damning himself, damned all his offspring.
EN.28: 'As a result, for centuries the human race
EN.29: lay sick in an abyss of error
EN.30: until the Word of God chose to descend,
EN.31: 'uniting human nature, estranged now
EN.32: from its Maker, with Himself in His own person
EN.33: by a single act of His eternal Love.
EN.34: 'Now direct your inner sight on what evolves from that.
EN.35: This nature, united with its Maker,
EN.36: was pure and good, even as it was when first created.
EN.37: 'But through the fault of its own doing
EN.38: it was expelled from Eden
EN.39: because it turned away from truth and life.
EN.40: 'If, then, the penalty exacted by the cross
EN.41: is measured by the nature He assumed,
EN.42: no other ever stung so justly.
EN.43: 'Yet it is also true that there was never done
EN.44: so great an outrage with regard to Him who suffered,
EN.45: having taken on that nature.
EN.46: 'From a single act, then, came diverse effects,
EN.47: for the same death delighted God as well as Jews.
EN.48: Because of it earth quaked and Heaven opened.
EN.49: 'No longer, from now on, should it seem puzzling
EN.50: when you hear it said that a just vengeance
EN.51: was afterward avenged in a just court.
EN.52: 'But now I see your mind entangled,
EN.53: by one thought and another in a knot
EN.54: from which, eager, it waits to be untied:
EN.55: 'You say, "I follow closely what I hear,
EN.56: but why God wanted this to be the very way
EN.57: for our redemption is obscure to me."
EN.58: 'The reason for this decree, brother, lies buried,
EN.59: hidden from the eyes of all
EN.60: whose minds have not been ripened in the flame of love.
EN.61: 'Nonetheless, because so many strive to hit this mark,
EN.62: while so few can even see it, I shall explain
EN.63: the reason this was the most fitting choice.
EN.64: 'Spurning any kind of envy, Divine Goodness,
EN.65: burning within, so sparkles
EN.66: that it unfolds Eternal Beauty.
EN.67: 'That which, unmediated, derives from it
EN.68: is thus without an end, because its imprint,
EN.69: once stamped, can never wear away.
EN.70: 'That which, unmediated, rains down from it
EN.71: is wholly free, because it is not subject
EN.72: to the influence of things more recent,
EN.73: 'is more like that Goodness and thus more pleases Him.
EN.74: The holy ardor that irradiates all things
EN.75: shines brightest in what most resembles it.
EN.76: 'In all these gifts the human creature
EN.77: is advantaged, but, if a single gift is lacking,
EN.78: he must fall from his exalted state.
EN.79: 'Sin alone is what enslaves him,
EN.80: making him unlike the highest good
EN.81: so that he is illumined by its light but little,
EN.82: 'never returning to his privilege
EN.83: unless he fills the void created by his fault
EN.84: with penalties fit for his sinful pleasure.
EN.85: 'Your nature, when it sinned in toto
EN.86: in its seed, was separated
EN.87: from these privileges and from its Eden.
EN.88: 'Nor could they be recovered --
EN.89: if you consider closely -- by any other recourse
EN.90: except to ford one of these crossings:
EN.91: 'either that God, in His own clemency,
EN.92: had pardoned, or that man, of himself,
EN.93: had given satisfaction for his foolish pride.
EN.94: 'Now fix your eyes deep in the abyss
EN.95: of the everlasting will of God
EN.96: and give your strict attention to my words.
EN.97: 'With his limitations, man could never offer
EN.98: satisfaction, for he could not descend as deep
EN.99: into humility, by latter-day obedience,
EN.100: 'as, by disobeying, he had thought to rise.
EN.101: And this is the reason for which he was denied
EN.102: the power of giving satisfaction on his own.
EN.103: 'Thus it was necessary that God in His own ways
EN.104: restore man to the fullness of his life --
EN.105: by one way, that is, or by both of them.
EN.106: 'But since the deed more gratifies the doer
EN.107: the more it shows the goodness
EN.108: of the heart from which it springs,
EN.109: 'divine goodness, which puts its imprint
EN.110: on the world, was pleased to proceed
EN.111: in both its ways to raise you up again.
EN.112: 'Nor between the last night and the first day
EN.113: was, or will there be, a deed performed -- in the first way
EN.114: or the second -- so sublime or generous.
EN.115: 'More bountiful was God when He gave Himself,
EN.116: enabling man to rise again, than if,
EN.117: in His sole clemency, he had simply pardoned.
EN.118: 'All other means fell short of justice
EN.119: save that the Son of God
EN.120: should humble Himself by becoming flesh.
EN.121: 'Now, to satisfy each of your desires,
EN.122: I go back to clarify one point,
EN.123: that you may understand it just as I do.
EN.124: 'You say: "I see water, I see fire, air,
EN.125: and earth -- and all their combinations --
EN.126: become corrupted, lasting only briefly.
EN.127: '"And yet these things were created,
EN.128: so that, if what was said is true,
EN.129: they should be proof against corruption.
EN.130: 'The angels, brother, and this pure country
EN.131: where you are may be said to have been created
EN.132: just as they are and in their entire being,
EN.133: 'but those elements that have been named
EN.134: and those other things made from them
EN.135: take their form from a created power.
EN.136: 'Created was the matter that is in them,
EN.137: created, the informing power
EN.138: in these stars that wheel about them.
EN.139: 'The soul of every beast and every plant
EN.140: is drawn from a complex of potentials
EN.141: by the shining and the motion of the holy lights.
EN.142: 'But supreme goodness breathes life in you,
EN.143: unmediated, and He so enamors your soul
EN.144: of Himself that it desires Him forever after.
EN.145: 'From this you may, in consequence, deduce
EN.146: your resurrection, if you but recall
EN.147: how then your flesh was made
EN.148: in the making of the first two parents.'

IT.1: Solea creder lo mondo in suo periclo
IT.2: che la bella Ciprigna il folle amore
IT.3: raggiasse, volta nel terzo epiciclo;
IT.4: per che non pur a lei faceano onore
IT.5: di sacrificio e di votivo grido
IT.6: le genti antiche ne l'antico errore;
IT.7: ma Dïone onoravano e Cupido,
IT.8: quella per madre sua, questo per figlio,
IT.9: e dicean ch'el sedette in grembo a Dido;
IT.10: e da costei ond' io principio piglio
IT.11: pigliavano il vocabol de la stella
IT.12: che 'l sol vagheggia or da coppa or da ciglio.
IT.13: Io non m'accorsi del salire in ella;
IT.14: ma d'esservi entro mi fé assai fede
IT.15: la donna mia ch'i' vidi far più bella.
IT.16: E come in fiamma favilla si vede,
IT.17: e come in voce voce si discerne,
IT.18: quand' una è ferma e altra va e riede,
IT.19: vid' io in essa luce altre lucerne
IT.20: muoversi in giro più e men correnti,
IT.21: al modo, credo, di lor viste interne.
IT.22: Di fredda nube non disceser venti,
IT.23: o visibili o no, tanto festini,
IT.24: che non paressero impediti e lenti
IT.25: a chi avesse quei lumi divini
IT.26: veduti a noi venir, lasciando il giro
IT.27: pria cominciato in li alti Serafini;
IT.28: e dentro a quei che più innanzi appariro
IT.29: sonava "Osanna" sì, che unque poi
IT.30: di rïudir non fui sanza disiro.
IT.31: Indi si fece l'un più presso a noi
IT.32: e solo incominciò: "Tutti sem presti
IT.33: al tuo piacer, perché di noi ti gioi.
IT.34: Noi ci volgiam coi principi celesti
IT.35: d'un giro e d'un girare e d'una sete,
IT.36: ai quali tu del mondo già dicesti:
IT.37: 'Voi che 'ntendendo il terzo ciel movete';
IT.38: e sem sì pien d'amor, che, per piacerti,
IT.39: non fia men dolce un poco di quïete."
IT.40: Poscia che li occhi miei si fuoro offerti
IT.41: a la mia donna reverenti, ed essa
IT.42: fatti li avea di sé contenti e certi,
IT.43: rivolsersi a la luce che promessa
IT.44: tanto s'avea, e "Deh, chi siete?" fue
IT.45: la voce mia di grande affetto impressa.
IT.46: E quanta e quale vid' io lei far piùe
IT.47: per allegrezza nova che s'accrebbe,
IT.48: quando parlai, a l'allegrezze sue!
IT.49: Così fatta, mi disse: "Il mondo m'ebbe
IT.50: giù poco tempo; e se più fosse stato,
IT.51: molto sarà di mal, che non sarebbe.
IT.52: La mia letizia mi ti tien celato
IT.53: che mi raggia dintorno e mi nasconde
IT.54: quasi animal di sua seta fasciato.
IT.55: Assai m'amasti, e avesti ben onde;
IT.56: che s'io fossi giù stato, io ti mostrava
IT.57: di mio amor più oltre che le fronde.
IT.58: Quella sinistra riva che si lava
IT.59: di Rodano poi ch'è misto con Sorga,
IT.60: per suo segnore a tempo m'aspettava,
IT.61: e quel corno d'Ausonia che s'imborga
IT.62: di Bari e di Gaeta e di Catona,
IT.63: da ove Tronto e Verde in mare sgorga.
IT.64: Fulgeami già in fronte la corona
IT.65: di quella terra che 'l Danubio riga
IT.66: poi che le ripe tedesche abbandona.
IT.67: E la bella Trinacria, che caliga
IT.68: tra Pachino e Peloro, sopra 'l golfo
IT.69: che riceve da Euro maggior briga,
IT.70: non per Tifeo ma per nascente solfo,
IT.71: attesi avrebbe li suoi regi ancora,
IT.72: nati per me di Carlo e di Ridolfo,
IT.73: se mala segnoria, che sempre accora
IT.74: li popoli suggetti, non avesse
IT.75: mosso Palermo a gridar: 'Mora, mora!'
IT.76: E se mio frate questo antivedesse,
IT.77: l'avara povertà di Catalogna
IT.78: già fuggeria, perché non li offendesse;
IT.79: ché veramente proveder bisogna
IT.80: per lui, o per altrui, sì ch'a sua barca
IT.81: carcata più d'incarco non si pogna.
IT.82: La sua natura, che di larga parca
IT.83: discese, avria mestier di tal milizia
IT.84: che non curasse di mettere in arca."
IT.85: "Però ch'i' credo che l'alta letizia
IT.86: che 'l tuo parlar m'infonde, segnor mio,
IT.87: là 've ogne ben si termina e s'inizia,
IT.88: per te si veggia come la vegg' io,
IT.89: grata m'è più; e anco quest' ho caro
IT.90: perché 'l discerni rimirando in Dio.
IT.91: Fatto m'hai lieto, e così mi fa chiaro,
IT.92: poi che, parlando, a dubitar m'hai mosso
IT.93: com' esser può, di dolce seme, amaro."
IT.94: Questo io a lui; ed elli a me: "S'io posso
IT.95: mostrarti un vero, a quel che tu dimandi
IT.96: terrai lo viso come tien lo dosso.
IT.97: Lo ben che tutto il regno che tu scandi
IT.98: volge e contenta, fa esser virtute
IT.99: sua provedenza in questi corpi grandi.
IT.100: E non pur le nature provedute
IT.101: sono in la mente ch'è da sé perfetta,
IT.102: ma esse insieme con la lor salute:
IT.103: per che quantunque quest' arco saetta
IT.104: disposto cade a proveduto fine,
IT.105: sì come cosa in suo segno diretta.
IT.106: Se ciò non fosse, il ciel che tu cammine
IT.107: producerebbe sì li suoi effetti,
IT.108: che non sarebbero arti, ma ruine;
IT.109: e ciò esser non può, se li 'ntelletti
IT.110: che muovon queste stelle non son manchi,
IT.111: e manco il primo, che non li ha perfetti.
IT.112: Vuo' tu che questo ver più ti s'imbianchi?"
IT.113: E io "Non già; ché impossibil veggio
IT.114: che la natura, in quel ch'è uopo, stanchi."
IT.115: Ond' elli ancora: "Or dì: sarebbe il peggio
IT.116: per l'omo in terra, se non fosse cive?"
IT.117: "Sì," rispuos' io; "e qui ragion non cheggio."
IT.118: "E puot' elli esser, se giù non si vive
IT.119: diversamente per diversi offici?
IT.120: Non, se 'l maestro vostro ben vi scrive."
IT.121: Sì venne deducendo infino a quici;
IT.122: poscia conchiuse: "Dunque esser diverse
IT.123: convien di vostri effetti le radici:
IT.124: per ch'un nasce Solone e altro Serse,
IT.125: altro Melchisedèch e altro quello
IT.126: che, volando per l'aere, il figlio perse.
IT.127: La circular natura, ch'è suggello
IT.128: a la cera mortal, fa ben sua arte,
IT.129: ma non distingue l'un da l'altro ostello.
IT.130: Quinci addivien ch'Esaù si diparte
IT.131: per seme da Iacòb; e vien Quirino
IT.132: da sì vil padre, che si rende a Marte.
IT.133: Natura generata il suo cammino
IT.134: simil farebbe sempre a' generanti,
IT.135: se non vincesse il proveder divino.
IT.136: Or quel che t'era dietro t'è davanti:
IT.137: ma perché sappi che di te mi giova,
IT.138: un corollario voglio che t'ammanti.
IT.139: Sempre natura, se fortuna trova
IT.140: discorde a sé, com' ogne altra semente
IT.141: fuor di sua regïon, fa mala prova.
IT.142: E se 'l mondo là giù ponesse mente
IT.143: al fondamento che natura pone,
IT.144: seguendo lui, avria buona la gente.
IT.145: Ma voi torcete a la religïone
IT.146: tal che fia nato a cignersi la spada,
IT.147: e fate re di tal ch'è da sermone;
IT.148: onde la traccia vostra è fuor di strada."

EN.1: To its own cost, there was a time the world believed
EN.2: that the fair Cyprian beamed rays of maddened love,
EN.3: revolving in the wheel of the third epicycle,
EN.4: so that the ancient peoples in their ancient error
EN.5: not only did her honor
EN.6: with sacrifice and votive cr
EN.7: but honored Dïone, and Cupid too,
EN.8: one as her mother, the other as her son,
EN.9: and told how once he sat in Dido's lap.
EN.10: And from her with whom I here begin they took
EN.11: the name of the star that is wooed by the sun,
EN.12: now at her nape, now at her brow.
EN.13: I had not been aware of rising to that star,
EN.14: but was assured of being in it
EN.15: when I observed my lady turn more beautiful.
EN.16: And, as one sees a spark within a flame
EN.17: or hears, within a song, a second voice,
EN.18: holding its note while the other comes and goes,
EN.19: so I saw within that light still other lights,
EN.20: swifter and slower in their circling motions,
EN.21: it seemed in measure to their inner sight.
EN.22: Winds racing down from a cold cloud,
EN.23: in their swift motion, whether visible or not,
EN.24: would seem impeded, slow,
EN.25: to one who had seen these heavenly lights
EN.26: come toward us, pausing in the dance
EN.27: begun among the lofty Seraphim.
EN.28: And from among the closest that appeared
EN.29: rang out Hosanna so that ever since
EN.30: I have not been without the wish to hear it.
EN.31: Then one, alone, drew nearer and began:
EN.32: 'All of us desire to bring you pleasure
EN.33: so that you may in turn delight in us.
EN.34: 'In one orbit we revolve with these celestial princes --
EN.35: in one circle, with one circling, and with a single thirst --
EN.36: to whom, from the world, you addressed these words:
EN.37: '"You who, by understanding, move the third heaven."
EN.38: We are filled with love but, to give you pleasure,
EN.39: a little respite will be no less sweet to us.'
EN.40: After I had raised my reverent eyes
EN.41: to my lady and she had made them glad
EN.42: and made them sure of her consent,
EN.43: I turned them back to the light that had made
EN.44: such a promise, and 'Oh, who are you?'
EN.45: I asked, my voice expressing great affection.
EN.46: I watched the light grow larger
EN.47: and more luminescent as I spoke
EN.48: with new joy added to its joys!
EN.49: Thus changed, it said to me: 'The world kept me
EN.50: but a little while below, and, had that time been longer,
EN.51: much evil that shall be would not have been.
EN.52: 'It is my happiness that hides me from you,
EN.53: as it enfolds and hides me in its shining rays,
EN.54: like the creature that is sheathed in its own silk.
EN.55: 'You loved me well, and with good reason.
EN.56: Had I remained below, to you I would have shown
EN.57: much more than the first leaves of my affection.
EN.58: 'The left bank that is moistened by the Rhone
EN.59: once it mingles waters with the Sorgue
EN.60: awaited me as sovereign at a time to come,
EN.61: 'as did Ausonia's horn, from where it borders Bari,
EN.62: Gaeta, and Catona, to the place
EN.63: where the Tronto and the Verde flow into the sea.
EN.64: 'On my brow already shone the crown
EN.65: of the country furrowed by the Danube
EN.66: once it leaves behind its German banks.
EN.67: 'And fair Trinacria, overcast and murky
EN.68: between Pachynus and Pelorus,
EN.69: above the bay most vexed by the Sirocco,
EN.70: 'darkened not by Typhon but by rising sulphur --
EN.71: would still have waited for its kings,
EN.72: born through me of Charles and Rudolph,
EN.73: 'had not bad governance, which ever grieves the hearts
EN.74: of subject peoples, impelled Palermo
EN.75: to cry out, "Kill them, kill!"
EN.76: 'And if my brother but foresaw this
EN.77: he would shun the greedy poverty of Catalonia
EN.78: so that it not afflict him.
EN.79: 'For truly there is need that he or someone else
EN.80: should look to it, lest on his overloaded bark
EN.81: be laid a load of even greater weight.
EN.82: 'His stingy nature, though he came from worthy stock,
EN.83: would require officials who do not set their hearts
EN.84: on filling up their coffers.'
EN.85: 'Since I sense that the deep joy
EN.86: your words have filled me with, my lord,
EN.87: is seen by you as clearly as it's seen by me
EN.88: 'there where every good begins and ends,
EN.89: my joy is greater. And I also hold it dear
EN.90: that you discern this as you gaze on God.
EN.91: 'You have made me glad, now bring me light,
EN.92: for, listening to your words, I am confused:
EN.93: How from sweet seed may come a bitter fruit?'
EN.94: Thus I to him, and he: 'If I can prove a truth to you,
EN.95: then you will have before your eyes
EN.96: an answer to the question on which you turn your back.
EN.97: 'The Good, which revolves and gladdens
EN.98: all the realm you now are climbing,
EN.99: puts its plan to work through these great bodies.
EN.100: 'Not only are the natures of the souls foreseen
EN.101: within the Mind that in Itself is perfect,
EN.102: but, along with their natures, their well-being,
EN.103: 'and thus whatsoever this bow shoots
EN.104: falls predisposed to a determined end,
EN.105: as a shaft directed to its target.
EN.106: 'Were this not so, the heavens you traverse
EN.107: would engender such effects
EN.108: as would not seem crafted but chaotic,
EN.109: 'and such cannot be, unless the intellects that impel
EN.110: the spheres here were defective and defective, too,
EN.111: the primal Intellect, for failing to perfect them.
EN.112: 'Would you like to have this truth made clearer?'
EN.113: And I: 'No, for I understand it cannot be
EN.114: that nature should weary in her necessary chores.'
EN.115: And he continued: 'Now tell me, would it be worse
EN.116: for man on earth if he were not a social being?'
EN.117: 'Yes,' I agreed, 'and here I ask no proof.'
EN.118: 'And can he be such if men down there on earth
EN.119: live not in different ways for different tasks?
EN.120: Not if your master is correct in this.'
EN.121: Thus he brought his thesis to its point
EN.122: and then concluded, 'The roots of your activities,
EN.123: therefore, are necessarily diverse:
EN.124: 'Thus one is born Solon and another Xerxes,
EN.125: one Melchizedek, another one the man
EN.126: who flew up through the air and lost his son.
EN.127: 'Circling nature, which sets its seal
EN.128: on mortal wax, plies its craft with skill,
EN.129: but does not distinguish one house from another.
EN.130: 'Thus it happens that Esau differs even in the seed
EN.131: from Jacob, and Quirinus is born
EN.132: of so rude a father he is ascribed to Mars.
EN.133: 'Nature, once begotten, would always follow
EN.134: a course like that of its begetters
EN.135: if Divine Providence did not intervene.
EN.136: 'Now what was behind you is before you.

EN.139: 'Always, if nature meets a fate

EN.148: so that your path departs from the true way.'

EN.1: After your Charles had enlightened me,
EN.2: fair Clemence, he told of the deceptions
EN.3: his seed was destined still to bear,
EN.4: but said: 'Be silent, and let the years roll by.'
EN.5: And so I can reveal no more than this: fitting grief
EN.6: shall find the ones who do your family wrong.
EN.7: By now the spirit in its holy light
EN.8: had turned back to the Sun that fills its being,
EN.9: as to the goodness that suffices in all things.
EN.10: Ah, souls beguiled, creatures without reverence,
EN.11: who wrench your hearts away from so much good
EN.12: and set your minds on emptiness!
EN.13: Now another of those splendors moved
EN.14: in my direction, while its brightened glow
EN.15: proclaimed its wish to bring me joy.
EN.16: The eyes of Beatrice, fixed on me,
EN.17: as they had been before, held loving reassurance
EN.18: of her glad consent to my desire.
EN.19: 'Please let my wish receive its quick reward,
EN.20: blessèd spirit,' I asked, 'and give me proof
EN.21: that what I think reflects itself in you.'
EN.22: At that the radiance, as yet unknown to me,
EN.23: out of the very depth from which it sang before,
EN.24: responded as does someone who delights in doing good:
EN.25: 'In that part of degenerate Italy
EN.26: that extends from the Rialto
EN.27: to the sources of the Brenta and the Piave
EN.28: 'there rises a hill of no great height
EN.29: from which a firebrand came hurtling down
EN.30: to scourge the region with its fierce assault.
EN.31: 'This torch and I were born from a single root.
EN.32: Cunizza was my name and, overcome
EN.33: by this star's splendor, I shine here.
EN.34: 'I gladly pardon in myself the reason for my lot,
EN.35: nor does it grieve me -- a fact that may
EN.36: seem strange, perhaps, to those unschooled among you.
EN.37: 'Of this scintillating, precious jewel beside me
EN.38: in this heaven, great fame was left on earth.
EN.39: And, before it dies away completely,
EN.40: 'this centennial year will come again five times.
EN.41: Consider, then, should a man not strive to excel
EN.42: so that his first life leave behind a better?
EN.43: 'Of this the present rabble there enclosed
EN.44: by the Tagliamento and the Àdige have no thought,
EN.45: nor, for all their scourgings, do they yet repent.
EN.46: 'But soon the time will come when Padua shall stain
EN.47: the color of the water of Vicenza's marshes,
EN.48: because the people there resist their duty.
EN.49: 'Where the rivers Sile and Cagnano converge,
EN.50: one man lords it, with his head held high --
EN.51: but even now the web is spun to catch him.
EN.52: 'Feltre must still bewail the perfidy
EN.53: of her godless shepherd. This shall be so foul
EN.54: that, for its like, none yet has gone to prison.
EN.55: 'Large indeed the vat would have to be
EN.56: to hold so much of Ferrarese blood,
EN.57: and weary he who had to weigh it ounce by ounce,
EN.58: 'the blood this generous priest will offer as a gift
EN.59: to show his party just how staunch he is --
EN.60: such gifts will suit that city's way of life.
EN.61: 'Above us are the mirrors you call Thrones.
EN.62: From them the judging God shines down on us,
EN.63: so that we think it good to say such things.'
EN.64: Here she was silent and it seemed to me
EN.65: her thoughts had turned to other cares
EN.66: as she rejoined the ring where she had been before.
EN.67: The other joy, already known to me
EN.68: as precious, before my eyes became a splendid ruby,
EN.69: sparkling in the bright rays of the sun.
EN.70: There above, brightness is gained by joy,
EN.71: as is laughter here, but down below
EN.72: a shade shows dark when sadness clouds its mind.
EN.73: 'God sees all, and your sight is so in-Himmed,
EN.74: blessèd spirit,' I said, 'that no wish of any kind
EN.75: is able to conceal itself from you.
EN.76: 'Why then does your voice, which ever pleases Heaven,
EN.77: together with the singing of those loving flames
EN.78: that form their cowls from their six wings,
EN.79: 'not offer my desires their satisfaction?
EN.80: I would not await your question
EN.81: if I in-you'd me as you in-me'd you.'
EN.82: 'The widest expanse of water inside shores,'
EN.83: were the initial words of his response,
EN.84: 'drawn from the sea encircling all the world,
EN.85: 'between its opposing shores extends so far
EN.86: against the wheeling sun, it places the meridian
EN.87: where at first lay only the horizon.
EN.88: 'I was a dweller on that water's shore
EN.89: between the Ebro and the brief run of the Magra
EN.90: that separates the Tuscan from the Genovese.
EN.91: 'So close they nearly share sunset and dawn
EN.92: lie Bougie and the city that I came from.
EN.93: Once it made its harbor warm with its own blood.
EN.94: 'Folco the people called me, if they knew
EN.95: my name, and now this heaven
EN.96: is marked by me, as I was marked by it,
EN.97: 'for the daughter of Belus was no more aflame,
EN.98: bringing grief to Sychaeus and to Creusa,
EN.99: than I, until the color of my hair began to fade,
EN.100: 'nor was she of Rhodope, who was deceived
EN.101: by Demophoön, nor Alcides,
EN.102: when he embraced Iole in his heart.
EN.103: 'Yet here we don't repent, but smile instead,
EN.104: not at our fault, which comes not back to mind,
EN.105: but for that Power which ordered and foresaw.
EN.106: 'Here we contemplate the craft that beautifies
EN.107: such love, and here discern the good
EN.108: with which the world above informs the one below.
EN.109: 'However, so that you may leave this sphere
EN.110: with every wish that here has been engendered
EN.111: satisfied, I must go on.
EN.112: 'You want to know who occupies this luminescence
EN.113: that scintillates beside me here,
EN.114: like a sunbeam gleaming on clear water.
EN.115: 'Know then that within it Rahab is at peace,
EN.116: and, since she is of our number,
EN.117: our highest rank receives its seal from her.
EN.118: 'Into this heaven, where the shadow of your world
EN.119: comes to a point, before any other,
EN.120: first in Christ's triumph, she was taken up.
EN.121: 'Fitting it was indeed to leave her in one heaven,
EN.122: a trophy of the lofty victory
EN.123: He gained with both of His two palms,
EN.124: 'because she aided Joshua when he gained
EN.125: his first triumph in the Holy Land -- a place
EN.126: that hardly touches the memory of the pope.
EN.127: 'Your city, which was planted by him,
EN.128: the first to turn his back upon his Maker
EN.129: and from whose envy comes such great distress,
EN.130: 'puts forth and spreads the accursèd flower
EN.131: that has led astray both sheep and lambs,
EN.132: for it has made a wolf out of its shepherd.
EN.133: 'For it the Gospels and the lofty doctors
EN.134: are neglected and the Decretals alone are studied,
EN.135: as is readily apparent from their margins.
EN.136: 'To it the pope and his cardinals devote themselves,
EN.137: without a single thought for Nazareth,
EN.138: where Gabriel spread out his wings.
EN.139: 'But Vatican hill and other chosen Roman places
EN.140: that became the burial-ground
EN.141: for the soldiery that followed Peter
EN.142: will soon be free of this adultery.

EN.1: Gazing on His Son with the Love
EN.2: the One and the Other eternally breathe forth,

EN.6: cannot but taste of Him.
EN.7: With me, then, reader, raise your eyes
EN.8: up to the lofty wheels, directly to that part
EN.9: where the one motion and the other intersect,
EN.10: and from that point begin to gaze in rapture
EN.11: at the Master's work. He so loves it in Himself
EN.12: that never does His eye depart from it.
EN.13: See how from there the oblique circle
EN.14: that bears the planets on it branches off
EN.15: to satisfy the world that calls for them.
EN.16: And if their pathway were not thus deflected,
EN.17: many powers in the heavens would be vain
EN.18: and quite dead almost every potency on earth.
EN.19: And, if it slanted farther or less far
EN.20: in the upper or the lower hemisphere,
EN.21: much would be lacking in the order of the world.
EN.22: Stay on your bench now, reader,
EN.23: thinking of the joy you have but tasted,
EN.24: if, well before you tire, you would be happy.
EN.25: I have set your table. From here on feed yourself,
EN.26: for my attention now resides
EN.27: in that matter of which I have become the scribe.
EN.28: Nature's sublime and greatest minister,
EN.29: who imprints Heaven's power on the world
EN.30: and in his shining measures out our time,
EN.31: in conjunction with the place I note above,
EN.32: was wheeling through those spirals
EN.33: in which he comes forth earlier each day.
EN.34: And I was in it, aware of my ascent
EN.35: no more than one becomes aware
EN.36: of the beginnings of a thought before it comes.
EN.37: It is Beatrice who leads from good
EN.38: to better so suddenly that her action
EN.39: has no measurement in time.
EN.40: Whatever I saw within the sun, how shining
EN.41: it must have been, for, when I entered,
EN.42: it revealed itself, not by color, but by light.
EN.43: Were I to call on genius, skill, and practice,
EN.44: I could not ever tell how this might be imagined.
EN.45: Enough if one believes and longs to see it.
EN.46: And if the powers of our imagination
EN.47: are too earthbound for such height, it is no wonder,
EN.48: for eye has never seen light brighter than the sun.
EN.49: So brilliant the fourth family of the highest Father,
EN.50: who forever gives it satisfaction, shone,
EN.51: revealing how He breathes and how begets.
EN.52: And Beatrice began: 'Give thanks, give thanks
EN.53: to the Sun who makes the angels shine and who,
EN.54: by His grace, has raised you to this visible sun.'
EN.55: Never was mortal heart so well prepared
EN.56: for worship, nor so swift to yield itself
EN.57: to God with absolute assent
EN.58: as was mine when I heard those words,
EN.59: and all my love was so set on Him
EN.60: that it eclipsed Beatrice in forgetfulness.
EN.61: This did not displease her. Instead, she smiled,
EN.62: so that the splendor of her smiling eyes
EN.63: divided my mind's focus among many things.
EN.64: I saw many living lights of blinding brightness
EN.65: make of us a center and of themselves a crown,
EN.66: their voices sweeter than the radiance of their faces.
EN.67: Thus ringed we sometimes see Latona's daughter
EN.68: when the air has grown so heavy
EN.69: that it retains the thread that forms her belt.
EN.70: In the court of Heaven, from which I have returned,
EN.71: there are many gems of such worth and beauty
EN.72: that they may not be taken from the realm.
EN.73: These lights were singing of those jewels.
EN.74: He who fails to wing himself to fly there
EN.75: might as well await the dumb to tell the news.
EN.76: When, with just such songs, those blazing suns
EN.77: had three times made their way around us,
EN.78: like stars right near the still and steady poles,
EN.79: they seemed to me like ladies, poised to dance,
EN.80: pausing, silent, as they listen,
EN.81: until they have made out the new refrain.
EN.82: And from one of them I heard: 'Since the ray
EN.83: of grace by which true love is kindled
EN.84: and which, by loving, sees itself increase,
EN.85: 'multiplied in you, is so resplendent
EN.86: that it conducts you up that stair
EN.87: which none descends except to mount again,
EN.88: 'he who would deny your thirst the wine
EN.89: out of his bottle would not be free to do so,
EN.90: as water has no option but to flow into the sea.
EN.91: 'You want to know with what plants and blossoms
EN.92: this garland is in flower, encircling with delight
EN.93: the lovely lady who strengthens you for Heaven.
EN.94: 'I was a lamb among the holy flock
EN.95: led by Dominic along the road
EN.96: where sheep are fattened if they do not stray.
EN.97: 'He that is nearest to me on the right
EN.98: was both my brother and my teacher --
EN.99: he, Albert of Cologne, I, Thomas of Aquino.
EN.100: 'If you would like to find out who the others are,
EN.101: follow, as I name them, with your eyes,
EN.102: turning up your gaze along the blessèd wreath.
EN.103: 'The next flame issues from the smile of Gratian,
EN.104: who served one and the other court so well
EN.105: his service now gives joy in Paradise.
EN.106: 'The next one to adorn our choir
EN.107: was the Peter who, like the poor widow,
EN.108: offered up his treasure to Holy Church.
EN.109: 'The fifth light, the most beautiful among us,
EN.110: breathes forth such love that all the world below
EN.111: is greedy to discover how his soul has fared.
EN.112: 'Within his light there dwells a lofty mind,
EN.113: its wisdom so profound, if truth is true,
EN.114: there never rose another of such vision.
EN.115: 'Next to him behold the flaming of the candle
EN.116: that in the flesh below saw farthest
EN.117: into the nature and the ministry of angels.
EN.118: 'In the other little light there
EN.119: smiles that defender of the Christian Church
EN.120: of whose account Augustine made good use.
EN.121: 'If the eye of your mind is being drawn
EN.122: from light to light, following my praises,
EN.123: you are already thirsting for the eighth.
EN.124: 'Within it rejoices, in his vision of all goodness,
EN.125: the holy soul who makes quite plain
EN.126: the world's deceit to one who listens well.
EN.127: 'The body from which it was driven out
EN.128: lies down there in Cieldauro, and he has risen
EN.129: from martyrdom and exile to this peace.
EN.130: 'See, blazing just beyond him, the fiery breath
EN.131: of Isidore, of Bede, and then of Richard,
EN.132: the last in contemplation more than human.
EN.133: 'This one, from whom your look comes back to me,
EN.134: is the light of a spirit to whom it seemed,
EN.135: in his grave meditation, that death came on too slow.
EN.136: 'It is the eternal light of Siger,
EN.137: who, instructing in the Street of Straw,
EN.138: demonstrated enviable truths.'
EN.139: Then, like a clock that calls us at the hour
EN.140: when the bride of God gets up to sing
EN.141: matins to her bridegroom, that he should love her still,
EN.142: when a cog pulls one wheel and drives another,
EN.143: chiming its ting-ting with notes so sweet
EN.144: that the willing spirit swells with love,
EN.145: thus I saw that glorious wheel in motion,
EN.146: matching voice to voice in harmony
EN.147: and with sweetness that cannot be known
EN.148: except where joy becomes eternal.

EN.1: O foolish cares of mortals, how flawed
EN.2: are all the arguments that make you flap
EN.3: your wings in downward flight
EN.4: One pursued the law, one the Hippocratic
EN.5: Aphorisms, while yet another sought
EN.6: the priesthood, and another, rule by force or fraud,
EN.7: one was set on plunder, one on the public weal,
EN.8: one wearied himself in the toils of flesh
EN.9: and its delights, another gave himself to idleness,
EN.10: while I, set free from all these things,
EN.11: was, high in heaven with Beatrice,
EN.12: thus gloriously received.
EN.13: When each flame had returned to the same point
EN.14: on the circle where it had stood before,
EN.15: it stopped, like a candle on its sconce,
EN.16: and now the light that had already spoken
EN.17: from deep within began again to speak,
EN.18: smiling and shining still more bright:
EN.19: 'Even as I reflect its radiant beams, so,
EN.20: gazing into the Eternal Light, I grasp
EN.21: your thoughts and the source of their beginnings.
EN.22: 'You are in doubt and would have me restate
EN.23: my words, to make them clear and plain,
EN.24: matching the level of your understanding,
EN.25: 'as when I said, "Where sheep are fattened,"
EN.26: as well as, "Nor was there ever born another."
EN.27: And here one needs to make a clear distinction.
EN.28: 'The providence that rules the world
EN.29: with such deep wisdom that any God-created eye
EN.30: must fail before it reaches to the very depth --
EN.31: 'so that the bride of Him who, crying out
EN.32: in a loud voice, espoused her with His sacred blood,
EN.33: should go in joy to her belovèd
EN.34: 'sure of herself and now to Him more faithful --
EN.35: ordained in her behalf two princes,
EN.36: one on this side, one on that, to serve as guides.
EN.37: 'One was all seraphic in his ardor,
EN.38: the other, by his wisdom, was on earth
EN.39: resplendent with cherubic light.
EN.40: 'I shall speak of one, since praising one,
EN.41: whichever one we choose, is to speak of both,
EN.42: for they labored to a single end.
EN.43: 'Between the Topino and the waters that descend
EN.44: down from the hilltop chosen by the blessèd Ubaldo
EN.45: there hangs a fertile slope from one high peak
EN.46: 'that makes Perugia feel both heat and cold
EN.47: at Porta Sole, while behind its other flank
EN.48: Gualdo and Nocera mourn their heavy yoke.
EN.49: 'From this slope, where it interrupts
EN.50: its steep descent, a sun rose on the world,
EN.51: as from the Ganges our sun sometimes does.
EN.52: 'Therefore, let anyone who would speak of this place
EN.53: not say Ascesi, which would convey too little,
EN.54: but call it Orient, to sound its proper worth.
EN.55: 'Not much time as yet had passed
EN.56: when he first lent his comfort to the earth
EN.57: by the greatness of his virtuous power.
EN.58: 'For, still a youth, he fought against his father's wish
EN.59: for the favor of a lady to whom, as to death,
EN.60: no one unlocks the door with gladness,
EN.61: 'and before his spiritual court et coram patre
EN.62: he joined himself to her and, from then on,
EN.63: each passing day, he loved her more.
EN.64: 'She, bereft of her first husband, scorned and unknown
EN.65: one thousand and one hundred years and more,
EN.66: remained without a suitor till he came.
EN.67: 'Nor did it profit her when men heard that she stood
EN.68: unmoved, with Amyclas, despite the voice
EN.69: of him who put the whole wide world in fear.
EN.70: 'Nor did it profit her when, being fiercely loyal
EN.71: and undaunted, while Mary stayed below,
EN.72: she wept with Christ upon the cross.
EN.73: 'But, lest I make my meaning dark,
EN.74: let it be understood, in all that I have said,
EN.75: that these two lovers are Francis and Poverty.
EN.76: 'Their happy countenances and their harmony,
EN.77: their love and wonder and sweet contemplation
EN.78: made them a cause for holy thoughts,
EN.79: 'so that the venerable Bernard was the first
EN.80: to shed his shoes and run, pursuing such great peace,
EN.81: and, running, thought himself too slow.
EN.82: 'O unknown riches and prolific good Barefoot goes Giles,
EN.83: barefoot goes Sylvester, following the groom,
EN.84: so greatly pleasing is the bride.
EN.85: 'Then that father and teacher went his way
EN.86: in company of his lady and that family,
EN.87: each one girt with the same humble cord.
EN.88: 'Nor did an unworthy shame weigh on his brow
EN.89: for being Pietro Bernardone's son,
EN.90: nor for being an object of amazed contempt,
EN.91: 'but he regally laid bare his stern resolve
EN.92: to Innocent and, from him, he received
EN.93: the first seal of his order.
EN.94: 'When his followers, sworn to poverty,
EN.95: increased their number, he, whose admirable life
EN.96: were better sung in the glorious realm of Heaven,
EN.97: 'was affirmed with a second crown
EN.98: by the eternal Breath, through Honorius,
EN.99: in his holy purpose as shepherd of this flock.
EN.100: 'And when, in his thirst for martyrdom,
EN.101: he preached Christ and the Apostles who came after
EN.102: in the proud presence of the Sultan,
EN.103: 'finding the people unripe for conversion
EN.104: and unwilling to remain to no good purpose,
EN.105: he returned to reap the harvest of Italian fields.
EN.106: 'On the harsh rock between the Tiber and the Arno
EN.107: from Christ he had the final seal, then for two years
EN.108: he bore His wounds upon his limbs.
EN.109: 'When He who had chosen him for so much good
EN.110: was pleased to take him to the high reward
EN.111: that he had won with his devoted meekness,
EN.112: 'he recommended his most cherished lady
EN.113: to his brothers, as to his rightful heirs,
EN.114: commanding them to love her faithfully.
EN.115: 'From his lady's bosom the illustrious soul
EN.116: chose to set forth, returning to its kingdom,
EN.117: and for its corpse would have no other bier.
EN.118: 'Now think what kind of man it took
EN.119: to be a fit companion to maintain
EN.120: the steadfast course of Peter's bark upon the sea,
EN.121: 'and just such was our patriarch. From this
EN.122: you may perceive that he who follows him
EN.123: as he commands is freighted with good cargo.
EN.124: 'But his flock has grown so greedy
EN.125: for new sustenance that it is forced
EN.126: to scatter through remote and distant pastures,
EN.127: 'and the farther his sheep go wandering off
EN.128: from him, the emptier of milk
EN.129: do they at last come back into the fold.
EN.130: 'There are some, indeed, who, fearing harm,
EN.131: huddle near the shepherd, but these are so few
EN.132: that a tiny piece of cloth can furnish all their cowls.
EN.133: 'And so, if my words are not too dark,
EN.134: and if your ears have been intent,
EN.135: and if you can recall exactly what was said,
EN.136: 'then shall your wish be in part fulfilled
EN.137: and you shall see the reason why the plant is cleft
EN.138: and what is meant by the rebuke
EN.139: where sheep are fattened if they do not stray.'

IT.56: de la fede cristiana, il santo atleta
IT.57: benigno a' suoi e a' nemici crudo;
IT.58: e come fu creata, fu repleta
IT.59: sì la sua mente di viva vertute,
IT.60: che, ne la madre, lei fece profeta.
IT.61: Poi che le sponsalizie fuor compiute
IT.62: al sacro fonte intra lui e la Fede,
IT.63: u' si dotar di mutüa salute,
IT.64: la donna che per lui l'assenso diede,
IT.65: vide nel sonno il mirabile frutto
IT.66: ch'uscir dovea di lui e de le rede;
IT.67: e perché fosse qual era in costrutto,
IT.68: quinci si mosse spirito a nomarlo
IT.69: del possessivo di cui era tutto.
IT.70: Domenico fu detto; e io ne parlo
IT.71: sì come de l'agricola che Cristo
IT.72: elesse a l'orto suo per aiutarlo.
IT.73: Ben parve messo e famigliar di Cristo:
IT.74: ché 'l primo amor che 'n lui fu manifesto,
IT.75: fu al primo consiglio che diè Cristo.
IT.76: Spesse fïate fu tacito e desto
IT.77: trovato in terra da la sua nutrice,
IT.78: come dicesse: 'Io son venuto a questo.'
IT.79: Oh padre suo veramente Felice!
IT.80: oh madre sua veramente Giovanna,
IT.81: se, interpretata, val come si dice!
IT.82: Non per lo mondo, per cui mo s'affanna
IT.83: di retro ad Ostïense e a Taddeo,
IT.84: ma per amor de la verace manna
IT.85: in picciol tempo gran dottor si feo;
IT.86: tal che si mise a circüir la vigna
IT.87: che tosto imbianca, se 'l vignaio è reo.
IT.88: E a la sedia che fu già benigna
IT.89: più a' poveri giusti, non per lei,
IT.90: ma per colui che siede, che traligna,
IT.91: non dispensare o due o tre per sei,
IT.92: non la fortuna di prima vacante,
IT.93: non decimas, quae sunt pauperum Dei,
IT.94: addimandò, ma contro al mondo errante
IT.95: licenza di combatter per lo seme
IT.96: del qual ti fascian ventiquattro piante.
IT.97: Poi, con dottrina e con volere insieme,
IT.98: con l'officio appostolico si mosse
IT.99: quasi torrente ch'alta vena preme;
IT.100: e ne li sterpi eretici percosse
IT.101: l'impeto suo, più vivamente quivi
IT.102: dove le resistenze eran più grosse.
IT.103: Di lui si fecer poi diversi rivi
IT.104: onde l'orto catolico si riga,
IT.105: sì che i suoi arbuscelli stan più vivi.
IT.106: Se tal fu l'una rota de la biga
IT.107: in che la Santa Chiesa si difese
IT.108: e vinse in campo la sua civil briga,
IT.109: ben ti dovrebbe assai esser palese
IT.110: l'eccellenza de l'altra, di cui Tomma
IT.111: dinanzi al mio venir fu sì cortese.
IT.112: Ma l'orbita che fé la parte somma
IT.113: di sua circunferenza, è derelitta,
IT.114: sì ch'è la muffa dov' era la gromma.
IT.115: La sua famiglia, che si mosse dritta
IT.116: coi piedi a le sue orme, è tanto volta,
IT.117: che quel dinanzi a quel di retro gitta;
IT.118: e tosto si vedrà de la ricolta
IT.119: de la mala coltura, quando il loglio
IT.120: si lagnerà che l'arca li sia tolta.
IT.121: Ben dico, chi cercasse a foglio a foglio
IT.122: nostro volume, ancor troveria carta
IT.123: u' leggerebbe 'I' mi son quel ch'i' soglio';
IT.124: ma non fia da Casal né d'Acquasparta,
IT.125: là onde vegnon tali a la scrittura,
IT.126: ch'uno la fugge e altro la coarta.
IT.127: Io son la vita di Bonaventura
IT.128: da Bagnoregio, che ne' grandi offici
IT.129: sempre pospuosi la sinistra cura.
IT.130: Illuminato e Augustin son quici,
IT.131: che fuor de' primi scalzi poverelli
IT.132: che nel capestro a Dio si fero amici.
IT.133: Ugo da San Vittore è qui con elli,
IT.134: e Pietro Mangiadore e Pietro Spano,
IT.135: lo qual giù luce in dodici libelli;
IT.136: Natàn profeta e 'l metropolitano
IT.137: Crisostomo e Anselmo e quel Donato
IT.138: ch'a la prim' arte degnò porre mano.
IT.139: Rabano è qui, e lucemi dallato
IT.140: il calavrese abate Giovacchino
IT.141: di spirito profetico dotato.
IT.142: Ad inveggiar cotanto paladino
IT.143: mi mosse l'infiammata cortesia
IT.144: di fra Tommaso e 'l discreto latino;
IT.145: e mosse meco questa compagnia."

EN.1: As soon as the blessèd flame
EN.2: had spoken its last word
EN.3: the holy millstone once again began to wheel,
EN.4: and had not yet come full around
EN.5: before another circle closed it in,
EN.6: matching it motion for motion and song for song,
EN.7: song that, heard from such sweet instruments,
EN.8: as far excels our muses and our sirens
EN.9: as a first shining its reflected rays.
EN.10: As twin rainbows, parallel in shape and color,
EN.11: arc in their pathway through translucent clouds
EN.12: when Juno gives the order to her handmaid --
EN.13: the outer one born of the inner,
EN.14: like the voice of that wandering nymph
EN.15: whom love consumed as the sun does vapors --
EN.16: and allow the people here on earth to know the future
EN.17: because of the covenant God made with Noah,
EN.18: that the world would not again be flooded,
EN.19: so the two wreaths of those eternal roses
EN.20: circled all around us and, thus reflected,
EN.21: the outer circle shone in answer to the inner.
EN.22: When the dance and all the other celebration --
EN.23: the singing and the brilliant blaze of flames,
EN.24: light with light blent in ardent joy --
EN.25: came to a stop together and of one accord,
EN.26: as eyes, when beauty moves them,
EN.27: must open wide or close as one,
EN.28: from the core of one of these new lights,
EN.29: as the north star makes a compass needle veer,
EN.30: rose a voice that made me turn to where it came from.
EN.31: And it began: 'The love that makes me beautiful
EN.32: bids me, in turn, to laud that other leader
EN.33: because of whom my own has won such praise.
EN.34: 'It is fitting that, in naming one, we name the other
EN.35: so that, just as they were joined as one in combat
EN.36: with a single goal, their fame should shine as one.
EN.37: 'Rearmed at such high cost, the troops of Christ
EN.38: moved with halting steps behind the standard,
EN.39: full of doubt and few in number,
EN.40: 'when the Emperor who reigns forever
EN.41: provided for His soldiers in their peril --
EN.42: only of His grace, not for their merit --
EN.43: 'and, as was said, gave comfort to His bride
EN.44: through these two champions, whose deeds and words
EN.45: brought together the scattered people.
EN.46: 'In that place where gentle Zephyr's breath
EN.47: rises to open the unfolding leaves
EN.48: in which Europe sees herself reclad,
EN.49: 'not far from the pounding waves
EN.50: beyond which the sun, having finished his long course,
EN.51: sometimes hides himself from human sight,
EN.52: 'favored Calaroga lies
EN.53: behind the shelter of the noble shield
EN.54: that shows one lion in defeat and one in triumph.
EN.55: 'In that town was born the amorous lover
EN.56: of the Christian faith, the holy athlete,
EN.57: gentle to his own and savage to his foes.
EN.58: 'His mind, at the moment of its making,
EN.59: was so full of living power that,
EN.60: yet in his mother's womb, he made of her a prophet.
EN.61: 'After his nuptials with the Faith
EN.62: were celebrated at the holy font
EN.63: at which each dowered the other's safety,
EN.64: 'the lady who offered her assent for his
EN.65: saw in a dream the admirable fruit
EN.66: destined to spring from him and from his heirs.
EN.67: 'And, that he might be known as what he was indeed,
EN.68: a spirit from Heaven came and named him
EN.69: from the possessive form of Him whose he already was.
EN.70: 'He was called Dominic, and I shall speak of him
EN.71: as that laborer chosen by Christ
EN.72: to help Him dress and keep His garden.
EN.73: 'He seemed indeed a messenger and intimate of Christ,
EN.74: since the first affection manifest in him
EN.75: was for the initial precept taught by Christ.
EN.76: 'Many a time did his nurse find him
EN.77: awake and silent on the ground,
EN.78: as if he said, "It is for this I have come."
EN.79: 'O happy father, indeed Felix!
EN.80: O blessèd mother, indeed Giovanna,
EN.81: if, rightly construed, her name means what they say!
EN.82: 'Not for this world, for which men toil today,
EN.83: following Taddeo and the Ostian,
EN.84: but for love of the true manna,
EN.85: 'he soon became a teacher so renowned
EN.86: that he began to travel through the vineyard,
EN.87: which quickly withers if the keeper is corrupt.
EN.88: 'And to the papal seat, not now as benevolent
EN.89: to the upright poor as it was once -- not flawed in itself,
EN.90: but degenerate in its occupant -- he made appeal,
EN.91: 'not to give away just two or three instead of six,
EN.92: not for his chance at the first vacancy,
EN.93: not for the decimas, quae sunt pauperum Dei,
EN.94: 'but for the privilege of fighting
EN.95: against the errors of the world, thus to preserve the seed
EN.96: of the twenty-four plants now wreathing you in light.
EN.97: 'Then, both with learning and with zeal,
EN.98: secure in apostolic office, he went forth,
EN.99: like a torrent gushing from its lofty source,
EN.100: 'and fell upon the tangled weeds of heresy,
EN.101: attacking with his overwhelming force
EN.102: wherever the resistance was most stubborn.
EN.103: 'From him there sprang still other streams
EN.104: from which the Catholic garden draws its moisture,
EN.105: so that its saplings grow with greater vigor.
EN.106: 'If such was one of the wheels of the chariot
EN.107: used by Holy Church in self-defense
EN.108: to overcome the rebels in the field,
EN.109: 'surely the excellence of that other,
EN.110: about whom Thomas spoke so courteously
EN.111: before I came, must be well known to you.
EN.112: 'But the track left by the outer rim
EN.113: of its circumference is abandoned,
EN.114: so that where once was crust, there now is mold.
EN.115: 'His family, which started out setting their feet
EN.116: upon his footprints, is now turned backward,
EN.117: setting their toes where once they placed their heels.
EN.118: 'Soon that harvest of bad tillage
EN.119: shall occur, when the tares complain
EN.120: that the barn is shut against them.
EN.121: 'I readily admit that, should one search our volume
EN.122: leaf by leaf, one still could find some pages
EN.123: where one might read, "What once I was, I am."
EN.124: 'But these will not come from Casale or Acquasparta,
EN.125: for those from there come to the Rule
EN.126: either to flee it or constrict it further.
EN.127: 'I am the living soul of Bonaventura
EN.128: from Bagnoregio, who in great office
EN.129: ever put last the left-hand care.
EN.130: 'Here are Illuminato and Augustine,
EN.131: among the first brothers barefoot in poverty,
EN.132: who, with the cord, became God's friends.
EN.133: 'Here with them is Hugh of St. Victor,
EN.134: Peter the Bookworm, and Peter the Spaniard --
EN.135: who casts light from his twelve books below,
EN.136: 'Nathan the prophet, Chrysostom
EN.137: the Metropolitan, Anselm, and that Donatus
EN.138: who, to the first art, deigned to set his hand.
EN.139: 'Rabanus is here and, shining at my side,
EN.140: abbot Joachim of Calabria,
EN.141: who was endowed with prophetic spirit.
EN.142: 'To sing the praises of so great a champion
EN.143: the ardent courtesy and fitting discourse
EN.144: of Brother Thomas has inspired me
EN.145: and did the same to my companions.'

IT.1: Imagini, chi bene intender cupe
IT.2: quel ch'i' or vidi -- e ritegna l'image,
IT.3: mentre ch'io dico, come ferma rupe --,
IT.4: quindici stelle che 'n diverse plage
IT.5: lo cielo avvivan di tanto sereno
IT.6: che soperchia de l'aere ogne compage;
IT.7: imagini quel carro a cu' il seno
IT.8: basta del nostro cielo e notte e giorno,
IT.9: sì ch'al volger del temo non vien meno;
IT.10: imagini la bocca di quel corno
IT.11: che si comincia in punta de lo stelo
IT.12: a cui la prima rota va dintorno,
IT.13: aver fatto di sé due segni in cielo,
IT.14: qual fece la figliuola di Minoi
IT.15: allora che sentì di morte il gelo;
IT.16: e l'un ne l'altro aver li raggi suoi,
IT.17: e amendue girarsi per maniera
IT.18: che l'uno andasse al primo e l'altro al poi;
IT.19: e avrà quasi l'ombra de la vera
IT.20: costellazione e de la doppia danza
IT.21: che circulava il punto dov' io era:
IT.22: poi ch'è tanto di là da nostra usanza,
IT.23: quanto di là dal mover de la Chiana
IT.24: si move il ciel che tutti li altri avanza.
IT.25: Lì si cantò non Bacco, non Peana,
IT.26: ma tre persone in divina natura,
IT.27: e in una persona essa e l'umana.
IT.28: Compié 'l cantare e 'l volger sua misura;
IT.29: e attesersi a noi quei santi lumi,
IT.30: felicitando sé di cura in cura.
IT.31: Ruppe il silenzio ne' concordi numi
IT.32: poscia la luce in che mirabil vita
IT.33: del poverel di Dio narrata fumi,
IT.34: e disse: "Quando l'una paglia è trita,
IT.35: quando la sua semenza è già riposta,
IT.36: a batter l'altra dolce amor m'invita.
IT.37: Tu credi che nel petto onde la costa
IT.38: si trasse per formar la bella guancia
IT.39: il cui palato a tutto 'l mondo costa,
IT.40: e in quel che, forato da la lancia,
IT.41: e prima e poscia tanto sodisfece,
IT.42: che d'ogne colpa vince la bilancia,
IT.43: quantunque a la natura umana lece
IT.44: aver di lume, tutto fosse infuso
IT.45: da quel valor che l'uno e l'altro fece;
IT.46: e però miri a ciò ch'io dissi suso,
IT.47: quando narrai che non ebbe 'l secondo
IT.48: lo ben che ne la quinta luce è chiuso.
IT.49: Or apri li occhi a quel ch'io ti rispondo,
IT.50: e vedräi il tuo credere e 'l mio dire
IT.51: nel vero farsi come centro in tondo.
IT.52: Ciò che non more e ciò che può morire
IT.53: non è se non splendor di quella idea
IT.54: che partorisce, amando, il nostro Sire;
IT.55: ché quella viva luce che sì mea
IT.56: dal suo lucente, che non si disuna
IT.57: da lui né da l'amor ch'a lor s'intrea,
IT.58: per sua bontate il suo raggiare aduna,
IT.59: quasi specchiato, in nove sussistenze,
IT.60: etternalmente rimanendosi una.
IT.61: Quindi discende a l'ultime potenze
IT.62: giù d'atto in atto, tanto divenendo,
IT.63: che più non fa che brevi contingenze;
IT.64: e queste contingenze essere intendo
IT.65: le cose generate, che produce
IT.66: con seme e sanza seme il ciel movendo.
IT.67: La cera di costoro e chi la duce
IT.68: non sta d'un modo; e però sotto 'l segno
IT.69: idëale poi più e men traluce.
IT.70: Ond' elli avvien ch'un medesimo legno,
IT.71: secondo specie, meglio e peggio frutta;
IT.72: e voi nascete con diverso ingegno.
IT.73: Se fosse a punto la cera dedutta
IT.74: e fosse il cielo in sua virtù supprema,
IT.75: la luce del suggel parrebbe tutta;
IT.76: ma la natura la dà sempre scema,
IT.77: similemente operando a l'artista
IT.78: ch'a l'abito de l'arte ha man che trema.
IT.79: Però se 'l caldo amor la chiara vista
IT.80: de la prima virtù dispone e segna,
IT.81: tutta la perfezion quivi s'acquista.
IT.82: Così fu fatta già la terra degna
IT.83: di tutta l'animal perfezïone;
IT.84: così fu fatta la Vergine pregna;
IT.85: sì ch'io commendo tua oppinïone,
IT.86: che l'umana natura mai non fue
IT.87: né fia qual fu in quelle due persone.
IT.88: Or s'i' non procedesse avanti piùe,
IT.89: 'Dunque, come costui fu sanza pare?'
IT.90: comincerebber le parole tue.
IT.91: Ma perché paia ben ciò che non pare,
IT.92: pensa chi era, e la cagion che 'l mosse,
IT.93: quando fu detto 'Chiedi,' a dimandare.
IT.94: Non ho parlato sì, che tu non posse
IT.95: ben veder ch'el fu re, che chiese senno
IT.96: acciò che re sufficïente fosse;
IT.97: non per sapere il numero in che enno
IT.98: li motor di qua sù, o se necesse
IT.99: con contingente mai necesse fenno;
IT.100: non si est dare primum motum esse,
IT.101: o se del mezzo cerchio far si puote
IT.102: trïangol sì ch'un retto non avesse.
IT.103: Onde, se ciò ch'io dissi e questo note,
IT.104: regal prudenza è quel vedere impari
IT.105: in che lo stral di mia intenzion percuote;
IT.106: e se al "surse" drizzi li occhi chiari,
IT.107: vedrai aver solamente respetto
IT.108: ai regi, che son molti, e ' buon son rari.
IT.109: Con questa distinzion prendi 'l mio detto;
IT.110: e così puote star con quel che credi
IT.111: del primo padre e del nostro Diletto.
IT.112: E questo ti sia sempre piombo a' piedi,
IT.113: per farti mover lento com' uom lasso
IT.114: e al sì e al no che tu non vedi:
IT.115: ché quelli è tra li stolti bene a basso,
IT.116: che sanza distinzione afferma e nega
IT.117: ne l'un così come ne l'altro passo;
IT.118: perch' elli 'ncontra che più volte piega
IT.119: l'oppinïon corrente in falsa parte,
IT.120: e poi l'affetto l'intelletto lega.
IT.121: Vie più che 'ndarno da riva si parte,
IT.122: perché non torna tal qual e' si move,
IT.123: chi pesca per lo vero e non ha l'arte.
IT.124: E di ciò sono al mondo aperte prove
IT.125: Parmenide, Melisso e Brisso e molti,
IT.126: li quali andaro e non sapëan dove;
IT.127: sì fé Sabellio e Arrio e quelli stolti
IT.128: che furon come spade a le Scritture
IT.129: in render torti li diritti volti.
IT.130: Non sien le genti, ancor, troppo sicure
IT.131: a giudicar, sì come quei che stima
IT.132: le biade in campo pria che sien mature;
IT.133: ch'i' ho veduto tutto 'l verno prima
IT.134: lo prun mostrarsi rigido e feroce,
IT.135: poscia portar la rosa in su la cima;
IT.136: e legno vidi già dritto e veloce
IT.137: correr lo mar per tutto suo cammino,
IT.138: perire al fine a l'intrar de la foce.
IT.139: Non creda donna Berta e ser Martino,
IT.140: per vedere un furare, altro offerere,
IT.141: vederli dentro al consiglio divino;
IT.142: ché quel può surgere, e quel può cadere."

EN.1: Let him, who would fully understand
EN.2: what I now saw, imagine -- and let him, while I speak,
EN.3: hold that image, steady as a rock --
EN.4: fifteen stars that light up various regions
EN.5: of the sky, and with such brightness
EN.6: as to overcome the intervening haze.
EN.7: Let him imagine the Wain, nestling
EN.8: in the bosom of our sky both night and day
EN.9: so that its wheeling shaft is never out of sight.
EN.10: Let him imagine the mouth of that horn
EN.11: descending from the axle's endpoint
EN.12: around which the first wheel revolves,
EN.13: and all these seen together to have formed, up in the sky,
EN.14: a double constellation, like the ring once formed
EN.15: of Minos' daughter when she felt the chill of death,
EN.16: the rays of one reflected in the other,
EN.17: with both revolving in such manner
EN.18: that one went first and then the other followed.
EN.19: Then he will have, as it were, the shadow
EN.20: of the true constellation and the double dance
EN.21: that wheeled around the point where I now was,
EN.22: for it is as far beyond our understanding
EN.23: as the speed of the heaven that exceeds all others
EN.24: outstrips the muddy stirrings of the Chiana.
EN.25: There they sang the praises not of Bacchus nor of Paean
EN.26: but praised the divine nature in three Persons,
EN.27: and in one Person sang that nature joined with man.
EN.28: Having done the measure of their song and circling dance,
EN.29: these holy lights turned toward us,
EN.30: rejoicing as they passed from task to task.
EN.31: The silence among those holy souls in harmony
EN.32: was broken by the light that had told me
EN.33: the wondrous life of the poor man of God.
EN.34: He said: 'Now that one sheaf is threshed
EN.35: and its grain now gathered,
EN.36: sweet charity bids me thresh the other.
EN.37: 'You believe that, into the side from which
EN.38: the rib was drawn to form the lovely features
EN.39: of her whose palate costs the world so dear,
EN.40: 'and into His, pierced by the spear, which gave
EN.41: such satisfaction for sins, both done or yet to be,
EN.42: as outweighs any fault found in the balance,
EN.43: 'all the light that is allowed to human nature
EN.44: was infused by the very Power
EN.45: which made the one and made the other.
EN.46: 'And thus you marvel at what I said before,
EN.47: when I told you that the goodness
EN.48: contained in the fifth light never had an equal.
EN.49: 'Open your eyes to the answer I shall give
EN.50: and you shall find your thoughts and what I say
EN.51: meet at the truth as in the center of a circle.
EN.52: 'That which does not die and that which must
EN.53: are nothing but a bright reflection of that Idea
EN.54: which our Lord, in loving, brings to birth.
EN.55: 'For that living Light, which so streams forth
EN.56: from its shining Source that it neither parts from it
EN.57: nor from the Love that is intrined with them,
EN.58: 'of its own goodness gathers its own shining,
EN.59: as though it were a mirror, in nine subsistences,
EN.60: and yet eternally endures as one.
EN.61: 'From that height light descends to the lowest elements,
EN.62: passing down from act to act, becoming such
EN.63: that it produces nothing more than brief contingencies.
EN.64: 'By these contingent things I mean
EN.65: things generated, with seed or without,
EN.66: produced by the movements of the heavens.
EN.67: 'Their wax and that which molds it vary so
EN.68: that, beneath the Idea's imprint,
EN.69: light shines in varying degrees.
EN.70: And so it happens that trees of the very same kind
EN.71: bear fruit, some of it better and some of it worse,
EN.72: and that you are born with differing talents.
EN.73: 'If the wax were perfectly prepared
EN.74: and the heaven at the height of its power,
EN.75: in all its brightness would the seal be seen.
EN.76: 'But nature always fashions it defective,
EN.77: working like the craftsman who, to the practice
EN.78: of his craft, brings an unsteady hand.
EN.79: 'However, if the clear vision of the primal Power
EN.80: is moved by burning Love and makes of that its seal,
EN.81: then all perfection is attained in it.
EN.82: 'In that way was the dust made ready to receive --
EN.83: once -- perfection in a living creature,
EN.84: in that way was the Virgin made to be with child.
EN.85: 'Thus do I agree with your opinion
EN.86: that human nature never was -- nor shall it be --
EN.87: what it was in these two creatures.
EN.88: 'Now, if I went no farther,
EN.89: "How, then, was that other without equal?"
EN.90: would be the first words from your mouth.
EN.91: 'But, to make quite clear what still remains obscure,
EN.92: think who he was and what it was that moved him
EN.93: to his request when he was bidden "Ask."
EN.94: 'I did not speak so darkly that you cannot see
EN.95: he was a king and asked for wisdom
EN.96: that he might become a worthy king.
EN.97: 'He did not ask to know the number of the angels
EN.98: here above, nor if necesse
EN.99: with a contingent ever made necesse,
EN.100: 'nor si est dare primum motum esse,
EN.101: nor if in a semicircle a triangle can be formed
EN.102: without its having one right angle.
EN.103: 'Therefore, if you reflect on this and what I said,
EN.104: kingly prudence is that peerless vision
EN.105: on which the arrow of my purpose strikes.
EN.106: 'And if you examine my use of "rose" with open eyes,
EN.107: you will see that it referred alone to kings --
EN.108: of whom there are so many, but the good ones rare.
EN.109: 'Take my words, along with this distinction,
EN.110: and they can stand alongside your beliefs
EN.111: concerning the first father and the One we love.
EN.112: 'And let this always be as lead upon your feet
EN.113: to make you slow, just like a weary man, in moving,
EN.114: whether to yes or no, unless you see both clearly.
EN.115: 'For he ranks low among the fools
EN.116: who, without making clear distinctions,
EN.117: affirms or denies in one case or another,
EN.118: 'since it often happens that a hasty opinion
EN.119: inclines one to the erring side, and then
EN.120: fondness for it fetters the working of the mind.
EN.121: 'He who casts off from shore to fish for truth
EN.122: without the necessary skill does not return the same
EN.123: as he sets out, but worse, and all in vain.
EN.124: 'Clear proof of this was given to the world
EN.125: by Parmenides, Melissus, Bryson, and others,
EN.126: who went to sea without a port in mind.
EN.127: 'Such were Sabellius and Arius and the fools
EN.128: who misread Scripture as a sword reflecting
EN.129: the distorted image of a face upon its blade.
EN.130: 'Let the people, then, not be too certain
EN.131: in their judgments, like those that harvest in their minds
EN.132: corn still in the field before it ripens.
EN.133: 'For I have seen the briar first look dry and thorny
EN.134: right through all the winter's cold,
EN.135: then later wear the bloom of roses at its tip,
EN.136: 'and once I saw a ship, which had sailed straight
EN.137: and swift upon the sea through all its voyage,
EN.138: sinking at the end as it made its way to port.
EN.139: 'Let not Dame Bertha and Master Martin,
EN.140: when they see one steal and another offer alms,
EN.141: think that they behold them with God's wisdom,
EN.142: for the first may still rise up, the other fall.'

EN.1: From center to rim, as from rim to center,
EN.2: the water in a rounded vessel moves
EN.3: as it is struck from outside or within.
EN.4: This thought, just as I phrase it,
EN.5: dropped into my mind the very instant
EN.6: the glorious living soul of Thomas fell silent,
EN.7: because of the like effects that sprang
EN.8: from his speech and from the words of Beatrice,
EN.9: who, responding, graciously began:
EN.10: 'This man has need, but does not tell of it
EN.11: either by word or yet in thought,
EN.12: because he seeks the root of still another truth.
EN.13: 'Tell him if the light that blooms
EN.14: and makes your substance radiant shall remain
EN.15: with you eternally the way it shines today,
EN.16: 'and, if it remains, tell him how,
EN.17: when all of you are visible once more,
EN.18: this would not prove distressing to your sight.'
EN.19: As, impelled and drawn by heightened joy,
EN.20: dancers in a round may raise their voices,
EN.21: their pleasure showing in their movements,
EN.22: so, at that eager and devout appeal,
EN.23: the holy circles showed new joy in wheeling
EN.24: as well as in their wondrous song.
EN.25: Whoever here on earth laments that we must die
EN.26: to find our life above knows not the fresh relief
EN.27: found there in these eternal showers.
EN.28: That ever-living One and Two and Three
EN.29: who reigns forever in Three and Two and One,
EN.30: uncircumscribed and circumscribing all,
EN.31: was sung three times by each and every one
EN.32: of these spirits, and with such melody
EN.33: as would be fit reward for any merit.
EN.34: And I heard in the most resplendent light
EN.35: of the lesser circle a modest voice,
EN.36: such perhaps as the angel's was to Mary,
EN.37: reply: 'Just as long as the festival of Paradise
EN.38: shall last, that is how long our love
EN.39: shall dress us in this radiance.
EN.40: 'Its brightness answers to our ardor,
EN.41: the ardor to our vision, and that is given
EN.42: in greater measure of grace than we deserve.
EN.43: 'When we put on again our flesh,
EN.44: glorified and holy, then our persons
EN.45: will be more pleasing for being all complete,
EN.46: 'so that the light, granted to us freely
EN.47: by the Highest Good, shall increase,
EN.48: the light that makes us fit to see Him.
EN.49: 'From that light, vision must increase,
EN.50: and love increase what vision kindles,
EN.51: and radiance increase, which comes from love.
EN.52: 'But like a coal that shoots out flame
EN.53: and in its glowing center still outshines it
EN.54: so that it does not lose its own appearance,
EN.55: 'just so this splendor that enfolds us now
EN.56: will be surpassed in brightness by the flesh
EN.57: that earth as yet still covers.
EN.58: 'Nor will such shining have the power to harm us,
EN.59: for our body's organs shall be strengthened
EN.60: to deal with all that can delight us.'
EN.61: So quick and eager seemed to me both choirs
EN.62: to say their Amen that they clearly showed
EN.63: their desire for their dead bodies,
EN.64: not perhaps for themselves alone, but for their mothers,
EN.65: for their fathers, and for others whom they loved
EN.66: before they all became eternal flames.
EN.67: And lo, all around and all of equal brightness,
EN.68: rose a splendor, surpassing what had been,
EN.69: as the horizon, at the rising sun, grows brighter.
EN.70: And just as, at the approach of evening,
EN.71: new lights begin to show throughout the sky,
EN.72: so faint they seem both real and yet unreal,
EN.73: it seemed to me that I began to see
EN.74: new subsistences there that formed a ring
EN.75: beyond the other two circumferences.
EN.76: Ah, true incandescence of the Holy Breath!
EN.77: How suddenly its glowing shone before me,
EN.78: so bright my eyes could not endure it!
EN.79: But Beatrice showed herself to me so fair
EN.80: and smiling, this vision of her must remain
EN.81: among those sights that have escaped my memory.
EN.82: At this my eyes regained their sight and, raising them,
EN.83: I saw myself translated, alone now with my lady,
EN.84: to a more exalted state of bliss.
EN.85: I was assured that I had risen higher
EN.86: by the planet's fiery smile. It seemed to me
EN.87: to glow more red than usual.
EN.88: With all my heart and in that tongue
EN.89: which is the same for all, I made
EN.90: burnt-offering to God befitting the new grace.
EN.91: And the burning of the sacrifice
EN.92: had not yet finished in my breast before I knew
EN.93: my offering was propitious and accepted,
EN.94: for splendors of such brightness, glowing red,
EN.95: appeared to me within two beams that I cried out:
EN.96: 'O Helios, who so adorn them!'
EN.97: As the Milky Way, arrayed with greater and lesser lights,
EN.98: glows white between the universal poles,
EN.99: making even sages wonder how and why,
EN.100: these rays, thus constellated, made, deep within Mars,
EN.101: the venerable sign that the crossing
EN.102: of its quadrants fixes in a circle.
EN.103: Here my memory outstrips my skill,
EN.104: for that cross so flamed forth Christ
EN.105: that I can find no fit comparison.
EN.106: But he who takes his cross and follows Christ
EN.107: shall yet forgive me what I leave untold,
EN.108: for shining in that dawn I did see Christ.
EN.109: From arm to arm, and between the head
EN.110: and foot, moved brilliant lights
EN.111: that scintillated as they met and passed.
EN.112: Just so we see on earth, straight and slanting,
EN.113: swift and slow, changing in appearance,
EN.114: tiny motes of matter, long and short,
EN.115: move through the beam of light that sometimes streaks
EN.116: the shades that men devise for their protection
EN.117: both with cunning and with skill.
EN.118: And as viol and harp strung with many strings
EN.119: in their harmony will sound sweet
EN.120: even to one who fails to catch their tune,
EN.121: so from the lights that there appeared to me
EN.122: a melody gathered and came from the cross,
EN.123: enchanting me, though I could not make out the hymn.
EN.124: I could tell that it contained high praise,
EN.125: for the words 'Arise' and 'Conquer' came to me
EN.126: as to one who hears but does not understand.
EN.127: I was moved to such great love by this
EN.128: that up until that moment I had not been bound
EN.129: by chains so sweet and gentle.
EN.130: My words, perhaps, may seem too bold,
EN.131: slighting the beauty of those lovely eyes --
EN.132: gazing into them my longing finds repose.
EN.133: But one who understands that the living seals
EN.134: of all that's beautiful gain potency with each ascent
EN.135: and that I had not turned to her eyes there
EN.136: may excuse me for that of which, accusing myself,
EN.137: I make my excuse and see that I speak the truth:
EN.138: for holy beauty may not be excluded here
EN.139: because, as it ascends, it gains in purity.
