IT.136: Moronto fu mio frate ed Eliseo;
IT.137: mia donna venne a me di val di Pado,
IT.138: e quindi il sopranome tuo si feo.
IT.139: Poi seguitai lo 'mperador Currado;
IT.140: ed el mi cinse de la sua milizia,
IT.141: tanto per bene ovrar li venni in grado.
IT.142: Dietro li andai incontro a la nequizia
IT.143: di quella legge il cui popolo usurpa,
IT.144: per colpa d'i pastor, vostra giustizia.
IT.145: Quivi fu' io da quella gente turpa
IT.146: disviluppato dal mondo fallace,
IT.147: lo cui amor molt'anime deturpa;
IT.148: e venni dal martiro a questa pace."

EN.1: Benevolent will, in which a righteous love
EN.2: whose breath is true must always show itself,
EN.3: as does cupidity within an evil will,
EN.4: had silenced the sweet-sounding lyre
EN.5: and hushed the sacred strings that Heaven's right hand
EN.6: loosens and draws taut.
EN.7: How can they be deaf to righteous prayers,
EN.8: the very spirits who, to prompt my prayers,
EN.9: fell silent as with one accord?
EN.10: It is well that endless be his grief
EN.11: who, for love of things that do not last,
EN.12: casts off a love that never dies.
EN.13: As through the clear and tranquil evening sky
EN.14: from time to time a sudden fire will shoot,
EN.15: drawing the eyes that just before had calmly gazed,
EN.16: and seems a star escaping from its place --
EN.17: except from where it first was kindled
EN.18: no star is missing and it lasts but a brief while --
EN.19: so from the arm of that great cross
EN.20: extending on the right a star raced to the foot
EN.21: of the resplendent constellation there.
EN.22: Nor did this jewel leave its ribbon,
EN.23: but ran along the shining band so that
EN.24: it seemed a flame that glows in alabaster.
EN.25: With such affection did Anchises' shade reach out,
EN.26: if our greatest muse is owed belief,
EN.27: when in Elysium he knew his son.
EN.28: 'O sanguis meus, o superinfusa
EN.29: gratïa Deï, sicut tibi cui
EN.30: bis unquam celi ianüa reclusa?'
EN.31: Thus spoke that light. And I gave heed,
EN.32: then turned my eyes back to my lady --
EN.33: whichever way I looked I was amazed,
EN.34: for there glowed such a smile within her eyes
EN.35: I thought that with my own I had attained
EN.36: my ultimate bliss, my final paradise.
EN.37: Then, a joy to hear and a joy to see,
EN.38: the spirit added to what first he said
EN.39: words so profound I could not understand them.
EN.40: Nor did he hide his thoughts from me by choice
EN.41: but by necessity, for his conceptions
EN.42: were set beyond our mortal limit.
EN.43: And when his bow of ardent love
EN.44: relaxed enough to let his speech descend
EN.45: down toward the limits of our intellect,
EN.46: the first thing I could understand was:
EN.47: 'May you be blessed, Threefold and One,
EN.48: who show such favor to my seed!'
EN.49: And he went on: 'That long and welcome craving,
EN.50: derived from reading in the massive book
EN.51: where neither black nor white is ever altered,
EN.52: 'you have satisfied, my son, within this light
EN.53: from which I speak to you by grace of her
EN.54: who dressed you out in wings for this high flight.
EN.55: 'You think your thoughts flow into mine through Him
EN.56: who is the First, as from the number one
EN.57: will radiate the five and six, if one is known.
EN.58: 'For that reason you do not ask me who I am
EN.59: nor why I seem to you more filled with joy
EN.60: than any other in this happy throng.
EN.61: 'And you are right, for the humble and the mighty
EN.62: up here in this life gaze into the mirror
EN.63: in which, before you think them, thoughts shine clear.
EN.64: 'But, that the sacred love, which keeps me watching
EN.65: with enduring vision and makes me thirst
EN.66: with sweet desire, may be more happily fulfilled,
EN.67: 'let your voice resound sure, bold, and joyful,
EN.68: to proclaim the will, proclaim the desire,
EN.69: for which my answer is already set.'
EN.70: I turned to Beatrice, who had heard
EN.71: before I spoke and smiled a sign
EN.72: that made my will put forth its wings.
EN.73: And I began: 'Love and intelligence,
EN.74: once the prime Equality appeared to you,
EN.75: then became yours in equal measure,
EN.76: 'since that Sun that lit your way and made you warm
EN.77: distributes both its heat and light so evenly
EN.78: that all comparisons fall short.
EN.79: 'But for mortals, as you well know,
EN.80: the will to act and the power to carry through
EN.81: have wings that are not feathered equally,
EN.82: 'so that I, who am mortal, feel in myself
EN.83: this inequality and thus can only offer thanks
EN.84: for your paternal welcome with my heart.
EN.85: 'But I implore you, living topaz
EN.86: set into this priceless ornament,
EN.87: that you reward my longing with your name.'
EN.88: 'O bough of my tree, in whom I have rejoiced
EN.89: even in expectation, I was your root.'
EN.90: Such was the preface of his words to me.
EN.91: Then: 'He from whom your house derives its name
EN.92: and who for a hundred years and more
EN.93: has circled the mountain on its lowest bank
EN.94: 'was your great-grandfather and my son.
EN.95: It is most fitting that you shorten
EN.96: his long and weary labor with your prayers.
EN.97: 'Florence, within the circle of her ancient walls
EN.98: from which she still hears tierce and nones,
EN.99: dwelled then in peace, temperate and chaste.
EN.100: 'No bracelet, no tiara did she wear,
EN.101: no embroidered gown, no waistband
EN.102: more striking to the eye than was its wearer.
EN.103: 'Nor did a new-born daughter make her father fear,
EN.104: for marriage age and dowry were not yet extreme,
EN.105: the one too low, the other one too high.
EN.106: 'No houses then stood uninhabited,
EN.107: nor had Sardanapalus as yet arrived
EN.108: to show what might be done behind closed doors.
EN.109: 'Not yet did your Uccellatoio surpass
EN.110: in splendor Montemario but, exceeding
EN.111: in its rise, it shall surpass it in its fall.
EN.112: 'I saw Bellincion Berti wear a belt of leather
EN.113: and plain bone, and saw his lady step back
EN.114: from the glass, her face untouched by paint.
EN.115: 'And I saw one of the Nerli and a del Vecchio
EN.116: both content with wearing simple, unlined skins,
EN.117: their ladies busy with their spindles and their flax.
EN.118: 'O fortunate women! Each knew for certain
EN.119: where she would be buried, nor was any yet
EN.120: forsaken in her bed at France's call.
EN.121: 'One kept eager watch upon the cradle,
EN.122: using sounds and words that first delight
EN.123: fathers and mothers when they soothe their child.
EN.124: 'Another, while drawing the wool from its spool,
EN.125: would delight her household with the tales
EN.126: of Troy, Fiesole, and Rome.
EN.127: 'A Cianghella or a Lapo Salterello,
EN.128: in those days would have caused the same surprise
EN.129: as now would Cincinnatus or Cornelia.
EN.130: 'It was to a municipal life so peaceful
EN.131: and so fair, to a citizenry so loyal,
EN.132: to so sweet a place to live,
EN.133: 'that Mary gave me when invoked with cries
EN.134: of childbirth, and in your ancient Baptistry,
EN.135: I was at once Cacciaguida and a Christian.
EN.136: 'Moronto was my brother, as was Eliseo.
EN.137: My wife came from the valley of the Po,
EN.138: and from her you took the surname that you bear.
EN.139: 'Later, I became a partisan of Emperor Conrad,
EN.140: who girded me to be his knight
EN.141: once, with my faithful service, I had won his favor.
EN.142: 'I followed him to oppose the iniquity
EN.143: of that false creed whose people, by the failure
EN.144: of your shepherds, usurp your right.
EN.145: 'There was I freed by that foul race
EN.146: from all the snares of the deceitful world --
EN.147: the love of which corrupts so many souls --
EN.148: and came from being martyred to this peace.'

IT.1: O poca nostra nobiltà di sangue,
IT.2: se glorïar di te la gente fai
IT.3: qua giù dove l'affetto nostro langue,
IT.4: mirabil cosa non mi sarà mai:
IT.5: ché là dove appetito non si torce,
IT.6: dico nel cielo, io me ne gloriai.
IT.7: Ben se' tu manto che tosto raccorce:
IT.8: sì che, se non s'appon di dì in die,
IT.9: lo tempo va dintorno con le force.
IT.10: Dal "voi" che prima a Roma s'offerie,
IT.11: in che la sua famiglia men persevra,
IT.12: ricominciaron le parole mie;
IT.13: onde Beatrice, ch'era un poco scevra,
IT.14: ridendo, parve quella che tossio
IT.15: al primo fallo scritto di Ginevra.
IT.16: Io cominciai: "Voi siete il padre mio;
IT.17: voi mi date a parlar tutta baldezza;
IT.18: voi mi levate sì, ch'i' son più ch'io.
IT.19: Per tanti rivi s'empie d'allegrezza
IT.20: la mente mia, che di sé fa letizia
IT.21: perché può sostener che non si spezza.
IT.22: Ditemi dunque, cara mia primizia,
IT.23: quai fuor li vostri antichi e quai fuor li anni
IT.24: che si segnaro in vostra püerizia;
IT.25: ditemi de l'ovil di San Giovanni
IT.26: quanto era allora, e chi eran le genti
IT.27: tra esso degne di più alti scanni."
IT.28: Come s'avviva a lo spirar d'i venti
IT.29: carbone in fiamma, così vid' io quella
IT.30: luce risplendere a' miei blandimenti;
IT.31: e come a li occhi miei si fé più bella,
IT.32: così con voce più dolce e soave,
IT.33: ma non con questa moderna favella,
IT.34: dissemi: "Da quel dì che fu detto 'Ave'
IT.35: al parto in che mia madre, ch'è or santa,
IT.36: s'allevïò di me ond' era grave,
IT.37: al suo Leon cinquecento cinquanta
IT.38: e trenta fiate venne questo foco
IT.39: a rinfiammarsi sotto la sua pianta.
IT.40: Li antichi miei e io nacqui nel loco
IT.41: dove si truova pria l'ultimo sesto
IT.42: da quei che corre il vostro annüal gioco.
IT.43: Basti d'i miei maggiori udirne questo:
IT.44: chi ei si fosser e onde venner quivi,
IT.45: più è tacer che ragionare onesto.
IT.46: Tutti color ch'a quel tempo eran ivi
IT.47: da poter arme tra Marte e 'l Batista,
IT.48: erano il quinto di quei ch'or son vivi.
IT.49: Ma la cittadinanza, ch'è or mista
IT.50: di Campi, di Certaldo e di Fegghine,
IT.51: pura vediesi ne l'ultimo artista.
IT.52: Oh quanto fora meglio esser vicine
IT.53: quelle genti ch'io dico, e al Galluzzo
IT.54: e a Trespiano aver vostro confine,
IT.55: che averle dentro e sostener lo puzzo
IT.56: del villan d'Aguglion, di quel da Signa,
IT.57: che già per barattare ha l'occhio aguzzo!
IT.58: Se la gente ch'al mondo più traligna
IT.59: non fosse stata a Cesare noverca,
IT.60: ma come madre a suo figlio benigna,
IT.61: tal fatto è fiorentino e cambia e merca,
IT.62: che si sarebbe vòlto a Simifonti,
IT.63: là dove andava l'avolo a la cerca;
IT.64: sariesi Montemurlo ancor de' Conti;
IT.65: sarieno i Cerchi nel piovier d'Acone,
IT.66: e forse in Valdigrieve i Buondelmonti.
IT.67: Sempre la confusion de le persone
IT.68: principio fu del mal de la cittade,
IT.69: come del vostro il cibo che s'appone;
IT.70: e cieco toro più avaccio cade
IT.71: che cieco agnello; e molte volte taglia
IT.72: più e meglio una che le cinque spade.
IT.73: Se tu riguardi Luni e Orbisaglia
IT.74: come sono ite, e come se ne vanno
IT.75: di retro ad esse Chiusi e Sinigaglia,
IT.76: udir come le schiatte si disfanno
IT.77: non ti parrà nova cosa né forte,
IT.78: poscia che le cittadi termine hanno.
IT.79: Le vostre cose tutte hanno lor morte,
IT.80: sì come voi; ma celasi in alcuna
IT.81: che dura molto, e le vite son corte.
IT.82: E come 'l volger del ciel de la luna
IT.83: cuopre e discuopre i liti sanza posa,
IT.84: così fa di Fiorenza la Fortuna:
IT.85: per che non dee parer mirabil cosa
IT.86: ciò ch'io dirò de li alti Fiorentini
IT.87: onde è la fama nel tempo nascosa.
IT.88: Io vidi li Ughi e vidi i Catellini,
IT.89: Filippi, Greci, Ormanni e Alberichi,
IT.90: già nel calare, illustri cittadini;
IT.91: e vidi così grandi come antichi,
IT.92: con quel de la Sannella, quel de l'Arca,
IT.93: e Soldanieri e Ardinghi e Bostichi.
IT.94: Sovra la porta ch'al presente è carca
IT.95: di nova fellonia di tanto peso
IT.96: che tosto fia iattura de la barca,
IT.97: erano i Ravignani, ond' è disceso
IT.98: il conte Guido e qualunque del nome
IT.99: de l'alto Bellincione ha poscia preso.
IT.100: Quel de la Pressa sapeva già come
IT.101: regger si vuole, e avea Galigaio
IT.102: dorata in casa sua già l'elsa e 'l pome.
IT.103: Grand' era già la colonna del Vaio,
IT.104: Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti e Barucci
IT.105: e Galli e quei ch'arrossan per lo staio.
IT.106: Lo ceppo di che nacquero i Calfucci
IT.107: era già grande, e già eran tratti
IT.108: a le curule Sizii e Arrigucci.
IT.109: Oh quali io vidi quei che son disfatti
IT.110: per lor superbia! e le palle de l'oro
IT.111: fiorian Fiorenza in tutt' i suoi gran fatti.
IT.112: Così facieno i padri di coloro
IT.113: che, sempre che la vostra chiesa vaca,
IT.114: si fanno grassi stando a consistoro.
IT.115: L'oltracotata schiatta che s'indraca
IT.116: dietro a chi fugge, e a chi mostra 'l dente
IT.117: o ver la borsa, com' agnel si placa,
IT.118: già venìa sù, ma di picciola gente;
IT.119: sì che non piacque ad Ubertin Donato

IT.121: Già era 'l Caponsacco nel mercato
IT.122: disceso giù da Fiesole, e già era
IT.123: buon cittadino Giuda e Infangato.
IT.124: Io dirò cosa incredibile e vera:
IT.125: nel picciol cerchio s'entrava per porta
IT.126: che si nomava da quei de la Pera.
IT.127: Ciascun che de la bella insegna porta
IT.128: del gran barone il cui nome e 'l cui pregio
IT.129: la festa di Tommaso riconforta,
IT.130: da esso ebbe milizia e privilegio;
IT.131: avvegna che con popol si rauni
IT.132: oggi colui che la fascia col fregio.
IT.133: Già eran Gualterotti e Importuni;
IT.134: e ancor saria Borgo più quïeto,
IT.135: se di novi vicin fosser digiuni.
IT.136: La casa di che nacque il vostro fleto,
IT.137: per lo giusto disdegno che v'ha morti
IT.138: e puose fine al vostro viver lieto,
IT.139: era onorata, essa e suoi consorti:
IT.140: o Buondelmonte, quanto mal fuggisti
IT.141: le nozze süe per li altrui conforti!
IT.142: Molti sarebber lieti, che son tristi,
IT.143: se Dio t'avesse conceduto ad Ema
IT.144: la prima volta ch'a città venisti.
IT.145: Ma conveniesi, a quella pietra scema
IT.146: che guarda 'l ponte, che Fiorenza fesse
IT.147: vittima ne la sua pace postrema.
IT.148: Con queste genti, e con altre con esse,
IT.149: vid' io Fiorenza in sì fatto riposo,
IT.150: che non avea cagione onde piangesse.
IT.151: Con queste genti vid' io glorïoso
IT.152: e giusto il popol suo, tanto che 'l giglio
IT.153: non era ad asta mai posto a ritroso,

EN.1: O insignificant nobility of blood,
EN.2: if you make us glory in you here below,
EN.3: where our affections are ephemeral,
EN.4: I will not ever think it strange,
EN.5: for there, where appetite is never warped --
EN.6: in, I mean, the heavens themselves -- I gloried in you too.
EN.7: You are indeed a cloak that quickly shrinks,
EN.8: so that, if we do not add to it day by day,
EN.9: time trims the edges with its shears.
EN.10: With that You which had its origin in Rome
EN.11: and which her offspring least preserve by use,
EN.12: I once again began to speak,
EN.13: and Beatrice, who stood somewhat apart,
EN.14: smiled, like the lady who discreetly coughed
EN.15: at the first fault inscribed of Guinevere.
EN.16: I began: 'You are my father,
EN.17: You prompt me to speak with bold assurance.
EN.18: You raise me up, so I am more than I.
EN.19: 'My mind is flooded by such rivers of delight
EN.20: that it exults it has not burst
EN.21: with so much happiness and joy.
EN.22: 'Tell me then, belovèd stock from which I spring,
EN.23: who were Your ancestors, and say what were the years
EN.24: written in the record of Your childhood.
EN.25: 'Tell me of the sheepfold of Saint John,
EN.26: how many people lived there and who among them
EN.27: were worthy of its highest offices.'
EN.28: As embers leap to flame on a puff of wind,
EN.29: I watched that light become resplendent
EN.30: at my respectful and persuasive words.
EN.31: And as it became more pleasing to my sight,
EN.32: so, with a voice more sweet and gentle,
EN.33: but not in this our modern tongue,
EN.34: he said: 'From the day Ave was first spoken
EN.35: until the birthpangs by which my mother,
EN.36: now blessed, was lightened of me, her burden,
EN.37: 'this fiery star came to its Lion
EN.38: five hundred fifty times and thirty more
EN.39: to be rekindled underneath its paw.
EN.40: 'My ancestors and I were born just where
EN.41: the horsemen in your yearly race
EN.42: first come upon the farthest district.
EN.43: 'Let that be enough for you about my forebears.
EN.44: As to who they were and where they came from,
EN.45: it is more modest to be silent than to speak.
EN.46: 'All who lived there then, fit to bear arms,
EN.47: and who dwelt between Mars and the Baptist,
EN.48: amounted to a fifth of those who live there now,
EN.49: 'but the city's bloodline, now mixed
EN.50: with that of Campi, of Certaldo, and Figline,
EN.51: was then found pure in the humblest artisan.
EN.52: 'Ah, how much better would it be
EN.53: had those cities which I name remained but neighbors,
EN.54: had you kept your borders at Galluzzo and Trespiano,
EN.55: 'than to have them in your midst and bear the stench
EN.56: of the lout from Aguglion and of him from Signa
EN.57: who already has so sharp an eye for graft!
EN.58: 'If that tribe, which is the most degenerate
EN.59: in all the world, had not been like a stepmother
EN.60: to Caesar, but kind as a mother to her son,
EN.61: 'there is one, become a Florentine, who is in trade
EN.62: and changes money, who would be sent straight back
EN.63: to Semifonte, where his granddad scoured the country.
EN.64: 'Montemurlo would still owe fealty to the Conti,
EN.65: the Cerchi would be in the parish of Acone,
EN.66: and the Buondelmonti might remain in Valdigreve.
EN.67: 'Intermingling of peoples has ever been
EN.68: the source of all the city's ills,
EN.69: as eating in excess is to the body.
EN.70: 'A blind bull is more prone to fall
EN.71: than a blind lamb, and frequently a single sword
EN.72: cuts deeper and more sharp than five.
EN.73: 'If you consider Luni, Urbisaglia --
EN.74: how they've ceased to be -- and how Chiusi
EN.75: and Senigallia soon will join them,
EN.76: 'then to hear how families come to nothing
EN.77: will not seem strange or difficult to grasp,
EN.78: since even cities cease to be.
EN.79: 'All your concerns are mortal, even as are you,
EN.80: but in some things that are more lasting
EN.81: this lies hidden, because all lives are brief.
EN.82: 'And, as the turning of the lunar sphere covers
EN.83: and endlessly uncovers the edges of the shore,
EN.84: thus does fortune deal with Florence.
EN.85: 'Then it should not seem strange or marvelous to you
EN.86: to hear me talk of noble Florentines,
EN.87: whose fame is buried in the depth of time.
EN.88: 'I saw the Ughi, I saw the Catellini,
EN.89: Filippi, Greci, Ormanni and Alberichi,
EN.90: illustrious citizens already in decline,
EN.91: 'and I saw, as great as they were ancient,
EN.92: dell'Arca alongside della Sannella,
EN.93: and Soldanieri and Ardinghi and Bostichi.
EN.94: 'Over the gate, which is today weighed down
EN.95: with such burden of new and unspeakable treachery
EN.96: that some cargo soon shall be hurled from the ship,
EN.97: 'lived the Ravignani, from whom Count Guido
EN.98: and all those who since have taken their name
EN.99: from the noble Bellincione are descended.
EN.100: 'The Della Pressa already knew the way to rule,
EN.101: and in their house the Galigaio already had
EN.102: the gilded hilt and pommel.
EN.103: 'Great already was the stripe of fur,
EN.104: great were the Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti, Barucci,
EN.105: Galli, and those who blush because of the bushel.
EN.106: 'The stock from which the Calfucci sprang
EN.107: was already great, and already called
EN.108: to the seats of power were Sizii and Arrigucci.
EN.109: 'Ah, in what glory I saw those,
EN.110: now quite undone by pride! And the golden balls
EN.111: made Florence flower with all their glorious deeds.
EN.112: 'Thus did the fathers of those who now,
EN.113: whenever your church needs to fill the bishop's seat,
EN.114: fatten themselves by sitting long in council.
EN.115: 'The proud and insolent race, playing the dragon
EN.116: at the back of him who flees, but mild as a lamb
EN.117: to him who shows his teeth -- or else his purse,
EN.118: 'was already on the rise, but of mean stock,
EN.119: so that it gave no joy to Ubertin Donato
EN.120: when his father-in-law made him their kinsman.
EN.121: 'The Caponsacchi had already made their way
EN.122: from Fiesole to the market-place, and both Giuda
EN.123: and Infangato were already citizens of note.
EN.124: 'I will tell a thing incredible but true:
EN.125: The old city walls were entered through a gate
EN.126: that took its name from the della Pera.
EN.127: 'Everyone bearing the noble coat of arms
EN.128: of the great baron whose name and praise
EN.129: are celebrated at the feast of Thomas
EN.130: 'had from him their knighthood and their privilege,
EN.131: although he that decks it with a golden fringe
EN.132: today takes the side of the common folk.
EN.133: 'Gualterotti and Importuni were already there,
EN.134: and the Borgo would even now be more at peace
EN.135: had they been left hungry for new neighbors.
EN.136: 'The house that is the wellspring of your tears,
EN.137: whose just disdain brought death among you
EN.138: and put an end to your light-hearted life,
EN.139: 'was honored then, both it and its allies.
EN.140: O Buondelmonte, how ill-fated that you fled
EN.141: those nuptials at another's urging!
EN.142: 'Many would be happy who now grieve
EN.143: if God had let the river Ema take you
EN.144: the first time that you came into our town.
EN.145: 'But it was destined that, to the shattered stone
EN.146: that guards the bridge, Florence should offer
EN.147: a sacrificial victim in her final days of peace.
EN.148: 'With these noble families, and with others still,
EN.149: I saw Florence in such tranquility
EN.150: that there was nothing that might cause her grief.
EN.151: 'With these noble families I saw her people
EN.152: so glorious and just, that the lily
EN.153: had not yet been reversed upon the lance
EN.154: nor by dissension changed to red.'

IT.1: Qual venne a Climenè, per accertarsi
IT.2: di ciò ch'avëa incontro a sé udito,
IT.3: quei ch'ancor fa li padri ai figli scarsi;
IT.4: tal era io, e tal era sentito
IT.5: e da Beatrice e da la santa lampa

IT.48: tal di Fiorenza partir ti convene.
IT.49: Questo si vuole e questo già si cerca,

EN.1: Like him who came to Clymene to cast out doubt
EN.2: upon the rumor he had heard against himself,
EN.3: who still makes fathers cautious with their sons,
EN.4: such was I and such was I perceived to be
EN.5: both by Beatrice and by the holy light
EN.6: that earlier for me had changed its place.
EN.7: And so my lady said to me: ''Send forth
EN.8: the flame of your desire, and let it issue
EN.9: with the clear imprint of its inner stamp,
EN.10: 'not that our knowledge be increased by what you say
EN.11: but that you rehearse the telling of your thirst
EN.12: so that the drink be poured for you.'
EN.13: 'O my precious root, you are raised so high
EN.14: that, even as earthly minds discern no triangle
EN.15: can contain two angles, both of them obtuse,
EN.16: 'so you, gazing on the point that holds all time
EN.17: are able to discern contingencies
EN.18: before they are apparent in themselves.
EN.19: 'While I was still in Virgil's company,
EN.20: both on the mountain that restores our souls
EN.21: and during our descent into the region of the dead,
EN.22: 'grave words were said to me about my future life --
EN.23: however much I feel myself prepared
EN.24: foursquare against the blows of chance --
EN.25: 'so that my will would be content
EN.26: if I could know what fate draws near,
EN.27: for the arrow one expects comes slower.
EN.28: I said these words to the very light
EN.29: that had just spoken and, as Beatrice wished,
EN.30: my wish was now declared.
EN.31: Not with cloudy sayings, by which the foolish folk
EN.32: were once ensnared, before the Lamb of God,
EN.33: who takes away our sins, was slain,
EN.34: but in plain words and with clear speech
EN.35: that paternal love replied,
EN.36: hidden and yet revealed in his own smile:
EN.37: 'Contingent things, which do not extend
EN.38: beyond the pages of your material world,
EN.39: are all depicted in the Eternal Sight,
EN.40: 'yet are by that no more enjoined
EN.41: than is a ship, moved downstream on a river's flow,
EN.42: by the eyes that mirror it.
EN.43: 'And thus, as harmony's sweet sound may rise
EN.44: from mingled voices to the ear, so rises to my sight
EN.45: a vision of the time that lies in store for you.
EN.46: 'As Hippolytus was forced to flee from Athens,
EN.47: because of his stepmother, treacherous and fierce,
EN.48: so shall you be forced to flee from Florence.
EN.49: 'This is the plan, already set in motion,
EN.50: that soon will bring success to him who plots it
EN.51: where Christ is bought and sold all day.
EN.52: 'The populace shall blame the injured party,
EN.53: as it always does, but vengeance
EN.54: shall bear witness to the Truth that metes it out.
EN.55: 'You shall leave behind all you most dearly love,
EN.56: and that shall be the arrow
EN.57: first loosed from exile's bow.
EN.58: 'You shall learn how salt is the taste
EN.59: of another man's bread and how hard is the way,
EN.60: going down and then up another man's stairs.
EN.61: 'But the heaviest burden your shoulders must bear
EN.62: shall be the companions, wicked and witless,
EN.63: among whom you shall fall in your descent.
EN.64: 'They, utterly ungrateful, mad, and faithless,
EN.65: shall turn against you. But soon enough they, not you,
EN.66: shall feel their faces blushing past their brows.
EN.67: 'Of their brutish state the results
EN.68: shall offer proof. And it shall bring you honor
EN.69: to have made a single party of yourself alone.
EN.70: 'You shall find welcome and a first refuge
EN.71: in the courtesy of the noble Lombard,
EN.72: the one who bears the sacred bird above the ladder.
EN.73: 'It is he who will hold you in such gracious favor
EN.74: that, as for granting and asking, between you two,
EN.75: that shall be first which, between all others, happens after.
EN.76: 'In his company you shall find one who, at birth,
EN.77: so took the imprint of this mighty star
EN.78: that his deeds will truly be renowned.
EN.79: 'As yet the people, because of his youth,
EN.80: take small note of him, since these wheels
EN.81: have revolved above him only for nine years.
EN.82: 'But, before the Gascon can deceive the noble Henry,
EN.83: sparks of his virtue shall at first shine forth
EN.84: in his indifference to wealth or toil,
EN.85: 'and his munificence shall one day be so widely known
EN.86: even his enemies will not contrive
EN.87: to keep their tongues from praising it.
EN.88: 'Look to him and trust his gracious deeds.
EN.89: On his account many will find alteration,
EN.90: rich men changing states with beggars.
EN.91: 'And you shall bear this written in your memory,
EN.92: but shall not tell of it' -- and he foretold events
EN.93: that even those who witness them shall not believe.
EN.94: Then he added: 'Son, these are the glosses
EN.95: on what was told you, these are the snares
EN.96: that lurk behind a few revolving years.
EN.97: 'Yet I would not have you feel envious disdain
EN.98: for your fellow-townsmen, since your life shall far outlast
EN.99: the punishment of their treachery.'
EN.100: After the holy soul, by falling silent,
EN.101: showed that he had done with putting the woof
EN.102: into the web for which I had set the warp,
EN.103: I began, like a man in doubt,
EN.104: but one filled with great desire for advice
EN.105: from someone of clear sight, right will, and love:
EN.106: 'I can see, father, that time is spurring toward me
EN.107: to deal me such a blow as falls most heavily
EN.108: on one proceeding heedless on his way.
EN.109: 'Thus it is good I arm myself with forethought
EN.110: so that, if my belovèd town is torn from me,
EN.111: I may not lose still others through my songs.
EN.112: 'Down through the world of endless bitterness,
EN.113: and upward on the mountain from whose lovely peak
EN.114: my lady raised me with her eyes,
EN.115: 'and after, rising through the heavens, light to light,
EN.116: I have learned things that, should I retell them,
EN.117: would discomfort many with their bitter taste.
EN.118: 'Yet, should I be a timid friend to truth,
EN.119: I fear that I shall not live on for those
EN.120: to whom our times shall be the ancient days.'
EN.121: The light, in which the treasure that I found there
EN.122: had been smiling, now became resplendent
EN.123: as a mirror, golden in the sun,
EN.124: and then made this reply: 'A conscience dark,
EN.125: whether with its own or with a kinsman's shame,
EN.126: is sure to feel your words are harsh.
EN.127: 'Nonetheless, forswear all falsehood,
EN.128: revealing all that you have seen,
EN.129: and then let him who itches scratch.
EN.130: 'For, if your voice is bitter at first taste,
EN.131: it will later furnish vital nourishment
EN.132: once it has been swallowed and digested.
EN.133: 'This cry of yours shall do as does the wind
EN.134: that strikes the highest peaks with greater force --
EN.135: this loftiness itself no little sign of honor.
EN.136: 'That is why you have been shown, within these wheels,
EN.137: upon the mountain, and in the woeful valley,
EN.138: those souls alone that are well known to fame,
EN.139: 'since the mind of one who listens will not heed
EN.140: nor fix its faith on an example
EN.141: that has its roots in things unknown or hidden
EN.142: or on some other proof not clearly shown.'

IT.1: Già si godeva solo del suo verbo

IT.3: lo mio, temprando col dolce l'acerbo;

IT.8: del mio conforto; e qual io allor vidi
IT.9: ne li occhi santi amor, qui l'abbandono:

IT.15: libero fu da ogne altro disire,
IT.16: fin che 'l piacere etterno, che diretto
IT.17: raggiava in Bëatrice, dal bel viso
IT.18: mi contentava col secondo aspetto.

IT.22: Come si vede qui alcuna volta

IT.30: e frutta sempre e mai non perde foglia,

IT.32: che venissero al ciel, fuor di gran voce,

IT.40: E al nome de l'alto Macabeo

EN.1: That blessèd mirror continued to rejoice
EN.2: in his own thoughts and I was tasting mine,
EN.3: tempering the bitter with the sweet,
EN.4: when that lady, who was leading me to God,
EN.5: said: 'Change your thoughts. Consider that I dwell
EN.6: with Him who lifts the weight of every wrong.'
EN.7: At the loving sound of my comfort's voice
EN.8: I turned, and the great love I saw then,
EN.9: in her holy eyes, I have to leave untold,
EN.10: not just because I cannot trust my speech,
EN.11: but because memory cannot retrace its path
EN.12: that far unless Another guide it.
EN.13: This much only of that moment can I tell again,
EN.14: that, when I fixed my gaze on her,
EN.15: my affections were released from any other longing
EN.16: as long as the eternal Beauty,
EN.17: shining its light on Beatrice, made me content
EN.18: with its reflected glow in her fair eyes.
EN.19: Conquering me with her radiant smile,
EN.20: she said: 'Turn now and listen:
EN.21: not in my eyes alone is Paradise.'
EN.22: As, on occasion, here on earth, affection
EN.23: may be read in someone's face
EN.24: if it is strong enough to capture all the soul,
EN.25: so, in the flaming of that holy radiance
EN.26: to which I turned, I recognized his wish
EN.27: to share some further thoughts with me.
EN.28: And he began: 'On this fifth tier of the branches
EN.29: of the tree that draws its sustenance from above
EN.30: and always is in fruit and never sheds its leaves
EN.31: 'are blessèd spirits who below, on earth,
EN.32: before they rose to Heaven, were of such renown
EN.33: that any poet's page would be enriched by them.
EN.34: 'Look, therefore, at the two arms of the cross,
EN.35: and each one whom I name will, flashing, dart
EN.36: as does swift fire from within a cloud.'
EN.37: I saw a streak of light drawn through the cross
EN.38: at Joshua's name as soon as it was spoken,
EN.39: nor could I tell the naming and the deed apart.
EN.40: And, at the name of valorous Maccabaeus,
EN.41: I saw shoot by another whirling light --
EN.42: and it was joy that whipped that spinning top.
EN.43: My watchful gaze was fastened
EN.44: on Charlemagne and Roland there, as well,
EN.45: just as the eye pursues the falcon in its flight.
EN.46: William, Renouard, and then Duke Godfrey
EN.47: next drew my eyes along that cross,
EN.48: and Robert Guiscard also did so.
EN.49: Then, leaving me to mingle with the other lights,
EN.50: the soul who'd spoken last with me displayed
EN.51: his artistry among the singers of that heaven.
EN.52: I turned to my right to learn
EN.53: from Beatrice what I ought to do,
EN.54: whether signaled by some word or gesture,
EN.55: and I saw her eyes so clear, so joyful,
EN.56: that her aspect in its radiance outshone
EN.57: her former glory, even that most recent.
EN.58: And as, from feeling more delight in doing good,
EN.59: a man becomes aware from day to day
EN.60: of his increasing virtue,
EN.61: seeing that miracle adorned with greater brightness,
EN.62: I became aware my wheeling circles
EN.63: through the heavens had grown wider in their arc.
EN.64: And such a change as passes in a moment
EN.65: from the blushing face of a fair-skinned lady,
EN.66: unburdened of the reason for her shame,
EN.67: greeted my eyes once I had turned around,
EN.68: because of the white radiance of the temperate
EN.69: sixth star, which had gathered me into itself.
EN.70: In that torch of Jupiter I watched
EN.71: the sparkling of the love resplendent there
EN.72: make signs, before my eyes, of our speech.
EN.73: And as birds risen from the river's edge,
EN.74: seeming to celebrate their pleasure in their food,
EN.75: form now a rounded arc, and now another shape,
EN.76: so, radiant within their lights, the holy creatures
EN.77: sang as they flew and shaped themselves
EN.78: in figures, now D, now I, now L.
EN.79: At first, singing, they danced to their own tune.
EN.80: And then, taking on one of these shapes,
EN.81: they paused in their movement and were silent.
EN.82: O divine Pegasean, who bestow glory
EN.83: and long life on genius, as, with your help,
EN.84: it gives life to towns and kingdoms,
EN.85: inspire me with your light so that I may set down
EN.86: their shapes as I conceived them in my mind.
EN.87: May your power appear in these few lines.
EN.88: They then displayed themselves in five times seven
EN.89: consonants and vowels, and I saw these letters
EN.90: singly, and in the order they were traced.
EN.91: DILIGITE IUSTITIAM -- these letters,
EN.92: placed together, verb and noun, came first,
EN.93: QUI IUDICATIS TERRAM, last.
EN.94: Then they came to rest in the fifth word's M
EN.95: so that this place in Jupiter was shining
EN.96: as does silver overlaid with gold.
EN.97: And I saw other lights descend and settle
EN.98: on the M's high crest to sing, I think,
EN.99: of that great Good which draws them to Itself.
EN.100: Then, as when someone strikes a burning log,
EN.101: causing innumerable sparks to fly,
EN.102: sparks from which the foolish form their divinations,
EN.103: just so a thousand lights and more appeared
EN.104: to rise from there and mount, some more, some less,
EN.105: as the Sun that kindles them ordained.
EN.106: When each had settled in its place
EN.107: I saw an eagle's head and neck
EN.108: take shape out of that overlay of fire.
EN.109: He who fashions there has need of none to guide Him
EN.110: but Himself. Thus we recognize as His
EN.111: the form that every bird takes for its nest.
EN.112: The other blessèd spirits, who seemed at first content
EN.113: to turn themselves into a lily on the M,
EN.114: with gentle motion joined, completing the design.
EN.115: O lovely star, how many and how bright the jewels
EN.116: that showed me that our earthly justice
EN.117: comes from that heaven, brilliant with your gems!
EN.118: Therefore, I entreat the Mind, in which your motion
EN.119: and your power begin, to look down on the source
EN.120: of smoke that dims your radiant beam,
EN.121: so that your wrath come down once more
EN.122: on those who buy and sell within the temple,
EN.123: whose walls were built of miracle and martyrdom.
EN.124: O soldiery of Heaven, whom I contemplate,
EN.125: pray for those still on the earth,
EN.126: those led astray by bad example!
EN.127: It was the custom once to go to war with swords.
EN.128: Now wars are fought withholding here and there
EN.129: the bread our loving Father keeps from none.
EN.130: But you who write only to cancel,
EN.131: remember this: Peter and Paul, who died
EN.132: to save the vineyard you lay waste, still live.
EN.133: Well may you say: 'I have so set my heart
EN.134: on him who chose to live in solitude
EN.135: and who for a dance was dragged to martyrdom
EN.136: that I know neither the Fisherman nor Paul.'

IT.1: Parea dinanzi a me con l'ali aperte
IT.2: la bella image che nel dolce frui
IT.3: liete facevan l'anime conserte;
IT.4: parea ciascuna rubinetto in cui
IT.5: raggio di sole ardesse sì acceso,
IT.6: che ne' miei occhi rifrangesse lui.
IT.7: E quel che mi convien ritrar testeso,
IT.8: non portò voce mai, né scrisse incostro,
IT.9: né fu per fantasia già mai compreso;
IT.10: ch'io vidi e anche udi' parlar lo rostro,
IT.11: e sonar ne la voce e "io" e "mio,"
IT.12: quand' era nel concetto e "noi" e "nostro."
IT.13: E cominciò: "Per esser giusto e pio
IT.14: son io qui essaltato a quella gloria
IT.15: che non si lascia vincere a disio;
IT.16: e in terra lasciai la mia memoria
IT.17: sì fatta, che le genti lì malvage
IT.18: commendan lei, ma non seguon la storia."
IT.19: Così un sol calor di molte brage
IT.20: si fa sentir, come di molti amori
IT.21: usciva solo un suon di quella image.
IT.22: Ond' io appresso: "O perpetüi fiori
IT.23: de l'etterna letizia, che pur uno
IT.24: parer mi fate tutti vostri odori,
IT.25: solvetemi, spirando, il gran digiuno
IT.26: che lungamente m'ha tenuto in fame,
IT.27: non trovandoli in terra cibo alcuno.
IT.28: Ben so io che, se 'n cielo altro reame
IT.29: la divina giustizia fa suo specchio,
IT.30: che 'l vostro non l'apprende con velame.
IT.31: Sapete come attento io m'apparecchio
IT.32: ad ascoltar; sapete qual è quello
IT.33: dubbio che m'è digiun cotanto vecchio."
IT.34: Quasi falcone ch'esce del cappello,
IT.35: move la testa e con l'ali si plaude,
IT.36: voglia mostrando e faccendosi bello,
IT.37: vid' io farsi quel segno, che di laude
IT.38: de la divina grazia era contesto,
IT.39: con canti quai si sa chi là sù gaude.
IT.40: Poi cominciò: "Colui che volse il sesto
IT.41: a lo stremo del mondo, e dentro ad esso
IT.42: distinse tanto occulto e manifesto,
IT.43: non poté suo valor sì fare impresso
IT.44: in tutto l'universo, che 'l suo verbo
IT.45: non rimanesse in infinito eccesso.
IT.46: E ciò fa certo che 'l primo superbo,
IT.47: che fu la somma d'ogne creatura,
IT.48: per non aspettar lume, cadde acerbo;
IT.49: e quinci appar ch'ogne minor natura
IT.50: è corto recettacolo a quel bene
IT.51: che non ha fine e sé con sé misura.
IT.52: Dunque vostra veduta, che convene
IT.53: essere alcun de' raggi de la mente
IT.54: di che tutte le cose son ripiene,
IT.55: non pò da sua natura esser possente
IT.56: tanto, che suo principio non discerna
IT.57: molto di là da quel che l'è parvente.
IT.58: Però ne la giustizia sempiterna
IT.59: la vista che riceve il vostro mondo,
IT.60: com' occhio per lo mare, entro s'interna;
IT.61: che, ben che da la proda veggia il fondo,
IT.62: in pelago nol vede; e nondimeno
IT.63: èli, ma cela lui l'esser profondo.
IT.64: Lume non è, se non vien dal sereno
IT.65: che non si turba mai; anzi è tenèbra
IT.66: od ombra de la carne o suo veleno.
IT.67: Assai t'è mo aperta la latebra
IT.68: che t'ascondeva la giustizia viva,
IT.69: di che facei question cotanto crebra;
IT.70: ché tu dicevi: 'Un uom nasce a la riva
IT.71: de l'Indo, e quivi non è chi ragioni
IT.72: di Cristo né chi legga né chi scriva;
IT.73: e tutti suoi voleri e atti buoni
IT.74: sono, quanto ragione umana vede,
IT.75: sanza peccato in vita o in sermoni.
IT.76: Muore non battezzato e sanza fede:
IT.77: ov' è questa giustizia che 'l condanna?
IT.78: ov' è la colpa sua, se ei non crede?'
IT.79: Or tu chi se', che vuo' sedere a scranna,
IT.80: per giudicar di lungi mille miglia
IT.81: con la veduta corta d'una spanna?
IT.82: Certo a colui che meco s'assottiglia,
IT.83: se la Scrittura sovra voi non fosse,
IT.84: da dubitar sarebbe a maraviglia.
IT.85: Oh terreni animali! oh menti grosse!
IT.86: La prima volontà, ch'è da sé buona,
IT.87: da sé, ch'è sommo ben, mai non si mosse.
IT.88: Cotanto è giusto quanto a lei consuona:
IT.89: nullo creato bene a sé la tira,
IT.90: ma essa, radïando, lui cagiona."
IT.91: Quale sovresso il nido si rigira
IT.92: poi c'ha pasciuti la cicogna i figli,
IT.93: e come quel ch'è pasto la rimira;
IT.94: cotal si fece, e sì leväi i cigli,
IT.95: la benedetta imagine, che l'ali
IT.96: movea sospinte da tanti consigli.
IT.97: Roteando cantava, e dicea: "Quali
IT.98: son le mie note a te, che non le 'ntendi,
IT.99: tal è il giudicio etterno a voi mortali."
IT.100: Poi si quetaro quei lucenti incendi
IT.101: de lo Spirito Santo ancor nel segno
IT.102: che fé i Romani al mondo reverendi,
IT.103: esso ricominciò: "A questo regno
IT.104: non salì mai chi non credette 'n Cristo,
IT.105: né pria né poi ch'el si chiavasse al legno.
IT.106: Ma vedi: molti gridan 'Cristo, Cristo!'
IT.107: che saranno in giudicio assai men prope
IT.108: a lui, che tal che non conosce Cristo;
IT.109: e tai Cristian dannerà l'Etïòpe,
IT.110: quando si partiranno i due collegi,
IT.111: l'uno in etterno ricco e l'altro inòpe.
IT.112: Che poran dir li Perse a' vostri regi,
IT.113: come vedranno quel volume aperto
IT.114: nel qual si scrivon tutti suoi dispregi?
IT.115: Lì si vedrà, tra l'opere d'Alberto,
IT.116: quella che tosto moverà la penna,
IT.117: per che 'l regno di Praga fia diserto.
IT.118: Lì si vedrà il duol che sovra Senna
IT.119: induce, falseggiando la moneta,
IT.120: quel che morrà di colpo di cotenna.
IT.121: Lì si vedrà la superbia ch'asseta,
IT.122: che fa lo Scotto e l'Inghilese folle,
IT.123: sì che non può soffrir dentro a sua meta.
IT.124: Vedrassi la lussuria e 'l viver molle
IT.125: di quel di Spagna e di quel di Boemme,
IT.126: che mai valor non conobbe né volle.
IT.127: Vedrassi al Ciotto di Ierusalemme
IT.128: segnata con un i la sua bontate,
IT.129: quando 'l contrario segnerà un emme.
IT.130: Vedrassi l'avarizia e la viltate
IT.131: di quei che guarda l'isola del foco,
IT.132: ove Anchise finì la lunga etate;
IT.133: e a dare ad intender quanto è poco,
IT.134: la sua scrittura fian lettere mozze,
IT.135: che noteranno molto in parvo loco.
IT.136: E parranno a ciascun l'opere sozze
IT.137: del barba e del fratel, che tanto egregia
IT.138: nazione e due corone han fatte bozze.
IT.139: E quel di Portogallo e di Norvegia
IT.140: lì si conosceranno, e quel di Rascia
IT.141: che male ha visto il conio di Vinegia.
IT.142: O beata Ungheria, se non si lascia
IT.143: più malmenare! e beata Navarra,
IT.144: se s'armasse del monte che la fascia!
IT.145: E creder de' ciascun che già, per arra
IT.146: di questo, Niccosïa e Famagosta
IT.147: per la lor bestia si lamenti e garra,
IT.148: che dal fianco de l'altre non si scosta."

EN.1: Before my eyes, its open wings outstretched,
EN.2: appeared the lovely image of those interwoven souls,
EN.3: reveling in sweet enjoyment.
EN.4: Each one seemed to be a single ruby
EN.5: in which the sun's ray burned with such a flame
EN.6: it felt as though a sunbeam struck my eyes.
EN.7: And what I now must tell
EN.8: no voice has ever uttered, nor ink ever wrote,
EN.9: nor was it ever seen in phantasy.
EN.10: For I saw and heard it was the beak that spoke,
EN.11: sounding with its voice the words for I and my
EN.12: when, in conception, it meant we and our.
EN.13: It said: 'For being just and merciful
EN.14: I here am raised unto that glory
EN.15: which by itself desire cannot attain.
EN.16: 'On earth I left behind such vestiges
EN.17: as even wicked people there commend,
EN.18: without, however, hewing to the form.'
EN.19: Just as from many coals we feel a single heat,
EN.20: so from that image there came forth
EN.21: the undivided sound of many loves.
EN.22: And I then answered: 'O everlasting blossoms
EN.23: of eternal bliss, you make all odors
EN.24: blend into what seems a single fragrance,
EN.25: 'breathe forth and free me from this endless fast
EN.26: that ever keeps me famished,
EN.27: since I can find no food for it on earth.
EN.28: 'It is clear to me that, even though God's Justice
EN.29: has its mirror in another realm of heaven,
EN.30: in yours it also shines without a veil.
EN.31: 'You know with what care I prepare myself
EN.32: to listen, and you know the nature of the doubt
EN.33: that now has kept me fasting for so long.'
EN.34: As the falcon, freed from its encumbering hood,
EN.35: raises its head, and flapping, as in winged applause,
EN.36: displays its beauty and its eagerness,
EN.37: just so I witnessed that emblem, made with strands
EN.38: of praise for God's own grace, surge into songs
EN.39: known but to those who live above in bliss.
EN.40: Then it began: 'He who with His compass
EN.41: drew the boundaries of the world and then, within them,
EN.42: created distinctions, both hidden and quite clear,
EN.43: 'did not imprint His power so deep
EN.44: throughout the universe that His Word
EN.45: would not with infinite excess surpass His making.
EN.46: 'In proof of this, the first and prideful being,
EN.47: who was created highest of all creatures,
EN.48: by not waiting for the light, plummeted unripe.
EN.49: 'And thus it is clear that every lesser nature
EN.50: is too small a vessel for that goodness
EN.51: which has no limit, which is measured by itself alone.
EN.52: 'Thus your vision, which must be
EN.53: but a single ray of many in the mind
EN.54: of Him of whom all things are full,
EN.55: 'by its nature must not have such power
EN.56: that it should not perceive its source
EN.57: as lying far beyond all it can see.
EN.58: 'Thus, the vision granted to your world
EN.59: may make its way into eternal justice
EN.60: as deep as eyes may penetrate the sea.
EN.61: 'From shore they well may glimpse the bottom,
EN.62: but not once out upon the open sea,
EN.63: and yet it is there, hidden in the depths.
EN.64: 'No light is never overcast unless it comes
EN.65: from that clear sky which always shines. All others
EN.66: darken in the shadow or the bane of flesh.
EN.67: 'Now the hiding-place has been laid bare
EN.68: that concealed from you the living justice
EN.69: about which you have posed so many questions.
EN.70: 'For you have often asked: "A man is born
EN.71: upon the bank along the Indus, with no one there
EN.72: to speak, or read, or write of Christ,
EN.73: '"and all that he desires, everything he does, is good.
EN.74: As far as human reason can discern,
EN.75: he is sinless in his deeds and in his words.
EN.76: '"He dies unbaptized, dies outside the faith.
EN.77: Wherein lies the justice that condemns him?
EN.78: Wherein lies his fault if he does not believe?"
EN.79: 'Now, who are you to sit upon the bench,
EN.80: judging from a thousand miles away
EN.81: with eyesight that is shorter than a span?
EN.82: 'To be sure, for one who wanted to debate this,
EN.83: had the Scripture not been set above you,
EN.84: there might be ample room for question.
EN.85: 'Oh, earthly creatures! oh, gross minds!
EN.86: The primal Will, good in Itself,
EN.87: has never from Itself, the highest good, declined.
EN.88: 'Only what accords with It is just: It is not drawn
EN.89: to a created good but, sending forth Its rays,
EN.90: It is the source of every good.'
EN.91: As a stork will circle above her nest
EN.92: after she has fed her young,
EN.93: and as the one just fed looks up at her,
EN.94: so, lifting up my brow, I watched
EN.95: as over me the blessèd image flew on wings
EN.96: that took their thrust from such shared counsel.
EN.97: Wheeling, it sang, then spoke:
EN.98: 'As my notes exceed your understanding,
EN.99: such is eternal judgment to all mortals.'
EN.100: When these, the Holy Spirit's fiery lights,
EN.101: grew quiet, still shaped into the sign
EN.102: that made the world revere the Romans,
EN.103: the eagle once again began: 'To this kingdom
EN.104: no one ever rose without belief in Christ,
EN.105: whether before or after He was nailed up on the tree.
EN.106: 'But observe that many shout out 'Christ, O Christ!'
EN.107: who shall be farther off from Him,
EN.108: on Judgment Day, than such as know not Christ.
EN.109: 'The Ethiopian shall condemn such Christians
EN.110: when the two assemblies go their separate ways,
EN.111: the one forever rich, the other poor.
EN.112: 'What shall the Persians say then to your kings
EN.113: when they see that volume lying open
EN.114: in which their many infamies are all inscribed?
EN.115: 'There they shall see, among the deeds of Albert,
EN.116: the deed -- now soon to move the pen --
EN.117: through which the realm of Prague shall suffer desolation.
EN.118: 'There they shall see the sorrow brought upon the Seine
EN.119: by one who falsifies his country's coin
EN.120: and who will die assaulted by a boar.
EN.121: 'There they shall see the pride that makes men thirst
EN.122: and so drives both the Englishman and Scot to fury
EN.123: that neither will remain within his borders.
EN.124: 'Of him from Spain, and of Bohemia's king,
EN.125: the text will show their wanton luxury and lazy ways
EN.126: and that they never knew nor searched for valor.
EN.127: 'Of the Cripple of Jerusalem the text will show
EN.128: an I to mark his only generous act,
EN.129: while an M will mark the other traits in him.
EN.130: 'Of him who rules the isle of fire,
EN.131: where the long life of Anchises had its end,
EN.132: the text will show the greed and cowardice.
EN.133: 'Displayed will be his utter worthlessness,
EN.134: requiring the use of shorthand
EN.135: that will note much in little space.
EN.136: 'Displayed for all to see will be the wicked deeds
EN.137: by which his uncle and his brother brought disgrace
EN.138: to so renowned a line and both their kingdoms.
EN.139: 'Displayed will be the kings of Portugal and Norway,
EN.140: and he of Rascia, who, to his own hurt,
EN.141: laid his eyes upon Venetian coinage.
EN.142: 'O happy Hungary, if only she no longer lets
EN.143: herself be poorly led! Happy Navarre, if she but takes
EN.144: protection from the mountains that surround her!
EN.145: 'And, in proof of this, all men should know
EN.146: that Nicosia and Famagosta
EN.147: lament and complain of their own beast,
EN.148: who takes his place among the others.'

IT.1: Quando colui che tutto 'l mondo alluma
IT.2: de l'emisperio nostro sì discende,
IT.3: che 'l giorno d'ogne parte si consuma,
IT.4: lo ciel, che sol di lui prima s'accende,
IT.5: subitamente si rifà parvente
IT.6: per molte luci, in che una risplende;
IT.7: e questo atto del ciel mi venne a mente,
IT.8: come 'l segno del mondo e de' suoi duci
IT.9: nel benedetto rostro fu tacente;
IT.10: però che tutte quelle vive luci,
IT.11: vie più lucendo, cominciaron canti
IT.12: da mia memoria labili e caduci.
IT.13: O dolce amor che di riso t'ammanti,
IT.14: quanto parevi ardente in que' flailli,
IT.15: ch'avieno spirto sol di pensier santi!
IT.16: Poscia che i cari e lucidi lapilli
IT.17: ond' io vidi ingemmato il sesto lume
IT.18: puoser silenzio a li angelici squilli,
IT.19: udir mi parve un mormorar di fiume
IT.20: che scende chiaro giù di pietra in pietra,
IT.21: mostrando l'ubertà del suo cacume.
IT.22: E come suono al collo de la cetra
IT.23: prende sua forma, e sì com' al pertugio
IT.24: de la sampogna vento che penètra,
IT.25: così, rimosso d'aspettare indugio,
IT.26: quel mormorar de l'aguglia salissi
IT.27: su per lo collo, come fosse bugio.
IT.28: Fecesi voce quivi, e quindi uscissi
IT.29: per lo suo becco in forma di parole,
IT.30: quali aspettava il core ov' io le scrissi.
IT.31: "La parte in me che vede e pate il sole
IT.32: ne l'aguglie mortali," incominciommi,
IT.33: "or fisamente riguardar si vole,
IT.34: perché d'i fuochi ond' io figura fommi,
IT.35: quelli onde l'occhio in testa mi scintilla,
IT.36: e' di tutti lor gradi son li sommi.
IT.37: Colui che luce in mezzo per pupilla,
IT.38: fu il cantor de lo Spirito Santo,
IT.39: che l'arca traslatò di villa in villa:
IT.40: ora conosce il merto del suo canto,
IT.41: in quanto effetto fu del suo consiglio,
IT.42: per lo remunerar ch'è altrettanto.
IT.43: Dei cinque che mi fan cerchio per ciglio,
IT.44: colui che più al becco mi s'accosta,
IT.45: la vedovella consolò del figlio:
IT.46: ora conosce quanto caro costa
IT.47: non seguir Cristo, per l'esperïenza
IT.48: di questa dolce vita e de l'opposta.
IT.49: E quel che segue in la circunferenza
IT.50: di che ragiono, per l'arco superno,
IT.51: morte indugiò per vera penitenza:
IT.52: ora conosce che 'l giudicio etterno
IT.53: non si trasmuta, quando degno preco
IT.54: fa crastino là giù de l'odïerno.
IT.55: L'altro che segue, con le leggi e meco,
IT.56: sotto buona intenzion che fé mal frutto,
IT.57: per cedere al pastor si fece greco:
IT.58: ora conosce come il mal dedutto
IT.59: dal suo bene operar non li è nocivo,
IT.60: avvegna che sia 'l mondo indi distrutto.
IT.61: E quel che vedi ne l'arco declivo,
IT.62: Guiglielmo fu, cui quella terra plora
IT.63: che piagne Carlo e Federigo vivo:
IT.64: ora conosce come s'innamora
IT.65: lo ciel del giusto rege, e al sembiante
IT.66: del suo fulgore il fa vedere ancora.
IT.67: Chi crederebbe giù nel mondo errante
IT.68: che Rifëo Troiano in questo tondo
IT.69: fosse la quinta de le luci sante?
IT.70: Ora conosce assai di quel che 'l mondo
IT.71: veder non può de la divina grazia,
IT.72: ben che sua vista non discerna il fondo."
IT.73: Quale allodetta che 'n aere si spazia
IT.74: prima cantando, e poi tace contenta
IT.75: de l'ultima dolcezza che la sazia,
IT.76: tal mi sembiò l'imago de la 'mprenta
IT.77: de l'etterno piacere, al cui disio

EN.1: When he who floods the whole world with his light
EN.2: sinks steadily from sight within our hemisphere
EN.3: until the day is spent on every side,
EN.4: the sky, lit up before by him alone,
EN.5: suddenly sparkles with a multitude of lights
EN.6: which all reflect a single one.
EN.7: I was reminded of this alteration in the sky
EN.8: when the emblem of the world and of its lords
EN.9: ceased speaking from within its blessèd beak,
EN.10: and all those living lights, shining
EN.11: still more bright, began their songs
EN.12: that slip, and fade, and fall from memory.
EN.13: O sweet love, mantled in a smile,
EN.14: how ardent did you sound within those pipes,
EN.15: filled with the breath of holy thoughts alone!
EN.16: Once the bright and precious stones of the sixth light,
EN.17: which scintillated in their setting there,
EN.18: had silenced their angelic tones,
EN.19: it seemed to me I heard the murmur of a stream,
EN.20: its waters falling crystal clear from rock to rock,
EN.21: revealing the abundance of its source above.
EN.22: And as a sound is given shape
EN.23: at the neck of the lute or by the wind
EN.24: forced through the vent-holes of a bagpipe,
EN.25: so, holding me no longer in suspense,
EN.26: the murmur of the eagle issued through its neck
EN.27: as though it had been hollowed out.
EN.28: There it became a voice and, coming from the beak,
EN.29: it formed the words my heart was waiting for,
EN.30: and on my heart I wrote them down.
EN.31: 'The part of me that, in mortal eagles,
EN.32: sees and endures the sun, you now must watch
EN.33: with fixed attention,' were its words to me,
EN.34: 'for, from the flames from which I take my form,
EN.35: those that make my eye shine so brightly in my head,
EN.36: those are the very highest spirits in their ranks.
EN.37: 'He that blazes as the pupil with a central spark
EN.38: was the one who sang the praises of the Holy Ghost
EN.39: and brought the ark from town to town.
EN.40: 'Now he knows the merit of his song,
EN.41: insofar as it derived from his own thought,
EN.42: by the fit reward he now enjoys.
EN.43: 'Of the five who arc to form my eyebrow,
EN.44: the one who is closest to my beak
EN.45: consoled the widow when she lost her son.
EN.46: 'Now he knows how dear the cost, should one fail
EN.47: to follow Christ, since he has lived
EN.48: both this sweet life and, long ago, that other.
EN.49: 'And he that follows on the arc of which I speak,
EN.50: there on its upward curve, delayed his death
EN.51: by offering up his true repentance.
EN.52: 'Now he knows God's irrevocable decree
EN.53: remains unaltered even when a worthy prayer postpones
EN.54: what might occur on earth today until tomorrow.
EN.55: 'The next one there, with good intent that bore bad fruit,
EN.56: turned Greek, along with both the laws and me,
EN.57: thus yielding his position to the shepherd.
EN.58: 'Now he knows that the evil which derived
EN.59: from his good act does him no harm,
EN.60: even if it brought the world to ruin.
EN.61: 'And the one you see on the downward arc was William,
EN.62: for whom those lands lament which weep in woe
EN.63: because of living Charles and living Frederick.
EN.64: 'Now he knows how Heaven is moved by love
EN.65: for a righteous king, as the effulgence
EN.66: of his aspect still makes plain.
EN.67: 'Who in the erring world below would think
EN.68: that Trojan Ripheus should be the fifth
EN.69: among the holy lights along this arc?
EN.70: 'Now he knows much the world cannot discern
EN.71: of heavenly grace, although his sight
EN.72: cannot make out the bottom of this sea.'
EN.73: Like the lark that soars in air,
EN.74: first singing, then silent, content and rejoicing
EN.75: in the final joyous sweetness of its song,
EN.76: such did that image seem to me, the very imprint
EN.77: of the eternal Beauty, by whose will
EN.78: all things become that which they truly are.
EN.79: And even though I was as clear in my perplexity
EN.80: as color shows through glass that covers it,
EN.81: my question could not bear to wait its turn in silence,
EN.82: but, by the pressure of its weight,
EN.83: forced from my lips: 'What are these things I see?'
EN.84: For there I saw a glittering revelry of lights.
EN.85: And then, its eye lit up with greater brilliance,
EN.86: the blessèd emblem, to set me free
EN.87: from suspense and wonder, gave its answer:
EN.88: 'I see that you believe these things because I say them
EN.89: but fail to see, how, though you believe them,
EN.90: they came to pass, because their cause is hidden.
EN.91: 'You are like the man who knows a thing by name
EN.92: but does not understand its quiddity
EN.93: unless another makes that plain to him.
EN.94: 'Regnum celorum suffers violence
EN.95: from fervent love and living hope.
EN.96: These conquer the very will of God,
EN.97: 'not as man may master man, but conquer it
EN.98: because it would be conquered, and,
EN.99: once conquered, itself conquers by its goodness.
EN.100: 'The first living soul in the eyebrow and the fifth
EN.101: make you wonder to find them adorning
EN.102: the dwelling-place of angels.
EN.103: They left their bodies not as gentiles
EN.104: but as Christians, firm in their beliefs, the one
EN.105: before, the other after, the piercing of His feet.
EN.106: 'For from Hell, where no one may return
EN.107: to righteous will, the one came back into his bones --
EN.108: this his reward for living hope,
EN.109: 'the living hope that furnished power to the prayers
EN.110: addressed to God to raise him from the dead
EN.111: so that his will might find its moving force.
EN.112: 'The blessèd soul of whom I speak,
EN.113: back in his flesh for but a while,
EN.114: believed in Him who had the power to help,
EN.115: 'and, believing, was kindled to such fire
EN.116: of the one true love that, on his second death,
EN.117: he was deemed worthy to enjoy our happiness.
EN.118: 'The other soul, through grace, which wells up
EN.119: from a source so deep there never was a creature
EN.120: who could thrust his vision to its primal spring,
EN.121: 'set all his love below on righteousness.
EN.122: And for that reason, from grace to grace,
EN.123: God opened his eyes to our redemption yet to come,
EN.124: 'so that he believed and, from that time on,
EN.125: endured no longer paganism's stench
EN.126: but rebuked the wayward peoples for it.
EN.127: 'The three ladies you saw near the right-hand wheel
EN.128: served to baptize him one thousand years and more
EN.129: before the sacrament existed.
EN.130: 'O predestination, how distant is your root
EN.131: from the gaze of those who cannot grasp
EN.132: the Primal Cause in its entirety!
EN.133: 'And you mortals, find some restraint
EN.134: in making judgments, for we, who gaze on God,
EN.135: have yet to know all those who are elect.
EN.136: 'And to us this very lack is sweet,
EN.137: because in this good is our good perfected,
EN.138: for that which God wills we will too.'
EN.139: Thus did that holy image,
EN.140: to cure the shortness of my vision,
EN.141: apply sweet medication to my eyes.
EN.142: And, as a practiced lute player will follow
EN.143: a practiced singer with his quivering chords,
EN.144: giving the song a sweeter sound,
EN.145: so, all the while the eagle spoke, as I recall,
EN.146: I kept my eyes on those two blessèd lights and saw,
EN.147: just as blinking eyes keep time as one,
EN.148: they timed their flames' pulsations to the words.

EN.1: Now my eyes were fixed again
EN.2: upon my lady's face. And with my eyes,
EN.3: my mind drew back from any other thought.
EN.4: She was not smiling. 'If I smiled,'
EN.5: she said, 'you would become what Semele became
EN.6: when she was turned to ashes,
EN.7: 'for my beauty, which you have seen
EN.8: flame up more brilliantly the higher we ascend
EN.9: the stairs of this eternal palace,
EN.10: 'is so resplendent that, were it not tempered
EN.11: in its blazing, your mortal powers would be
EN.12: like tree limbs rent and scorched by lightning.
EN.13: 'We have risen to the seventh splendor,
EN.14: which, beneath the burning Lion's breast,
EN.15: sends down its rays, now mingled with his power.
EN.16: 'Set your mind behind your eyes
EN.17: so that they may become the mirrors for the shape
EN.18: that in this heaven's mirror will appear to you.'
EN.19: When I was told to set my mind on other things,
EN.20: only one who knew how much my eyes could feast
EN.21: upon that blessèd countenance
EN.22: would understand what joy it was to me
EN.23: but to obey my heavenly guide,
EN.24: weighing one side of the scale against the other.
EN.25: Within the crystal, circling our earth,
EN.26: that bears the name of the world's belovèd king,
EN.27: under whose rule all wickedness lay dead,
EN.28: the color of gold in a ray of sunlight,
EN.29: I saw a ladder, rising to so great a height
EN.30: my eyesight could not rise along with it.
EN.31: I also saw, descending on its rungs,
EN.32: so many splendors that I thought that every light
EN.33: shining in the heavens was pouring down.
EN.34: And as, following their native instinct,
EN.35: rooks rise up together at the break of day,
EN.36: warming their feathers, stiffened by the cold,
EN.37: and some of them fly off, not to return,
EN.38: while some turn back to where they had set out,
EN.39: and some keep wheeling overhead,
EN.40: just such varied motions did I observe
EN.41: within that sparkling throng, which came as one,
EN.42: as soon as it had reached a certain rung.
EN.43: And the one that stayed the closest there to us
EN.44: grew so shining bright I said, but not aloud,
EN.45: 'This sign makes clear your love for me.
EN.46: 'But she, upon whose word I wait to know
EN.47: when and how to speak or to be silent, she keeps still
EN.48: and I do well, against my will, to ask no question.'
EN.49: She, therefore, who could see my silence plain
EN.50: in the sight of Him whose sight beholds all things,
EN.51: then said: 'Satisfy the ardent wish that burns within you.'
EN.52: And I: 'My merit does not make me worthy
EN.53: of your answer, but for the sake of her
EN.54: who gives me leave to ask,
EN.55: 'blessèd living soul, still hidden
EN.56: in the radiance of your joy, make known to me
EN.57: the cause that made you draw so near
EN.58: 'and tell me why, within this wheel,
EN.59: the sweet symphony of Paradise falls silent,
EN.60: which lower down resounds with such devotion.'
EN.61: 'Your hearing is as mortal as your sight,'
EN.62: he answered. 'Thus here there is no song
EN.63: for the very reason Beatrice has not smiled.
EN.64: 'I have come down the sacred ladder's rungs this far
EN.65: only to bid you welcome with my words
EN.66: and with the light that wraps me in its glow.
EN.67: 'It was not greater love that made me come more swiftly,
EN.68: for as much and more love burns above,
EN.69: as that flaming luminescence shows,
EN.70: 'but the profound affection prompting us
EN.71: to serve the Wisdom governing the world
EN.72: has brought about the outcome you perceive.'
EN.73: 'I see indeed, O sacred light,' I said,
EN.74: 'how acts of love, unbidden, serve this court
EN.75: in concord with that knowledge which foresees,
EN.76: 'but it is hard for me to understand
EN.77: why you alone among your peers
EN.78: were foreordained to act upon this charge.'
EN.79: I had not yet quite finished with my words
EN.80: when the light began to spin around its core,
EN.81: whirling like a quickly turning millstone.
EN.82: Then the love that was within it spoke:
EN.83: 'Divine light focuses on me, piercing
EN.84: the radiance that holds me in its womb.
EN.85: 'Its power, conjoined with my own sight,
EN.86: raises me so far above myself that I can see
EN.87: the Highest Essence, the source from which it flows.
EN.88: 'And this inflames the joy with which I burn:
EN.89: for, in the clarity of my sight,
EN.90: I match the clearness of my flame.
EN.91: 'Nonetheless, the most enlightened soul in Heaven,
EN.92: that seraph who fixes most his eye on God,
EN.93: could not produce an answer to your question,
EN.94: 'for what you ask is hidden in the depths
EN.95: of the abyss of God's eternal law, so that the sight
EN.96: of any being He created is cut off from it.
EN.97: 'And to the mortal world, when you return,
EN.98: bear this report, so that it shall no more presume
EN.99: to set its steps toward such a goal.
EN.100: 'The mind, here bright, is dimmed by smoke on earth.
EN.101: Ask yourself, then, how could it do down there
EN.102: what it cannot, though Heaven raise it to itself?'
EN.103: His words so reined me in
EN.104: that I withdrew the question, limiting myself
EN.105: to asking humbly who he was.
EN.106: 'Between Italy's two shores
EN.107: and not far distant from your homeland,
EN.108: crags rise so high that thunder rolls below them.
