IT.124: ciascun di quei candori in sù si stese
IT.125: con la sua cima, sì che l'alto affetto
IT.126: ch'elli avieno a Maria mi fu palese.
IT.127: Indi rimaser lì nel mio cospetto,
IT.128: "Regina celi" cantando sì dolce,
IT.129: che mai da me non si partì 'l diletto.
IT.130: Oh quanta è l'ubertà che si soffolce
IT.131: in quelle arche ricchissime che fuoro
IT.132: a seminar qua giù buone bobolce!
IT.133: Quivi si vive e gode del tesoro
IT.134: che s'acquistò piangendo ne lo essilio
IT.135: di Babillòn, ove si lasciò l'oro.
IT.136: Quivi trïunfa, sotto l'alto Filio
IT.137: di Dio e di Maria, di sua vittoria,
IT.138: e con l'antico e col novo concilio,
IT.139: colui che tien le chiavi di tal gloria.

EN.1: As the bird among the leafy branches that she loves,
EN.2: perched on the nest with her sweet brood
EN.3: all through the night, which keeps things veiled from us,
EN.4: who in her longing to look upon their eyes and beaks
EN.5: and to find the food to nourish them --
EN.6: a task, though difficult, that gives her joy --
EN.7: now, on an open bough, anticipates that time
EN.8: and, in her ardent expectation of the sun,
EN.9: watches intently for the dawn to break,
EN.10: so was my lady, erect and vigilant,
EN.11: seeking out the region of the sky
EN.12: in which the sun reveals less haste.
EN.13: I, therefore, seeing her suspended, wistful,
EN.14: became as one who, filled with longing,
EN.15: finds satisfaction in his hope.
EN.16: But time was short between one moment and the next,
EN.17: I mean between my expectation and the sight
EN.18: of the sky turned more and more resplendent.
EN.19: And Beatrice said: 'Behold the hosts
EN.20: of Christ in triumph and all the fruit
EN.21: gathered from the wheeling of these spheres!'
EN.22: It seemed to me her face was all aflame,
EN.23: her eyes so full of gladness
EN.24: that I must leave that moment undescribed.
EN.25: As, on clear nights when the moon is full,
EN.26: Trivia smiles among the eternal nymphs
EN.27: that deck the sky through all its depths,
EN.28: I saw, above the many thousand lamps,
EN.29: a Sun that kindled each and every one
EN.30: as ours lights up the sights we see above us,
EN.31: and through that living light poured down
EN.32: a shining substance. It blazed so bright
EN.33: into my eyes that I could not sustain it.
EN.34: O Beatrice, my sweet belovèd guide!
EN.35: To me she said: 'What overwhelms you
EN.36: is a force against which there is no defense.
EN.37: 'Here is the Wisdom and the Power that repaired
EN.38: the roads connecting Heaven and the earth
EN.39: that had so long been yearned for and desired.'
EN.40: As fire breaks from a cloud,
EN.41: swelling till it finds no room there,
EN.42: and, against its nature, falls to earth,
EN.43: just so my mind, grown greater at that feast,
EN.44: burst forth, transported from itself,
EN.45: and now cannot recall what it became.
EN.46: 'Open your eyes and see me as I am.
EN.47: The things that you have witnessed
EN.48: have given you the strength to bear my smile.'
EN.49: I was like a man who finds himself awakened
EN.50: from a dream that has faded and who strives
EN.51: in vain to bring it back to mind
EN.52: when I heard this invitation, deserving
EN.53: of such gratitude as can never be erased
EN.54: from the book that registers the past.
EN.55: If at this moment all the tongues
EN.56: that Polyhymnia and her sisters nurtured
EN.57: with their sweetest, richest milk
EN.58: should sound to aid me now, their song could not attain
EN.59: one thousandth of the truth in singing of that holy smile
EN.60: and how it made her holy visage radiant.
EN.61: And so, in representing Paradise,
EN.62: the sacred poem must make its leap across,
EN.63: as does a man who finds his path cut off.
EN.64: But considering the heavy theme
EN.65: and the mortal shoulder it weighs down,
EN.66: no one would cast blame if it trembled with its load.
EN.67: This is no easy voyage for a little bark,
EN.68: this stretch of sea the daring prow now cleaves,
EN.69: nor for a pilot who would spare himself.
EN.70: 'Why does my face arouse you so to love
EN.71: you do not turn to see the lovely garden
EN.72: now blossoming beneath the rays of Christ?
EN.73: 'There is the rose in which the Word of God
EN.74: was turned to flesh. There are the lilies
EN.75: for whose fragrance the right way was chosen.'
EN.76: Beatrice said these words. And I, all eager
EN.77: to follow her instruction, again resumed
EN.78: the struggle, despite my feeble power of sight.
EN.79: As, lit by the sun's rays streaming through broken clouds,
EN.80: my eyes, sheltered by the shade,
EN.81: once saw a field of flowers,
EN.82: so now I saw a many-splendored throng
EN.83: illuminated from above by blazing rays,
EN.84: but could not see the source of all that brightness.
EN.85: O gracious Power, who did thus imprint them!
EN.86: You rose to more exalted heights to grant
EN.87: their sight to eyes not ready to behold you.
EN.88: The name of the fair flower I invoke
EN.89: each morning and at evening time, enthralled my mind
EN.90: as I gazed at the brightest of the flames.
EN.91: When the quality and magnitude of the living star,
EN.92: who surpasses up above as she surpassed below,
EN.93: were painted on my eyes,
EN.94: there descended through the sky a torch that,
EN.95: circling, took on the likeness of a crown.
EN.96: It encircled her and wheeled around her.
EN.97: The sweetest melody, heard here below,
EN.98: that most attracts our souls,
EN.99: would seem a burst of cloud-torn thunder
EN.100: compared with the reverberation of that lyre
EN.101: with which the lovely sapphire that so ensapphires
EN.102: the brightest heaven was encrowned.
EN.103: 'I am angelic love and I encircle
EN.104: the exalted joy breathed from the womb
EN.105: that was the dwelling place of our desire,
EN.106: 'and I shall circle you, Lady of Heaven,
EN.107: until you follow your Son to the highest sphere,
EN.108: making it the more divine because you enter.'
EN.109: Thus that circling music, sealing itself,
EN.110: came to its conclusion, while all the other lights
EN.111: made Mary's name resound.
EN.112: The royal mantle of the universal turning spheres,
EN.113: which most burns and is most quickened
EN.114: in the breath of God and in His works,
EN.115: was, at its inner boundary,
EN.116: so very far above us that as yet,
EN.117: from where I was, it was well beyond my seeing,
EN.118: so that my eyes had not the power
EN.119: to fasten on the crown-tipped flame
EN.120: that rose along the path left by her sowing.
EN.121: And, like a baby reaching out its arms
EN.122: to mamma after it has drunk her milk,
EN.123: its inner impulse kindled into outward flame,
EN.124: all these white splendors were reaching upward
EN.125: with their fiery tips, so that their deep affection
EN.126: for Mary was made clear to me.
EN.127: Then they remained there in my sight,
EN.128: singing Regina celi with such sweetness
EN.129: that my feeling of delight has never left me.
EN.130: Oh, how great is the abundance
EN.131: that is stored in granaries so rich above,
EN.132: that down on earth were fields ripe for the sowing!
EN.133: There they live, rejoicing in the treasure
EN.134: they gained with tears of exile,
EN.135: in Babylon, where they spurned the gold.
EN.136: Beneath the exalted Son of God and Mary,
EN.137: up there he triumphs in his victory,
EN.138: with souls of the covenants old and new,
EN.139: the one who holds the keys to such great glory.

IT.1: "O sodalizio eletto a la gran cena
IT.2: del benedetto Agnello, il qual vi ciba
IT.3: sÃ¬, che la vostra voglia Ã¨ sempre piena,
IT.4: se per grazia di Dio questi preliba
IT.5: di quel che cade de la vostra mensa,
IT.6: prima che morte tempo li prescriba,
IT.7: ponete mente a l'affezione immensa
IT.8: e roratelo alquanto: voi bevete
IT.9: sempre del fonte onde vien quel ch'ei pensa."
IT.10: Così Beatrice; e quelle anime liete
IT.11: si fero spere sopra fissi poli,
IT.12: fiammando, volte, a guisa di comete.
IT.13: E come cerchi in tempra d'orïuoli
IT.14: si giran sì, che 'l primo a chi pon mente
IT.15: quïeto pare, e l'ultimo che voli;
IT.16: così quelle carole, differente-
IT.17: mente danzando, de la sua ricchezza
IT.18: mi facieno stimar, veloci e lente.
IT.19: Di quella ch'io notai di più carezza
IT.20: vid' ïo uscire un foco sì felice,
IT.21: che nullo vi lasciò di più chiarezza;
IT.22: e tre fïate intorno di Beatrice
IT.23: si volse con un canto tanto divo,
IT.24: che la mia fantasia nol mi ridice.
IT.25: Però salta la penna e non lo scrivo:
IT.26: ché l'imagine nostra a cotai pieghe,
IT.27: non che 'l parlare, è troppo color vivo.
IT.28: "O santa suora mia che sì ne prieghe
IT.29: divota, per lo tuo ardente affetto
IT.30: da quella bella spera mi disleghe."
IT.31: Poscia fermato, il foco benedetto
IT.32: a la mia donna dirizzò lo spiro,
IT.33: che favellò così com' i' ho detto.
IT.34: Ed ella: "O luce etterna del gran viro
IT.35: a cui Nostro Segnor lasciò le chiavi,
IT.36: ch'ei portò giù, di questo gaudio miro,
IT.37: tenta costui di punti lievi e gravi,
IT.38: come ti piace, intorno de la fede,
IT.39: per la qual tu su per lo mare andavi.
IT.40: S'elli ama bene e bene spera e crede,
IT.41: non t'è occulto, perché 'l viso hai quivi
IT.42: dov' ogne cosa dipinta si vede;
IT.43: ma perché questo regno ha fatto civi
IT.44: per la verace fede, a glorïarla,
IT.45: di lei parlare è ben ch'a lui arrivi."
IT.46: Sì come il baccialier s'arma e non parla
IT.47: fin che 'l maestro la question propone,
IT.48: per approvarla, non per terminarla,
IT.49: così m'armava io d'ogne ragione
IT.50: mentre ch'ella dicea, per esser presto
IT.51: a tal querente e a tal professione.
IT.52: "Dì, buon Cristiano, fatti manifesto:
IT.53: fede che è?" Ond' io levai la fronte
IT.54: in quella luce onde spirava questo;
IT.55: poi mi volsi a Beatrice, ed essa pronte
IT.56: sembianze femmi perch'ïo spandessi
IT.57: l'acqua di fuor del mio interno fonte.
IT.58: "La Grazia che mi dà ch'io mi confessi,"
IT.59: comincia' io, "da l'alto primipilo,
IT.60: faccia li miei concetti bene espressi."
IT.61: E seguitai: "Come 'l verace stilo
IT.62: ne scrisse, padre, del tuo caro frate
IT.63: che mise teco Roma nel buon filo,
IT.64: fede è sustanza di cose sperate
IT.65: e argomento de le non parventi;
IT.66: e questa pare a me sua quiditate."
IT.67: Allora udi': "Dirittamente senti,
IT.68: se bene intendi perché la ripuose
IT.69: tra le sustanze, e poi tra li argomenti."
IT.70: E io appresso: "Le profonde cose
IT.71: che mi largiscon qui la lor parvenza,
IT.72: a li occhi di là giù son sì ascose,
IT.73: che l'esser loro v'è in sola credenza,
IT.74: sopra la qual si fonda l'alta spene;
IT.75: e però di sustanza prende intenza.
IT.76: E da questa credenza ci convene
IT.77: silogizzar, sanz' avere altra vista:
IT.78: però intenza d'argomento tene."
IT.79: Allora udi': "Se quantunque s'acquista
IT.80: giù per dottrina, fosse così 'nteso,
IT.81: non lì avria loco ingegno di sofista."
IT.82: Così spirò di quello amore acceso;
IT.83: indi soggiunse: "Assai bene è trascorsa
IT.84: d'esta moneta già la lega e 'l peso;
IT.85: ma dimmi se tu l'hai ne la tua borsa."
IT.86: Ond' io: "Sì ho, sì lucida e sì tonda,
IT.87: che nel suo conio nulla mi s'inforsa."
IT.88: Appresso uscì de la luce profonda
IT.89: che lì splendeva: "Questa cara gioia
IT.90: sopra la quale ogne virtù si fonda,
IT.91: onde ti venne?" E io: "La larga ploia
IT.92: de lo Spirito Santo, ch'è diffusa
IT.93: in su le vecchie e 'n su le nuove cuoia,
IT.94: è silogismo che la m'ha conchiusa
IT.95: acutamente sì, che 'nverso d'ella
IT.96: ogne dimostrazion mi pare ottusa."
IT.97: Io udi' poi: "L'antica e la novella
IT.98: proposizion che così ti conchiude,
IT.99: perché l'hai tu per divina favella?"
IT.100: E io: "La prova che 'l ver mi dischiude,
IT.101: son l'opere seguite, a che natura
IT.102: non scalda ferro mai né batte incude."
IT.103: Risposto fummi: "Dì, chi t'assicura
IT.104: che quell' opere fosser? Quel medesmo
IT.105: che vuol provarsi, non altri, il ti giura."
IT.106: "Se 'l mondo si rivolse al cristianesmo,"
IT.107: diss' io, "sanza miracoli, quest' uno
IT.108: è tal, che li altri non sono il centesmo:
IT.109: ché tu intrasti povero e digiuno
IT.110: in campo, a seminar la buona pianta
IT.111: che fu già vite e ora è fatta pruno."
IT.112: Finito questo, l'alta corte santa
IT.113: risonò per le spere un "Dio laudamo"
IT.114: ne la melode che là sù si canta.
IT.115: E quel baron che sì di ramo in ramo,
IT.116: essaminando, già tratto m'avea,
IT.117: che a l'ultime fronde appressavamo,
IT.118: ricominciò: "La Grazia, che donnea
IT.119: con la tua mente, la bocca t'aperse
IT.120: infino a qui come aprir si dovea,
IT.121: sì ch'io approvo ciò che fuori emerse;
IT.122: ma or convien espremer quel che credi,
IT.123: e onde a la credenza tua s'offerse."
IT.124: "O santo padre, e spirito che vedi
IT.125: ciò che credesti sì, che tu vincesti
IT.126: ver' lo sepulcro più giovani piedi,"
IT.127: comincia' io, "tu vuo' ch'io manifesti
IT.128: la forma qui del pronto creder mio,
IT.129: e anche la cagion di lui chiedesti.
IT.130: E io rispondo: Io credo in uno Dio
IT.131: solo ed etterno, che tutto 'l ciel move,
IT.132: non moto, con amore e con disio;
IT.133: e a tal creder non ho io pur prove
IT.134: fisice e metafisice, ma dalmi
IT.135: anche la verità che quinci piove
IT.136: per Moïsè, per profeti e per salmi,
IT.137: per l'Evangelio e per voi che scriveste
IT.138: poi che l'ardente Spirto vi fé almi;
IT.139: e credo in tre persone etterne, e queste
IT.140: credo una essenza sì una e sì trina,
IT.141: che soffera congiunto 'sono' ed 'este.'
IT.142: De la profonda condizion divina
IT.143: ch'io tocco mo, la mente mi sigilla
IT.144: più volte l'evangelica dottrina.
IT.145: Quest' è 'l principio, quest' è la favilla
IT.146: che si dilata in fiamma poi vivace,
IT.147: e come stella in cielo in me scintilla."
IT.148: Come 'l segnor ch'ascolta quel che i piace,
IT.149: da indi abbraccia il servo, gratulando
IT.150: per la novella, tosto ch'el si tace;
IT.152: tre volte cinse me, sì com' io tacqui,
IT.154: io avea detto: sì nel dir li piacqui!

EN.1: 'O company of the elect chosen to feast
EN.2: at the great supper of the blessÃ¨d Lamb,
EN.3: who feeds you so that your desire is ever satisfied,
EN.4: 'since by God's grace this man enjoys a foretaste
EN.5: of whatsoever falls beneath your table,
EN.6: before death sets a limit to his time,
EN.7: 'heed his immeasurable craving and with dewdrops
EN.8: from that fountain where you drink forever,
EN.9: refresh him at the very source of all his thoughts.'
EN.10: Thus Beatrice. And those joyful spirits
EN.11: transformed themselves to rings around fixed poles,
EN.12: circling, like blazing comets, in their brightness.
EN.13: And as wheels in the movements of a clock
EN.14: turn in such a way that, to an observer,
EN.15: the innermost seems standing still, the outermost to fly,
EN.16: just so those dancers in their circling,
EN.17: moving to a different measure, fast or slow,
EN.18: let me gauge their wealth of gladness.
EN.19: From the dancer I made out to be most precious
EN.20: I saw come forth a flame so full of joy
EN.21: that not one there produced a greater brightness.
EN.22: Three times it circled Beatrice,
EN.23: its song so filled with heavenly delight
EN.24: my phantasy cannot repeat it.
EN.25: And so my pen skips and I do not write it,
EN.26: for our imagination is too crude, as is our speech,
EN.27: to paint the subtler colors of the folds of bliss.
EN.28: 'O my holy sister, who pray to us
EN.29: with such devotion, by the ardor of your love
EN.30: you draw me forth from that fair circle.'
EN.31: Once the blessèd fire had come to rest,
EN.32: for my lady it breathed forth these words,
EN.33: just as here I've set them down.
EN.34: And she: 'O everlasting light of that great man
EN.35: with whom our Lord did leave the keys,
EN.36: which He brought down from this astounding joy,
EN.37: 'test this man as you see fit on points,
EN.38: both minor and essential, about the faith
EN.39: by which you walked upon the sea.
EN.40: 'Whether his love is just, and just his hope and faith,
EN.41: is not concealed from you because your sight
EN.42: can reach the place where all things are revealed.
EN.43: 'But since this realm elects its citizens
EN.44: by measure of true faith, it surely is his lot
EN.45: to speak of it, that he may praise its glory.'
EN.46: Just as the bachelor arms himself and does not speak
EN.47: while the master is setting forth the question --
EN.48: for discussion, not for final disposition --
EN.49: so I armed myself with all my arguments
EN.50: while she was speaking, readying myself
EN.51: for such an examiner and such professing.
EN.52: 'Speak up, good Christian, and make your declaration.
EN.53: What is faith?' At that I lifted up my brow
EN.54: to the light from which this breathed,
EN.55: and then I faced Beatrice, who quickly signaled,
EN.56: with a glance, that I should now pour forth
EN.57: the waters welling from the source within me.
EN.58: 'May the grace that allows me to make confession
EN.59: to the great centurion,' I began,
EN.60: 'grant clear expression to my thoughts.'
EN.61: And I continued: 'As the truthful pen,
EN.62: father, of your dear brother wrote it,
EN.63: he who, with you, set Rome upon the path to truth,
EN.64: 'faith is the substance of things hoped for,
EN.65: the evidence of things that are not seen.
EN.66: And this I take to be its quiddity.'
EN.67: Then I heard: 'You reason rightly if you understand
EN.68: why he placed it, first, among the substances,
EN.69: only then to set it down as evidence.'
EN.70: And I: 'The profound mysteries
EN.71: that here so richly manifest themselves to me,
EN.72: to our eyes below are so concealed
EN.73: 'that they exist there through belief alone,
EN.74: on which is based our hope to rise above.
EN.75: And therefore it assumes the name of substance.
EN.76: 'It is from this belief that we must argue,
EN.77: when there is nothing else we can examine.
EN.78: And it therefore has the name of evidence.'
EN.79: Then I heard: 'If all that is acquired below
EN.80: from doctrine taught were this well learned,
EN.81: there would be left no room for sophistry.'
EN.82: This breathed forth from that kindled love.
EN.83: And it continued: 'Now this coin's alloy
EN.84: and weight are well examined,
EN.85: 'but tell me if you have it in your purse.'
EN.86: And I: 'I do indeed, so bright and round
EN.87: that of its coinage I am not in doubt.'
EN.88: Then came forth from the depth of the light
EN.89: refulgent there: 'This precious gem
EN.90: upon which all the virtues rest,
EN.91: 'what was its origin and how did you obtain it?'
EN.92: And I: 'The abundant rain of the Holy Ghost,
EN.93: poured out onto the parchments old and new,
EN.94: 'is the syllogism that has proven it to me
EN.95: with such great force that any other demonstration,
EN.96: compared with it, would seem completely pointless.'
EN.97: Then I heard: 'The premises, both old and new,
EN.98: that you find so convincing in their truth,
EN.99: why do you take them for the word of God?'
EN.100: And I: 'The proof that revealed the truth to me
EN.101: are the works that followed, for which nature
EN.102: neither makes iron red with heat nor smites an anvil.'
EN.103: 'Say,' came the answer, 'who assures you that these works
EN.104: all really happened? The very thing requiring proof,
EN.105: and nothing else, is your sole warrant of them.'
EN.106: 'For the world to have turned to Christ,'
EN.107: I said, 'without miracles, that indeed was one
EN.108: to outdo all others more than hundredfold.
EN.109: 'For poor and fasting did you come into the field
EN.110: to sow the good plant that was once a vine
EN.111: and now has turned into a thornbush.'
EN.112: My words ended, the high and holy court resounded
EN.113: through all its starry spheres with 'Lord, we praise you'
EN.114: with such melody as is only sung above.
EN.115: And that nobleman who now had led me thus
EN.116: from branch to branch in his examination
EN.117: so that we neared the highest boughs,
EN.118: began again: 'The grace that woos your mind
EN.119: has until this moment opened your lips
EN.120: and made your mouth say what it should,
EN.121: 'so that I approve what has come forth from it.
EN.122: But now you must declare what you believe
EN.123: and through what means you came to such belief.'
EN.124: 'O holy father, spirit who now can see
EN.125: that which you once believed with such conviction
EN.126: you outstripped younger feet to reach the sepulcher,'
EN.127: I began, 'you would have me here declare
EN.128: the substance of my ready faith, and also tell
EN.129: the source of it, the reason why I hold it dear.
EN.130: 'And I reply: I believe in one God,
EN.131: one and eternal, who, Himself unmoved, moves
EN.132: all the heavens with His love and their desire.
EN.133: 'In defense of this belief I do have proof, not only
EN.134: physical and metaphysical, but offered
EN.135: also by the truth that pours like rain from here
EN.136: 'through Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms,
EN.137: through what the Gospel says and what you wrote
EN.138: once the burning Spirit made you holy.
EN.139: 'I believe in three eternal Persons. I believe
EN.140: these are a single Essence, at once threefold and one
EN.141: so as to allow agreement both with "are" and "is."
EN.142: 'The profound truth of God's own state of which I speak
EN.143: is many times imprinted in my mind
EN.144: by the true instructions of the Gospel.
EN.145: 'This is the beginning, this the living spark
EN.146: that swells into a living flame
EN.147: and shines within me like a star in heaven.'
EN.148: As the master to whom a servant brings good news
EN.149: rejoices when he hears it, and puts his arms around
EN.150: the speaker just as soon as he has finished,
EN.151: thus, blessing me as he sang,
EN.152: the apostolic light, at whose command I spoke,
EN.153: encircled me three times once I was silent,
EN.154: because my words had brought him such delight.

IT.1: Se mai continga che 'l poema sacro
IT.2: al quale ha posto mano e cielo e terra,
IT.3: sì che m'ha fatto per molti anni macro,
IT.4: vinca la crudeltà che fuor mi serra
IT.5: del bello ovile ov' io dormi' agnello,
IT.6: nimico ai lupi che li danno guerra;
IT.7: con altra voce omai, con altro vello
IT.8: ritornerò poeta, e in sul fonte
IT.9: del mio battesmo prenderò 'l cappello;
IT.10: però che ne la fede, che fa conte

EN.1: Should it ever come to pass that this sacred poem,
EN.2: to which both Heaven and earth have set their hand
EN.3: so that it has made me lean for many years,
EN.4: should overcome the cruelty that locks me out
EN.5: of the fair sheepfold where I slept as a lamb,
EN.6: foe of the wolves at war with it,
EN.7: with another voice then, with another fleece,
EN.8: shall I return a poet and, at the font

EN.11: that recommends the soul to God, and now,

EN.14: out of which had come the first-fruit of the stock
EN.15: of vicars Christ did leave for us on earth,
EN.16: and my lady, brimming with joy, said to me:
EN.17: 'Look, look, here is the nobleman
EN.18: who down below draws pilgrims to Galicia.'

EN.20: and each displays, circling and cooing,
EN.21: its fondness for the other,
EN.22: so I saw one great and glorious prince
EN.23: welcomed by the other, both giving praise
EN.24: for the feast that there above they share.

EN.26: they both stopped, silent, coram me,
EN.27: so brightly flaming that they overcame my sight.
EN.28: Then, smiling, Beatrice said:
EN.29: 'Illustrious living soul, you who wrote
EN.30: of the abundant gifts of our heavenly court,
EN.31: 'make Hope resound here at this height, since you
EN.32: know how, you who were the very figure of it
EN.33: when Jesus showed most favor to the three.'
EN.34: 'Lift up your head and then take heart,
EN.35: for all that comes here from the mortal world
EN.36: will here be ripened in our radiance.'
EN.37: The second fire offered this assurance.
EN.38: Therefore I raised my eyes up to the hills
EN.39: whose blazing light had weighed them down before.
EN.40: 'Since our Emperor, of His grace,
EN.41: wills that you come, before your death,
EN.42: to meet His nobles in His secret chamber,
EN.43: 'so that, having known the reality of this court,
EN.44: you may then strengthen in yourself and others
EN.45: the hope that brings true love to those on earth,
EN.46: 'tell what it is and how it blossoms in your mind,
EN.47: and tell from where it came to you.'

EN.49: And the compassionate soul who guided
EN.50: the feathers on my wings to that great height
EN.51: answered for me before I could reply:
EN.52: 'The Church Militant has no other son
EN.53: so filled with hope, as it is written
EN.54: in the Sun that shines its rays on all our host.
EN.55: 'Therefore is it granted him to come from Egypt
EN.56: to Jerusalem that he may see the city
EN.57: before his time of warfare has its end.

EN.61: 'I leave to him. For they will not be difficult,
EN.62: nor offer grounds for boasting of himself.

EN.64: Like the student answering his teacher,
EN.65: ready and eager in the subject he prepared,
EN.66: intending to display his worth,
EN.67: 'Hope,' I said, 'is the certain expectation
EN.68: of future glory, springing
EN.69: from heavenly grace and merit we have won.
EN.70: 'This light comes down to me from many stars,

EN.72: was that exalted singer of our exalted Lord.

EN.74: in his god-song, "those who know your name."

EN.89: set forth the goal for souls that God has made his friends

EN.2: from the resplendent flame that blinded me
EN.3: there breathed a voice that caught my ear:
EN.4: 'Until you have regained the sight
EN.5: you have consumed on me, you will do well
EN.6: to make good for its loss with speech.

EN.9: is but confounded, not forever lost,
EN.10: 'for the lady who guides you through
EN.11: this holy place possesses in her glance
EN.12: the power the hand of Ananias had.'
EN.13: And I said: 'As soon or as late as she wishes,
EN.14: may the cure come to eyes that were the portals
EN.15: she entered with the fire in which I always burn.
EN.16: 'The good that satisfies this court
EN.17: is alpha and omega of whatever scripture
EN.18: Love teaches me in loud or gentle tones.'
EN.19: The same voice that had set me free
EN.20: from fear at my sudden blindness
EN.21: made me hesitate before I spoke again,
EN.22: when it said: 'It is clear you need to sift
EN.23: with a finer sieve, for you must reveal
EN.24: who made you aim your bow at such a target.'
EN.25: And I: 'Both philosophic reasoning
EN.26: and the authority that descends from here
EN.27: made me receive the imprint of such love,
EN.28: 'for the good, by measure of its goodness, kindles
EN.29: love as soon as it is known, and so much more
EN.30: the more of goodness it contains.
EN.31: 'To that essence, then, which holds such store of goodness
EN.32: that every good outside of it is nothing
EN.33: but a light reflected of its rays,
EN.34: 'the mind of everyone who sees the truth
EN.35: on which this argument is based
EN.36: must, more than anything, be moved by love.

EN.38: by him who demonstrates to me the primal love
EN.39: of all eternal substances.
EN.40: 'And the voice of the truthful Author sets it forth
EN.41: when, speaking of Himself, He says to Moses:
EN.42: "I will make all My goodness pass before you."
EN.43: 'You also set it forth to me in the beginning
EN.44: of your great message, which, more than any other herald,
EN.45: proclaims the mystery of this high place on earth.'
EN.46: And I heard: 'In accord with human reason
EN.47: and with the authorities concordant with it,
EN.48: the highest of your loves is turned to God.

IT.84: con le bellezze d'ogne sua paroffia;
IT.85: così fec'ïo, poi che mi provide
IT.86: la donna mia del suo risponder chiaro,
IT.87: e come stella in cielo il ver si vide.
IT.88: E poi che le parole sue restaro,
IT.89: non altrimenti ferro disfavilla
IT.90: che bolle, come i cerchi sfavillaro.
IT.91: L'incendio suo seguiva ogne scintilla;
IT.92: ed eran tante, che 'l numero loro
IT.93: più che 'l doppiar de li scacchi s'inmilla.
IT.94: Io sentiva osannar di coro in coro
IT.95: al punto fisso che li tiene a li ubi,
IT.96: e terrà sempre, ne' quai sempre fuoro.
IT.97: E quella che vedëa i pensier dubi
IT.98: ne la mia mente, disse: "I cerchi primi
IT.99: t'hanno mostrato Serafi e Cherubi.
IT.100: Così veloci seguono i suoi vimi,
IT.101: per somigliarsi al punto quanto ponno;
IT.102: e posson quanto a veder son soblimi.
IT.103: Quelli altri amori che 'ntorno li vonno,
IT.104: si chiaman Troni del divino aspetto,
IT.105: per che 'l primo ternaro terminonno;
IT.106: e dei saper che tutti hanno diletto
IT.107: quanto la sua veduta si profonda
IT.108: nel vero in che si queta ogne intelletto.
IT.109: Quinci si può veder come si fonda
IT.110: l'esser beato ne l'atto che vede,
IT.111: non in quel ch'ama, che poscia seconda;
IT.112: e del vedere è misura mercede,
IT.113: che grazia partorisce e buona voglia:
IT.114: così di grado in grado si procede.
IT.115: L'altro ternaro, che così germoglia
IT.116: in questa primavera sempiterna
IT.117: che notturno Arïete non dispoglia,
IT.118: perpetüalemente 'Osanna' sberna
IT.119: con tre melode, che suonano in tree
IT.120: ordini di letizia onde s'interna.
IT.121: In essa gerarcia son l'altre dee:
IT.122: prima Dominazioni, e poi Virtudi;
IT.123: l'ordine terzo di Podestadi èe.
IT.124: Poscia ne' due penultimi tripudi
IT.125: Principati e Arcangeli si girano;
IT.126: l'ultimo è tutto d'Angelici ludi.
IT.127: Questi ordini di sù tutti s'ammirano,
IT.128: e di giù vincon sì, che verso Dio
IT.129: tutti tirati sono e tutti tirano.
IT.130: E Dïonisio con tanto disio
IT.131: a contemplar questi ordini si mise,
IT.132: che li nomò e distinse com' io.
IT.133: Ma Gregorio da lui poi si divise;
IT.134: onde, sì tosto come li occhi aperse
IT.135: in questo ciel, di sé medesmo rise.
IT.136: E se tanto secreto ver proferse
IT.137: mortale in terra, non voglio ch'ammiri:
IT.138: ché chi 'l vide qua sù gliel discoperse
IT.139: con altro assai del ver di questi giri."

EN.1: When she who does imparadise my mind
EN.2: had revealed the truth against
EN.3: the present life of wretched mortals,
EN.4: then, as one whose way is lit by a double-candled lamp
EN.5: held at his back, who suddenly in a mirror sees
EN.6: the flame before he has seen or even thought of it
EN.7: and turns to see if the glass is telling him the truth,
EN.8: and then sees that it reflects things as they are --
EN.9: as notes reflect the score when they are sung --
EN.10: just so do I remember having done,
EN.11: gazing into the beautiful eyes
EN.12: which Love had made into the snare that caught me.
EN.13: When I turned back and my eyes were struck
EN.14: by what appears on that revolving sphere --
EN.15: if one but contemplates its circling --
EN.16: I saw a point that flashed a beam of light
EN.17: so sharp the eye on which it burns
EN.18: must close against its piercing brightness.
EN.19: The star that, seen from here below, seems smallest
EN.20: would seem a moon if put beside it,
EN.21: as when one star is set beside another.
EN.22: As near, perhaps, as a halo seems to be
EN.23: when it encircles the light that colors it,
EN.24: where the vapor that forms it is most dense,
EN.25: there whirled about that point a ring of fire
EN.26: so quick it would have easily outsped
EN.27: the swiftest sphere circling the universe.
EN.28: This point was encircled by another ring,
EN.29: and that by the third, the third by the fourth,
EN.30: the fourth by the fifth, and the fifth by the sixth.
EN.31: Higher there followed the seventh, now spread so wide
EN.32: that the messenger of Juno, in full circle,
EN.33: would be unable to contain its size.
EN.34: And so, too, the eighth and ninth,
EN.35: each one revolving with diminished speed
EN.36: the farther it was wheeling from the first.
EN.37: And that one least removed from the blazing point of light
EN.38: possessed the clearest flame, because, I think,
EN.39: it was the one that is the most intruthed by it.
EN.40: My lady, who saw me in grave doubt
EN.41: yet eager to know and comprehend, said:
EN.42: 'From that point depend the heavens and all nature.
EN.43: 'Observe that circle nearest it,
EN.44: and understand its motion is so swift
EN.45: because it is spurred on by flaming love.'
EN.46: And I to her: 'If the universe were arranged
EN.47: in the order I see here among these wheels
EN.48: I would be content with what you've set before me.
EN.49: 'However, in the world of sense we see
EN.50: the farther from the center they revolve
EN.51: the more divinity is in their orbits.
EN.52: 'And so, if my desire to know shall gain its end
EN.53: in this rare temple of the angels,
EN.54: which has but light and love for boundaries,
EN.55: 'then I still need to learn exactly why
EN.56: model and copy fail to follow the same plan,
EN.57: for, using my own powers, I reflect on this in vain.'
EN.58: 'That your fingers are not fit to undo this knot
EN.59: is not surprising, so entangled
EN.60: has it become from never being tried.'
EN.61: My lady said this, then went on: 'Take
EN.62: what I shall tell you if you would be fed,
EN.63: and see you sharpen your wits on it.
EN.64: 'The material heavens are wide or narrow
EN.65: according as power, greater or less,
EN.66: is diffused through all their parts.
EN.67: 'Greater goodness makes for greater blessedness,
EN.68: and greater bliss takes on a greater body
EN.69: when all its parts are equal in perfection.
EN.70: 'This sphere, therefore, which sweeps into its motion
EN.71: the rest of the universe, must correspond
EN.72: to the ring that loves and knows the most,
EN.73: 'so that, if you apply your measure,
EN.74: not to their appearances but to the powers themselves
EN.75: of the angels that appear to you as circles,
EN.76: 'you will see a marvelous congruence,
EN.77: larger with more, smaller with less, in each sphere
EN.78: according to its celestial Intelligence.
EN.79: As the vault of our air is left
EN.80: serene and shining when Boreas
EN.81: blows from his gentler cheek
EN.82: and the dark refuse of the sky is cleared
EN.83: and purged away so that the heavens smile
EN.84: as all their quarters fill with loveliness,
EN.85: just so did I feel when my lady
EN.86: bestowed on me her lucid answer,
EN.87: and, like a star in heaven, the truth shone clear.
EN.88: And, when she paused in her speech,
EN.89: as boiling iron shoots out sparks
EN.90: so did these circles sparkle,
EN.91: each spark keeping to its flaming ring. They were
EN.92: so many that their number ran to thousands more
EN.93: than the successive doubling of a chessboard's squares.
EN.94: From choir to choir I heard Hosanna sung
EN.95: to the fixed point, which holds them -- and forever shall --
EN.96: in those ubi that have always been theirs.
EN.97: And she, who understood the puzzled thoughts
EN.98: now present in my mind, said: 'The closer rings
EN.99: reveal to you both Seraphim and Cherubim.
EN.100: 'They pursue their bonds so swiftly, hoping they may gain
EN.101: as much as they can hold of likeness to the point,
EN.102: and this they can attain, the loftier their vision.
EN.103: 'These other loving spirits circling them
EN.104: are called the Thrones of God,
EN.105: and with them the first triad was complete.
EN.106: 'And you should know that all of them delight
EN.107: in measure of the depth to which their sight
EN.108: can penetrate the truth, where every intellect finds rest.
EN.109: 'From this, it may be seen, beatitude itself
EN.110: is based upon the act of seeing,
EN.111: not on that of love, which follows after,
EN.112: 'and the measure of their sight reveals their worth,
EN.113: which grace and proper will beget in them.
EN.114: Such, then, is the process, step by step.
EN.115: 'The second triad thus blossoming
EN.116: in this eternity of spring
EN.117: which no nocturnal Ram cuts short
EN.118: 'ever sings hosannas, the threefold strain
EN.119: resounding in the threefold ranks
EN.120: of bliss by which they are intrined.
EN.121: 'In this hierarchy are found the next divinities --
EN.122: Dominions first, then Virtues,
EN.123: and the third are Powers.
EN.124: 'The penultimate two of these festive throngs
EN.125: are whirling Principalities and Archangels,
EN.126: while the last one is all Angels at their play.
EN.127: 'All these orders gaze in ecstasy above.
EN.128: The highest so prevail on those below,
EN.129: that the rest are drawn, and also draw, to God.
EN.130: 'Dionysius with such passion set his mind
EN.131: to contemplate these orders
EN.132: that he named them and arranged them as do I.
EN.133: 'But later Gregory took a different view,
EN.134: so that, opening his eyes here in this heaven,
EN.135: he saw his errors, laughing at himself.
EN.136: 'And if a mortal man on earth set forth
EN.137: such hidden truth, you need not wonder: for he
EN.138: who saw it here above revealed it then to him,
EN.139: along with many other truths about these circlings.'

IT.1: Quando ambedue li figli di Latona,
IT.2: coperti del Montone e de la Libra,
IT.3: fanno de l'orizzonte insieme zona,
IT.4: quant' è dal punto che 'l cenìt inlibra
IT.5: infin che l'uno e l'altro da quel cinto,
IT.6: cambiando l'emisperio, si dilibra,
IT.7: tanto, col volto di riso dipinto,
IT.8: si tacque Bëatrice, riguardando
IT.9: fiso nel punto che m'avëa vinto.
IT.10: Poi cominciò: "Io dico, e non dimando,
IT.11: quel che tu vuoli udir, perch' io l'ho visto
IT.12: là 've s'appunta ogne ubi e ogne quando.
IT.13: Non per aver a sé di bene acquisto,
IT.14: ch'esser non può, ma perché suo splendore
IT.15: potesse, risplendendo, dir 'Subsisto,'
IT.16: in sua etternità di tempo fore,
IT.17: fuor d'ogne altro comprender, come i piacque,
IT.18: s'aperse in nuovi amor l'etterno amore.
IT.19: Né prima quasi torpente si giacque;
IT.20: ché né prima né poscia procedette
IT.21: lo discorrer di Dio sovra quest' acque.
IT.22: Forma e materia, congiunte e purette,
IT.23: usciro ad esser che non avia fallo,
IT.24: come d'arco tricordo tre saette.
IT.25: E come in vetro, in ambra o in cristallo
IT.26: raggio resplende sì, che dal venire
IT.27: a l'esser tutto non è intervallo,
IT.28: così 'l triforme effetto del suo sire
IT.29: ne l'esser suo raggiò insieme tutto
IT.30: sanza distinzïone in essordire.
IT.31: Concreato fu ordine e costrutto
IT.32: a le sustanze; e quelle furon cima
IT.33: nel mondo in che puro atto fu produtto;
IT.34: pura potenza tenne la parte ima;
IT.35: nel mezzo strinse potenza con atto
IT.36: tal vime, che già mai non si divima.
IT.37: Ieronimo vi scrisse lungo tratto
IT.38: di secoli de li angeli creati
IT.39: anzi che l'altro mondo fosse fatto;
IT.40: ma questo vero è scritto in molti lati
IT.41: da li scrittor de lo Spirito Santo,
IT.42: e tu te n'avvedrai se bene agguati;
IT.43: e anche la ragione il vede alquanto,
IT.44: che non concederebbe che ' motori
IT.45: sanza sua perfezion fosser cotanto.
IT.46: Or sai tu dove e quando questi amori
IT.47: furon creati e come: sì che spenti
IT.48: nel tuo disïo già son tre ardori.
IT.49: Né giugneriesi, numerando, al venti
IT.50: sì tosto, come de li angeli parte
IT.51: turbò il suggetto d'i vostri alimenti.
IT.52: L'altra rimase, e cominciò quest' arte
IT.53: che tu discerni, con tanto diletto,
IT.54: che mai da circüir non si diparte.
IT.55: Principio del cader fu il maladetto
IT.56: superbir di colui che tu vedesti
IT.57: da tutti i pesi del mondo costretto.
IT.58: Quelli che vedi qui furon modesti
IT.59: a riconoscer sé da la bontate
IT.60: che li avea fatti a tanto intender presti:
IT.61: per che le viste lor furo essaltate
IT.62: con grazia illuminante e con lor merto,
IT.63: sì c'hanno ferma e piena volontate;
IT.64: e non voglio che dubbi, ma sia certo,
IT.65: che ricever la grazia è meritorio
IT.66: secondo che l'affetto l'è aperto.
IT.67: Omai dintorno a questo consistorio
IT.68: puoi contemplare assai, se le parole
IT.69: mie son ricolte, sanz' altro aiutorio.
IT.70: Ma perché 'n terra per le vostre scole
IT.71: si legge che l'angelica natura
IT.72: è tal, che 'ntende e si ricorda e vole,
IT.73: ancor dirò, perché tu veggi pura
IT.74: la verità che là giù si confonde,
IT.75: equivocando in sì fatta lettura.
IT.76: Queste sustanze, poi che fur gioconde
IT.77: de la faccia di Dio, non volser viso
IT.78: da essa, da cui nulla si nasconde:
IT.79: però non hanno vedere interciso
IT.80: da novo obietto, e però non bisogna
IT.81: rememorar per concetto diviso;
IT.82: sì che là giù, non dormendo, si sogna,
IT.83: credendo e non credendo dicer vero;
IT.84: ma ne l'uno è più colpa e più vergogna.
IT.85: Voi non andate giù per un sentiero
IT.86: filosofando: tanto vi trasporta
IT.87: l'amor de l'apparenza e 'l suo pensiero!
IT.88: E ancor questo qua sù si comporta
IT.89: con men disdegno che quando è posposta
IT.90: la divina Scrittura o quando è torta.
IT.91: Non vi si pensa quanto sangue costa
IT.92: seminarla nel mondo e quanto piace
IT.93: chi umilmente con essa s'accosta.
IT.94: Per apparer ciascun s'ingegna e face
IT.95: sue invenzioni; e quelle son trascorse
IT.96: da' predicanti e 'l Vangelio si tace.
IT.97: Un dice che la luna si ritorse
IT.98: ne la passion di Cristo e s'interpuose,
IT.99: per che 'l lume del sol giù non si porse;
IT.100: e mente, ché la luce si nascose
IT.101: da sé: però a li Spani e a l'Indi
IT.102: come a' Giudei tale eclissi rispuose.
IT.103: Non ha Fiorenza tanti Lapi e Bindi
IT.104: quante sì fatte favole per anno
IT.105: in pergamo si gridan quinci e quindi:
IT.106: sì che le pecorelle, che non sanno,
IT.107: tornan del pasco pasciute di vento,
IT.108: e non le scusa non veder lo danno.
IT.109: Non disse Cristo al suo primo convento:
IT.110: 'Andate, e predicate al mondo ciance';
IT.111: ma diede lor verace fondamento;
IT.112: e quel tanto sonò ne le sue guance,
IT.113: sì ch'a pugnar per accender la fede
IT.114: de l'Evangelio fero scudo e lance.
IT.115: Ora si va con motti e con iscede
IT.116: a predicare, e pur che ben si rida,
IT.117: gonfia il cappuccio e più non si richiede.
IT.118: Ma tale uccel nel becchetto s'annida,
IT.119: che se 'l vulgo il vedesse, vederebbe
IT.120: la perdonanza di ch'el si confida:
IT.121: per cui tanta stoltezza in terra crebbe,
IT.122: che, sanza prova d'alcun testimonio,
IT.123: ad ogne promession si correrebbe.
IT.124: Di questo ingrassa il porco sant' Antonio,
IT.125: e altri assai che sono ancor più porci,
IT.126: pagando di moneta sanza conio.
IT.127: Ma perché siam digressi assai, ritorci
IT.128: li occhi oramai verso la dritta strada,
IT.129: sì che la via col tempo si raccorci.
IT.130: Questa natura sì oltre s'ingrada
IT.131: in numero, che mai non fu loquela
IT.132: né concetto mortal che tanto vada;
IT.133: e se tu guardi quel che si revela
IT.134: per Danïel, vedrai che 'n sue migliaia
IT.135: determinato numero si cela.
IT.136: La prima luce, che tutta la raia,
IT.137: per tanti modi in essa si recepe,
IT.138: quanti son li splendori a chi s'appaia.
IT.139: Onde, però che a l'atto che concepe
IT.140: segue l'affetto, d'amar la dolcezza
IT.141: diversamente in essa ferve e tepe.
IT.142: Vedi l'eccelso omai e la larghezza
IT.143: de l'etterno valor, poscia che tanti
IT.144: speculi fatti s'ha in che si spezza,
IT.145: uno manendo in sé come davanti."

EN.1: When the two offspring of Latona,
EN.2: one covered by the Ram, one by the Scales,
EN.3: together make a belt of the horizon
EN.4: for the moment that the zenith
EN.5: holds them balanced, until each of them,
EN.6: in changing hemispheres, unbalances that belt,
EN.7: for just that long, her face lit by a smile,
EN.8: Beatrice was silent, staring intently
EN.9: at the point that overcame me.
EN.10: Then she began: 'I tell, I do not ask,
EN.11: what you would like to hear. For I have seen it there
EN.12: where every ubi and every quando has its center.
EN.13: 'Not to increase His store of goodness,
EN.14: a thing impossible, but that His splendor,
EN.15: shining back, might say Subsisto,
EN.16: 'in His eternity, beyond time, beyond
EN.17: any other limit, as it pleased Him,
EN.18: in these new loves, Eternal Love unfolded.
EN.19: 'Nor, before then, did He rest in torpor,
EN.20: for until God moved upon these waters
EN.21: there existed no "before," there was no "after."
EN.22: 'Form and matter, conjoined and separate,
EN.23: came into being without defect,
EN.24: shot like three arrows from a three-stringed bow.
EN.25: 'And, as a ray shines right through glass, amber,
EN.26: or crystal, so that between its presence
EN.27: and its shining there is no lapse of time,
EN.28: 'just so did the threefold creation flash --
EN.29: with no intervals in its beginning --
EN.30: from its Lord into being, all at once.
EN.31: 'With it, order was created and ordained
EN.32: for the angels, and these were the summit
EN.33: of the universe, for in them God produced pure act.
EN.34: 'Pure potential held the lowest place.
EN.35: Between them, potential and act were held together
EN.36: by such a bond as may not be unbound.
EN.37: 'Jerome's writing tells you all the angels
EN.38: were created many centuries before
EN.39: the rest of the universe came into being.
EN.40: 'Yet the scribes of the Holy Ghost declare
EN.41: the truth on many pages,
EN.42: as you shall find on searching with some care.
EN.43: 'And even reason sees it, in some measure,
EN.44: for it would not grant that the movers of the heavens
EN.45: should remain so long without becoming perfect.
EN.46: 'Now you know both where and when these loving spirits
EN.47: were created, and you know how, as well.
EN.48: And thus three flames of your desire have been quenched.
EN.49: 'Then, sooner than one might count to twenty,
EN.50: one band of angels had disturbed
EN.51: the lowest of your elements.
EN.52: 'The other band remained and gave itself
EN.53: with such abandon to this task, which you behold,
EN.54: that never does it cease its circling motion.
EN.55: 'The cause accounting for the fall
EN.56: was the accursèd pride of him you saw
EN.57: crushed beneath the weight of all the world.
EN.58: 'These whom you observe here all were humble,
EN.59: acknowledging the Goodness that had made them fit
EN.60: to be endowed with an intelligence so vast.
EN.61: 'Thus their vision was exalted
EN.62: by illuminating grace, along with their own merit,
EN.63: so that theirs is a will both whole and steadfast.
EN.64: 'And I would not have you doubt, but rather be assured,
EN.65: that there is merit in receiving grace
EN.66: in measure as the heart inclines to it.
EN.67: 'Henceforth, if you have understood my words,
EN.68: you may examine anything you like
EN.69: in this assembly without need of aid.
EN.70: 'But since in schools on earth you still are taught
EN.71: that the angelic nature is possessed
EN.72: of understanding, memory, and will,
EN.73: 'I will continue, so that you clearly see
EN.74: how truth is made unclear down there
EN.75: by such equivocation in its teaching.
EN.76: 'These angelic beings, since they first rejoiced
EN.77: in the face of God, from which nothing may be hidden,
EN.78: have never turned their eyes away from it,
EN.79: 'so that their sight is never interrupted
EN.80: by some new object. And thus they have no need
EN.81: to search the past for some forgotten construct.
EN.82: 'Thus down there men are dreaming while they wake,
EN.83: believing that they speak the truth. And those
EN.84: who don't believe so share the greater guilt and shame.
EN.85: 'Down there, when you philosophize, you fail
EN.86: to follow one true path, so does the love of show
EN.87: preoccupy your mind and carry you away,
EN.88: 'and even this is tolerated here
EN.89: with less wrath than when holy Scripture
EN.90: is neglected or its doctrines are mistaught.
EN.91: 'There is no thought among you of the blood it costs
EN.92: to sow the world with it, or how acceptable he is
EN.93: who humbly makes his way to it.
EN.94: 'Each strives to gain attention by inventing new ideas,
EN.95: expounded by the preachers at some length --
EN.96: but the Gospel remains silent.
EN.97: 'One says that at Christ's passion the moon turned back
EN.98: and interposed itself in such a way
EN.99: the sun's light did not reach below.
EN.100: 'He lies, for the light chose to hide itself.
EN.101: And therefore Spaniards and Indians,
EN.102: as well as Jews, could all see that eclipse take place.
EN.103: 'Florence has not as many named Lapo and Bindo
EN.104: as it has tales like these that are proclaimed
EN.105: from the pulpit, here and there, throughout the year,
EN.106: 'so that the ignorant flocks return from feeding
EN.107: fed on wind. And that they fail
EN.108: to see their loss does not excuse them.
EN.109: 'Christ did not say to His first congregation:
EN.110: "Go preach idle nonsense to the world,"
EN.111: but gave to them a sound foundation.
EN.112: 'And that alone resounded from their lips,
EN.113: so that, in their warfare to ignite the faith,
EN.114: they used the Gospel as their shield and lance.
EN.115: 'Now preachers ply their trade with buffoonery and jokes,
EN.116: their cowls inflating if they get a laugh,
EN.117: and the people ask for nothing more.
EN.118: 'But such a bird nests in their hoods
EN.119: that, if the people saw it, they would see
EN.120: the kind of pardoning to which they give their trust.
EN.121: 'Because of these such foolishness has grown on earth
EN.122: that, with no warrant vouching for its truth,
EN.123: they still would flock to any promise.
EN.124: 'On this Saint Anthony fattens his swine,
EN.125: along with many others who are still more swinish,
EN.126: repaying them with unstamped coin.
EN.127: 'But, since we have digressed enough,
EN.128: now turn your eyes to the true road again,
EN.129: that the way may be made shorter -- and the time.
EN.130: 'The angelic host mounts by degrees
EN.131: to such high numbers, no mortal speech or thought
EN.132: could ever count so far,
EN.133: 'and, if you consider what Daniel reveals,
EN.134: you shall see that in his many thousands
EN.135: a finite number stays concealed.
EN.136: 'The Primal Light that irradiates them all
EN.137: is received by them in just as many ways
EN.138: as there are splendors joined with It.
EN.139: 'Therefore, since affection follows
EN.140: the act of conceiving, love's sweetness glows
EN.141: with differing radiance, more brightly or subdued.
EN.142: 'See now the height and breadth of the Eternal Worth,
EN.143: one light, which shines dispersed among
EN.144: so many mirrors yet remains
EN.145: in Itself one, just as It was before.'

IT.1: Forse semilia miglia di lontano
IT.2: ci ferve l'ora sesta, e questo mondo
IT.3: china già l'ombra quasi al letto piano,
IT.4: quando 'l mezzo del cielo, a noi profondo,
IT.5: comincia a farsi tal, ch'alcuna stella
IT.6: perde il parere infino a questo fondo;

IT.8: del sol più oltre, così 'l ciel si chiude

IT.11: sempre dintorno al punto che mi vinse,
IT.12: parendo inchiuso da quel ch'elli 'nchiude,
IT.13: a poco a poco al mio veder si stinse:

IT.18: poca sarebbe a fornir questa vice.

IT.20: non pur di là da noi, ma certo io credo

IT.23: più che già mai da punto di suo tema
IT.24: soprato fosse comico o tragedo:
IT.25: ché, come sole in viso che più trema,
IT.26: così lo rimembrar del dolce riso
IT.27: la mente mia da me medesmo scema.
IT.28: Dal primo giorno ch'i' vidi il suo viso
IT.29: in questa vita, infino a questa vista,
IT.30: non m'è il seguire al mio cantar preciso;
IT.31: ma or convien che mio seguir desista
IT.32: più dietro a sua bellezza, poetando,

IT.35: che quel de la mia tuba, che deduce
IT.36: l'ardüa sua matera terminando,
IT.37: con atto e voce di spedito duce
IT.38: ricominciò: "Noi siamo usciti fore
IT.39: del maggior corpo al ciel ch'è pura luce:
IT.40: luce intellettüal, piena d'amore;
IT.41: amor di vero ben, pien di letizia;
IT.42: letizia che trascende ogne dolzore.
IT.43: Qui vederai l'una e l'altra milizia
IT.44: di paradiso, e l'una in quelli aspetti
IT.45: che tu vedrai a l'ultima giustizia."
IT.46: Come sùbito lampo che discetti
IT.47: li spiriti visivi, sì che priva
IT.48: da l'atto l'occhio di più forti obietti,
IT.49: così mi circunfulse luce viva,
IT.50: e lasciommi fasciato di tal velo
IT.51: del suo fulgor, che nulla m'appariva.
IT.52: "Sempre l'amor che queta questo cielo
IT.53: accoglie in sé con sì fatta salute,
IT.54: per far disposto a sua fiamma il candelo."
IT.55: Non fur più tosto dentro a me venute
IT.56: queste parole brievi, ch'io compresi
IT.57: me sormontar di sopr' a mia virtute;
IT.58: e di novella vista mi raccesi
IT.59: tale, che nulla luce è tanto mera,
IT.60: che li occhi miei non si fosser difesi;
IT.61: e vidi lume in forma di rivera
IT.62: fulvido di fulgore, intra due rive
IT.63: dipinte di mirabil primavera.
IT.64: Di tal fiumana uscian faville vive,
IT.65: e d'ogne parte si mettien ne' fiori,
IT.66: quasi rubin che oro circunscrive;
IT.67: poi, come inebrïate da li odori,
IT.68: riprofondavan sé nel miro gurge,
IT.69: e s'una intrava, un'altra n'uscia fori.
IT.70: "L'alto disio che mo t'infiamma e urge,
IT.71: d'aver notizia di ciò che tu vei,
IT.72: tanto mi piace più quanto più turge;
IT.73: ma di quest' acqua convien che tu bei
IT.74: prima che tanta sete in te si sazi":
IT.75: così mi disse il sol de li occhi miei.
IT.76: Anche soggiunse: "Il fiume e li topazi
IT.77: ch'entrano ed escono e 'l rider de l'erbe
IT.78: son di lor vero umbriferi prefazi.
IT.79: Non che da sé sian queste cose acerbe;
IT.80: ma è difetto da la parte tua,
IT.81: che non hai viste ancor tanto superbe."
IT.82: Non è fantin che sì sùbito rua
IT.83: col volto verso il latte, se si svegli
IT.84: molto tardato da l'usanza sua
IT.85: come fec' io, per far migliori spegli
IT.86: ancor de li occhi, chinandomi a l'onda
IT.87: che si deriva perché vi s'immegli;
IT.88: e sì come di lei bevve la gronda
IT.89: de le palpebre mie, così mi parve
IT.90: di sua lunghezza divenuta tonda.
IT.91: Poi, come gente stata sotto larve,
IT.92: che pare altro che prima, se si sveste
IT.93: la sembianza non süa in che disparve,
IT.94: così mi si cambiaro in maggior feste

IT.98: l'alto trïunfo del regno verace,
IT.99: dammi virtù a dir com'ïo il vidi!
IT.100: Lume è là sù che visibile face
IT.101: lo creatore a quella creatura
IT.102: che solo in lui vedere ha la sua pace.
IT.103: E' si distende in circular figura,
IT.104: in tanto che la sua circunferenza
IT.105: sarebbe al sol troppo larga cintura.
IT.106: Fassi di raggio tutta sua parvenza
IT.107: reflesso al sommo del mobile primo,
IT.108: che prende quindi vivere e potenza.
IT.109: E come clivo in acqua di suo imo
IT.110: si specchia, quasi per vedersi addorno,
IT.111: quando è nel verde e ne' fioretti opimo,
IT.112: sì, soprastando al lume intorno intorno,
IT.113: vidi specchiarsi in più di mille soglie

IT.116: sì grande lume, quanta è la larghezza
IT.117: di questa rosa ne l'estreme foglie!
IT.118: La vista mia ne l'ampio e ne l'altezza
IT.119: non si smarriva, ma tutto prendeva
IT.120: il quanto e 'l quale di quella allegrezza.
IT.121: Presso e lontano, lì, né pon né leva:
IT.122: ché dove Dio sanza mezzo governa,
IT.123: la legge natural nulla rileva.
IT.124: Nel giallo de la rosa sempiterna,
IT.125: che si digrada e dilata e redole
IT.126: odor di lode al sol che sempre verna,
IT.127: qual è colui che tace e dicer vole,
IT.128: mi trasse Bëatrice, e disse: "Mira
IT.129: quanto è 'l convento de le bianche stole!
IT.130: Vedi nostra città quant' ella gira;
IT.131: vedi li nostri scanni sì ripieni,
IT.132: che poca gente più ci si disira.
IT.133: E 'n quel gran seggio a che tu li occhi tieni

IT.135: prima che tu a queste nozze ceni,
IT.136: sederà l'alma, che fia giù agosta,

IT.138: verrà in prima ch'ella sia disposta.
IT.139: La cieca cupidigia che v'ammalia
IT.140: simili fatti v'ha al fantolino
IT.141: che muor per fame e caccia via la balia.

IT.143: allora tal, che palese e coverto
IT.144: non anderà con lui per un cammino.
IT.145: Ma poco poi sarà da Dio sofferto
IT.146: nel santo officio: ch'el sarà detruso
