EN.1: About six thousand miles away from here
EN.2: the sixth hour burns and even now this world
EN.3: inclines its shadow almost to a level bed,
EN.4: when, deep in intervening air, above us,
EN.5: begins such change that here and there,
EN.6: at our depth, a star is lost to sight.
EN.7: And, as that brightest handmaid of the sun advances,
EN.8: the sky extinguishes its lights,
EN.9: even the most beautiful, one by one.
EN.10: Not otherwise the victory that revels
EN.11: in eternal joy around the point that overcame me
EN.12: and seems enclosed by that which it encloses
EN.13: little by little faded from my sight,
EN.14: so that, compelled by seeing nothing and by love,
EN.15: I turned my eyes to gaze on Beatrice.
EN.16: If all things said of her up to this point
EN.17: were gathered in a single hymn of praise,
EN.18: it would be paltry, matched to what is due.
EN.19: The beauty that I saw transcends
EN.20: all thought of beauty, and I must believe
EN.21: only its maker may savor it all.
EN.22: I declare myself defeated at this point
EN.23: more than any poet, whether comic or tragic,
EN.24: was ever thwarted by a topic in his theme,
EN.25: for, like sunlight striking on the weakest eyes,
EN.26: the memory of the sweetness of that smile
EN.27: deprives my mind of my mental powers.
EN.28: From the first day, when in this life I saw her face
EN.29: until my vision of her now, pursuit
EN.30: of her in song has never been cut off.
EN.31: But now I must desist in my pursuit,
EN.32: no longer following her beauty in my verse,
EN.33: as every artist, having reached his limit, must.
EN.34: Thus I leave her to more glorious trumpeting
EN.35: than that of my own music, as, laboring on,
EN.36: I bring my difficult subject toward its close.
EN.37: With the voice and bearing of a guide
EN.38: who has discharged his duty, she began: 'We have issued
EN.39: from the largest body to the Heaven of pure light,
EN.40: 'light intellectual, full of love,
EN.41: love of true good, full of joy,
EN.42: joy that surpasses every sweetness.
EN.43: 'Here you shall see both soldieries of Paradise,
EN.44: one of them in just such form
EN.45: as you shall see it at the final judgment.'
EN.46: Like sudden lightning that confounds
EN.47: the faculty of sight, depriving eyes
EN.48: of taking in the clearest objects,
EN.49: thus did a living light shine all around me,
EN.50: leaving me so swathed in the veil of its effulgence
EN.51: that I saw nothing else.
EN.52: 'The love that calms this heaven
EN.53: always offers welcome with such greetings,
EN.54: to make the candle ready for its flame.'
EN.55: No sooner had these few words reached my mind
EN.56: than I became aware of having risen
EN.57: above and well beyond my powers,
EN.58: and such was the new vision kindled within me
EN.59: that there exists no light so vivid that my eyes
EN.60: could not have borne its brightness.
EN.61: And I saw light that flowed as flows a river,
EN.62: pouring its golden splendor between two banks
EN.63: painted with the wondrous colors of spring.
EN.64: From that torrent issued living sparks
EN.65: and, on either bank, they settled on the flowers,
EN.66: like rubies ringed in gold.
EN.67: Then, as though intoxicated by the odors,
EN.68: they plunged once more into the marvelous flood,
EN.69: and, as one submerged, another would come forth.
EN.70: 'The deep desire that now inflames and prods you
EN.71: to understand at last all that you see
EN.72: pleases me the more the more it surges.
EN.73: 'But you must drink first of these waters
EN.74: before your great thirst may be satisfied.'
EN.75: Thus the sun of my eyes spoke to me.
EN.76: Then she continued: 'The river, the topazes
EN.77: that enter and leave it, and the laughter of the meadows
EN.78: are all shadowy prefaces of their truth,
EN.79: 'not that these things are in themselves unripe,
EN.80: but because the failure lies with you,
EN.81: your vision not yet strong enough to soar.'
EN.82: No infant, waking up too late
EN.83: for his accustomed feeding, will thrust his face
EN.84: up to his milk with greater urgency,
EN.85: than I, to make still better mirrors of my eyes,
EN.86: inclined my head down toward the water
EN.87: that flows there for our betterment,
EN.88: and no sooner had the eaves of my eyelids
EN.89: drunk deep of that water than to me it seemed
EN.90: it had made its length into a circle.
EN.91: Then, like people wearing masks,
EN.92: once they put off the likeness not their own
EN.93: in which they hid, seem other than before,
EN.94: the flowers and the sparks were changed before my eyes
EN.95: into a greater celebration, so that I saw,
EN.96: before my very eyes, both courts of Heaven.
EN.97: O splendor of God, by which I saw
EN.98: the lofty triumph of the one true kingdom,
EN.99: grant me the power to tell of what I saw!
EN.100: There is a light above that makes the Creator
EN.101: visible to every creature
EN.102: that finds its only peace in seeing Him.
EN.103: It spreads itself into so vast a circle
EN.104: that its circumference would be larger
EN.105: than the sphere that is the sun.
EN.106: All that is seen of it comes as a ray reflected
EN.107: from the summit of the Primum Mobile,
EN.108: which draws from this its motion and its powers.
EN.109: And as a hillside is mirrored by the water
EN.110: at its foot, as if it saw itself adorned
EN.111: when it is lush with grass and flowers,
EN.112: so I saw, rising above the light and all around it
EN.113: mirrored in more than a thousand tiers,
EN.114: all those of us who have returned on high.
EN.115: And, if the lowest of its ranks encloses
EN.116: a light so large, how vast is the expanse containing
EN.117: the farthest petals of this rose?
EN.118: Within that breadth and height,
EN.119: my sight was not confused but shared
EN.120: the full extent and quality of that rejoicing.
EN.121: There, near and far do neither add nor take away,
EN.122: for where God, unmediated, rules
EN.123: natural law has no effect.
EN.124: Into the yellow of the sempiternal rose,
EN.125: which rises in its ranks, expands, and exhales
EN.126: fragrances that praise the Sun's perpetual spring,
EN.127: I, like a man who is silent but would speak,
EN.128: was led by Beatrice, and she said: 'Behold
EN.129: how vast the white-robed gathering!
EN.130: 'See our city, with its vast expanse!
EN.131: See how many are the seats already filled --
EN.132: few are the souls still absent there!
EN.133: 'And in that great seat which draws your eyes
EN.134: for the crown already set above it,
EN.135: before you shall dine at this wedding feast,
EN.136: 'shall sit the soul of noble Henry,
EN.137: who on earth, as emperor, shall attempt
EN.138: to set things straight for Italy before she is prepared.
EN.139: 'Blind cupidity, bewitching you,
EN.140: has made you like the infant, dying of hunger,
EN.141: who shoves his nurse's breast away.
EN.142: 'At that time the prefect of the sacred court
EN.143: will be a man who will not make his way
EN.144: on the same road by daylight as he will by night.
EN.145: 'But short shall be the time God suffers him
EN.146: in holy office, for he shall be thrust
EN.147: down there where Simon Magus gets what he deserves,
EN.148: and push that fellow from Anagni deeper down.'

IT.1: In forma dunque di candida rosa
IT.2: mi si mostrava la milizia santa
IT.3: che nel suo sangue Cristo fece sposa;
IT.4: ma l'altra, che volando vede e canta
IT.5: la gloria di colui che la 'nnamora
IT.6: e la bontà che la fece cotanta,
IT.7: sì come schiera d'ape che s'infiora
IT.8: una fïata e una si ritorna
IT.9: là dove suo laboro s'insapora,
IT.10: nel gran fior discendeva che s'addorna
IT.11: di tante foglie, e quindi risaliva
IT.12: là dove 'l süo amor sempre soggiorna.
IT.13: Le facce tutte avean di fiamma viva
IT.14: e l'ali d'oro, e l'altro tanto bianco,
IT.15: che nulla neve a quel termine arriva.
IT.16: Quando scendean nel fior, di banco in banco
IT.17: porgevan de la pace e de l'ardore
IT.18: ch'elli acquistavan ventilando il fianco.
IT.19: Né l'interporsi tra 'l disopra e 'l fiore
IT.20: di tanta moltitudine volante
IT.21: impediva la vista e lo splendore:
IT.22: ché la luce divina è penetrante
IT.23: per l'universo secondo ch'è degno,
IT.24: sì che nulla le puote essere ostante.
IT.25: Questo sicuro e gaudïoso regno,
IT.26: frequente in gente antica e in novella,
IT.27: viso e amore avea tutto ad un segno.
IT.28: Oh trina luce che 'n unica stella
IT.29: scintillando a lor vista, sì li appaga!
IT.30: guarda qua giuso a la nostra procella!
IT.31: Se i barbari, venendo da tal plaga
IT.32: che ciascun giorno d'Elice si cuopra,
IT.33: rotante col suo figlio ond' ella è vaga,
IT.34: veggendo Roma e l'ardüa sua opra,
IT.35: stupefaciensi, quando Laterano
IT.36: a le cose mortali andò di sopra;
IT.37: ïo, che al divino da l'umano,
IT.38: a l'etterno dal tempo era venuto,
IT.39: e di Fiorenza in popol giusto e sano,
IT.40: di che stupor dovea esser compiuto!
IT.41: Certo tra esso e 'l gaudio mi facea
IT.42: libito non udire e starmi muto.
IT.43: E quasi peregrin che si ricrea
IT.44: nel tempio del suo voto riguardando,
IT.45: e spera già ridir com' ello stea,
IT.46: su per la viva luce passeggiando,
IT.47: menava ïo li occhi per li gradi,
IT.48: mo sù, mo giù e mo recirculando.
IT.49: Vedëa visi a carità süadi,
IT.50: d'altrui lume fregiati e di suo riso,
IT.51: e atti ornati di tutte onestadi.
IT.52: La forma general di paradiso
IT.53: già tutta mïo sguardo avea compresa,
IT.54: in nulla parte ancor fermato fiso;
IT.55: e volgeami con voglia rïaccesa
IT.56: per domandar la mia donna di cose
IT.57: di che la mente mia era sospesa.
IT.58: Uno intendëa, e altro mi rispuose:
IT.59: credea veder Beatrice e vidi un sene
IT.60: vestito con le genti glorïose.
IT.61: Diffuso era per li occhi e per le gene
IT.62: di benigna letizia, in atto pio
IT.63: quale a tenero padre si convene.
IT.64: E "Ov' è ella?" sùbito diss' io.
IT.65: Ond' elli: "A terminar lo tuo disiro
IT.66: mosse Beatrice me del loco mio;
IT.67: e se riguardi sù nel terzo giro
IT.68: dal sommo grado, tu la rivedrai
IT.69: nel trono che suoi merti le sortiro."
IT.70: Sanza risponder, li occhi sù levai,
IT.71: e vidi lei che si facea corona
IT.72: reflettendo da sé li etterni rai.
IT.73: Da quella regïon che più sù tona
IT.74: occhio mortale alcun tanto non dista,
IT.75: qualunque in mare più giù s'abbandona,
IT.76: quanto lì da Beatrice la mia vista;
IT.77: ma nulla mi facea, ché süa effige
IT.78: non discendëa a me per mezzo mista.
IT.79: "O donna in cui la mia speranza vige,
IT.80: e che soffristi per la mia salute
IT.81: in inferno lasciar le tue vestige,
IT.82: di tante cose quant' i' ho vedute,
IT.83: dal tuo podere e da la tua bontate
IT.84: riconosco la grazia e la virtute.
IT.85: Tu m'hai di servo tratto a libertate
IT.86: per tutte quelle vie, per tutt' i modi
IT.87: che di ciò fare avei la potestate.
IT.88: La tua magnificenza in me custodi,
IT.89: sì che l'anima mia, che fatt' hai sana,
IT.90: piacente a te dal corpo si disnodi."
IT.91: Così orai; e quella, sì lontana
IT.92: come parea, sorrise e riguardommi;
IT.93: poi si tornò a l'etterna fontana.
IT.94: E 'l santo sene: "Acciò che tu assommi
IT.95: perfettamente," disse, "il tuo cammino,
IT.96: a che priego e amor santo mandommi,
IT.97: vola con li occhi per questo giardino;
IT.98: ché veder lui t'acconcerà lo sguardo
IT.99: più al montar per lo raggio divino.
IT.100: E la regina del cielo, ond'ïo ardo
IT.101: tutto d'amor, ne farà ogne grazia,
IT.102: però ch'i' sono il suo fedel Bernardo."
IT.103: Qual è colui che forse di Croazia
IT.104: viene a veder la Veronica nostra,
IT.105: che per l'antica fame non sen sazia,
IT.106: ma dice nel pensier, fin che si mostra:
IT.107: "Segnor mio Iesù Cristo, Dio verace,
IT.108: or fu sì fatta la sembianza vostra?";
IT.109: tal era io mirando la vivace
IT.110: carità di colui che 'n questo mondo,
IT.111: contemplando, gustò di quella pace.
IT.112: "Figliuol di grazia, quest' esser giocondo,"
IT.113: cominciò elli, "non ti sarà noto,
IT.114: tenendo li occhi pur qua giù al fondo;
IT.115: ma guarda i cerchi infino al più remoto,
IT.116: tanto che veggi seder la regina
IT.117: cui questo regno è suddito e devoto."
IT.118: Io levai li occhi; e come da mattina
IT.119: la parte orïental de l'orizzonte
IT.120: soverchia quella dove 'l sol declina,
IT.121: così, quasi di valle andando a monte
IT.122: con li occhi, vidi parte ne lo stremo
IT.123: vincer di lume tutta l'altra fronte.
IT.124: E come quivi ove s'aspetta il temo
IT.125: che mal guidò Fetonte, più s'infiamma,
IT.126: e quinci e quindi il lume si fa scemo,
IT.127: così quella pacifica oriafiamma
IT.128: nel mezzo s'avvivava, e d'ogne parte
IT.129: per igual modo allentava la fiamma;
IT.130: e a quel mezzo, con le penne sparte,
IT.131: vid' io più di mille angeli festanti,
IT.132: ciascun distinto di fulgore e d'arte.
IT.133: Vidi a lor giochi quivi e a lor canti
IT.134: ridere una bellezza, che letizia
IT.135: era ne li occhi a tutti li altri santi;
IT.136: e s'io avessi in dir tanta divizia
IT.137: quanta ad imaginar, non ardirei
IT.138: lo minimo tentar di sua delizia.
IT.139: Bernardo, come vide li occhi miei
IT.140: nel caldo suo caler fissi e attenti,
IT.141: li suoi con tanto affetto volse a lei,
IT.142: che ' miei di rimirar fé più ardenti.

EN.1: In form, then, of a luminous white rose
EN.2: I saw the saintly soldiery that Christ,
EN.3: with His own blood, took as His bride.
EN.4: But the others -- who, even as they fly, behold
EN.5: and sing the glory of Him who stirs their love,
EN.6: and sing His goodness that raised them up so high,
EN.7: as a swarm of bees that in one instant plunge
EN.8: deep into blossoms and, the very next, go back
EN.9: to where their toil is turned to sweetness --
EN.10: these descended to the splendid flower,
EN.11: adorned with many petals, and then flew up
EN.12: to where their love forever dwells.
EN.13: Their faces were of living flame,
EN.14: their wings were gold, the rest
EN.15: was of a whiteness never matched by snow.
EN.16: When they descended to the flower, they bestowed
EN.17: the peace and love acquired with their beating wings
EN.18: upon the petals, row on row.
EN.19: Nor did so vast a flying throng,
EN.20: coming between the flower and the light above,
EN.21: obstruct the looking up or shining down,
EN.22: for the light of God so penetrates the universe,
EN.23: according to the fitness of its parts to take it in,
EN.24: that there is nothing can withstand its beam.
EN.25: This sure and joyful kingdom,
EN.26: thronged with souls from both the old times and the new,
EN.27: aimed sight and love upon a single goal.
EN.28: O threefold Light, which, in a single star
EN.29: sparkling in their sight, contents them so!
EN.30: Look down upon our tempest here below.
EN.31: If the barbarians, coming from that region
EN.32: which Helice covers every day,
EN.33: wheeling with her son, in whom she takes delight,
EN.34: were dumbstruck at the sight of Rome
EN.35: and her majestic monuments,
EN.36: when the Lateran surpassed all other works of man,
EN.37: I, who had come to things divine from man's estate,
EN.38: to eternity from time,
EN.39: from Florence to a people just and sane,
EN.40: with what amazement must I have been filled!
EN.41: Indeed, between the wonder and my joy, I was content
EN.42: neither to hear nor speak a word.
EN.43: And, as a pilgrim, in the temple of his vow,
EN.44: content within himself, looks lovingly about
EN.45: and expects to tell his tale when he gets home,
EN.46: so, through the living light I let my eyes
EN.47: range freely through the ranks, now up, now down,
EN.48: now circling freely all around again.
EN.49: I saw visages informed by heavenly love, resplendent
EN.50: with Another's light and their own smiles,
EN.51: their every movement graced with dignity.
EN.52: My gaze by now had taken in
EN.53: the general form of Paradise
EN.54: but not yet fixed on any single part of it,
EN.55: and I turned, with newly kindled eagerness
EN.56: to ask my lady many things
EN.57: that kept my mind yet in suspense.
EN.58: I expected one thing but found another:
EN.59: instead of Beatrice, an old man, adorned
EN.60: as were the rest of those in glory, met my eyes.
EN.61: His eyes and cheeks were quite suffused
EN.62: with kindly joy, and from his whole appearance shone
EN.63: a loving father's tenderness.
EN.64: Then 'Where is she?' I asked at once
EN.65: and he replied: 'To lead your longing to its goal
EN.66: Beatrice called me from my place.
EN.67: 'If you raise your eyes to the third circle
EN.68: below the highest tier, you shall see her again,
EN.69: now on the throne her merits have assigned.'
EN.70: Without a word, I lifted up my eyes
EN.71: and saw that she, reflecting the eternal rays,
EN.72: appeared to be encircled by a crown.
EN.73: From the highest region where the thunder breaks
EN.74: down to the bottom of the deepest sea,
EN.75: no mortal eye is ever quite so far
EN.76: as was my sight removed from Beatrice.
EN.77: Yet to me that mattered not, because her image
EN.78: came down undimmed by anything between.
EN.79: 'O lady who give strength to all my hope
EN.80: and who allowed yourself, for my salvation,
EN.81: to leave your footprints there in Hell,
EN.82: 'of all the many things that I have seen,
EN.83: I know the grace and virtue I've been shown
EN.84: come from your goodness and your power.
EN.85: 'It is you who, on no matter what the path,
EN.86: have drawn me forth from servitude to freedom
EN.87: by every means that you had in your power.
EN.88: 'Keep your munificence alive in me, so that
EN.89: my soul, which you have healed,
EN.90: may please you when it leaves its mortal frame.'
EN.91: This was my prayer. And she, however far away
EN.92: she seemed, smiled and looked down at me,
EN.93: then turned again to the eternal fountain.
EN.94: And the holy ancient spoke: 'So that you may achieve
EN.95: your journey's consummation now,
EN.96: both sacred love and prayer have sent me here:
EN.97: 'Let your sight fly through this garden,
EN.98: for seeing it will help prepare your eyes
EN.99: to rise, along the beam of holy light.
EN.100: 'And Heaven's queen, for whom I burn
EN.101: with love, will grant us every grace,
EN.102: since I am her own, her faithful Bernard.'
EN.103: As the man who, perhaps from Croatia, has come
EN.104: to set his gaze on our Veronica,
EN.105: his ancient craving still not satisfied,
EN.106: and who thinks to himself while it is shown:
EN.107: 'My Lord Jesus Christ, God Himself,
EN.108: was this then how You really looked?',
EN.109: just so was I, gazing on the living love
EN.110: of him who, still within the confines of this world,
EN.111: in contemplation tasted of that peace.
EN.112: 'Child of grace,' he said, 'you will not know
EN.113: this joyful state if you maintain your gaze,
EN.114: instead of upward, fixed down here.
EN.115: 'Rather to the highest circles raise your eyes
EN.116: so that you may behold the queen enthroned,
EN.117: her to whom this realm is subject and devout.'
EN.118: I raised my eyes. As, at break of day,
EN.119: the eastern part of the horizon shines
EN.120: with a brighter glow than where the sun goes down,
EN.121: so, as though my eyes were moving from a valley
EN.122: up a mountain, I saw that one far crest
EN.123: surpassed in brightness all the others.
EN.124: Where we await the shaft of Phaeton's car,
EN.125: poorly guided there, where it is most aflame,
EN.126: while on this side and on that the light shades off,
EN.127: just so that peaceful oriflamme showed brightest
EN.128: in the middle, while on either side
EN.129: the flame was dimmed in equal measure.
EN.130: Around that point I saw more than a thousand angels,
EN.131: their wings outspread, in joyful festival,
EN.132: each distinct in brightness and in motion.
EN.133: I saw there, smiling at their games and songs,
EN.134: beauty that brought pleasure to the gaze
EN.135: of all the other gathered saints.
EN.136: Were I as rich with words as in my store of images,
EN.137: I still would never dare attempt to tell
EN.138: the least of these delights that came from her.
EN.139: Bernard, who saw my eyes were fixed, intent
EN.140: upon the very fire that made him warm,
EN.141: turned his own on her with such affection
EN.142: that he made mine more ardent in their gaze.

IT.1: Affetto al suo piacer, quel contemplante
IT.2: libero officio di dottore assunse,
IT.3: e cominciò queste parole sante:
IT.4: "La piaga che Maria richiuse e unse,
IT.5: quella ch'è tanto bella da' suoi piedi
IT.6: è colei che l'aperse e che la punse.
IT.7: Ne l'ordine che fanno i terzi sedi,
IT.8: siede Rachel di sotto da costei
IT.9: con Bëatrice, sì come tu vedi.
IT.10: Sarra e Rebecca, Iudìt e colei
IT.11: che fu bisava al cantor che per doglia
IT.12: del fallo disse 'Miserere mei,'
IT.13: puoi tu veder così di soglia in soglia
IT.14: giù digradar, com' io ch'a proprio nome
IT.15: vo per la rosa giù di foglia in foglia.
IT.16: E dal settimo grado in giù, sì come
IT.17: infino ad esso, succedono Ebree,
IT.18: dirimendo del fior tutte le chiome;
IT.19: perché, secondo lo sguardo che fée
IT.20: la fede in Cristo, queste sono il muro
IT.21: a che si parton le sacre scalee.
IT.22: Da questa parte onde 'l fiore è maturo
IT.23: di tutte le sue foglie, sono assisi
IT.24: quei che credettero in Cristo venturo;
IT.25: da l'altra parte onde sono intercisi
IT.26: di vòti i semicirculi, si stanno
IT.27: quei ch'a Cristo venuto ebber li visi.
IT.28: E come quinci il glorïoso scanno
IT.29: de la donna del cielo e li altri scanni
IT.30: di sotto lui cotanta cerna fanno,
IT.31: così di contra quel del gran Giovanni,
IT.32: che sempre santo 'l diserto e 'l martiro
IT.33: sofferse, e poi l'inferno da due anni;
IT.34: e sotto lui così cerner sortiro
IT.35: Francesco, Benedetto e Augustino
IT.36: e altri fin qua giù di giro in giro.
IT.37: Or mira l'alto proveder divino:
IT.38: ché l'uno e l'altro aspetto de la fede
IT.39: igualmente empierà questo giardino.
IT.40: E sappi che dal grado in giù che fiede
IT.41: a mezzo il tratto le due discrezioni,
IT.42: per nullo proprio merito si siede,
IT.43: ma per l'altrui, con certe condizioni:
IT.44: ché tutti questi son spiriti asciolti
IT.45: prima ch'avesser vere elezïoni.
IT.46: Ben te ne puoi accorger per li volti
IT.47: e anche per le voci püerili,
IT.48: se tu li guardi bene e se li ascolti.
IT.49: Or dubbi tu e dubitando sili;
IT.50: ma io discioglierò 'l forte legame
IT.51: in che ti stringon li pensier sottili.
IT.52: Dentro a l'ampiezza di questo reame
IT.53: casüal punto non puote aver sito,
IT.54: se non come tristizia o sete o fame:
IT.55: ché per etterna legge è stabilito
IT.56: quantunque vedi, sì che giustamente
IT.57: ci si risponde da l'anello al dito;
IT.58: e però questa festinata gente
IT.59: a vera vita non è sine causa
IT.60: intra sé qui più e meno eccellente.
IT.61: Lo rege per cui questo regno pausa
IT.62: in tanto amore e in tanto diletto,
IT.63: che nulla volontà è di più ausa,
IT.64: le menti tutte nel suo lieto aspetto
IT.65: creando, a suo piacer di grazia dota
IT.66: diversamente; e qui basti l'effetto.
IT.67: E ciò espresso e chiaro vi si nota
IT.68: ne la Scrittura santa in quei gemelli
IT.69: che ne la madre ebber l'ira commota.
IT.70: Però, secondo il color d'i capelli,
IT.71: di cotal grazia l'altissimo lume
IT.72: degnamente convien che s'incappelli.
IT.73: Dunque, sanza mercé di lor costume,
IT.74: locati son per gradi differenti,
IT.75: sol differendo nel primiero acume.
IT.76: Bastavasi ne' secoli recenti
IT.77: con l'innocenza, per aver salute,
IT.78: solamente la fede d'i parenti;
IT.79: poi che le prime etadi fuor compiute,
IT.80: convenne ai maschi a l'innocenti penne
IT.81: per circuncidere acquistar virtute;
IT.82: ma poi che 'l tempo de la grazia venne,
IT.83: sanza battesmo perfetto di Cristo
IT.84: tale innocenza là giù si ritenne.
IT.85: Riguarda omai ne la faccia che a Cristo
IT.86: più si somiglia, ché la sua chiarezza
IT.87: sola ti può disporre a veder Cristo."
IT.88: Io vidi sopra lei tanta allegrezza
IT.89: piover, portata ne le menti sante
IT.90: create a trasvolar per quella altezza,
IT.91: che quantunque io avea visto davante,
IT.92: di tanta ammirazion non mi sospese,
IT.93: né mi mostrò di Dio tanto sembiante;
IT.94: e quello amor che primo lì discese,
IT.95: cantando "Ave Maria, gratïa plena,"
IT.96: dinanzi a lei le sue ali distese.
IT.97: Rispuose a la divina cantilena
IT.98: da tutte parti la beata corte,
IT.99: si ch'ogne vista sen fé più serena.
IT.100: "O santo padre, che per me comporte
IT.101: l'esser qua giù, lasciando il dolce loco
IT.102: nel qual tu siedi per etterna sorte,
IT.103: qual è quell' angel che con tanto gioco
IT.104: guarda ne li occhi la nostra regina,
IT.105: innamorato sì che par di foco?"
IT.106: Così ricorsi ancora a la dottrina
IT.107: di colui ch'abbelliva di Maria,
IT.108: come del sole stella mattutina.
IT.109: Ed elli a me: "Baldezza e leggiadria
IT.110: quant' esser puote in angelo e in alma,
IT.111: tutta è in lui; e sì volem che sia,
IT.112: perch' elli è quelli che portò la palma
IT.113: giuso a Maria, quando 'l Figliuol di Dio
IT.114: carcar si volse de la nostra salma.
IT.115: Ma vieni omai con li occhi sì com' io
IT.116: andrò parlando, e nota i gran patrici
IT.117: di questo imperio giustissimo e pio.
IT.118: Quei due che seggon là sù più felici
IT.119: per esser propinquissimi ad Agusta,
IT.120: son d'esta rosa quasi due radici:
IT.121: colui che da sinistra le s'aggiusta
IT.122: è 'l padre per lo cui ardito gusto
IT.123: l'umana specie tanto amaro gusta;
IT.124: dal destro vedi quel padre vetusto
IT.125: di Santa Chiesa a cui Cristo le chiavi
IT.126: raccomandò di questo fior venusto.
IT.127: E quei che vide tutti i tempi gravi,
IT.128: pria che morisse, de la bella sposa
IT.129: che s'acquistò con la lancia e coi clavi,
IT.130: siede lungh' esso, e lungo l'altro posa
IT.131: quel duca sotto cui visse di manna
IT.132: la gente ingrata, mobile e retrosa.
IT.133: Di contr' a Pietro vedi sedere Anna,
IT.134: tanto contenta di mirar sua figlia,
IT.135: che non move occhio per cantare osanna;
IT.136: e contro al maggior padre di famiglia
IT.137: siede Lucia, che mosse la tua donna
IT.138: quando chinavi, a rovinar, le ciglia.
IT.139: Ma perché 'l tempo fugge che t'assonna,
IT.140: qui farem punto, come buon sartore
IT.141: che com' elli ha del panno fa la gonna;
IT.142: e drizzeremo li occhi al primo amore,
IT.143: sì che, guardando verso lui, penètri
IT.144: quant' è possibil per lo suo fulgore.
IT.145: Veramente, ne forse tu t'arretri
IT.146: movendo l'ali tue, credendo oltrarti,
IT.147: orando grazia conven che s'impetri
IT.148: grazia da quella che puote aiutarti;
IT.149: e tu mi seguirai con l'affezione,
IT.150: sì che dal dicer mio lo cor non parti."

EN.1: Absorbed in his delight, that man of contemplation
EN.2: took upon himself the teacher's role
EN.3: and spoke these holy words:
EN.4: 'The wound that Mary closed up and anointed
EN.5: was opened and inflicted
EN.6: by the lovely woman now at Mary's feet.
EN.7: 'Below her, in the order
EN.8: formed by the third tier of the seats,
EN.9: as you can see, Rachel sits with Beatrice.
EN.10: 'Sarah and Rebecca, Judith and she --
EN.11: great-grandmother of that singer who,
EN.12: grieving for his sin, cried: "Miserere mei" --
EN.13: 'may be seen there, one beneath the other,
EN.14: in their ordered ranks, while I, pausing for each name,
EN.15: move petal by petal down through the rose.
EN.16: 'And downward from the seventh tier, or up,
EN.17: parting all the petals of this flower,
EN.18: are the appointed seats of Hebrew women.
EN.19: 'For, according to whether in their faith
EN.20: they looked forward to Christ or back,
EN.21: this is the wall that separates the sacred tiers.
EN.22: 'On this side, where the flower is in fullest bloom
EN.23: with all its petals, those are seated
EN.24: who believed in Christ as yet to come.
EN.25: 'On the other side, where the semi-circles
EN.26: are interspersed with vacant spaces, are seated
EN.27: those who kept their eyes on Christ already come.
EN.28: 'And just as here the glorious seat
EN.29: of heaven's lady and the other seats beneath it
EN.30: form that long dividing line,
EN.31: 'so, opposite, does that of the exalted soul of John,
EN.32: who, holy since his birth, endured the wilderness
EN.33: and martyrdom, and then two years of Hell.
EN.34: 'Below him, and continuing that line,
EN.35: sit Francis, Benedict, Augustine, and others,
EN.36: assigned as far as this, down from tier to tier.
EN.37: 'Now behold the depth of God's foreseeing,
EN.38: for both the ways of showing faith
EN.39: shall fill this garden equally.
EN.40: 'And know that downward from the row
EN.41: that midway cuts the two dividing lines
EN.42: the seats are held by those who had no merit of their own,
EN.43: 'but through deserving others, under fixed conditions,
EN.44: were freed from sin, for all of these are spirits
EN.45: released before they exercised free choice.
EN.46: 'This, indeed, you may discover for yourself
EN.47: from their faces and their childish voices,
EN.48: if you look at them with care and if you listen.
EN.49: 'Now you are perplexed and silent in perplexity.
EN.50: Let me untie the complicated knot
EN.51: in which your over-subtle thoughts have bound you.
EN.52: 'In all the ample range of this domain
EN.53: no trace of chance can find a place --
EN.54: no more than sorrow, thirst, or hunger,
EN.55: 'for all you see here is ordained by law eternal,
EN.56: so that the circling ring here fits
EN.57: the finger that was meant for it.
EN.58: 'Thus, the company of those who prematurely
EN.59: came to this true life are not sine causa
EN.60: placed more and less exalted here among themselves.
EN.61: 'The King, through whom this kingdom rests
EN.62: in love so great and in so great delight
EN.63: their will would never dare to ask for more,
EN.64: 'creating every mind in His own bliss,
EN.65: variously bestows His grace and as He pleases --
EN.66: and, in this case, let the fact suffice.
EN.67: 'This is clearly and expressly noted for you
EN.68: by Holy Scripture in the account of twins
EN.69: who, still in their mother's womb, were moved to wrath.
EN.70: 'Therefore, according to the color of the hair
EN.71: bestowed with so much grace, the Sovereign Light
EN.72: will crown them with their fitting aureoles.
EN.73: Not for what they've done or have not done
EN.74: they thus are placed in separate ranks, separated
EN.75: only by the keenness of the vision they were born to.
EN.76: 'In early times their parents' faith alone,
EN.77: coupled with the innocence that they possessed,
EN.78: gave sufficient proof of their salvation.
EN.79: 'Once the first age had run its course,
EN.80: male children had to find the strength
EN.81: for innocent wings in circumcision.
EN.82: 'But once the time of grace had come,
EN.83: then, without perfect baptism in Christ,
EN.84: such innocents were cast below.
EN.85: 'Look now on the face that most resembles Christ,
EN.86: for nothing but its brightness
EN.87: can make you fit to look on Christ.'
EN.88: I saw such joy rain down on her,
EN.89: conveyed within the minds and borne
EN.90: by holy spirits framed to soar those heights,
EN.91: that, however much I had seen before,
EN.92: nothing had held me in such wonder and suspense,
EN.93: nor shown me so close a likeness to God,
EN.94: and the loving spirit that had first descended,
EN.95: singing 'Ave Maria, gratia plena'
EN.96: hovered before her with his wings outspread.
EN.97: From every side the blessèd court all sang,
EN.98: responding to the solemn sacred chant,
EN.99: so that each face became more luminous with joy.
EN.100: 'O holy father, who on my behalf
EN.101: deign to be here below, leaving the sweet place
EN.102: where by eternal lot you have your seat,
EN.103: 'who is the angel gazing with such joy
EN.104: upon the eyes of her our Queen,
EN.105: so much in love he seems to be a flame?'
EN.106: Thus I tried once more to gain instruction
EN.107: from him who glowed in Mary's beauty
EN.108: as the morning star reflects the sun.
EN.109: And he: 'All confidence and grace of movement
EN.110: that can be found in angel or in any blessèd soul
EN.111: are found in him -- and we would have it so,
EN.112: 'for it is he who brought the palm to Mary
EN.113: when the Son of God elected to take on
EN.114: the burden of our flesh.
EN.115: 'But let your eyes follow my words, as I continue,
EN.116: noting the eminent patricians
EN.117: of this most just and pious empire.
EN.118: 'These two who are seated there above us,
EN.119: most happy for being so near the Empress,
EN.120: are, as it were, the two roots of this rose:
EN.121: 'He who sits beside her to her left
EN.122: is that father for whose reckless tasting
EN.123: mankind still tastes such bitterness.
EN.124: 'To her right behold that ancient father
EN.125: of Holy Church to whose care Christ entrusted
EN.126: the keys to this, the fairest flower.
EN.127: 'And he who was doomed to see before he died
EN.128: the years of grief of the beautiful bride,
EN.129: she who was won with the lance and the nails,
EN.130: 'sits next to him and, next to the other, rests
EN.131: that leader under whose rule that stiff-necked people,
EN.132: fickle and ungrateful, lived on manna.
EN.133: 'Look at Anna, where she sits across from Peter,
EN.134: so content merely to gaze upon her daughter
EN.135: she does not move her eyes as she sings hosanna.
EN.136: 'And opposite the greatest father of a family
EN.137: sits Lucy, who urged on your lady when,
EN.138: with lowered gaze, you headed down your path to ruin.
EN.139: 'But since the time runs short that readies you for sleep,
EN.140: let us stop here, as a good tailor would,
EN.141: who cuts the cloak as he is stocked with cloth.
EN.142: 'And let us fix our eyes on Primal Love,
EN.143: so that, looking up toward Him, you penetrate,
EN.144: as far as may be done, His brilliance.
EN.145: 'But, lest by any chance, beating your wings
EN.146: and thinking to advance, you should fall back,
EN.147: you must gain your grace through prayer,
EN.148: 'grace from her who has the power to help you.
EN.149: You shall follow me with your devotion
EN.150: so your heart does not stray from my words.'
EN.151: He then began this holy supplication:

IT.1: "Vergine Madre, figlia del tuo figlio,
IT.2: umile e alta più che creatura,
IT.3: termine fisso d'etterno consiglio,
IT.4: tu se' colei che l'umana natura
IT.5: nobilitasti sì, che 'l suo fattore
IT.6: non disdegnò di farsi sua fattura.
IT.7: Nel ventre tuo si raccese l'amore,
IT.8: per lo cui caldo ne l'etterna pace
IT.9: così è germinato questo fiore.
IT.10: Qui se' a noi meridïana face
IT.11: di caritate, e giuso, intra ' mortali,
IT.12: se' di speranza fontana vivace.
IT.13: Donna, se' tanto grande e tanto vali,
IT.14: che qual vuol grazia e a te non ricorre,
IT.15: sua disïanza vuol volar sanz' ali.
IT.16: La tua benignità non pur soccorre
IT.17: a chi domanda, ma molte fïate
IT.18: liberamente al dimandar precorre.
IT.19: In te misericordia, in te pietate,
IT.20: in te magnificenza, in te s'aduna
IT.21: quantunque in creatura è di bontate.
IT.22: Or questi, che da l'infima lacuna
IT.23: de l'universo infin qui ha vedute
IT.24: le vite spiritali ad una ad una,
IT.25: supplica a te, per grazia, di virtute
IT.26: tanto, che possa con li occhi levarsi
IT.27: più alto verso l'ultima salute.
IT.28: E io, che mai per mio veder non arsi
IT.29: più ch'i' fo per lo suo, tutti miei prieghi
IT.30: ti porgo, e priego che non sieno scarsi,
IT.31: perché tu ogne nube li disleghi
IT.32: di sua mortalità co' prieghi tuoi,
IT.33: sì che 'l sommo piacer li si dispieghi.
IT.34: Ancor ti priego, regina, che puoi
IT.35: ciò che tu vuoli, che conservi sani,
IT.36: dopo tanto veder, li affetti suoi.
IT.37: Vinca tua guardia i movimenti umani:
IT.38: vedi Beatrice con quanti beati
IT.39: per li miei prieghi ti chiudon le mani!"
IT.40: Li occhi da Dio diletti e venerati,
IT.41: fissi ne l'orator, ne dimostraro
IT.42: quanto i devoti prieghi le son grati;
IT.43: indi a l'etterno lume s'addrizzaro,
IT.44: nel qual non si dee creder che s'invii
IT.45: per creatura l'occhio tanto chiaro.
IT.46: E io ch'al fine di tutt' i disii
IT.47: appropinquava, sì com' io dovea,
IT.48: l'ardor del desiderio in me finii.
IT.49: Bernardo m'accennava, e sorridea,
IT.50: perch' io guardassi suso; ma io era
IT.51: già per me stesso tal qual ei volea:
IT.52: ché la mia vista, venendo sincera,
IT.53: e più e più intrava per lo raggio
IT.54: de l'alta luce che da sé è vera.
IT.55: Da quinci innanzi il mio veder fu maggio
IT.56: che 'l parlar mostra, ch'a tal vista cede,
IT.57: e cede la memoria a tanto oltraggio.
IT.58: Qual è colüi che sognando vede,
IT.59: che dopo 'l sogno la passione impressa
IT.60: rimane, e l'altro a la mente non riede,
IT.61: cotal son io, ché quasi tutta cessa
IT.62: mia visïone, e ancor mi distilla
IT.63: nel core il dolce che nacque da essa.
IT.64: Così la neve al sol si disigilla;
IT.65: così al vento ne le foglie levi
IT.66: si perdea la sentenza di Sibilla.
IT.67: O somma luce che tanto ti levi
IT.68: da' concetti mortali, a la mia mente
IT.69: ripresta un poco di quel che parevi,
IT.70: e fa la lingua mia tanto possente,
IT.71: ch'una favilla sol de la tua gloria
IT.72: possa lasciare a la futura gente;
IT.73: ché, per tornare alquanto a mia memoria
IT.74: e per sonare un poco in questi versi,
IT.75: più si conceperà di tua vittoria.
IT.76: Io credo, per l'acume ch'io soffersi
IT.77: del vivo raggio, ch'i' sarei smarrito,
IT.78: se li occhi miei da lui fossero aversi.
IT.79: E' mi ricorda ch'io fui più ardito
IT.80: per questo a sostener, tanto ch'i' giunsi
IT.81: l'aspetto mio col valore infinito.
IT.82: Oh abbondante grazia ond' io presunsi
IT.83: ficcar lo viso per la luce etterna,
IT.84: tanto che la veduta vi consunsi!
IT.85: Nel suo profondo vidi che s'interna,
IT.86: legato con amore in un volume,
IT.87: ciò che per l'universo si squaderna:
IT.88: sustanze e accidenti e lor costume
IT.89: quasi conflati insieme, per tal modo
IT.90: che ciò ch'i' dico è un semplice lume.
IT.91: La forma universal di questo nodo
IT.92: credo ch'i' vidi, perché più di largo,
IT.93: dicendo questo, mi sento ch'i' godo.
IT.94: Un punto solo m'è maggior letargo
IT.95: che venticinque secoli a la 'mpresa
IT.96: che fé Nettuno ammirar l'ombra d'Argo.
IT.97: Così la mente mia, tutta sospesa,
IT.98: mirava fissa, immobile e attenta,
IT.99: e sempre di mirar faceasi accesa.
IT.100: A quella luce cotal si diventa,
IT.101: che volgersi da lei per altro aspetto
IT.102: è impossibil che mai si consenta;
IT.103: però che 'l ben, ch'è del volere obietto,
IT.104: tutto s'accoglie in lei, e fuor di quella
IT.105: è defettivo ciò ch'è lì perfetto.
IT.106: Omai sarà più corta mia favella,
IT.107: pur a quel ch'io ricordo, che d'un fante
IT.108: che bagni ancor la lingua a la mammella.
IT.109: Non perché più ch'un semplice sembiante
IT.110: fosse nel vivo lume ch'io mirava,
IT.111: che tal è sempre qual s'era davante;
IT.112: ma per la vista che s'avvalorava
IT.113: in me guardando, una sola parvenza,
IT.114: mutandom' io, a me si travagliava.
IT.115: Ne la profonda e chiara sussistenza
IT.116: de l'alto lume parvermi tre giri
IT.117: di tre colori e d'una contenenza;
IT.118: e l'un da l'altro come iri da iri
IT.119: parea reflesso, e 'l terzo parea foco
IT.120: che quinci e quindi igualmente si spiri.
IT.121: Oh quanto è corto il dire e come fioco
IT.122: al mio concetto! e questo, a quel ch'i' vidi,
IT.123: è tanto, che non basta a dicer "poco."
IT.124: O luce etterna che sola in te sidi,
IT.125: sola t'intendi, e da te intelletta
IT.126: e intendente te ami e arridi!
IT.127: Quella circulazion che sì concetta
IT.128: pareva in te come lume reflesso,
IT.129: da li occhi miei alquanto circunspetta,
IT.130: dentro da sé, del suo colore stesso,
IT.131: mi parve pinta de la nostra effige:
IT.132: per che 'l mio viso in lei tutto era messo.
IT.133: Qual è 'l geomètra che tutto s'affige
IT.134: per misurar lo cerchio, e non ritrova,
IT.135: pensando, quel principio ond' elli indige,
IT.136: tal era io a quella vista nova:
IT.137: veder voleva come si convenne
IT.138: l'imago al cerchio e come vi s'indova;
IT.139: ma non eran da ciò le proprie penne:
IT.140: se non che la mia mente fu percossa
IT.141: da un fulgore in che sua voglia venne.
IT.142: A l'alta fantasia qui mancò possa;
IT.143: ma già volgeva il mio disio e 'l velle,
IT.144: sì come rota ch'igualmente è mossa,
IT.145: l'amor che move il sole e l'altre stelle.

EN.1: 'Virgin Mother, daughter of your Son,
EN.2: more humble and exalted than any other creature,
EN.3: fixed goal of the eternal plan,
EN.4: 'you are the one who so ennobled human nature
EN.5: that He, who made it first, did not disdain
EN.6: to make Himself of its own making.
EN.7: 'Your womb relit the flame of love --
EN.8: its heat has made this blossom seed
EN.9: and flower in eternal peace.
EN.10: 'To us you are a noonday torch of charity,
EN.11: while down below, among those still in flesh,
EN.12: you are the living fountainhead of hope.
EN.13: 'Lady, you are so great and so prevail above,
EN.14: should he who longs for grace not turn to you,
EN.15: his longing would be doomed to wingless flight.
EN.16: 'Your loving kindness does not only aid
EN.17: whoever seeks it, but many times
EN.18: gives freely what has yet to be implored.
EN.19: 'In you clemency, in you compassion,
EN.20: in you munificence, in you are joined
EN.21: all virtues found in any creature.
EN.22: 'This man who, from within the deepest pit
EN.23: the universe contains up to these heights
EN.24: has seen the disembodied spirits, one by one,
EN.25: 'now begs you, by your grace, to grant such power
EN.26: that, by lifting up his eyes,
EN.27: he may rise higher toward his ultimate salvation.
EN.28: 'And I, who never burned for my own seeing
EN.29: more than now I burn for his, offer all my prayers,
EN.30: and pray that they may not fall short,
EN.31: 'so that your prayers disperse on his behalf
EN.32: all clouds of his mortality and let
EN.33: the highest beauty be displayed to him.
EN.34: 'This too, my Queen, I ask of you, who can achieve
EN.35: whatever you desire, that you help him preserve,
EN.36: after such vision, the purity of his affections.
EN.37: 'Let your protection rule his mortal passions.
EN.38: See Beatrice, with so many of the blessed,
EN.39: palms pressed together, joining me in prayer.'
EN.40: Those eyes belovèd and revered by God,
EN.41: fixed on him who prayed, made clear to us
EN.42: how dear to her all true devotion is.
EN.43: Then she turned her gaze to the eternal Light.
EN.44: It is incorrect to think that any living being
EN.45: can penetrate that brightness with such unblinking eyes.
EN.46: And, as I neared the end of all desire,
EN.47: I extended to its limit, as was right,
EN.48: the ardor of the longing in my soul.
EN.49: With his smile, Bernard signaled
EN.50: that I look upward, but of my own accord
EN.51: I was already doing what he wished,
EN.52: for my sight, becoming pure,
EN.53: rose higher and higher through the ray
EN.54: of the exalted light that in itself is true.
EN.55: From that time on my power of sight exceeded
EN.56: that of speech, which fails at such a vision,
EN.57: as memory fails at such abundance.
EN.58: Just as the dreamer, after he awakens,
EN.59: still stirred by feelings that the dream evoked,
EN.60: cannot bring the rest of it to mind,
EN.61: such am I, my vision almost faded from my mind,
EN.62: while in my heart there still endures
EN.63: the sweetness that was born of it.
EN.64: Thus the sun unseals an imprint in the snow.
EN.65: Thus the Sibyl's oracles, on weightless leaves,
EN.66: lifted by the wind, were swept away.
EN.67: O Light exalted beyond mortal thought,
EN.68: grant that in memory I see again
EN.69: but one small part of how you then appeared
EN.70: and grant my tongue sufficient power
EN.71: that it may leave behind a single spark
EN.72: of glory for the people yet to come,
EN.73: since, if you return but briefly to my mind
EN.74: and then resound but softly in these lines,
EN.75: the better will your victory be conceived.
EN.76: I believe, from the keenness of the living ray
EN.77: that I endured, I would have been undone
EN.78: had I withdrawn my eyes from it.
EN.79: And I remember that, on this account,
EN.80: I grew more bold and thus sustained my gaze
EN.81: until I reached the Goodness that is infinite.
EN.82: O plenitude of grace, by which I could presume
EN.83: to fix my eyes upon eternal Light
EN.84: until my sight was spent on it!
EN.85: In its depth I saw contained,
EN.86: by love into a single volume bound,
EN.87: the pages scattered through the universe:
EN.88: substances, accidents, and the interplay between them,
EN.89: as though they were conflated in such ways
EN.90: that what I tell is but a simple light.
EN.91: I believe I understood the universal form
EN.92: of this dense knot because I feel my joy expand,
EN.93: rejoicing as I speak of it.
EN.94: My memory of that moment is more lost
EN.95: than five and twenty centuries make dim that enterprise
EN.96: when, in wonder, Neptune at the Argo's shadow stared.
EN.97: Thus all my mind, absorbed,
EN.98: was gazing, fixed, unmoving and intent,
EN.99: becoming more enraptured in its gazing.
EN.100: He who beholds that Light is so enthralled
EN.101: that he would never willingly consent
EN.102: to turn away from it for any other sight,
EN.103: because the good that is the object of the will
EN.104: is held and gathered in perfection there
EN.105: that elsewhere would imperfect show.
EN.106: Now my words will come far short
EN.107: of what I still remember, like a babe's
EN.108: who at his mother's breast still wets his tongue.
EN.109: Not that the living Light at which I gazed
EN.110: took on other than a single aspect --
EN.111: for It is always what It was before --
EN.112: but that my sight was gaining strength, even as I gazed
EN.113: at that sole semblance and, as I changed,
EN.114: it too was being, in my eyes, transformed.
EN.115: In the deep, transparent essence of the lofty Light
EN.116: there appeared to me three circles
EN.117: having three colors but the same extent,
EN.118: and each one seemed reflected by the other
EN.119: as rainbow is by rainbow, while the third one seemed fire,
EN.120: equally breathed forth by one and by the other.
EN.121: O how scant is speech, too weak to frame my thoughts.
EN.122: Compared to what I still recall my words are faint --
EN.123: to call them little is to praise them much.
EN.124: O eternal Light, abiding in yourself alone,
EN.125: knowing yourself alone, and, known to yourself
EN.126: and knowing, loving and smiling on yourself!
EN.127: That circling which, thus conceived,
EN.128: appeared in you as light's reflection,
EN.129: once my eyes had gazed on it a while, seemed,
EN.130: within itself and in its very color,
EN.131: to be painted with our likeness,
EN.132: so that my sight was all absorbed in it.
EN.133: Like the geometer who fully applies himself
EN.134: to square the circle and, for all his thought,
EN.135: cannot discover the principle he lacks,
EN.136: such was I at that strange new sight.
EN.137: I tried to see how the image fit the circle
EN.138: and how it found its where in it.
EN.139: But my wings had not sufficed for that
EN.140: had not my mind been struck by a bolt
EN.141: of lightning that granted what I asked.
EN.142: Here my exalted vision lost its power.
EN.143: But now my will and my desire, like wheels revolving
EN.144: with an even motion, were turning with
EN.145: the Love that moves the sun and all the other stars.
